第一章 木屋: 一八二九年十月初的一天，公证人西蒙·巴比拉·拉图奈尔先生挽着儿子的手臂，并在夫人的陪同下，从勒阿弗尔步行到安古维尔去。像侍从一样走在他夫人旁边的，是他律师事务所的首席文书。他个子小小的，驼着背，名叫让·比查。他们四人（其中两人每天晚上都会走这条路）来到了路的一个肘弯处，意大利语称之为“檐口”，路到了就反方向折回。他们走到这里时，公证人四下观望了一下，看是否有人能够从上方的阶梯或者下方的小道听到他讲话。为进一步谨慎起见，他说话时嗓门压得很低。
Chapter I The Chalet: At the beginning of October, 1829, Monsieur Simon Babylas Latournelle, notary, was walking up from Havre to Ingouville, arm in arm with his son and accompanied by his wife, at whose side the head clerk of the lawyer’s office, a little hunchback named Jean Butscha, trotted along like a page.When these four personages (two of whom came the same way every evening) reached the elbow of the road where it turns back upon itself like those called in Italy “cornice,” the notary looked about to see if any one could overhear him either from the terrace above or the path beneath, and when he spoke he lowered his voice as a further precaution.

第一章 木屋: “埃克絮佩，”他对儿子说，“我这就告诉你要做什么，你一定要机智地按计划行事，但不要问意图何在。如果你猜到了我的意图，也给我把它抛到冥河里去。每一名律师，每一个想参与本国政府事务的人，心底都应该有这样一条冥河，把别人的秘密深藏其中。一会儿，你先向米尼翁夫人、米尼翁小姐、迪迈先生和迪迈夫人请安。如果哥本海姆先生也在别墅的话，你也要问候他。之后，等大家一安静下来，迪迈先生就会把你带到一边，在他与你说话的过程中，你要一直聚精会神地打量莫黛斯特小姐（是的，我允许你这样做）。之后，我那可敬的朋友会叫你出去散散步。一个小时之后，也就是大约九点钟，你要慌慌张张地跑回来，装作上气不接下气的样子，朝迪迈先生耳语：‘那小伙子来了。’声音要轻，但要确保让莫黛斯特小姐听到。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Exupere,” he said to his son, “you must try to carry out intelligently a little manoeuvre which I shall explain to you, but you are not to ask the meaning of it; and if you guess the meaning I command you to toss it into that Styx which every lawyer and every man who expects to have a hand in the government of his country is bound to keep within him for the secrets of others.After you have paid your respects and compliments to Madame and Mademoiselle Mignon, to Monsieur and Madame Dumay, and to Monsieur Gobenheim if he is at the Chalet, and as soon as quiet is restored, Monsieur Dumay will take you aside; you are then to look attentively at Mademoiselle Modeste (yes, I am willing to allow it) during the whole time he is speaking to you.My worthy friend will ask you to go out and take a walk; at the end of an hour, that is, about nine o’clock, you are to come back in a great hurry; try to puff as if you were out of breath, and whisper in Monsieur Dumay’s ear, quite low, but so that Mademoiselle Modeste is sure to overhear you, these words: ‘The young man has come.’”

第一章 木屋: 埃克絮佩第二天早晨便要动身去巴黎攻读法律了。正因他即将出行，拉图奈尔才决定把他的儿子推荐给他的朋友迪迈，让他在一桩重大的阴谋里充当帮凶。从他给出的上述指示，已经能看出这是个阴谋了。
Chapter I The Chalet: Exupere was to start the next morning for Paris to begin the study of law.This impending departure had induced Latournelle to propose him to his friend Dumay as an accomplice in the important conspiracy which these directions indicate.

第一章 木屋: “是有人怀疑莫黛斯特小姐有情人吗？”比查胆怯地问拉图奈尔夫人。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Is Mademoiselle Modeste suspected of having a lover?” asked Butscha in a timid voice of Madame Latournelle.

第一章 木屋: “嘘，比查。”她回答道，然后又挽起了丈夫的胳膊。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Hush, Butscha,” she replied, taking her husband’s arm.

第一章 木屋: 拉图奈尔夫人是最高法院一名书记员的女儿。她觉得自己出身高贵，足以和国会世家的人分庭抗礼。这种自命不凡正好解释了为什么这个脸上长了不少斑的女人总要极力摆出上法庭般的严肃姿态。那些法庭判决都是由她父亲亲笔记录的呢。她吸鼻烟，腰板挺得像枪的通条一样笔直，一副故作深沉的姿态，活像一具被电击后暂时复活的木乃伊。她嗓音刺耳，极力想用高贵的语调说话，却总是失败，掩盖不了自己总体上缺乏教养的事实。然而，我们只要看看她头上缀满花朵的帽子、前额弯曲的假刘海以及她所挑选的裙袍，就会发现她的社会价值不容置疑。要是没有拉图奈尔夫人这样的人，商人要怎么处理掉这些商品呢？这位可敬的女士，的确是位信仰虔诚、心肠慈悲之人。她的愚蠢滑稽本可以不被人发觉的，然而大自然往往喜欢自娱自乐，造出这种可笑的人物不说，还要赋予她鼓乐队指挥般的身段。这样，她那粗野本性中的滑稽之处就显而易见了。　她从未离开过勒阿弗尔，她认为勒阿弗尔完美无缺，她自称是个百分之百的诺曼人，她崇敬她的父亲，并热爱自己的丈夫。
Chapter I The Chalet: Madame Latournelle, the daughter of a clerk of the supreme court, feels that her birth authorizes her to claim issue from a parliamentary family.This conviction explains why the lady, who is somewhat blotched as to complexion, endeavors to assume in her own person the majesty of a court whose decrees are recorded in her father’s pothooks.She takes snuff, holds herself as stiff as a ramrod, poses for a person of consideration, and resembles nothing so much as a mummy brought momentarily to life by galvanism.She tries to give high-bred tones to her sharp voice, and succeeds no better in doing that than in hiding her general lack of breeding.Her social usefulness seems, however, incontestable when we glance at the flower-bedecked cap she wears, at the false front frizzling around her forehead, at the gowns of her choice; for how could shopkeepers dispose of those products if there were no Madame Latournelle?All these absurdities of the worthy woman, who is truly pious and charitable, might have passed unnoticed, if nature, amusing herself as she often does by turning out these ludicrous creations, had not endowed her with the height of a drum-major, and thus held up to view the comicalities of her provincial nature.She has never been out of Havre; she believes in the infallibility of Havre; she proclaims herself Norman to the very tips of her fingers; she venerates her father, and adores her husband.

第一章 木屋: 小拉图奈尔娶她的时候，她已经三十三岁，过了适婚年龄。他真有胆量，不但娶了她，还让她给自己生了个儿子。由于她那六万法郎的嫁妆他通过其他方式也可以获得，所以大家普遍认为他的弥天大勇是为了避免弥诺陶洛斯的入侵，因为如果他轻率地拿自己的命运做赌注，娶一位年轻貌美的女子为妻，那仅凭他的个人条件是很难抵挡住弥诺陶洛斯的。然而，事实是公证人看到了阿涅丝小姐（拉图奈尔夫人的闺名）真正的美好品质，而且他明白，一个女人的美貌对于她的丈夫来说是转瞬即逝的。说到她年轻的儿子——本书一个无足轻重的角色，在他接受洗礼时，他那位在法院当书记员的外祖父给他取了这个诺曼味十足的名字“埃克絮佩”。能在三十五岁零七个月的年纪生下这个孩子，拉图奈尔夫人至今还觉得十分惊奇，而且如果有必要的话，她现在还能给他喂奶——这说法有点夸张了，但仅这一点就足以充分表明她那热烈的母爱。“看我那儿子，长得多帅气啊！”每当她和她年轻的好友莫黛斯特去做礼拜，她那仪表堂堂的埃克絮佩走在她们前面时，她就会这样说道。“他长得像你。”莫黛斯特·米尼翁答道。她说这话的语气跟她说“天气真糟糕！”一类的话时没太大差别，完全是出于礼貌。由于近三年来，拉图奈尔夫人经常陪伴在少女莫黛斯特左右，而公证人和他的朋友迪迈正在为莫黛斯特设计一个“婚姻生理学”中称作“捕鼠器”的圈套，所以拉图奈尔夫人就成了一名重要的帮凶。
Chapter I The Chalet: Little Latournelle was bold enough to marry this lady after she had attained the anti-matrimonial age of thirty-three, and what is more, he had a son by her.As he could have got the sixty thousand francs of her “dot” in several other ways, the public assigned his uncommon intrepidity to a desire to escape an invasion of the Minotaur, against whom his personal qualifications would have insufficiently protected him had he rashly dared his fate by bringing home a young and pretty wife.The fact was, however, that the notary recognized the really fine qualities of Mademoiselle Agnes (she was called Agnes) and reflected to himself that a woman’s beauty is soon past and gone to a husband.As to the insignificant youth on whom the clerk of the court bestowed in baptism his Norman name of “Exupere,” Madame Latournelle is still so surprised at becoming his mother, at the age of thirty-five years and seven months, that she would still provide him, if it were necessary, with her breast and her milk,—an hyperbole which alone can fully express her impassioned maternity.“How handsome he is, that son of mine!” she says to her little friend Modeste, as they walk to church, with the beautiful Exupere in front of them.“He is like you,” Modeste Mignon answers, very much as she might have said, “What horrid weather!”This silhouette of Madame Latournelle is quite important as an accessory, inasmuch as for three years she has been the chaperone of the young girl against whom the notary and his friend Dumay are now plotting to set up what we have called, in the “Physiologie du Mariage,” a “mouse-trap.”

第一章 木屋: 至于拉图奈尔，大家可以想象一个值得尊敬的小个子男子，既诚实正直，又十分狡猾——任何一个陌生人见了他，都会因为他那奇怪的相貌而把他当成坏人，而勒阿弗尔人早已对他的外表习以为常了。据说他视力不好，眼睛总是红肿，为了保护眼睛，这位可敬的人物不得不戴上绿色的护目镜。他那毛发稀疏的眉弓围着褐色的玳瑁镜框，看上去像是两对直径不同的同心圆。每一侧的同心圆都是大圈套小圈，两圈之间隔着一条凹陷的皮肤，如果你从未在一张人脸上见过这样的景象，那你很难想象看到它你会有多诧异，何况这张脸还是面色苍白、两颊干瘪，下巴尖得活像画家们按照猫脸画的魔鬼靡菲斯特。巴比拉·拉图奈尔的脸就是这样，看上去既像猫，又像魔鬼。在那吓人的绿色眼镜上面是光秃秃的脑壳，白色的假发在前额分开一条歪歪扭扭的发线，四面散开，看上去好像会动似的。这一切使他脸上的表情更显狡猾。这位杰出的诺曼人一袭黑衣，迈动双腿的样子就像一只被钉在大头针上的甲虫。如果一个人了解他正直可信的品格，又看到他这副样貌，一定想知道为什么他的外表与内心如此不符，虽然答案是找不到的。
Chapter I The Chalet: As for Latournelle, imagine a worthy little fellow as sly as the purest honor and uprightness would allow him to be,—a man whom any stranger would take for a rascal at sight of his queer physiognomy, to which, however, the inhabitants of Havre were well accustomed.His eyesight, said to be weak, obliged the worthy man to wear green goggles for the protection of his eyes, which were constantly inflamed.The arch of each eyebrow, defined by a thin down of hair, surrounded the tortoise-shell rim of the glasses and made a couple of circles as it were, slightly apart.If you have never observed on the human face the effect produced by these circumferences placed one within the other, and separated by a hollow space or line, you can hardly imagine how perplexing such a face will be to you, especially if pale, hollow-cheeked, and terminating in a pointed chin like that of Mephistopheles,—a type which painters give to cats.This double resemblance was observable on the face of Babylas Latournelle.Above the atrocious green spectacles rose a bald crown, all the more crafty in expression because a wig, seemingly endowed with motion, let the white hairs show on all sides of it as it meandered crookedly across the forehead.An observer taking note of this excellent Norman, clothed in black and mounted on his two legs like a beetle on a couple of pins, and knowing him to be one of the most trustworthy of men, would have sought, without finding it, for the reason of such physical misrepresentation.

第一章 木屋: 让·比查是个被遗弃的私生子，由法院书记员和他女儿抚养成人。现在，他全凭刻苦工作，成了公证人的首席文书，在他老板那里吃住，每个月还能领到九百法郎的薪水。他几乎是个侏儒，没有一点年轻人的样子，却视莫黛斯特为偶像，为她赔上自己的性命也在所不惜。他那厚厚的眼皮底下，眼珠像火炮的点火孔一样凹陷下去，脑袋大得不合身体比例，显得头重脚轻，长着一头卷发，满脸麻子。这个可怜的小伙子，从七岁开始就生活在别人怜悯的目光下。难道这些还不足以解释他的整个性格吗？他沉默寡言，信仰虔诚，做事中规中矩。他独自游荡在爱情地图上被称为“无望爱情”的国度里，那是一片寸草不生而又令人赞叹的“欲望草原”。莫黛斯特把这位奇丑无比的文书叫做她的“黑侏儒”。听到这个绰号，他便去读瓦尔特·司各特的小说。后来有一天，他对莫黛斯特说道：“您能接受您神秘的侏儒献上的一朵玫瑰吗？它能为您消灾解难。”莫黛斯特狠狠地瞪了他一眼，这马上把她这位崇拜者打回了他那污秽的小泥屋里。少女们总会对那些无法取悦他们的男子投以这种目光。比查的自我观念很卑微，而且跟他老板的夫人一样，他也从未离开过勒阿弗尔。
Chapter I The Chalet: Jean Butscha, a natural son abandoned by his parents and taken care of by the clerk of the court and his daughter, and now, through sheer hard work, head-clerk to the notary, fed and lodged by his master, who gave him a salary of nine hundred francs, almost a dwarf, and with no semblance of youth,—Jean Butscha made Modeste his idol, and would willingly have given his life for hers.The poor fellow, whose eyes were hollowed beneath their heavy lids like the touch-holes of a cannon, whose head overweighted his body, with its shock of crisp hair, and whose face was pock-marked, had lived under pitying eyes from the time he was seven years of age.Is not that enough to explain his whole being?Silent, self-contained, pious, exemplary in conduct, he went his way over that vast tract of country named on the map of the heart Love-without-Hope, the sublime and arid steppes of Desire.Modeste had christened this grotesque little being her “Black Dwarf.”The nickname sent him to the pages of Walter Scott’s novel, and he one day said to Modeste: “Will you accept a rose against the evil day from your mysterious dwarf?”Modeste instantly sent the soul of her adorer to its humble mud-cabin with a terrible glance, such as young girls bestow on the men who cannot please them.Butscha’s conception of himself was lowly, and, like the wife of his master, he had never been out of Havre.

第一章 木屋: 也许，为了那些从没去过勒阿弗尔的读者起见，这里有必要解释一下拉图奈尔一家以及首席文书现在要去往哪里。安古维尔之于勒阿弗尔，类似于蒙马特尔之于巴黎——都是高高的山丘，城市就坐落在它们脚下。而不同之处在于，巴黎是被塞纳河环绕的，而勒阿弗尔的山丘和城市则是四面环海，还被封闭的防御工事所包围。简而言之，在勒阿弗尔，河流入海处、港口、码头所呈现的景象，与巴黎那五万幢房屋的景象是完全不同的。在蒙马特尔脚下，石板瓦屋顶组成的汪洋就像是静止的蓝色波涛,而在安古维尔，大海就像是被风吹动的石板瓦屋顶。这座山丘，或者说这座绵延的山脉，沿着塞纳河从鲁昂一直延伸到大海，山谷与河流之间形成了窄窄的狭长谷地，这里的城市、山涧、溪谷和草地都是风景如画。自一八一六年勒阿弗尔开始繁荣以来，这些美景便成了安古维尔一带的宝贵财富。从那时开始，这个小镇就变成了类似洛特依、达弗赖城和蒙莫朗西的地方，简言之，就是勒阿弗尔商人的城郊住宅区。在这里，商人们在山坡的梯田上建起了一幢幢房子，他们呼吸着海洋的气息，那气息中还弥漫着他们的豪华花园散发的芳香。由于勒阿弗尔的人口不断增加，加上那些无法更改的防御工事和不断扩大的码头，使得投机商们原来的房子都成了建筑垃圾，房屋紧挨在一起，很少有空地，甚至往往连院子都没有。而在安古维尔，这些大胆的投机商们可以抛下账房的重担，忘掉市区房子的压抑氛围，释放压力。结果就是，这些人在勒阿弗尔时身心疲惫，在安古维尔则轻松快活。社会发展的法则使得格拉维尔郊区的建筑像雨后春笋般多了起来。如今，格拉维尔城比勒阿弗尔还要大，像一条巨蟒盘在山脚下。
Chapter I The Chalet: Perhaps it will be well, for the sake of those who have never seen that city, to say a few words as to the present destination of the Latournelle family,—the head clerk being included in the latter term.Ingouville is to Havre what Montmartre is to Paris,—a high hill at the foot of which the city lies; with this difference, that the hill and the city are surrounded by the sea and the Seine, that Havre is helplessly circumscribed by enclosing fortifications, and, in short, that the mouth of the river, the harbor, and the docks present a very different aspect from the fifty thousand houses of Paris.At the foot of Montmartre an ocean of slate roofs lies in motionless blue billows; at Ingouville the sea is like the same roofs stirred by the wind.This eminence, or line of hills, which coasts the Seine from Rouen to the seashore, leaving a margin of valley land more or less narrow between itself and the river, and containing in its cities, its ravines, its vales, its meadows, veritable treasures of the picturesque, became of enormous value in and about Ingouville, after the year 1816, the period at which the prosperity of Havre began.This township has become since that time the Auteuil, the Ville-d’Avray, the Montmorency, in short, the suburban residence of the merchants of Havre.Here they build their houses on terraces around its amphitheatre of hills, and breathe the sea air laden with the fragrance of their splendid gardens.Here these bold speculators cast off the burden of their counting-rooms and the atmosphere of their city houses, which are built closely together without open spaces, often without court-yards,—a vice of construction with the increasing population of Havre, the inflexible line of the fortifications, and the enlargement of the docks has forced upon them.The result is, weariness of heart in Havre, cheerfulness and joy at Ingouville.The law of social development has forced up the suburb of Graville like a mushroom.It is today more extensive than Havre itself, which lies at the foot of its slopes like a serpent.

第一章 木屋: 安古维尔山的山顶上只有一条街，而且（正如所有这种情况下那样），面朝塞纳河的房屋同马路另一边那些视线受阻的房屋相比，有着相当的优势。从这一边踮起脚尖，就能看见对面房屋的屋顶。然而，这里也像其他地方一样，存在着一些地役权的限制。一些建在山顶的房屋有着更好的地理位置，或者说拥有合法的俯瞰风景的权利，这迫使它们对面的邻居只能将房屋保持在某一规定的高度以内。此外，嶙峋的山石被开凿成山路，山路沿着斜坡走势而建，以使这里更适宜居住，一些房屋也能通过山石的缺口俯瞰城市、河流或者大海的远景。这座小山没有一个真正的顶峰，而是形成了一座唐突而陡峭的悬崖。沿着山顶走到街道的尽头，便能看到峡谷，那里坐落着几个村落（其中一个叫圣阿德雷斯，还有另外两三个也叫“圣”什么的），还有几条随着海潮静静流淌的小溪。安古维尔山这一侧荒芜的峭壁，同另一侧盖满了能够眺望塞纳河山谷的别墅的丘陵，形成了强烈的对比。是这面的风太大，草木不能生长？还是开发这里需要巨额投资，所以商人们都退缩了呢？不论什么原因，那些乘坐轮船来到勒阿弗尔的游客，都会对安古维尔西侧贫瘠的海岸和错综复杂的峡谷感到惊讶。打个比方，就像是看到一个衣衫褴褛的乞丐站在一个满身香气、衣冠楚楚的阔佬旁边一样。
Chapter I The Chalet: At the crest of the hill Ingouville has but one street, and (as in all such situations) the houses which overlook the river have an immense advantage over those on the other side of the road, whose view they obstruct, and which present the effect of standing on tip-toe to look over the opposing roofs.However, there exist here, as elsewhere, certain servitudes.Some houses standing at the summit have a finer position or possess legal rights of view which compel their opposite neighbors to keep their buildings down to a required height.Moreover, the openings cut in the capricious rock by roads which follow its declensions and make the amphitheatre habitable, give vistas through which some estates can see the city, or the river, or the sea.Instead of rising to an actual peak, the hill ends abruptly in a cliff.At the end of the street which follows the line of the summit, ravines appear in which a few villages are clustered (Sainte–Adresse and two or three other Saint-somethings) together with several creeks which murmur and flow with the tides of the sea.These half-deserted slopes of Ingouville form a striking contrast to the terraces of fine villas which overlook the valley of the Seine.Is the wind on this side too strong for vegetation?Do the merchants shrink from the cost of terracing it?However this may be, the traveller approaching Havre on a steamer is surprised to find a barren coast and tangled gorges to the west of Ingouville, like a beggar in rags beside a perfumed and sumptuously apparelled rich man.

第一章 木屋: 一八二九年，最后一批靠海的房子建起来了，其中有一座——今天它很可能已经是安古维尔的中心了——被称作“木屋”。现在，说不定人们还是这样叫它。起初，那只是一间看门人住的小屋，前面是一座修剪整齐的小花园。木屋后面的别墅是一座带有庭院、花园、鸟房、温室以及草坪的宅邸。别墅主人想让这栋小木屋与自己的豪宅风格更加一致，便按照农舍式小别墅的样子对其进行了重建。他用一道矮墙将这座小农舍同别墅的草坪分开，又沿墙种上树篱将墙遮住。农舍边围绕着花床，算是别墅的露台区。这座农舍式小别墅（尽管主人费劲心思，人们还是叫它“木屋”）的后面便是果园和菜园。木屋不养奶牛，也不产乳制品。它与道路之间隔着一道木栅栏，栅栏的木桩被茂盛的树篱盖住了。道路另一边与之相对的房屋也遵从地役权的规定，建造了相似高度的栅栏和围篱，这样从木屋别墅便能将勒阿弗尔的景色一览无遗。
Chapter I The Chalet: In 1829 one of the last houses looking toward the sea, and which in all probability stands about the centre of the Ingouville today, was called, and perhaps is still called, “the Chalet.”Originally it was a porter’s lodge with a trim little garden in front of it.The owner of the villa to which it belonged,—a mansion with park, gardens, aviaries, hot-houses, and lawns—took a fancy to put the little dwelling more in keeping with the splendor of his own abode, and he reconstructed it on the model of an ornamental cottage.He divided this cottage from his own lawn, which was bordered and set with flower-beds and formed the terrace of his villa, by a low wall along which he planted a concealing hedge.Behind the cottage (called, in spite of all his efforts to prevent it, the Chalet) were the orchards and kitchen gardens of the villa.The Chalet, without cows or dairy, is separated from the roadway by a wooden fence whose palings are hidden under a luxuriant hedge.On the other side of the road the opposite house, subject to a legal privilege, has a similar hedge and paling, so as to leave an unobstructed view of Havre to the Chalet.

第一章 木屋: 这所小木屋令别墅的现任主人维尔坎先生头疼不已，原因说来话长。这座别墅里每个奢华的角落仿佛都高喊着：“看我们的万贯家财！”别墅的最初建造者把庭院延伸到远处的原野，用他的话说，就是为了不让园丁们在他眼皮底下工作。因此，木屋建成以后，也只有别墅主人的朋友才能来住。别墅的第二位主人米尼翁先生非常喜欢他的账房总管迪迈先生，而接下来的故事也将证明这种喜欢是相互的。于是，他让迪迈先生住到这间小木屋来。迪迈是一个严格按法律程序办事的人，他坚持要和东家签一个为期十二年、每年租金三百法郎的租约，米尼翁先生很乐意地签了，并说道：
Chapter I The Chalet: This little dwelling was the torment of the present proprietor of the villa, Monsieur Vilquin; and here is the why and the wherefore.The original creator of the villa, whose sumptuous details cry aloud, “Behold our millions!” extended his park far into the country for the purpose, as he averred, of getting his gardeners out of his pockets; and so, when the Chalet was finished, none but a friend could be allowed to inhabit it.Monsieur Mignon, the next owner of the property, was very much attached to his cashier, Dumay, and the following history will prove that the attachment was mutual; to him therefore he offered the little dwelling.Dumay, a stickler for legal methods, insisted on signing a lease for three hundred francs for twelve years, and Monsieur Mignon willingly agreed, remarking,—

第一章 木屋: “亲爱的迪迈，记住，从现在开始，你要同我在这里住上十二年。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My dear Dumay, remember, you have now bound yourself to live with me for twelve years.”

第一章 木屋: 后来，由于发生了一些变故——我们不久就会讲到这些变故——这位曾是勒阿弗尔首富的米尼翁先生将房产卖给了他在生意场上的一个对手，维尔坎。能够得到远近闻名的米尼翁别墅，维尔坎自然是高兴得不得了，兴头之下，忘记了和迪迈解除租约。迪迈没有急于阻止这笔交易，维尔坎让他签什么合约他就签什么合约，可买卖成交之后，他却死守着那份租约不放。而且，他一直留在维尔坎眼皮底下，深入维尔坎家庭生活的内部，观察维尔坎，刺激维尔坎，总之，对维尔坎一家来说，他就像是一只牛虻。每天早晨，维尔坎从窗前向外眺望，都会看到外面那座耗资六万法郎、在阳光下像块红宝石般闪闪发光的小木屋——整座别墅的精华所在。每当这时，一股怒火便会从他心头升起。将木屋比作红宝石真是太贴切了。建筑师建造这座农舍式小别墅时，用的是最鲜亮耀眼的红砖，砖缝则填涂了白色的水泥。窗框漆成鲜绿色，木家具则刷成接近于黄色的浅棕色。屋檐向外伸出几英尺远。底楼上方有一条漂亮的回廊，栏杆是透雕细工的，在房子正面的中间形成一个镶着玻璃的凉台。一楼有一间漂亮的客厅和一间餐厅，两厅由一个木制的楼梯平台隔开，楼梯的设计和装饰朴素而典雅。餐厅后面是厨房，客厅后面原来是间书房，现在改成了迪迈先生和迪迈夫人的卧室。建筑师在二楼建了两间大卧室，每间都配有梳妆室，凉台可以当作客厅。三层的房顶像是两张抵在一起的扑克牌，这一层有两间仆人卧室，每一间的屋顶都是复折式的，开着圆形的天窗，倒也敞亮。
Chapter I The Chalet: In consequence of certain events which will presently be related, the estates of Monsieur Mignon, formerly the richest merchant in Havre, were sold to Vilquin, one of his business competitors.In his joy at getting possession of the celebrated villa Mignon, the latter forgot to demand the cancelling of the lease.Dumay, anxious not to hinder the sale, would have signed anything Vilquin required, but the sale once made, he held to his lease like a vengeance.And there he remained, in Vilquin’s pocket as it were; at the heart of Vilquin’s family life, observing Vilquin, irritating Vilquin,—in short, the gadfly of all the Vilquins.Every morning, when he looked out of his window, Vilquin felt a violent shock of annoyance as his eye lighted on the little gem of a building, the Chalet, which had cost sixty thousand francs and sparkled like a ruby in the sun.That comparison is very nearly exact.The architect has constructed the cottage of brilliant red brick pointed with white.The window-frames are painted of a lively green, the woodwork is brown verging on yellow.The roof overhangs by several feet.A pretty gallery, with open-worked balustrade, surmounts the lower floor and projects at the centre of the facade into a veranda with glass sides.The ground-floor has a charming salon and a dining-room, separated from each other by the landing of a staircase built of wood, designed and decorated with elegant simplicity.The kitchen is behind the dining-room, and the corresponding room back of the salon, formerly a study, is now the bedroom of Monsieur and Madame Dumay.On the upper floor the architect has managed to get two large bedrooms, each with a dressing-room, to which the veranda serves as a salon; and above this floor, under the eaves, which are tipped together like a couple of cards, are two servants’ rooms with mansard roofs, each lighted by a circular window and tolerably spacious.

第一章 木屋: 维尔坎十分小气，他在果园和菜园的一侧修起了一堵高墙，而这一恶意行为的结果就是，租约中归木屋所属的那一小块地看上去就像一个巴黎花园了。木屋外围建筑的油漆与木屋保持一致，背靠着邻家的墙。
Chapter I The Chalet: Vilquin has been petty enough to build a high wall on the side toward the orchard and kitchen garden; and in consequence of this piece of spite, the few square feet which the lease secured to the Chalet resembled a Parisian garden.The out-buildings, painted in keeping with the cottage, stood with their backs to the wall of the adjoining property.

第一章 木屋: 这间漂亮的小屋，其内部风格也与其外观十分协调。客厅的整个地板都是实木的，油漆的风格让人联想到精美的中国漆器。黑底金边的木板上镶着的颜色各异的鸟儿、鲜绿异常的叶子和奇特的东方图样，绚丽夺目、闪闪发光。整个餐厅都铺着北方木材，用的是透雕细工的工艺，像是漂亮的俄罗斯小木屋。楼梯与楼梯平台之间形成的小小前厅被漆成了古橡木色，呈现出哥特式的装饰风格。卧室里挂着印花纱帐，风格简单，却价格不菲，散发着独特的魅力。账房总管和他夫人现在住的书房，墙和天花板上上下下都镶着装饰木板，就像一艘轮船的船舱。别墅前任主人留下的奢华装饰让维尔坎感到十分恼火。他本想让他的女儿女婿住到这座农舍式别墅来。迪迈对他的这种想法心知肚明，可他有着布列塔尼人典型的固执脾气，就是不肯搬走。
Chapter I The Chalet: The interior of this charming dwelling harmonized with its exterior.The salon, floored entirely with iron-wood, was painted in a style that suggested the beauties of Chinese lacquer.On black panels edged with gold, birds of every color, foliage of impossible greens, and fantastic oriental designs glowed and shimmered.The dining-room was entirely sheathed in Northern woods carved and cut in open-work like the beautiful Russian chalets.The little antechamber formed by the landing and the well of the staircase was painted in old oak to represent Gothic ornament.The bedrooms, hung with chintz, were charming in their costly simplicity.The study, where the cashier and his wife now slept, was panelled from top to bottom, on the walls and ceiling, like the cabin of a steamboat.These luxuries of his predecessor excited Vilquin’s wrath.He would fain have lodged his daughter and her husband in the cottage.This desire, well known to Dumay, will presently serve to illustrate the Breton obstinacy of the latter.

第一章 木屋: 木屋的进门处是一扇小小的格子状铁门，铁栏上的金属刺要比栅栏和树篱高出几英寸。小花园几乎和那片迷人的草坪一样开阔，里面正开着各种各样的花，如玫瑰花、精选品种的大丽花，以及其他许多稀有的温室品种，因为（这也是让维尔坎痛苦不已的一个原因）那座小而华贵的温室，创意奇特的温室，代表着高贵和气派的温室，正是属木屋管辖的。温室在木屋和维尔坎的别墅之间，把二者分隔开来，或者你也可以说是把二者连在一起。迪迈精心照料着这座温室，以此缓解做生意的疲劳，那温室里的异国珍宝也是莫黛斯特的一大乐趣。维尔坎别墅的弹子房像一条长廊，曾经通过一座巨大的鸟舍与这间温室相连。但是，维尔坎修起高墙后，自己便看不到果园了，自那之后，迪迈便将这扇门用砖堵死了。“以墙还墙！”他说。
Chapter I The Chalet: The entrance to the Chalet is by a little trellised iron door, the uprights of which, ending in lance-heads, show for a few inches above the fence and its hedge.The little garden, about as wide as the more pretentious lawn, was just now filled with flowers, roses, and dahlias of the choicest kind, and many rare products of the hot-houses, for (another Vilquinard grievance) the elegant little hot-house, a very whim of a hot-house, a hot-house representing dignity and style, belonged to the Chalet, and separated, or if you prefer, united it to the villa Vilquin.Dumay consoled himself for the toils of business in taking care of this hot-house, whose exotic treasures were one of Modeste’s joys.The billiard-room of the villa Vilquin, a species of gallery, formerly communicated through an immense aviary with this hot-house.But after the building of the wall which deprived him of a view into the orchards, Dumay bricked up the door of communication.“Wall for wall!” he said.

第一章 木屋: 一八二七年，维尔坎提出如果迪迈愿意放弃租约，他将给迪迈每年六千法郎的薪水，外加一万法郎作为赔偿。尽管当时这位账房总管只能从他原东家的文员哥本海姆那里得到三千法郎，但他还是拒绝了维尔坎的提议。迪迈本是一位布列塔尼人，由于命运的安排，移居到了诺曼底。因此，大家可以想象一下，对于身价达到三百万的诺曼人维尔坎而言，木屋的房客令他何等痛恨！让这样一个富有的人感到金钱的无能，这位账房总管可真是犯了亵渎万贯金钱罪啊！在这件事上，维尔坎表现得孤注一掷，这已成了勒阿弗尔人的笑柄。最近他又提出把自己的一栋漂亮房子给迪迈，但又被拒绝了。勒阿弗尔人开始为这位先生的固执感到不安，许多人用这样一句话来解释：“迪迈是布列塔尼人。”对于这位账房总管来说，他认为米尼翁夫人和小姐住到其他地方去肯定会觉得不适。他所崇拜的两位偶像现在正住在与她们相称的神庙里，这座奢华的小农舍式别墅能给她们一个家，让这些被罢黜的贵族保持外在的尊严，而许多曾经风光的人是得不到这种尊严的。
Chapter I The Chalet: In 1827 Vilquin offered Dumay a salary of six thousand francs, and ten thousand more as indemnity, if he would give up the lease.The cashier refused; though he had but three thousand francs from Gobenheim, a former clerk of his master.Dumay was a Breton transplanted by fate into Normandy.Imagine therefore the hatred conceived for the tenants of the Chalet by the Norman Vilquin, a man worth three millions!What criminal leze-million on the part of a cashier, to hold up to the eyes of such a man the impotence of his wealth!Vilquin, whose desperation in the matter made him the talk of Havre, had just proposed to give Dumay a pretty house of his own, and had again been refused.Havre itself began to grow uneasy at the man’s obstinacy, and a good many persons explained it by the phrase, “Dumay is a Breton.”As for the cashier, he thought Madame and Mademoiselle Mignon would be ill-lodged elsewhere.His two idols now inhabited a temple worthy of them; the sumptuous little cottage gave them a home, where these dethroned royalties could keep the semblance of majesty about them,—a species of dignity usually denied to those who have seen better days.

第一章 木屋: 在继续这个故事之前，先了解一下莫黛斯特·米尼翁住在哪里，平常都和哪些人来往，读者们应该不会感到后悔的。因为在莫黛斯特·米尼翁这个年龄段，周围的人和事物对她未来人生的影响毫不亚于她个人性格造成的影响。事实上，周围的环境往往会给一个人的性格带来不可磨灭的烙印。
Chapter I The Chalet: Perhaps as the story goes on, the reader will not regret having learned in advance a few particulars as to the home and the habitual companions of Modeste Mignon, for, at her age, people and things have as much influence upon the future life as a person’s own character,—indeed, character often receives ineffaceable impressions from its surroundings.

第一章 木屋: 第二章 一幅生活图
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter II A Portrait from Life

第一章 木屋: 从拉图奈尔一家人走进木屋的样子，一个陌生人很容易就可以猜到他们每晚都会去那里。
Chapter I The Chalet: From the manner with which the Latournelles entered the Chalet a stranger would readily have guessed that they came there every evening.

第一章 木屋: “啊，你已经到了。”公证人看到那位年轻的银行家哥本海姆时这样说道。哥本海姆是巴黎大银行董事长哥本海姆-凯勒的亲戚。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, you are here already,” said the notary, perceiving the young banker Gobenheim, a connection of Gobenheim-Keller, the head of the great banking house in Paris.

第一章 木屋: 这个年轻人脸色灰白，金发黑眼，坚定的目光中带有一种说不出的魅力，言行举止都很冷静。他一身黑衣，瘦得像个肺病患者，但看体格还算有活力。他时常去拜访前东家一家和账房总管，但与其说是出于感情，还不如说是打着自己的小算盘。他们在这里玩惠斯特纸牌，两苏一个筹码。这种场合不需要穿礼服，除了几杯糖水，他也不吃其他茶点，因此也不用拘泥任何礼节。这种对米尼翁一家表面上的忠心让人们觉得哥本海姆很有良心，同时，他也就不必到勒阿弗尔去进行社交，花那些冤枉钱，影响他的生活支出平衡。这位金钱的信徒每天十点半睡觉，五点钟起床。此外，他深信拉图奈尔和比查会守口如瓶，这样他就可以跟他们讨论棘手的生意问题，得到公证人的免费建议，并一窥街头巷尾那些传言的真相。这个冷漠无情的恋金癖（比查语），本性就像化学中被称为“吸附剂”的那类物质。凯勒银行起初是派他到米尼翁家去学习海上贸易的经验。自从米尼翁家破产后，木屋里任何人都没让他做过一点点小事情，任何事情都没有，因为大家都知道他的回答会是什么。这个年轻小伙子仔细端详莫黛斯特时，就像是在看一幅廉价的平版印刷品。
Chapter I The Chalet: This young man with a livid face—a blonde of the type with black eyes, whose immovable glance has an indescribable fascination, sober in speech as in conduct, dressed in black, lean as a consumptive, but nevertheless vigorously framed—visited the family of his former master and the house of his cashier less from affection than from self-interest.Here they played whist at two sous a point; a dress-coat was not required; he accepted no refreshment except “eau sucree,” and consequently had no civilities to return.This apparent devotion to the Mignon family allowed it to be supposed that Gobenheim had a heart; it also released him from the necessity of going into the society of Havre and incurring useless expenses, thus upsetting the orderly economy of his domestic life.This disciple of the golden calf went to bed at half-past ten o’clock and got up at five in the morning.Moreover, being perfectly sure of Latournelle’s and Butscha’s discretion, he could talk over difficult business matters, obtain the advice of the notary gratis, and get an inkling of the real truth of the gossip of the street.This stolid gold-glutton (the epithet is Butscha’s) belonged by nature to the class of substances which chemistry terms absorbents.Ever since the catastrophe of the house of Mignon, where the Kellers had placed him to learn the principles of maritime commerce, no one at the Chalet had ever asked him to do the smallest thing, no matter what; his reply was too well known.The young fellow looked at Modeste precisely as he would have looked at a cheap lithograph.

第一章 木屋: “他就像‘贸易’这部庞大机器中的一个活塞。”可怜的比查这样说道。比查有时候会胆怯地冒出几句这样的话，让人觉得他还挺聪明。
Chapter I The Chalet: “He’s one of the pistons of the big engine called ‘Commerce,’” said poor Butscha, whose clever mind made itself felt occasionally by such little sayings timidly jerked out.

第一章 木屋: 拉图奈尔一家四口以最恭敬的方式向一位身穿黑丝绒长裙的老妇人鞠躬致敬。老妇人坐在扶手椅里，并未起身，因为她患有白内障，双眼已经被黄色的薄膜遮住了。她便是米尼翁夫人，可以用一句话来形容她。作为一名家庭主妇，她那令人敬畏的面容会立刻引起你的注意，她一生无可指摘，勇于反抗命运的打击，然而，她却偏偏成了无数尼俄柏人当中的一员，被命运选作放矢之的。她头上的金色假发有着细致的小卷，戴得熨熨贴贴，衬着她冰冷、白皙的脸庞，就像画家哈尔斯或米尔威特笔下的德国市长夫人。她的穿着极其整洁，丝绒靴、蕾丝衣领、平整的披肩，这一切都证明了莫黛斯特对她母亲无微不至的关爱。
Chapter I The Chalet: The four Latournelles bowed with the most respectful deference to an old lady dressed in black velvet, who did not rise from the armchair in which she was seated, for the reason that both eyes were covered with the yellow film produced by cataract.Madame Mignon may be sketched in one sentence.Her august countenance of the mother of a family attracted instant notice as that of one whose irreproachable life defies the assaults of destiny, which nevertheless makes her the target of its arrows and a member of the unnumbered tribe of Niobes.Her blonde wig, carefully curled and well arranged upon her head, became the cold white face which resembled that of some burgomaster’s wife painted by Hals or Mirevelt.The extreme neatness of her dress, the velvet boots, the lace collar, the shawl evenly folded and put on, all bore testimony to the solicitous care which Modeste bestowed upon her mother.

第一章 木屋: 正如公证人所料，华丽的客厅安静了下来，莫黛斯特坐在她母亲旁边，为她绣一块方巾。这位少女立即成为了众人关注的中心。来访的客人用俗套的寒暄来掩饰他们的好奇，就算是一个毫不相干的人，看到这场景也能发觉这一家人正在为莫黛斯特设计某个陷阱。但哥本海姆还不如一个毫不相干的人，他什么都没有察觉到，只是点亮了牌桌的蜡烛。迪迈的行为让比查、拉图奈尔一家，尤其是迪迈夫人，感到形势严峻，迪迈夫人知道，她的丈夫会像一只疯狗那样不顾一切地朝莫黛斯特的情人开枪。
Chapter I The Chalet: When silence was, as the notary had predicted, restored in the pretty salon, Modeste, sitting beside her mother, for whom she was embroidering a kerchief, became for an instant the centre of observation.This curiosity, barely veiled by the commonplace salutations and inquiries of the visitors, would have revealed even to an indifferent person the existence of the domestic plot to which Modeste was expected to fall a victim; but Gobenheim, more than indifferent, noticed nothing, and proceeded to light the candles on the card-table.The behavior of Dumay made the whole scene terrifying to Butscha, to the Latournelles, and above all to Madame Dumay, who knew her husband to be capable of firing a pistol at Modeste’s lover as coolly as though he were a mad dog.

第一章 木屋: 那天晚餐过后，账房总管带着两只名贵的比利牛斯猎犬出去散步。他怀疑那两条狗会出卖他，于是便将它们交给了一个曾经做过米尼翁先生佃户的农夫看管。回来后，就在拉图奈尔一家到达之前，他从床头取出几支手枪，背着莫黛斯特将它们放到壁炉架上。这位年轻姑娘竟然一点也没注意到这些奇怪的准备工作。
Chapter I The Chalet: After dinner that day the cashier had gone to walk followed by two magnificent Pyrenees hounds, whom he suspected of betraying him, and therefore left in charge of a farmer, a former tenant of Monsieur Mignon.On his return, just before the arrival of the Latournelles, he had taken his pistols from his bed’s head and placed them on the chimney-piece, concealing this action from Modeste.The young girl took no notice whatever of these preparations, singular as they were.

第一章 木屋: 这位布列塔尼人曾做过近卫军中尉，别看他长得矮小粗壮、满脸麻子，说话时声调很低，像是在自言自语一样，他的表情却十分坚毅，一脸冷酷，以至于他的一生中，就连在部队里，也没有人敢跟他开玩笑。他那小小的碧蓝色眼睛就像两块钢片，透着一丝沉着。他的办事方式、面部表情、言行举止，无不与他那简短的名字“迪迈”相称。他体格健壮，这一点无人不知，使得他不会面临任何被攻击的危险。他可以一拳打死一个人，在包岑他就有过这样的战绩。当时是他落在同伴的后面，手无寸铁地面对一个撒克逊人。现在，他那通常坚定而又温和的表情已经升华到一种悲剧美的崇高境界。他的脸和嘴唇都很苍白，说明他正在以布列塔尼人的毅力来控制着内心的烦乱。他的额头微微冒汗，眉毛都弄湿了，大家都注意到了，并认为他是在冒冷汗。这些迹象可能会导致一出足以上刑事法庭的悲剧，公证人对此再清楚不过了。事实上，这位账房总管是在为莫黛斯特·米尼翁下一盘棋，其中牵扯到在他看来比社会法则重要得多的荣誉感和忠诚感，而他现在的行为起因于一份契约，如果发生了什么不幸，恐怕也只有由上帝来裁决了。大多数戏剧之所以成为戏剧，正是由于我们自身对事物的看法。那些我们看来戏剧化的事情，其实只是因为我们根据个人的性格，用自己的心灵将它们转化成了悲剧或喜剧。
Chapter I The Chalet: Though short, thick-set, pockmarked, and speaking always in a low voice as if listening to himself, this Breton, a former lieutenant in the Guard, showed the evidence of such resolution, such sang-froid on his face that throughout life, even in the army, no one had ever ventured to trifle with him.His little eyes, of a calm blue, were like bits of steel.His ways, the look on his face, his speech, his carriage, were all in keeping with the short name of Dumay.His physical strength, well-known to every one, put him above all danger of attack.He was able to kill a man with a blow of his fist, and had performed that feat at Bautzen, where he found himself, unarmed, face to face with a Saxon at the rear of his company.At the present moment the usually firm yet gentle expression of the man’s face had risen to a sort of tragic sublimity; his lips were pale as the rest of his face, indicating a tumult within him mastered by his Breton will; a slight sweat, which every one noticed and guessed to be cold, moistened his brow.The notary knew but too well that these signs might result in a drama before the criminal courts.In fact the cashier was playing a part in connection with Modeste Mignon, which involved to his mind sentiments of honor and loyalty of far greater importance than mere social laws; and his present conduct proceeded from one of those compacts which, in case disaster came of it, could be judged only in a higher court than one of earth.The majority of dramas lie really in the ideas which we make to ourselves about things.Events which seem to us dramatic are nothing more than subjects which our souls convert into tragedy or comedy according to the bent of our characters.

第一章 木屋: 拉图奈尔夫人和迪迈夫人被安排监视莫黛斯特，她们举止很不自然，声音也有些颤抖。但那位被怀疑的少女却并没有察觉到这些，而是一心专注于她的刺绣。莫黛斯特把每一针都绣得恰到好处，这恐怕是普通的刺绣女工望尘莫及的。从她的表情可以看出，她正沉浸在绣花瓣的喜悦当中。矮子比查坐在他的女主人和哥本海姆中间，克制着自己的情绪，想着用什么办法靠近莫黛斯特，并在她耳边提醒一下她。
Chapter I The Chalet: Madame Latournelle and Madame Dumay, who were appointed to watch Modeste, had a certain assumed stiffness of demeanor and a quiver in their voices, which the suspected party did not notice, so absorbed was she in her embroidery.Modeste laid each thread of cotton with a precision that would have made an ordinary workwoman desperate.Her face expressed the pleasure she took in the smooth petals of the flower she was working.The dwarf, seated between his mistress and Gobenheim, restrained his emotion, trying to find means to approach Modeste and whisper a word of warning in her ear.

第一章 木屋: 拉图奈尔夫人使出她那虔诚教徒的鬼心眼儿，坐在米尼翁夫人前面的位子上，这样就将莫黛斯特与其他人隔离开了。米尼翁夫人双眼失明，因此总是保持沉默。她的脸色比平时更加苍白，这很清楚地说明她意识到了她女儿将要经受的考验。或许，她会在最后时刻起来反抗这一计谋，因为这对她来说似乎是有必要的。于是，她保持着沉默，心里却在流泪。埃克絮佩是整个计谋的扳机，但他对这个自己将在其中扮演一个角色的剧本全然不知。由于性格的原因，哥本海姆同莫黛斯特一样，仍保持着一种漠不关心的状态。一些人毫无察觉，另一些人却心跳加速、紧张兮兮，对于一个了解内情的旁观者来说，这种对比看上去真的很有意思。如今，浪漫主义作家总是会安排这样的效果，而且他们也确实有权利这样做，因为自古以来大自然编故事的本领总比他们高明。因此，你将会看到，这里的自然，即社会自然（它是大自然中的一种第二自然），将事实编造得比小说更有意思，以此来自娱自乐。正如山泉的蜿蜒曲折是画家无法描摹的，而泉水打磨石块的鬼斧神工，也令建筑师和雕刻家们叹为观止。
Chapter I The Chalet: By taking a position in front of Madame Mignon, Madame Latournelle, with the diabolical intelligence of conscientious duty, had isolated Modeste.Madame Mignon, whose blindness always made her silent, was even paler than usual, showing plainly that she was aware of the test to which her daughter was about to be subjected.Perhaps at the last moment she revolted from the stratagem, necessary as it might seem to her.Hence her silence; she was weeping inwardly.Exupere, the spring of the trap, was wholly ignorant of the piece in which he was to play a part.Gobenheim, by reason of his character, remained in a state of indifference equal to that displayed by Modeste.To a spectator who understood the situation, this contrast between the ignorance of some and the palpitating interest of others would have seemed quite poetic.Nowadays romance-writers arrange such effects; and it is quite within their province to do so, for nature in all ages takes the liberty to be stronger than they.In this instance, as you will see, nature, social nature, which is a second nature within nature, amused herself by making truth more interesting than fiction; just as mountain torrents describe curves which are beyond the skill of painters to convey, and accomplish giant deeds in displacing or smoothing stones which are the wonder of architects and sculptors.

第一章 木屋: 已经是晚上八点了。在那个季节，黄昏的最后一丝余晖仍未散去，天空万里无云，柔和的空气抚摸着大地，鲜花散发出芳香，归家的行人走在碎石路上，脚下沙沙作响，波光鳞鳞的大海像一面镜子。尽管窗户是敞开的，但风很小，牌桌上的烛火安静地燃烧着。这间客厅，这个夜晚，这套住宅——这一切就像一只美丽的画框，烘托着画中少女的美貌！此刻，人们都全神贯注地审视着这位少女，就像画家审视皮蒂画院的名画之一《玛德莱娜·多尼》一样。莫黛斯特就像诗人卡图卢斯笔下含苞待放的鲜花，这样的一位少女竟需要人们如此百般防范吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: It was eight o’clock.At that season twilight was still shedding its last gleams; there was not a cloud in the sky; the balmy air caressed the earth, the flowers gave forth their fragrance, the steps of pedestrians turning homeward sounded along the gravelly road, the sea shone like a mirror, and there was so little wind that the wax candles upon the card-tables sent up a steady flame, although the windows were wide open.This salon, this evening, this dwelling—what a frame for the portrait of the young girl whom these persons were now studying with the profound attention of a painter in presence of the Margharita Doni, one of the glories of the Pitti palace.Modeste,—blossom enclosed, like that of Catullus,—was she worth all these precautions?

第一章 木屋: 看完了鸟笼，下面来看看这只小鸟吧！莫黛斯特年方二十，窈窕纤弱，就像英国素描家们为《美女图》所创作的美女。她同她母亲年轻时一样，是优雅迷人的化身，但这种魅力大多数法国人无法理解，只是把它称作“多愁善感”。而对德国女人而言，这种魅力则是内心诗意在外表的体现——愚蠢的女子表现为矫揉造作，活泼聪明的女子则表现为非凡的迷人姿态。莫黛斯特那淡淡的金发十分引人注目，属于那种被称为“金发仙子”（这种说法大概是为了纪念夏娃）的女人；她那光滑的肌肤就像是贴在皮肉上的绢纸，会因冷峻的眼神而瑟瑟发抖，而在充满爱意的目光下，又会像受到阳光照射般舒展开来——真让人看着就想用手摸一下。她的头发柔软轻盈，打着许多波浪卷。头发下的额头就像是用圆规画出来的，线条完美无瑕，透出一股镇定和安详，又带着一丝思考的灵动：世上怎么可能有另外一个如此洁白无瑕、精致平滑的额头呢？它就像一颗珍珠，光彩夺目。她的双眸蓝中透灰，如孩童的眼睛那样清澈，还保留着儿童时代的全部淘气与单纯，与她那像是在一张中国脸谱上用毛笔轻轻勾勒出的眉弓浑然一体。她的眼周、眼角以及鬓角，都泛着蓝色的、珍珠般的光辉，这是只有皮肤娇嫩的人才有的特质，更加体现出她心灵的纯真。她长着一张鹅蛋脸，如同拉斐尔笔下的圣母玛利亚，那冷静、纯洁的面颊格外引人注目，柔嫩得像一朵孟加拉玫瑰。透明的眼睑上方，长长的睫毛投射出一抹半明半暗的阴影。她刺着绣，象牙白的脖子低垂着，轮廓精致纤美，让人想起列奥纳多·达芬奇爱用的那种若隐若现的线条。她的脸上有几颗雀斑，犹如十八世纪妇女用来装扮的美人斑，这证明了莫黛斯特确实是大地的女儿，而不是意大利天使学派幻想出来的尤物。她的双唇精致而饱满，带有一丝嘲弄的味道，颇具吸引力。她的腰柔软灵活，却并不柔弱，因此生小孩时不会有任何困难，不像有些少女为了追求美丽，被紧身衣勒出致命伤。她那优雅的身段浑然天成，裙撑、麻纱和饰带更凸显出她那蛇一般的曲线，使她看上去像一株风中摇曳的小白杨那样优美。
Chapter I The Chalet: You have seen the cage; behold the bird!Just twenty years of age, slender and delicate as the sirens which English designers invent for their “Books of Beauty,” Modeste was, like her mother before her, the captivating embodiment of a grace too little understood in France, where we choose to call it sentimentality, but which among German women is the poetry of the heart coming to the surface of the being and spending itself—in affectations if the owner is silly, in divine charms of manner if she is “spirituelle” and intelligent.Remarkable for her pale golden hair, Modeste belonged to the type of woman called, perhaps in memory of Eve, the celestial blonde; whose satiny skin is like a silk paper applied to the flesh, shuddering at the winter of a cold look, expanding in the sunshine of a loving glance,—teaching the hand to be jealous of the eye.Beneath her hair, which was soft and feathery and worn in many curls, the brow, which might have been traced by a compass so pure was its modelling, shone forth discreet, calm to placidity, and yet luminous with thought: when and where could another be found so transparently clear or more exquisitely smooth?It seemed, like a pearl, to have its orient.The eyes, of a blue verging on gray and limpid as the eyes of a child, had all the mischief, all the innocence of childhood, and they harmonized well with the arch of the eyebrows, faintly indicated by lines like those made with a brush on Chinese faces.This candor of the soul was still further evidenced around the eyes, in their corners, and about the temples, by pearly tints threaded with blue, the special privilege of these delicate complexions.The face, whose oval Raphael so often gave to his Madonnas, was remarkable for the sober and virginal tone of the cheeks, soft as a Bengal rose, upon which the long lashes of the diaphanous eyelids cast shadows that were mingled with light.The throat, bending as she worked, too delicate perhaps, and of milky whiteness, recalled those vanishing lines that Leonardo loved.A few little blemishes here and there, like the patches of the eighteenth century, proved that Modeste was indeed a child of earth, and not a creation dreamed of in Italy by the angelic school.Her lips, delicate yet full, were slightly mocking and somewhat sensuous; the waist, which was supple and yet not fragile, had no terrors for maternity, like those of girls who seek beauty by the fatal pressure of a corset.Steel and dimity and lacings defined but did not create the serpentine lines of the elegant figure, graceful as that of a young poplar swaying in the wind.

第一章 木屋: 她穿着一件珠灰色的连衣裙，镶着深红色的饰边，腰身很长，很好地勾勒出她上半身的轮廓，内穿一件紧身胸衣，掩盖住还有点消瘦的肩膀，人们只能看到脖子与肩膀相接处最上方的曲线。再来看看这位少女的脸庞吧：希腊式的鼻子精致细腻，鼻孔呈玫红色，轮廓分明的面颊透出几分自信、笃定，整张脸散发出一种优雅、聪慧的气息。近乎神秘的额头所呈现的诗意美有时候会被嘴角边嬉笑的表情所掩盖。深邃而又变幻莫测的双眼时而透出一股直率，时而又充满了后天训练与教育带来的嘲讽精神。从这张脸庞的方方面面，一位善于观察的人会感觉到，这位少女敏锐机灵的耳朵会被任何一个声音唤醒，她的鼻子随时可以捕捉到理想之花的芳香，她命中注定要在黎明时的诗情画意与白天的劳作之间、理想与现实之间，以及精神与生活之间，进行艰难的抉择。莫黛斯特是一位纯洁的少女，求知欲强，深知命理，贞洁自爱——与其说她是拉斐尔的圣母玛利亚，还不如说她是西班牙的圣女。
Chapter I The Chalet: A pearl-gray dress with crimson trimmings, made with a long waist, modestly outlined the bust and covered the shoulders, still rather thin, with a chemisette which left nothing to view but the first curves of the throat where it joined the shoulders.From the aspect of the young girl’s face, at once ethereal and intelligent, where the delicacy of a Greek nose with its rosy nostrils and firm modelling marked something positive and defined; where the poetry enthroned upon an almost mystic brow seemed belied at times by the pleasure-loving expression of the mouth; where candor claimed the depths profound and varied of the eye, and disputed them with a spirit of irony that was trained and educated,—from all these signs an observer would have felt that this young girl, with the keen, alert ear that waked at every sound, with a nostril open to catch the fragrance of the celestial flower of the Ideal, was destined to be the battle-ground of a struggle between the poesies of the dawn and the labors of the day; between fancy and reality, the spirit and the life.Modeste was a pure young girl, inquisitive after knowledge, understanding her destiny, and filled with chastity,—the Virgin of Spain rather than the Madonna of Raphael.

第一章 木屋: 她听到迪迈对埃克絮佩说“到这来，小伙子”，便抬起头来。她看到他们在客厅的一角，还以为他们是在谈巴黎的某桩差事。接着，她看看周围的朋友们，似乎很奇怪他们为什么这么安静。她自然地问道：“你们怎么不打牌呢？”并看了一眼被高大壮硕的拉图奈尔夫人称作“祭坛”的牌桌。

第一章 木屋: 不管此时的情形看上去多么有趣，如果我再解释一下迪迈先生在莫黛斯特问题上所处的立场，事情就会变得更加有趣了。如果我简短的解释显得有些干巴巴的，那还请读者谅解，因为我们希望尽快带过这些铺垫工作，并有必要将统筹整个故事的主要情况联系起来。

第一章 木屋: 让·弗朗索瓦·贝尔纳·迪迈，出生于瓦讷，一七九九年加入远征意大利的大军。迪迈的父亲曾是当地革命法庭的主席，任职时十分嚣张，于是，当这位狡诈的律师父亲于热月九日被送上断头台之后，那里再也没有迪迈的容身之处了。他母亲因这一突发的灾祸抑郁而终。母亲死后，让便变卖了所有家产，跑到了意大利，当时他二十二岁。也正是在那时，我们的军队开始向敌人屈服了。路上，他在瓦尔省遇到了一个年轻人，也跟他出于同样的原因，想去追求战功，感觉战场还不如自己的家乡普罗旺斯危险。这个人叫夏尔·米尼翁，巴黎有一条街是以他的家族命名的，还有一所公馆是由米尼翁红衣主教建造的。他是这个古老家族的最后子嗣，他父亲很是精明，善于算计，企图将他在孔塔的拉巴斯蒂伯爵封地从大革命的魔爪下拯救出来。于是这位拉巴斯蒂公爵也跟当时所有胆小怕事的人一样，给自己冠上了“公民”的称号，成了“米尼翁公民”。他明白，与其让别人砍自己的头，还不如去砍别人的头来得有益。这位假冒的恐怖分子在热月九日之后便消失了，接着便被列入了流亡者的名单。拉巴斯蒂封地被拍卖了，古老城堡的塔楼和堡垒被夷为平地。这位米尼翁公民很快就在奥尔良被发现，并同他的妻子和孩子们一起被处死。只有夏尔幸免于难，他当时被父亲派到上阿尔卑斯省，为家人找一个避难之所。
Chapter I The Chalet: Jean Francois Bernard Dumay, born at Vannes, started as a soldier for the army of Italy in 1799.His father, president of the revolutionary tribunal of that town, had displayed so much energy in his office that the place had become too hot to hold the son when the parent, a pettifogging lawyer, perished on the scaffold after the ninth Thermidor.On the death of his mother, who died of the grief this catastrophe occasioned, Jean sold all that he possessed and rushed to Italy at the age of twenty-two, at the very moment when our armies were beginning to yield.On the way he met a young man in the department of Var, who for reasons analogous to his own was in search of glory, believing a battle-field less perilous than his own Provence.Charles Mignon, the last scion of an ancient family, which gave its name to a street in Paris and to a mansion built by Cardinal Mignon, had a shrewd and calculating father, whose one idea was to save his feudal estate of La Bastie in the Comtat from the claws of the Revolution.Like all timid folk of that day, the Comte de La Bastie, now citizen Mignon, found it more wholesome to cut off other people’s heads than to let his own be cut off.The sham terrorist disappeared after the 9th Thermidor, and was then inscribed on the list of emigres.The estate of La Bastie was sold; the towers and bastions of the old castle were pulled down, and citizen Mignon was soon after discovered at Orleans and put to death with his wife and all his children except Charles, whom he had sent to find a refuge for the family in the Upper Alps.

第一章 木屋: 听到这个消息，夏尔惊恐万分，便躲在热内弗尔山谷中避风头。他在那里一直呆到一七九九年，靠临行前父亲给他的几个路易勉强度日。到夏尔二十三岁的时候，他除了自己的堂堂外表之外，已经一无所有。他有着典型的南方人美貌，当这种美达到极致时，可以说是无与伦比（罗马皇帝亚德里安最宠爱的安提弩斯就是这一类型）。夏尔决定拿他普罗旺斯人的胆量赌一把，和许多其他年轻人一样，他把这看作是一种天意，要去战场上大干一番。在去军队驻地尼斯的路上，他碰到了布列塔尼人迪迈。或许由于性格互补，两人成了亲密的伙伴，他们从路边的激流中同饮一杯水，分享一块饼干，马伦戈战役停战后，两个人又都成了中士。
Chapter I The Chalet: Horrorstruck at the news, Charles waited for better times in a valley of Mont Genevra; and there he remained till 1799, subsisting on a few louis which his father had put into his hand at starting.Finally, when twenty-three years of age, and without other fortune than his fine presence and that southern beauty which, when it reaches perfection, may be called sublime (of which Antinous, the favorite of Adrian, is the type), Charles resolved to wager his Provencal audacity—taking it, like many another youth, for a vocation—on the red cloth of war.On his way to the base of the army at Nice he met the Breton.The pair became intimate, partly from the contrasts in their characters; they drank from the same cup at the wayside torrents, broke the same biscuit, and were both made sergeants at the peace which followed the battle of Marengo.

第一章 木屋: 后来战事又开始了，夏尔·米尼翁被调入了骑兵团，并与他的战友失去了联系。到一八一二年，这位米尼翁·德拉巴斯蒂家族的末代子孙已经成了荣誉军团的军官和骑兵团的少校。后来，他被俄国人俘虏，并同其他许多人一样，被送往西伯利亚。途中，他与另外一个同是俘虏的可怜的陆军中尉结伴，他发现那人正是自己的老朋友让·迪迈。迪迈同其他上百万戴着羊毛肩章的普通士兵一样，没被授勋，他很勇敢，却默默无闻，穿着简朴，过得并不开心。拿破仑正是在这样一幅由无数士兵组成的油画上描绘了他的帝国蓝图。在西伯利亚的时候，中校为了打发时间，便教这个布列塔尼人写字和算术。对赛沃拉教长而言，对迪迈进行早期教育简直是浪费时间。在过去一起行军的日子里，夏尔发现这位老战友有着少有的好心肠，自己可以跟他吐露辛酸，也可以与之分享快乐。
Chapter I The Chalet: When the war recommenced, Charles Mignon was promoted into the cavalry and lost sight of his comrade.In 1812 the last of the Mignon de La Bastie was an officer of the Legion of honor and major of a regiment of cavalry.Taken prisoner by the Russians he was sent, like so many others, to Siberia.He made the journey in company with another prisoner, a poor lieutenant, in whom he recognized his old friend Jean Dumay, brave, neglected, undecorated, unhappy, like a million of other woollen epaulets, rank and file—that canvas of men on which Napoleon painted the picture of the Empire.While in Siberia, the lieutenant-colonel, to kill time, taught writing and arithmetic to the Breton, whose early education had seemed a useless waste of time to Pere Scevola.Charles found in the old comrade of his marching days one of those rare hearts into which a man can pour his griefs while telling his joys.

第一章 木屋: 这位普罗旺斯年轻人的人生际遇与所有英俊的单身汉相同。一八零四年，在美因河畔的法兰克福，一位银行家的独生女贝蒂娜·瓦朗罗德爱上了他。他满怀热情地跟她结了婚，因为她家境富裕、姿色过人，而他当时只是一个没有任何希望的中尉、小兵痞，前途十分渺茫。老瓦朗罗德是一个失势的德国男爵（德国的银行总由一个男爵掌管），当他得知这位英俊的陆军中尉便是米尼翁·德拉巴斯蒂家族的唯一后裔时，感到很高兴，同意了金发少女贝蒂娜的婚事。有一位画家（当时在法兰克福的确有这么一位）曾依照贝蒂娜美丽的脸庞画了一幅理想的德国美女头像。瓦朗罗德在法国国库里存了足够的钱，这样她的女儿每年可以拿到三万法郎。他还提前将这些钱赠与他未来的外孙们，给他们取名为拉巴斯蒂－瓦朗罗德伯爵。由于当时钱不值钱，因此这笔“嫁妆”只给他的钱匣子造成了一个小小的缺口。但当时的法兰西帝国效仿许多其他债务国，实行了一项政策，很少能把利息付清，因此夏尔很担心这笔存款。他对帝国雄鹰的信念远不如他的岳父那么大。信念，或者说是仰慕，这种现象只是一种短暂的信仰，当你同你的崇拜对象近距离接触时，这种崇拜往往就很难维持了。旅行者迷信机器，机修工却对机器不以为然。即使军队的军官们不是拿破仑这台机车的燃料，至少也是它的烧炉工人。
Chapter I The Chalet: The young Provencal had met the fate which attends all handsome bachelors.In 1804, at Frankfort on the Main, he was adored by Bettina Wallenrod, only daughter of a banker, and he married her with all the more enthusiasm because she was rich and a noted beauty, while he was only a lieutenant with no prospects but the extremely problematical future of a soldier of fortune of that day.Old Wallenrod, a decayed German baron (there is always a baron in a German bank) delighted to know that the handsome lieutenant was the sole representative of the Mignon de La Bastie, approved the love of the blonde Bettina, whose beauty an artist (at that time there really was one in Frankfort) had lately painted as an ideal head of Germany.Wallenrod invested enough money in the French funds to give his daughter thirty thousand francs a year, and settled it on his anticipated grandsons, naming them counts of La Bastie–Wallenrod.This “dot” made only a small hole in his cash-box, the value of money being then very low.But the Empire, pursuing a policy often attempted by other debtors, rarely paid its dividends; and Charles was rather alarmed at this investment, having less faith than his father-inlaw in the imperial eagle.The phenomenon of belief, or of admiration which is ephemeral belief, is not so easily maintained when in close quarters with the idol.The mechanic distrusts the machine which the traveller admires; and the officers of the army might be called the stokers of the Napoleonic engine,—if, indeed, they were not its fuel.

第一章 木屋: 然而，瓦朗罗德-图斯塔尔-巴登斯梯德男爵答应在必要的时候帮助这个家庭。夏尔和贝蒂娜·瓦朗罗都深爱着对方，并且程度相当，这样说可能有点儿理想化，但当一个普罗旺斯人充满激情的时候，他的一切感觉和情感都是真实而自然的。再说，他怎能不爱上这位仿佛从杜勒画中走下来的、生来便具有天使般的气质并拥有法兰克福财富的金发美女呢？这对夫妇生了四个孩子，到他向这位布列塔尼人吐露辛酸的时候，只剩下两个女儿还活着。迪迈尽管没看到这两个小家伙，但仅仅通过夏尔对她们深深的怜爱，他便爱上了她们。对女儿的怜爱使夏尔充满柔情，恨不得把每个小孩都当成自己的孩子。夏尔的大女儿叫贝蒂娜·卡罗琳，生于一八零五年，另外一个女儿叫玛丽·莫黛斯特，生于一八零八年。一八一四年，停战合约签订后，这位可怜的中校在中尉的陪同下，奉命徒步穿过俄罗斯和普鲁士。他很久都没有自己两个心爱的宝贝的消息了。对这一对朋友而言，军衔的差异已经不算什么了。他们到达法兰克福的时候，拿破仑正好在戛纳登陆。
Chapter I The Chalet: However, the Baron Wallenrod-Tustall-Bartenstild promised to come if necessary to the help of the household.Charles loved Bettina Wallenrod as much as she loved him, and that is saying a good deal; but when a Provencal is moved to enthusiasm all his feelings and attachments are genuine and natural.And how could he fail to adore that blonde beauty, escaping, as it were, from the canvas of Durer, gifted with an angelic nature and endowed with Frankfort wealth?The pair had four children, of whom only two daughters survived at the time when he poured his griefs into the Breton’s heart.Dumay loved these little ones without having seen them, solely through the sympathy so well described by Charlet, which makes a soldier the father of every child.The eldest, named Bettina Caroline, was born in 1805; the other, Marie Modeste, in 1808.The unfortunate lieutenant-colonel, long without tidings of these cherished darlings, was sent, at the peace of 1814, across Russia and Prussia on foot, accompanied by the lieutenant.No difference of epaulets could count between the two friends, who reached Frankfort just as Napoleon was disembarking at Cannes.

第一章 木屋: 夏尔在法兰克福找到了他的妻子，她正在为父亲服丧。她父亲一直都很宠爱她，总是尽量逗她开心，甚至连临终前也是这样。老瓦朗罗德没能幸免于帝国的灾难。七十岁的时候，他开始投机棉花，对拿破仑的天才深信不疑，殊不知就是天才也往往对变幻无常的世事束手无策。这位老人买了许多捆棉花，其数量几乎与在拿破仑宏大的法兰西战役中牺牲的士兵数相当。“我洗（死）也要洗（死）在棉发（花）堆里。”这位父亲对女儿说道。他是一位高老头式的父亲，极力抚慰女儿的悲伤，也让自己好过些。“我对鞋（谁）都没有任何的亏欠——”他咽了气，临死前还尽量用他女儿所喜爱的语言跟她说话。
Chapter I The Chalet: Charles found his wife in Frankfort, in mourning for her father, who had always idolized her and tried to keep a smile upon her lips, even by his dying bed.Old Wallenrod was unable to survive the disasters of the Empire.At seventy years of age he speculated in cottons, relying on the genius of Napoleon without comprehending that genius is quite as often beyond as at the bottom of current events.The old man had purchased nearly as many bales of cotton as the Emperor had lost men during his magnificent campaign in France.“I tie in goddon,” said the father to the daughter, a father of the Goriot type, striving to quiet a grief which distressed him.“I owe no mann anything—” and he died, still trying to speak to his daughter in the language that she loved.

第一章 木屋: 幸好，夏尔·米尼翁把妻子和女儿从这场大灾难中救了出来。之后他回到了巴黎，皇帝任命他为禁卫军胸甲骑兵中校，并担任荣誉军团的指挥官。中校还梦想着打完第一次胜仗后被提升为伯爵和将军。唉！这个希望随着血流成河的滑铁卢战役灰飞烟灭了。中校受了点轻伤，撤退到卢瓦尔河畔，并在军队解散之前离开了图尔。
Chapter I The Chalet: Thankful to have saved his wife and daughters from the general wreck, Charles Mignon returned to Paris, where the Emperor made him lieutenant-colonel in the cuirassiers of the Guard and commander of the Legion of honor.The colonel dreamed of being count and general after the first victory.Alas! that hope was quenched in the blood of Waterloo.The colonel, slightly wounded, retired to the Loire, and left Tours before the disbandment of the army.

第一章 木屋: 一八一六年春天，夏尔以将近四十万法郎的价钱卖掉了她妻子在国库里的财产，准备离开自己的国家，去美洲碰碰运气，因为当时国内已经开始对拿破仑的旧部大加迫害。滑铁卢之战后，在撤退的混乱中，他把迪迈带在自己坐骑后面，救了他一命。夏尔在迪迈的陪伴下去了勒阿弗尔。迪迈跟中校意见一致，也有着同样的焦虑。这个可怜的家伙像崇拜偶像一样地爱着夏尔的两个小女儿，并像一只西班牙猎犬一样跟着夏尔。夏尔自信这个生性驯良、惯于服从、为人正直且对自己很有感情的中尉完全可以成为一个既有用又忠诚的仆人，于是他提议让迪迈以平民身份跟着他。迪迈十分高兴能被这个家庭所收留，他决心依附这个家庭，就像槲寄生依附于橡树那样。
Chapter I The Chalet: In the spring of 1816 Charles sold his wife’s property out of the funds to the amount of nearly four hundred thousand francs, intending to seek his fortune in America, and abandon his own country where persecution was beginning to lay a heavy hand on the soldiers of Napoleon.He went to Havre accompanied by Dumay, whose life he had saved at Waterloo by taking him on the crupper of his saddle in the hurly-burly of the retreat.Dumay shared the opinions and the anxieties of his colonel; the poor fellow idolized the two little girls and followed Charles like a spaniel.The latter, confidence that the habit of obedience, the discipline of subordination, and the honesty and affection of the lieutenant would make him a useful as well as a faithful retainer, proposed to take him with him in a civil capacity.Dumay was only too happy to be adopted into the family, to which he resolved to cling like the mistletoe to an oak.

第一章 木屋: 中校一边待机登船，一边挑选船只，并思考那些船只所要去的各种港口能给他带来的机会。在这个过程中，他听到许多人说和平将给勒阿弗尔带来光明的前景。他听着商人们的谈话，预料到了发财的路子。于是他分秒必争，开始着手让自己成为地产主、银行家和运输商。他在镇上买了地和房子，并派了一艘商船到纽约，上面装着从里昂以折扣价买来的丝绸。他派迪迈做他的经纪人，随船出行。迪迈回来的时候发了两笔财，一是卖了丝绸，二是以低价格买回了棉花。这时，他发现他的中校一家已经搬进了王政街最漂亮的房子，以普罗旺斯人惊人的活力和聪明才智，学习着银行业务。
Chapter I The Chalet: While waiting for an opportunity to embark, at the same time making choice of a ship and reflecting on the chances offered by the various ports for which they sailed, the colonel heard much talk about the brilliant future which the peace seemed to promise to Havre.As he listened to these conversations among the merchants, he foresaw the means of fortune, and without loss of time he set about making himself the owner of landed property, a banker, and a shipping-merchant.He bought land and houses in the town, and despatched a vessel to New York freighted with silks purchased in Lyons at reduced prices.He sent Dumay on the ship as his agent; and when the latter returned, after making a double profit by the sale of the silks and the purchase of cottons at a low valuation, he found the colonel installed with his family in the handsomest house in the rue Royale, and studying the principles of banking with the prodigious activity and intelligence of a native of Provence.

第一章 木屋: 迪迈做的这两笔生意对米尼翁家族来说是一笔很大的财富。中校买下了安古维尔的别墅，还奖给他的经纪人一所位于王政街的简朴小屋。这位可怜而卖力的仆人从纽约带回来的，除了棉花之外，还有一位娇小美丽的妻子，她似乎是被他那法国人的天性所吸引了。格吕梅尔小姐大约有四千美元的财产（合两万法郎）。迪迈将这些钱投资到中校那里，现在，他已经是中校的至交了。他用很短的时间学会了替东家管账，用他的话来说，做这一行的可以称得上是商业中的军士长。这位天真纯朴的士兵，二十年来都没有受到过幸运之神的眷顾。而此时，他拥有了一所小房子，东家还慷慨地为他添置了家具，每年能得到一千二百法郎的分红以及三千六百法郎的薪水，他觉得自己是世界上最幸福的人了。迪迈中尉做梦都没想过会有这么好的境遇，而更让他感到满足的是，他觉得自己凭好运经营起来的产业已经成了勒阿弗尔最富有的商行的财富枢纽。
Chapter I The Chalet: This double operation of Dumay’s was worth a fortune to the house of Mignon.The colonel purchased the villa at Ingouville and rewarded his agent with the gift of a modest little house in the rue Royale.The poor toiler had brought back from New York, together with his cottons, a pretty little wife, attracted it would seem by his French nature.Miss Grummer was worth about four thousand dollars (twenty thousand francs), which sum Dumay placed with his colonel, to whom he now became an alter ego.In a short time he learned to keep his patron’s books, a science which, to use his own expression, pertains to the sergeant-majors of commerce.The simple-hearted soldier, whom fortune had forgotten for twenty years, thought himself the happiest man in the world as the owner of the little house (which his master’s liberality had furnished), with twelve hundred francs a year from money in the funds, and a salary of three thousand six hundred.Never in his dreams had Lieutenant Dumay hoped for a situation so good as this; but greater still was the satisfaction he derived from the knowledge that his lucky enterprise had been the pivot of good fortune to the richest commercial house in Havre.

第一章 木屋: 迪迈夫人是一位漂亮小巧的美国女人，不幸的是，她生了好几胎，每次都是孩子一生下来就死掉了。她的最后一次分娩更是死里逃生，彻底打碎了她再生孩子的希望。因此，她对两位米尼翁小姐十分喜爱，迪迈也很爱她们。说不定即使他们自己有孩子，迪迈还是会更喜欢这两位小姐。迪迈太太的父母都是勤俭节约的农民。现在自己和全家能有两千四百法郎作为家庭开支，她便已十分满足。于是，迪迈每年又将两千几百法郎投到米尼翁商行中去。每年年终清算账务的时候，中校都会为了感谢这位账务总管的勤劳工作而多给他一些奖金。这样，他的存款就越来越多了。到一八二四年，这位账务总管的存款已经达到了五万八千法郎。那时，再没有人称夏尔·米尼翁为德拉巴斯蒂伯爵了。米尼翁做了一件让其账务总管最为开心的事，就是让他住到木屋来。这个故事开始的时候，米尼翁夫人和她的女儿正隐居在那里。
Chapter I The Chalet: Madame Dumay, a rather pretty little American, had the misfortune to lose all her children at their birth; and her last confinement was so disastrous as to deprive her of the hope of any other.She therefore attached herself to the two little Mignons, whom Dumay himself loved, or would have loved, even better than his own children had they lived.Madame Dumay, whose parents were farmers accustomed to a life of economy, was quite satisfied to receive only two thousand four hundred francs of her own and her household expenses; so that every year Dumay laid by two thousand and some extra hundreds with the house of Mignon.When the yearly accounts were made up the colonel always added something to this little store by way of acknowledging the cashier’s services, until in 1824 the latter had a credit of fifty-eight thousand francs.In was then that Charles Mignon, Comte de La Bastie, a title he never used, crowned his cashier with the final happiness of residing at the Chalet, where at the time when this story begins Madame Mignon and her daughter were living in obscurity.

第一章 木屋: 米尼翁夫人这种糟糕的身体状况在某种程度上是出于一场灾祸，也正是这场灾祸，让她的丈夫离开了她。三年来，这位温和的德国女人被悲伤彻底击垮了。那种悲伤侵蚀着她的内心，就像一只蠕虫在啃食一只好果子的果心一样。她悲伤的原因显而易见，总结起来也很容易。两个孩子还在襁褓中就夭折了，这给她留下了刻骨铭心的痛。丈夫被流放到西伯利亚，对这个女人来说，每天都是生不如死。瓦朗罗德家族破产，父亲与世长辞，留下空空的金库，当时自己的丈夫又前途未卜，这对贝蒂娜来说又是一个沉重的打击。夏尔的归来让她兴奋不已，过度的欢乐差点摧毁了这朵脆弱的德国花朵。随着帝国的再度崩溃，他们准备流浪国外，这让她觉得像寒热复发一样难受。然而，最后终于有了长达十年的家族兴旺，她的家成了勒阿弗尔最豪华舒适的富商住宅，举办了各种晚宴、舞会、游乐会。米尼翁别墅金碧辉煌，丈夫受人尊敬、声望极高，又对她一往情深，用无与伦比的爱来报答她忠贞的爱——这一切，又让这个女人获得了重生。就在她的疑虑和担忧终于消除之后，在她展望历经风雨后幸福的晚年时，一场深埋在家族内部的灾难爆发了，带来一连串新的考验。我们下面很快就要讲到。
Chapter I The Chalet: The deplorable state of Madame Mignon’s health was caused in part by the catastrophe to which the absence of her husband was due.Grief had taken three years to break down the docile German woman; but it was a grief that gnawed at her heart like a worm at the core of a sound fruit.It is easy to reckon up its obvious causes.Two children, dying in infancy, had a double grave in a soul that could never forget.The exile of her husband to Siberia was to such a woman a daily death.The failure of the rich house of Wallenrod, and the death of her father, leaving his coffers empty, was to Bettina, then uncertain about the fate of her husband, a terrible blow.The joy of Charles’s return came near killing the tender German flower.After that the second fall of the Empire and the proposed expatriation acted on her feelings like a renewed attack of the same fever.At last, however, after ten years of continual prosperity, the comforts of her house, which was the finest in Havre, the dinners, balls, and fetes of a prosperous merchant, the splendors of the villa Mignon, the unbounded respect and consideration enjoyed by her husband, his absolute affection, giving her an unrivalled love in return for her single-minded love for him,—all these things brought the woman back to life.At the moment when her doubts and fears at last left her, when she could look forward to the bright evening of her stormy life, a hidden catastrophe, buried in the heart of the family, and of which we shall presently make mention, came as the precursor of renewed trials.

第一章 木屋: 交易所、港口、私人商号，所有的人都对这一灾难表示惋惜，他们交口称赞这位无可指责、受人敬重且乐善好施的先生。而拉图奈尔和迪迈则像蚂蚁一样默默地四处奔波，变卖地产，把财产兑成现钱，还债，打点一切事务。维尔坎摆出十分慷慨的样子，买下了别墅、市内的房子，还有一处农场。拉图奈尔也利用这一点，尽量让他出了个好价钱。社交场上的人想去看望米尼翁夫人和小姐，但她们听从了夏尔最后的叮嘱，暂避到木屋里。她们就是在夏尔动身的那天早上搬到木屋去的，他向她们隐瞒了他出发的具体时间。这位勇敢的男人，为了不让离别的悲伤动摇他的决心，在他的妻子和女儿还在熟睡时便同她们告别了。三百张名片留在了他们家门口。半个月过后，正如夏尔所预料的那样，人们已经将木屋忘得一干二净了。这也向她们证实了米尼翁先生的这个命令多么英明、伟大。
Chapter I The Chalet: While unanimous regrets for the disaster were expressed in counting-rooms, on the wharves, and in private houses, where praises of a man so irreproachable, honorable, and beneficent filled every mouth, Latournelle and Dumay, silent and active as ants, sold land, turned property into money, paid the debts, and settled up everything.Vilquin showed a good deal of generosity in purchasing the villa, the town-house, and a farm; and Latournelle made the most of his liberality by getting a good price out of him.Society wished to show civilities to Madame and Mademoiselle Mignon; but they had already obeyed the father’s last wishes and taken refuge in the Chalet, where they went on the very morning of his departure, the exact hour of which had been concealed from them.Not to be shaken in his resolution by his grief at parting, the brave man said farewell to his wife and daughter while they slept.Three hundred visiting cards were left at the house.A fortnight later, just as Charles had predicted, complete forgetfulness settled down upon the Chalet, and proved to these women the wisdom and dignity of his command.

第一章 木屋: 一个外表俊朗的年轻人，名叫夏尔·德埃斯图尼，跟其他人一样为了亲近大海，来到了勒阿弗尔，并在那里看到了贝蒂娜·米尼翁。一位自命时髦的巴黎人是从不愁无人引见的。他应米尼翁家的一个朋友之邀，参加一场在安古维尔举办的游乐会。他爱上了贝蒂娜和她的财产，花了三个月的时间引诱她，并把她给拐走了。一位有女儿的父亲不能将他没读过的书和报纸随便乱放，同样也不能让一个他不了解的年轻人到他家里去。一个年轻姑娘的单纯就如同牛奶一样，一声惊雷、一股有害的气味、一个大热天，甚至只是一阵微风，都会使之变酸。
Chapter I The Chalet: A young man of charming appearance, named Charles d’Estourny, came to Havre for the commonplace purpose of being near the sea, and there he saw Bettina Mignon.A “soi-disant” fashionable Parisian is never without introductions, and he was invited at the instance of a friend of the Mignons to a fete given at Ingouville.He fell in love with Bettina and with her fortune, and in three months he had done the work of seduction and enticed her away.The father of a family of daughters should no more allow a young man whom he does not know to enter his home than he should leave books and papers lying about which he has not read.A young girl’s innocence is like milk, which a small matter turns sour,—a clap of thunder, an evil odor, a hot day, a mere breath.

第一章 木屋: 迪迈夫人回到勒阿弗尔时，破产之灾已经降临，社会上的人也没再注意贝蒂娜的消失，以及账房总管夫人的归来。一八二七年初，报纸上充斥着审判夏尔·德埃斯图尼的消息，他被判赌博诈骗罪。这个年轻的盗贼丢下米尼翁小姐不管，跑到国外去了。自从她家银行破产之后，她对他而言就没有什么价值了。贝蒂娜几乎是在同一时间得知她已被那个无耻之徒抛弃，而她父亲也已经破产。她回到家时已是气息奄奄，没过多久就在木屋去世了。她的死亡至少保住了她的声誉。对于米尼翁先生称贝蒂娜离家是因为生病，还有家庭医生让贝蒂娜去尼斯养病的这些事，人们现在基本上信以为真了。直到最后一刻，母亲还是希望能挽救她女儿的生命。贝蒂娜是她的心头肉，而莫黛斯特则是父亲的心头肉。他们两人的偏爱都有其令人动容之处。贝蒂娜长得像夏尔，正如莫黛斯特跟她妈妈就像一个模子刻出来的一样。这对父母在他们的孩子身上继续爱着彼此。贝蒂娜——普罗旺斯的女儿，从他父亲那里继承了一头南方女子特有的鸦翅般黑亮的秀发，杏仁般的棕色眼睛像星星一样闪闪发亮，还有橄榄色的面容，犹如金果般的柔滑肌肤，拱形的脚背，以及像要撑破巴斯克式紧身衣的西班牙女子般的腰身。姐妹俩迥然不同、各具魅力，这令父母十分自豪。“一个魔鬼，一个天使！”他们笑着对彼此说道，却没想到竟然一语成谶。
Chapter I The Chalet: By the time Madame Dumay returned to Havre the catastrophe of the failure had taken place, and society paid no further attention to the absence of Bettina or the return of the cashier’s wife.At the beginning of 1827 the newspapers rang with the trial of Charles d’Estourny, who was found guilty of cheating at cards.The young corsair escaped into foreign parts without taking thought of Mademoiselle Mignon, who was of little value to him since the failure of the bank.Bettina heard of his infamous desertion and of her father’s ruin almost at the same time.She returned home struck by death, and wasted away in a short time at the Chalet.Her death at least protected her reputation.The illness that Monsieur Mignon alleged to be the cause of her absence, and the doctor’s order which sent her to Nice were now generally believed.Up to the last moment the mother hoped to save her daughter’s life.Bettina was her darling and Modeste was the father’s.There was something touching in the two preferences.Bettina was the image of Charles, just as Modeste was the reproduction of her mother.Both parents continued their love for each other in their children.Bettina, a daughter of Provence, inherited from her father the beautiful hair, black as a raven’s wing, which distinguishes the women of the South, the brown eye, almond-shaped and brilliant as a star, the olive tint, the velvet skin as of some golden fruit, the arched instep, and the Spanish waist from which the short basque skirt fell crisply.Both mother and father were proud of the charming contrast between the sisters.“A devil and an angel!” they said to each other, laughing, little thinking it prophetic.

Chapter I The Chalet: After weeping for a month in the solitude of her chamber, where she admitted no one, the mother came forth at last with injured eyes.Before losing her sight altogether she persisted, against the wishes of her friends, in visiting her daughter’s grave, on which she riveted her gaze in contemplation.That image remained vivid in the darkness which now fell upon her, just as the red spectrum of an object shines in our eyes when we close them in full daylight.This terrible and double misfortune made Dumay, not less devoted, but more anxious about Modeste, now the only daughter of the father who was unaware of his loss.Madame Dumay, idolizing Modeste, like other women deprived of their children, cast her motherliness about the girl,—yet without disregarding the commands of her husband, who distrusted female intimacies.Those commands were brief.“If any man, of any age, or any rank,” Dumay said, “speaks to Modeste, ogles her, makes love to her, he is a dead man.I’ll blow his brains out and give myself to the authorities; my death may save her.If you don’t wish to see my head cut off, do you take my place in watching her when I am obliged to go out.”

第一章 木屋: 现在，我们可以想象住在木屋里的这对母女过着怎样的生活了。拉图奈尔先生和夫人几乎每天晚上都到这里来拜访，和迪迈玩惠斯特牌，常常还有哥本海姆陪着。谈话总是围绕勒阿弗尔当地的一些传言，还有市区生活的一些琐事。这小小的聚会大约会在晚上九、十点钟散场。然后，莫黛斯特就服侍母亲上床睡觉，她们一起祷告，互相鼓励，并聊聊她们牵挂的那位旅人——米尼翁夫人的丈夫，莫黛斯特的父亲。莫黛斯特亲吻母亲、道过晚安后，在大约十点钟的时候回到自己的房间去。第二天早晨，她同样细心地帮母亲梳妆打扮，和她一起做同样的祷告，闲聊着同样的话题。说句夸奖的话，从那可怕的疾病夺去了她母亲视觉的那一天起，莫黛斯特就像她的仆人一样，始终如一地关心她，从不对所做的事感到疲倦，也从不觉得单调乏味。这种始终如一的孝顺，以及少女身上少有的温柔体贴，令所有的人赞不绝口。对于拉图奈尔一家，以及迪迈先生和迪迈夫人来说，莫黛斯特在道德品质方面就是一颗无价的珍珠。
Chapter I The Chalet: We can now imagine the sort of life led by mother and daughter at the Chalet.Monsieur and Madame Latournelle, often accompanied by Gobenheim, came to call and play whist with Dumay nearly every evening.The conversation turned on the gossip of Havre and the petty events of provincial life.The little company separated between nine and ten o’clock.Modeste put her mother to bed, and together they said their prayers, kept up each other’s courage, and talked of the dear absent one, the husband and father.After kissing her mother for good-night, the girl went to her own room about ten o’clock.The next morning she prepared her mother for the day with the same care, the same prayers, the same prattle.To her praise be it said that from the day when the terrible infirmity deprived her mother of a sense, Modeste had been like a servant to her, displaying at all times the same solicitude; never wearying of the duty, never thinking it monotonous.Such constant devotion, combined with a tenderness rare among young girls, was thoroughly appreciated by those who witnessed it.To the Latournelle family, and to Monsieur and Madame Dumay, Modeste was, in soul, the pearl of price.

第一章 木屋: “迪迈，坐下。”这位失明的女人说道，“唉，莫黛斯特正心花怒放呢。噢！在你们眼里，她不是那么快乐，你们看不到她这些变化，对于只能看到大自然外在表象的眼睛，这些变化过于微妙了。她说话的语气，还有某些只有我能捕捉和理解的声调，使我感觉到了她的心花怒放。莫黛斯特不再端坐在那里沉思默想了，她内心充满了狂热，做事很冲动——总之，她很快乐。她表达的那些想法中透露着一种优雅与魅力。啊，朋友们，我虽然历尽悲伤，但我也同样了解幸福的滋味，我知道它的征兆。从我的莫黛斯特给我的亲吻中，我能猜测得到她心里在想什么。我知道她是否得到了她所期盼的，我知道她是惴惴不安，还是期盼着什么。一个亲吻当中是有许多细微差别的，就连一位天真无邪的少女也是如此，而莫黛斯特就是天真无邪的化身。但她的天真无邪不是无知的单纯，而是懂事的单纯。我虽然瞎了，但我那颗慈母之心是看得清的，我要你们监视我的女儿。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Sit down, Dumay,” said the blind woman.“Well, then Modeste is gay.Oh! she is not gay to your sight; you cannot catch these gradations; they are too delicate for eyes that see only the outside of nature.Her gaiety is betrayed to me by the tones of her voice, by certain accents which I alone can catch and understand.Modeste then, instead of sitting still and thoughtful, gives vent to a wild, inward activity by impulsive movements,—in short, she is happy.There is a grace, a charm in the very ideas she utters.Ah, my friends, I know happiness as well as I know sorrow; I know its signs.By the kiss my Modeste gives me I can guess what is passing within her.I know whether she has received what she was looking for, or whether she is uneasy or expectant.There are many gradations in a kiss, even in that of an innocent young girl, and Modeste is innocence itself; but hers is the innocence of knowledge, not of ignorance.I may be blind, but my tenderness is all-seeing, and I charge you to watch over my daughter.”

第一章 木屋: 事实上，迪迈现在出奇愤怒，公证人一心要揭开谜底，女监护人拉图奈尔夫人感觉被欺骗了，而迪迈夫人则为她丈夫的安危感到担心。这些人马上组成了一个监视小团体，从那天开始，时刻不离莫黛斯特左右。每天晚上，迪迈都像个满腹狐疑的西班牙人一样，裹着大衣，蹲在莫黛斯特的窗下过夜，但即便凭借着他那军人的洞察力，他也没能查出任何蛛丝马迹。除非她爱上了别墅花园里的夜莺，或者是什么精灵王子，因为莫黛斯特不可能和任何人见过面，也没有发出或者收到任何信号。迪迈夫人每天都是等莫黛斯特睡着了之后才上床睡觉的，她像她丈夫一样警惕地从木屋别墅上面的窗户监视着马路上的情况。在这八只阿耳戈斯般的眼睛的注视下，这个清白的孩子的一举一动都被研究和分析过，最后，她终于经受住了考验，因并无私通之嫌而被无罪开释。这样一来，四位朋友私底下都认为是米尼翁夫人紧张过度了，实在有些可笑。一直以来，都是拉图奈尔夫人陪着莫黛斯特去教堂，再带她回来。于是大家派她去跟这位母亲说，是她误会了自己的女儿。
Chapter I The Chalet: Dumay, now actually ferocious, the notary, in the character of a man bound to ferret out a mystery, Madame Latournelle, the deceived chaperone, and Madame Dumay, alarmed for her husband’s safety, became at once a set of spies, and Modeste from this day forth was never left alone for an instant.Dumay passed nights under her window wrapped in his cloak like a jealous Spaniard; but with all his military sagacity he was unable to detect the least suspicious sign.Unless she loved the nightingales in the villa park, or some fairy prince, Modeste could have seen no one, and had neither given nor received a signal.Madame Dumay, who never went to bed till she knew Modeste was asleep, watched the road from the upper windows of the Chalet with a vigilance equal to her husband’s.Under these eight Argus eyes the blameless child, whose every motion was studied and analyzed, came out of the ordeal so fully acquitted of all criminal conversation that the four friends declared to each other privately that Madame Mignon was foolishly over-anxious.Madame Latournelle, who always took Modeste to church and brought her back again, was commissioned to tell the mother that she was mistaken about her daughter.

第一章 木屋: “莫黛斯特是一个道德高尚的年轻姑娘，”她说道，“她有时热衷于某位作家的诗歌，有时又沉醉于另外一个作家的散文。只要通过那首‘断头台交响乐’（比查语，他总是慷慨地把好点子提供给他的女恩人）《一个囚犯的末日》对她的影响，就能看出她对那位雨果先生的崇拜已经到了痴迷的地步。我真不晓得这些家伙（作为中产阶级的拉图奈尔夫人，自然会把维克多·雨果、拉马丁、拜伦这类人称作“这些家伙”）是从哪儿得到他们的灵感的。莫黛斯特总是跟我谈起恰尔德·哈罗尔德，而我为了能跟她好好探讨探讨，竟然傻到尝试去读这些东西。也许是译者的错吧，但它真的让我反胃，我读得头昏脑胀，根本不可能读完。为什么这个人要谈那些吼叫的对比，会晕过去的石头，还有战争的浪涛！然而，鉴于他只是个英国游子，作品中难免会有荒谬之处——不过他的那些东西实在是太不可理喻了。他把你带到西班牙，又把你裹入阿尔卑斯山顶的云雾之中，还让激流开口，让星星说话，他还说这世上贞女太多了！您听过这样的话吗？拿破仑打了胜仗之后，他的作品一页一页、字里行间满是响亮的军乐和燃烧的炮弹。莫黛斯特告诉我，那些矫揉造作之辞全是译者加进去的，而我应该读英文原版的。　但是，我都没学英语来教埃克絮佩，当然也不会学英语去读拜伦爵士的作品。比起所有这些英国传奇故事，我更喜欢迪克雷-迪梅尼的小说。我是一个太纯正的诺曼人，不喜欢外国的东西，尤其是英国的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Modeste,” she said, “is a young girl of very exalted ideas; she works herself into enthusiasm for the poetry of one writer or the prose of another.You have only to judge by the impression made upon her by that scaffold symphony, ‘The Last Hours of a Convict’” (the saying was Butscha’s, who supplied wit to his benefactress with a lavish hand); “she seemed to me all but crazy with admiration for that Monsieur Hugo.I’m sure I don’t know where such people” (Victor Hugo, Lamartine, Byron being such people to the Madame Latournelles of the bourgeoisie) “get their ideas.Modeste kept talking to me of Childe Harold, and as I did not wish to get the worst of the argument I was silly enough to try to read the thing.Perhaps it was the fault of the translator, but it actually turned my stomach; I was dazed; I couldn’t possibly finish it.Why, the man talks about comparisons that howl, rocks that faint, and waves of war!However, he is only a travelling Englishman, and we must expect absurdities,—though his are really inexcusable.He takes you to Spain, and sets you in the clouds above the Alps, and makes the torrents talk, and the stars; and he says there are too many virgins!Did you ever hear the like?Then, after Napoleon’s campaigns, the lines are full of sonorous brass and flaming cannon-balls, rolling along from page to page.Modeste tells me that all that bathos is put in by the translator, and that I ought to read the book in English.But I certainly sha’n’t learn English to read Lord Byron when I didn’t learn it to teach Exupere.I much prefer the novels of Ducray-Dumenil to all these English romances.I’m too good a Norman to fall in love with foreign things,—above all when they come from England.”

Chapter I The Chalet: Madame Mignon, notwithstanding her melancholy, could not help smiling at the idea of Madame Latournelle reading Childe Harold.The stern scion of a parliamentary house accepted the smile as an approval of her doctrine.

第一章 木屋: “所以，亲爱的米尼翁夫人，”她接着说道，“莫黛斯特的迷恋只是由读书造成的，没有别的，您却以为她是恋爱了。记住，她才二十岁。女孩子在这个年龄段都是自恋的，她们爱打扮，是为了让自己看着舒服。我还记得我以前常让我那已过世的妹妹戴一顶男人的帽子，然后和我假扮先生和太太。您看，您在法兰克福度过了十分幸福的青年时代，但公平点儿说，莫黛斯特在这里的生活一点儿乐趣都没有。尽管她的每个愿望都的确得到了满足，但她仍知道自己被关起来了，还被看管着，除了读书之外，她的生活根本不能给她任何快乐。好了，别担心了，她谁都不爱，只爱您。您应该很高兴地看到她钟情于拜伦笔下的海盗、瓦尔特·司各特笔下的英雄，还有你们德国的一些男人，如埃格蒙特伯爵、歌德、维特、席勒等等。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And, therefore, my dear Madame Mignon,” she went on, “you have taken Modeste’s fancies, which are nothing but the results of her reading, for a love-affair.Remember, she is just twenty.Girls fall in love with themselves at that age; they dress to see themselves well-dressed.I remember I used to make my little sister, now dead, put on a man’s hat and pretend we were monsieur and madame.You see, you had a very happy youth in Frankfort; but let us be just,—Modeste is living here without the slightest amusement.Although, to be sure, her every wish is attended to, still she knows she is shut up and watched, and the life she leads would give her no pleasure at all if it were not for the amusement she gets out of her books.Come, don’t worry yourself; she loves nobody but you.You ought to be very glad that she goes into these enthusiasms for the corsairs of Byron and the heroes of Walter Scott and your own Germans, Egmont, Goethe, Werther, Schiller, and all the other ‘ers.’”

第一章 木屋: 如果以上这段简洁的描述得以被清晰地拓展，那将会是一幅完整的社会风俗画，许多家庭都可以从中看到他们家族史上发生的种种事件。但在这里，我们只要对这个难忘的夜晚中的一些人和事略加解释就够了。那天晚上，这位老兵已经为这个年轻姑娘设计好了一个局，旨在把藏在莫黛斯特内心深处的秘密发掘出来。这个秘密关乎她的爱情，关乎她爱的人，目前只有她失明的母亲发现了。

第一章 木屋: 一个小时的时间就在这种严肃、沉寂的气氛中过去了，只有玩惠斯特牌的人那些奇怪的词句会不时地打破这宁静：“黑桃！”“王牌！”“切牌！”“比分多少？”“二比四。”“该谁发牌了？”——在如今这个时代，这些词句代表了欧洲贵族阶层昂扬的激情。莫黛斯特继续着手里的活儿，好像没有对她母亲的沉默感到奇怪。米尼翁夫人的手帕从膝头滑落到了地上，比查马上跑过去把它捡了起来。就在他把手帕放回米尼翁夫人膝头的时候，他在莫黛斯特的耳边低声说道：“小心！”莫黛斯特抬起眼睛，目光里满是惊讶，她那疑惑的眼光使这个可怜的跛子心中充满了无以言表的喜悦。“她没恋爱！”他一边自言自语，一边搓着手，手上的皮都快被搓掉了。就在这时，埃克絮佩飞奔着穿过花园和屋子，猛地冲进客厅，以大家都能听见的音量冲迪迈耳语道：“那个年轻人来了！”迪迈一跃而起，拿起手枪冲了出去。
Chapter I The Chalet: An hour went by in solemn stillness broken only by the cabalistic phrases of the whist-players: “Spades!”“Trumped!”“Cut!”“How are honors?”“Two to four.”“Whose deal?”—phrases which represent in these days the higher emotions of the European aristocracy.Modeste continued to work, without seeming to be surprised at her mother’s silence.Madame Mignon’s handkerchief slipped from her lap to the floor; Butscha precipitated himself upon it, picked it up, and as he returned it whispered in Modeste’s ear, “Take care!”Modeste raised a pair of wondering eyes, whose puzzled glance filled the poor cripple with joy unspeakable.“She is not in love!” he whispered to himself, rubbing his hands till the skin was nearly peeled off.At this moment Exupere tore through the garden and the house, plunged into the salon like an avalanche, and said to Dumay in an audible whisper, “The young man is here!”Dumay sprang for his pistols and rushed out.

第一章 木屋: 从城区房子搬到木屋的几件家具中，就有两位米尼翁小姐的那架钢琴。莫黛斯特常常通过自己练习钢琴来消除烦恼，不用老师教。她是个天生的音乐家，通过弹钢琴来让她母亲高兴。她还有一副天生的好歌喉，很喜爱她母亲教给她的那些德国小曲。有了母亲的传授，再加上努力自学，莫黛斯特便能作一些温柔的抒情小曲了——虽然她不懂和声学，还谈不上严格意义上的作曲。对于她这样天生富有音乐才能的人来说，也不算什么奇事。旋律之于音乐，正如意象和情感之于诗歌，是一朵自然绽放的鲜花。于是，在有和声学之前，各个国家就有了自己的音乐旋律，植物学也是在有花草之后才诞生的。同样，莫黛斯特除了看过姐姐画水彩画之外，对画画这门艺术一无所知。但站在拉斐尔、提香、鲁本斯、牟利罗、伦勃朗、阿尔贝·丢勒以及霍尔拜因的画作跟前——也就是说，在世界各国美的典范面前——她会被那些画面所征服，并陶醉其中。近来，至少有一个月了，莫黛斯特总是用柔和的颤声哼唱着夜曲和优美的狂想曲，曲调中的诗情和深意已经引起了她母亲的注意。女儿突发的创作热情，还有对给诗歌谱曲的迷恋，让她十分惊讶。
Chapter I The Chalet: The piano of the demoiselles Mignon was among the few articles of furniture which had been moved from the town-house to the Chalet.Modeste often conjured away her troubles by practising, without a master.Born a musician, she played to enliven her mother.She sang by nature, and loved the German airs which her mother taught her.From these lessons and these attempts at self-instruction came a phenomenon not uncommon to natures with a musical vocation; Modeste composed, as far as a person ignorant of the laws of harmony can be said to compose, tender little lyric melodies.Melody is to music what imagery and sentiment are to poetry, a flower that blossoms spontaneously.Consequently, nations have had melodies before harmony,—botany comes later than the flower.In like manner, Modeste, who knew nothing of the painter’s art except what she had seen her sister do in the way of water-color, would have stood subdued and fascinated before the pictures of Raphael, Titian, Rubens, Murillo, Rembrandt, Albert Durer, Holbein,—in other words, before the great ideals of many lands.Lately, for at least a month, Modeste had warbled the songs of nightingales, musical rhapsodies whose poetry and meaning had roused the attention of her mother, already surprised by her sudden eagerness for composition and her fancy for putting airs into certain verses.
