第一章 木屋: 这些忠诚的密探，这些正直的霸尔多洛，这些比利牛斯猎犬，他们刺探不出、察觉不到、甚至猜测不出意中人是谁、私情在哪里，连一点儿证据都抓不到。然而，是否就在他们的鼻子底下，正上演着那出无时无处不在上演的喜剧《关不住的少女》呢？但无论如何，这绝不是囚犯与看守争斗的结果，也不是地牢的专制同一名受害者的自由争斗的结果。这只是《创世纪》开幕时人类上演的第一幕戏的无休止重演——《夏娃在天堂》。
Chapter I The Chalet: Was the comedy of the “Fille mal Gardee” being played here,—as it is everywhere and forever,—under the noses of these faithful spies, these honest Bartholos, these Pyrenean hounds, without their being able to ferret out, detect, nor even surmise the lover, the love-affair, or the smoke of the fire?At any rate it was certainly not the result of a struggle between the jailers and the prisoner, between the despotism of a dungeon and the liberty of a victim,—it was simply the never-ending repetition of the first scene played by man when the curtain of the Creation rose; it was Eve in Paradise.

第一章 木屋: 而现在，母亲和监视人，究竟哪一方是正确的呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: And now, which of the two, the mother or the watch-dog, had the right of it?

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特身边没有一个人能理解她那颗少女之心——因为她的心灵与我们已经描述过的她的面容是和谐一致的。这个姑娘已经将自己的存在移植到另外一个世界里去了。直至今天，这个世界还像十六世纪时克里斯托弗·哥伦布发现的新世界一样，被人们怀疑和否认。幸好她总是把想法藏在心里，不然人们会认为她疯了。但首先我们必须解释一下往事对她性格的影响。
Chapter I The Chalet: None of the persons who were about Modeste could understand that maiden heart—for the soul and the face we have described were in harmony.The girl had transported her existence into another world, as much denied and disbelieved in in these days of ours as the new world of Christopher Columbus in the sixteenth century.Happily, she kept her own counsel, or they would have thought her crazy.But first we must explain the influence of the past upon her nature.

第一章 木屋: 有两件大事磨炼了这位少女的心灵，开发了她的才智。贝蒂娜遭受的厄运警醒了米尼翁先生和米尼翁夫人，就在家族破产之前，他们决定把莫黛斯特嫁出去。他们选择了一位富有的银行家的儿子，这位银行家以前是汉堡人，但从一八一五年起就在勒阿弗尔定居了。此外，这个人还受过他们的恩惠。年轻人名叫弗朗索瓦·阿尔图，是勒阿弗尔的花花公子，生来带有讨中产阶级喜欢的低俗美。他身材匀称，肌肉丰满，而且气色很好。他在莫黛斯特父亲破产的当天，便抛弃了他的未婚妻，从此，无论是莫黛斯特和她的母亲，还是迪迈一家，都没有再见过他。拉图奈尔曾就此事冒昧地问过他的父亲雅各布·阿尔图一个问题，但他只是耸耸肩膀，回答道：“我真的不明白你是什么意思。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Two events had formed the soul and developed the mind of this young girl.Monsieur and Madame Mignon, warned by the fate that overtook Bettina, had resolved, just before the failure, to marry Modeste.They chose the son of a rich banker, formerly of Hamburg, but established in Havre since 1815,—a man, moreover, who was under obligations to them.The young man, whose name was Francois Althor, the dandy of Havre, blessed with a certain vulgar beauty in which the middle classes delight, well-made, well-fleshed, and with a fine complexion, abandoned his betrothed so hastily on the day of her father’s failure that neither Modeste nor her mother nor either of the Dumays had seen him since.Latournelle ventured a question on the subject to Jacob Althor, the father; but he only shrugged his shoulders and replied, “I really don’t know what you mean.”

第一章 木屋: 为了给莫黛斯特增加一些生活经验，这个答复被转告给了她。再加上拉图奈尔和迪迈对这种懦弱地抛弃行为长篇大论地批判了很多次，莫黛斯特更加深刻地吸取了这个教训。夏尔·米尼翁的两个女儿像所有娇生惯养的孩子一样，所有的愿望都能得到满足。她们骑马外出，有自己专门的马匹和马夫，而且在其他方面也享有大胆冒险的自由。眼见自己有了一个正式的恋人，莫黛斯特便任由弗朗西斯克吻她的手，搂着她的腰扶她上马。她接受了他送的鲜花，还有所有那些表达柔情的小玩意，这些小东西多得足以把我们这位小姐围起来。她对两人之间的关系深信不疑，甚至还为他做了一只钱包。的确，这种关系对于高贵的心灵来说是坚不可摧的，但对于哥本海姆、维尔坎还有阿尔图之辈，却脆弱得如同蜘蛛网。
Chapter I The Chalet: This answer, told to Modeste to give her some experience of life, was a lesson which she learned all the more readily because Latournelle and Dumay made many and long comments on the cowardly desertion.The daughters of Charles Mignon, like spoiled children, had all their wishes gratified; they rode on horseback, kept their own horses and grooms, and otherwise enjoyed a perilous liberty.Seeing herself in possession of an official lover, Modeste had allowed Francisque to kiss her hand, and take her by the waist to mount her.She accepted his flowers and all the little proofs of tenderness with which it is proper to surround the lady of our choice; she even worked him a purse, believing in such ties,—strong indeed to noble souls, but cobwebs for the Gobenheims, the Vilquins, and the Althors.

第一章 木屋: 米尼翁夫人和她的女儿搬到木屋后的第二年春天，弗朗西斯克·阿尔图曾到维尔坎家赴宴。越过草坪尽头的墙，他碰巧看到了莫黛斯特，竟然把头转了过去。一个半月后，他便同维尔坎家的大小姐完婚了。这样一来，年轻貌美且出身高贵的莫黛斯特便明白了，在恋爱的那整整三个月里，她对他而言只不过是一位“百万小姐”。她的贫穷已是众人皆知，这也同拉图奈尔一家人的小心谨慎，以及迪迈的警惕一样，成了完全阻止别人接近木屋的哨兵。有一段时间，米尼翁小姐的身份曾经是镇上人们的谈资，但他们只是为了侮辱她。
Chapter I The Chalet: Some time during the spring which followed the removal of Madame Mignon and her daughter to the Chalet, Francisque Althor came to dine with the Vilquins.Happening to see Modeste over the wall at the foot of the lawn, he turned away his head.Six weeks later he married the eldest Mademoiselle Vilquin.In this way Modeste, young, beautiful, and of high birth, learned the lesson that for three whole months of her engagement she had been nothing more than Mademoiselle Million.Her poverty, well known to all, became a sentinel defending the approaches to the Chalet fully as well as the prudence of the Latournelles or the vigilance of Dumay.The talk of the town ran for a time on Mademoiselle Mignon’s position only to insult her.

Chapter I The Chalet: “What a fate! to have had the world at her feet; to have had the chance to marry Francisque Althor,—and now, nobody willing to take her!”

第一章 木屋: 而且，这些侮辱性的话不是背地里说的，也不是莫黛斯特想象出来的。她不止一次听前往安古维尔的勒阿弗尔的年轻男女们说过这些话，他们明明知道米尼翁夫人和她的女儿住在木屋里，在经过房子的时候却还是谈论着她们。这对母女竟然还愿意继续在她们曾显赫一时的地方生活，维尔坎的朋友们表示很诧异。透过关着的百叶窗后面那扇敞开的窗户，莫黛斯特有时能听到这样的侮辱之词：

Chapter I The Chalet: “What do you suppose they live on? they haven’t any means of earning money.”

Chapter I The Chalet: “I am told the old woman has gone blind.”

第一章 木屋: “米尼翁小姐还是那么漂亮吗？哎呀，她过去多么神气啊！咳，她现在可没马骑了。”

第一章 木屋: 这些充满恶意的胡言乱语纯粹是出于忌妒，要对过去进行报复。大多数年轻女孩听到这些话，火气都会窜到头顶，还有的会哭起来，更有甚者会气得抽筋。但莫黛斯特却一笑置之，就像我们在剧院看演员表演时那样微笑。她不会降低自己的尊严，去计较这些言论。
Chapter I The Chalet: Most young girls on hearing these spiteful and silly speeches, born of an envy that now rushed, peevish and drivelling, to avenge the past, would have felt the blood mount to their foreheads; others would have wept; some would have undergone spasms of anger; but Modeste smiled, as we smile at the theatre while watching the actors.Her pride could not descend so low as the level of such speeches.

第一章 木屋: 另一件事比这些唯利是图的卑鄙言行更为严重。贝蒂娜·卡罗琳是在她妹妹的怀里死去的。在此之前，莫黛斯特始终怀着少女的忠诚，以及纯洁无暇的好奇心照顾着姐姐。在那些寂静的长夜里，姐妹俩曾互诉过许多心里话。在天真无邪的莫黛斯特眼中，可怜的贝蒂娜的命运是多么戏剧化呢？贝蒂娜只是通过悲伤才了解了爱，而她也是因爱而死的。在少女们心里，就算那个男人是个恶棍，他也仍是自己的恋人。激情是世间万物中绝对真实的东西，而且它从来都是至高无上的。尽管夏尔·德埃斯图尼是个赌徒、罪犯、浪荡子，但在这对姐妹的记忆里，他仍是勒阿弗尔游乐会上风度翩翩的巴黎公子，是女人们爱慕的对象。贝蒂娜相信她从卖弄风情的维尔坎夫人那里夺来了夏尔·德埃斯图尼，而对于莫黛斯特，他是她姐姐的幸福恋人。这种少女的爱慕要比所有的社会谴责都强烈。贝蒂娜觉得是法院弄错了，不然怎么会给一个爱了她六个月的男人判刑呢？他把她带到隐居处，在那里狂热地爱着她——我们可以补充说，他本可以自行其事的。于是，这位即将离世的姑娘给她的妹妹打了一剂爱情预防针。她们一起谈论着伟大的戏剧，这些戏剧又因她们的想象变得更加伟大。贝蒂娜将她妹妹的天真无邪带进了坟墓，给妹妹留下了知识，至少是获得知识的渴望。
Chapter I The Chalet: The other event was more serious than these mercenary meannesses.Bettina Caroline died in the arms of her younger sister, who had nursed her with the devotion of girlhood, and the curiosity of an untainted imagination.In the silence of long nights the sisters exchanged many a confidence.With what dramatic interest was poor Bettina invested in the eyes of the innocent Modeste?Bettina knew love through sorrow only, and she was dying of it.Among young girls every man, scoundrel though he be, is still a lover.Passion is the one thing absolutely real in the things of life, and it insists on its supremacy.Charles d’Estourny, gambler, criminal, and debauchee, remained in the memory of the sisters, the elegant Parisian of the fetes of Havre, the admired of the womenkind.Bettina believed she had carried him off from the coquettish Madame Vilquin, and to Modeste he was her sister’s happy lover.Such adoration in young girls is stronger than all social condemnations.To Bettina’s thinking, justice had been deceived; if not, how could it have sentenced a man who had loved her for six months?—loved her to distraction in the hidden retreat to which he had taken her,—that he might, we may add, be at liberty to go his own way.Thus the dying girl inoculated her sister with love.Together they talked of the great drama which imagination enhances; and Bettina carried with her to the grave her sister’s ignorance, leaving her, if not informed, at least thirsting for information.

第一章 木屋: 然而，悔恨已经将毒牙深深刺入了贝蒂娜的心脏，使得她不得不对妹妹加以告诫。在她的忏悔中，她劝诫莫黛斯特要恪守本分，绝对服从。去世的那天晚上，她恳求妹妹记住这浸湿了枕头的泪水，不要重蹈覆辙，因为如果那样的话，就算受苦也无法获得救赎。贝蒂娜责怪自己给家庭带来了灾祸，并且因为无法得到父亲的原谅，在绝望中死去了。尽管她的悔恨感动了牧师，给了她无尽的安慰，她还是用尽最后一口气撕心裂肺地喊道：“噢，父亲！父亲！”“婚事未成之前，千万不要以心相许，”她在临死前一个小时对莫黛斯特说道，“最重要的是，在没有告诉爸爸妈妈所有情况之前，不要接受任何男子的好意。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Nevertheless, remorse had set its fangs too sharply in Bettina’s heart not to force her to warn her sister.In the midst of her own confessions she had preached duty and implicit obedience to Modeste.On the evening of her death she implored her to remember the tears that soaked her pillow, and not to imitate a conduct which even suffering could not expiate.Bettina accused herself of bringing a curse upon the family, and died in despair at being unable to obtain her father’s pardon.Notwithstanding the consolations which the ministers of religion, touched by her repentance, freely gave her, she cried in heartrending tones with her latest breath: “Oh father! father!”“Never give your heart without your hand,” she said to Modeste an hour before she died; “and above all, accept no attentions from any man without telling everything to papa and mamma.”

Chapter I The Chalet: Nevertheless, this drama of a poor seduced sister returning to die under a roof of elegant poverty, the failure of her father, the baseness of her betrothed, the blindness of her mother caused by grief, had touched the surface only of Modeste’s life, by which alone the Dumays and the Latournelles judged her; for no devotion of friends can take the place of a mother’s eye.The monotonous life in the dainty little Chalet, surrounded by the choice flowers which Dumay cultivated; the family customs, as regular as clock-work, the provincial decorum, the games at whist while the mother knitted and the daughter sewed, the silence, broken only by the roar of the sea in the equinoctial storms,—all this monastic tranquillity did in fact hide an inner and tumultuous life, the life of ideas, the life of the spiritual being.We sometimes wonder how it is possible for young girls to do wrong; but such as do so have no blind mother to send her plummet line of intuition to the depths of the subterranean fancies of a virgin heart.The Dumays slept when Modeste opened her window, as it were to watch for the passing of a man,—the man of her dreams, the expected knight who was to mount her behind him and ride away under the fire of Dumay’s pistols.

第一章 木屋: 姐姐的去世让她情绪十分低落，那段时间里，莫黛斯特埋头读书、心无旁骛。出生在一个双语家庭里，她的德语阅读和表达能力同法语一样好，她还同姐姐一起跟迪迈夫人学习了英语。她周围的人没有什么文化知识，也就很少在读书方面监督她。莫黛斯特便把英语、法语和德语的现代文学名著当作她的精神食粮。拜伦爵士、歌德、席勒、瓦尔特·司各特、雨果、拉马丁、克雷布、穆尔，十七、十八世纪的伟大作品，从历史、戏剧到小说，从阿斯脱利亚女神到曼侬·莱斯戈，从蒙田的《随笔集》到狄德罗，从法国中世纪的世俗故事到《新埃洛伊兹》——总之，三个国家的思想以混杂的意象充塞着少女的头脑。她的单纯、冷静，她天生的贞洁，都散发着高贵的气息，而通过阅读这些作品，她的头脑中又迸发出一种对天才的绝对崇拜，这种崇拜之情牢不可破、光芒四射、真挚而又强烈。对莫黛斯特而言，一本新书就是一个重大事件，一部让拉图奈尔夫人感到震惊的大作会使她高兴不已——同样，如果一部伟大的作品没能拨动她的心弦，那她就会不高兴。一种抒情的天性在她那颗充满青春美丽幻想的少女之心里汹涌着。但这燃烧的激情没有在日常生活的表象发出一丝光亮，它逃过了迪迈、他的妻子以及拉图奈尔一家人的眼睛，只有失明的母亲的耳朵听到了激情之火燃烧的劈啪声。
Chapter I The Chalet: During the depression caused by her sister’s death Modeste flung herself into the practice of reading, until her mind became sodden in it.Born to the use of two languages, she could speak and read German quite as well as French; she had also, together with her sister, learned English from Madame Dumay.Being very little overlooked in the matter of reading by the people about her, who had no literary knowledge, Modeste fed her soul on the modern masterpieces of three literatures, English, French, and German.Lord Byron, Goethe, Schiller, Walter Scott, Hugo, Lamartine, Crabbe, Moore, the great works of the 17th and 18th centuries, history, drama, and fiction, from Astraea to Manon Lescaut, from Montaigne’s Essays to Diderot, from the Fabliaux to the Nouvelle Heloise,—in short, the thought of three lands crowded with confused images that girlish head, august in its cold guilelessness, its native chastity, but from which there sprang full-armed, brilliant, sincere, and strong, an overwhelming admiration for genius.To Modeste a new book was an event; a masterpiece that would have horrified Madame Latournelle made her happy,—equally unhappy if the great work did not play havoc with her heart.A lyric instinct bubbled in that girlish soul, so full of the beautiful illusions of its youth.But of this radiant existence not a gleam reached the surface of daily life; it escaped the ken of Dumay and his wife and the Latournelles; the ears of the blind mother alone caught the crackling of its flame.

第一章 木屋: 此时，莫黛斯特对一切寻常男子的深度鄙视，给她的脸上烙上了一种傲慢的神情，一种难以形容的、桀骜不驯的羞怯，这调和了她那日耳曼式的单纯，与她独特的思想十分契合。思考在她眉宇间犁出了一条浅浅的垄沟，而她额头上有一处头发看上去就像是这垄沟的延续，这就使得她那桀骜不驯的表情更加明显。她父亲很喜欢她的机灵，习惯称她为自己的“所罗门小寓言家”。这个可爱的孩子通过练习三种语言，嗓音变得非常圆润婉转。除此之外，她说话的音调也是甜美清新，如清脆的铃声般悦耳动听。如果说，这位母亲再也不能从她女儿的眉宇间看到贵族命运的标志，她还是能够从充满爱意之音的声调中观察出她心灵的发展变化。
Chapter I The Chalet: The profound disdain which Modeste now conceived for ordinary men gave to her face a look of pride, an inexpressible untamed shyness, which tempered her Teutonic simplicity, and accorded well with a peculiarity of her head.The hair growing in a point above the forehead seemed the continuation of a slight line which thought had already furrowed between the eyebrows, and made the expression of untameability perhaps a shade too strong.The voice of this charming child, whom her father, delighting in her wit, was wont to call his “little proverb of Solomon,” had acquired a precious flexibility of organ through the practice of three languages.This advantage was still further enhanced by a natural bell-like tone both sweet and fresh, which touched the heart as delightfully as it did the ear.If the mother could no longer see the signs of a noble destiny upon her daughter’s brow, she could study the transitions of her soul’s development in the accents of that voice attuned to love.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特奋发读书一段时间之后，她那丰富的想象力又激发出一种神奇的能力，就是使自己成为梦境中的演员，在脑海中想象自己渴望的那些东西。那些想象已经生动到了近乎真实的地步。简言之，就是通过幻想来获得快乐——将她的年华在脑海中上演，结婚、变老、像查理五世那样参加自己的葬礼，在自己的内心上演生活的喜剧，如果需要的话，也上演死亡。莫黛斯特的确在表演，只不过是孤身一人，表演着这爱情喜剧。她想象自己在社会生活的许多阶段，如愿以偿地被人爱慕。有时候，作为一个黑色传奇故事的女主角，她爱上了一个侩子手，或是一个在绞刑台上结束性命的可怜虫，或者，像她姐姐那样，爱上一个在阁楼里辛苦度日、身无分文的巴黎小伙子。有时候，她把自己想象成尼农，流连于各种游乐会，对男人们嗤之以鼻。有时，她又会把自己想象成某个博得满堂彩的女演员，或者是无忧无虑的女冒险家。她乐此不疲地亲身体验吉尔·布拉斯的幸运，或是帕斯塔、马利布朗以及弗洛丽纳的伟大成就。后来，当她厌倦了那些恐惧和兴奋之后，便又回到了现实生活当中。她想象自己跟一个公证人结了婚，每天吃着靠正当收入挣来的淡然无味的黑面包。她想象自己成了拉图奈尔夫人那样的人，接受了一种艰苦的生活，忍受着所有发财致富所必经的考验。然后，她又回到浪漫之中去，一个法国贵族的儿子，一个性格古怪、富有艺术气息的年轻人因为她的美貌而爱上了她。这位年轻人猜透了她的心思，认出了像斯塔尔夫人般的天才在她眉宇间点上的福星。后来，她的父亲回来了，腰缠万贯。经过父亲的允许，她让她的不同追求者经受某些考验（她总是小心地保持着自己的独立性）。她拥有一座华丽的庄园，还有城堡、仆人、马匹、马车，凡是奢华生活中最上等的东西，都应有尽有。而且她还要让她的追求者一直捉摸不透，直到四十岁的时候才作出决定。
Chapter I The Chalet: To this period of Modeste’s eager rage for reading succeeded the exercise of a strange faculty given to vigorous imaginations,—the power, namely, of making herself an actor in a dream-existence; of representing to her own mind the things desired, with so vivid a conception that they seemed actually to attain reality; in short, to enjoy by thought,—to live out her years within her mind; to marry; to grow old; to attend her own funeral like Charles V.; to play within herself the comedy of life and, if need be, that of death.Modeste was indeed playing, but all alone, the comedy of Love.She fancied herself adored to the summit of her wishes in many an imagined phase of social life.Sometimes as the heroine of a dark romance, she loved the executioner, or the wretch who ended her days upon the scaffold, or, like her sister, some Parisian youth without a penny, whose struggles were all beneath a garret-roof.Sometimes she was Ninon, scorning men amid continual fetes; or some applauded actress, or gay adventuress, exhausting in her own behalf the luck of Gil Blas, or the triumphs of Pasta, Malibran, and Florine.Then, weary of the horrors and excitements, she returned to actual life.She married a notary, she ate the plain brown bread of honest everyday life, she saw herself a Madame Latournelle; she accepted a painful existence, she bore all the trials of a struggle with fortune.After that she went back to the romances: she was loved for her beauty; a son of a peer of France, an eccentric, artistic young man, divined her heart, recognized the star which the genius of a De Stael had planted on her brow.Her father returned, possessing millions.With his permission, she put her various lovers to certain tests (always carefully guarding her own independence); she owned a magnificent estate and castle, servants, horses, carriages, the choicest of everything that luxury could bestow, and kept her suitors uncertain until she was forty years old, at which age she made her choice.

第一章 木屋: 这独一无二的《一千零一夜》般的故事差不多持续了一年，教会了莫黛斯特从幻想中得到满足。她将自己的生活排演了太多次，太多次，她像个严肃的哲人般，满怀辛酸地问自己：“唉，生活到底是什么呢？”。所有的天才在通过大量从事他们所致力于的工作来结束那工作时，都会有这样的感觉。要不是莫黛斯特青春年少，又生性高贵，这时恐怕早已想着进修道院了。但这种满足感，让深谙天主教精神的她一头扑进了上帝的怀抱，扎进了广大无边的爱的天堂。她设想将慈善事业、为人服务作为她生活的真正事业。可她又像花萼底部的一条虫子，在忧郁沮丧中蜷缩成一团，无法为隐藏在内心的幻想找到食粮。此时，她静静地坐在那里，为穷人家的孩子缝制衣服，心不在焉地听着拉图奈尔先生喃喃地抱怨迪迈抓到了“第十三张牌”，或者抽走了他最后的王牌。
Chapter I The Chalet: This edition of the Arabian Nights in a single copy lasted nearly a year, and taught Modeste the sense of satiety through thought.She held her life too often in her hand, she said to herself philosophically and with too real a bitterness, too seriously, and too often, “Well, what is it, after all?” not to have plunged to her waist in the deep disgust which all men of genius feel when they try to complete by intense toil the work to which they have devoted themselves.Her youth and her rich nature alone kept Modeste at this period of her life from seeking to enter a cloister.But this sense of satiety cast her, saturated as she still was with Catholic spirituality, into the love of Good, the infinite of heaven.She conceived of charity, service to others, as the true occupation of life; but she cowered in the gloomy dreariness of finding in it no food for the fancy that lay crouching in her heart like an insect at the bottom of a calyx.Meanwhile she sat tranquilly sewing garments for the children of the poor, and listening abstractedly to the grumblings of Monsieur Latournelle when Dumay held the thirteenth card or drew out his last trump.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特的宗教信仰曾一度带给她一种与众不同的思考方式。她想象自己如果是无罪的（从教规上来讲），便能达到一种神圣的境界，上帝便会倾听她的心声，实现她的愿望。“信仰可以移山，”她想，“耶稣是这样说过的。救世主将他的信徒带到了太巴列湖上，而我，只请求主赐予我一个爱我的丈夫，那要比在海上行走容易得多。”她在下一个四旬斋节期间严守斋戒，没犯任何过错。于是她对自己说道，有一天当她走出教堂的时候，她会碰到一位与她般配的帅小伙，她的母亲会接受他，而他会疯狂地爱上她。就在她期望主给她派来一位天使的那天，她却被一个恶心的乞丐穷追不舍，而且那天还大雨滂沱，街上一个年轻男子都没有。还有一次，她到码头去散步，看到一群英国游客上岸来。但每个英国男人都带着一个英国女人，几乎跟莫黛斯特一样漂亮，她根本找不到任何一个恰尔德·哈罗德那样的浪子。她像马略那样坐在自己幻想的废墟上，泪流满面。但是，当她第三次召唤上帝的那一天，她深信自己的梦中情人就在教堂里，或许他是由于矜持，藏在某根柱子的后面。于是她拽着拉图奈尔夫人，绕着每根柱子都查了一遍。这次失败之后，她便不再相信神的无限威力了。她常常跟那位想象中的情人对话，为他编造出问题和答案，赋予他许多才能和智慧。
Chapter I The Chalet: Her religious faith drove Modeste for a time into a singular track of thought.She imagined that if she became sinless (speaking ecclesiastically) she would attain to such a condition of sanctity that God would hear her and accomplish her desires.“Faith,” she thought, “can move mountains; Christ has said so.The Saviour led his apostle upon the waters of the lake Tiberias; and I, all I ask of God is a husband to love me; that is easier than walking upon the sea.”She fasted through the next Lent, and did not commit a single sin; then she said to herself that on a certain day coming out of church she should meet a handsome young man who was worthy of her, whom her mother would accept, and who would fall madly in love with her.When the day came on which she had, as it were, summoned God to send her an angel, she was persistently followed by a rather disgusting beggar; moreover, it rained heavily, and not a single young man was in the streets.On another occasion she went to walk on the jetty to see the English travellers land; but each Englishman had an Englishwoman, nearly as handsome as Modeste herself, who saw no one at all resembling a wandering Childe Harold.Tears overcame her, as she sat down like Marius on the ruins of her imagination.But on the day when she subpoenaed God for the third time she firmly believed that the Elect of her dreams was within the church, hiding, perhaps out of delicacy, behind one of the pillars, round all of which she dragged Madame Latournelle on a tour of inspection.After this failure, she deposed the Deity from omnipotence.Many were her conversations with the imaginary lover, for whom she invented questions and answers, bestowing upon him a great deal of wit and intelligence.

第一章 木屋: 这些浪漫故事的背后，藏着她那颗志向远大的心。正因为如此，她才规规矩矩的，让那些监视她的善良人赞叹不已。他们大可以介绍一些阿尔图家族或维尔坎家族的年轻小伙给她认识，而她绝不会屈尊于这些小丑。一言以蔽之，她就是想要一个天才的男人——一般的才华她是看不上的，就像对一个想要嫁给大使的女孩来说，一个律师就算不上什么了。她对财富的唯一欲望，就是把它扔到自己偶像的脚下。的确，这些可见事物的金色背景，远不如她那细腻的女性内心所蕴藏的珍宝那样丰富，因为那颗心的主要愿望是要让一位像塔索、弥尔顿、让-雅克·卢梭、缪拉、或克里斯托弗·哥伦布那样的天才快乐。
Chapter I The Chalet: The high ambitions of her heart hidden within these romances were the real explanation of the prudent conduct which the good people who watched over Modeste so much admired; they might have brought her any number of young Althors or Vilquins, and she would never have stooped to such clowns.She wanted, purely and simply, a man of genius,—talent she cared little for; just as a lawyer is of no account to a girl who aims for an ambassador.Her only desire for wealth was to cast it at the feet of her idol.Indeed, the golden background of these visions was far less rich than the treasury of her own heart, filled with womanly delicacy; for its dominant desire was to make some Tasso, some Milton, a Jean–Jacques Rousseau, a Murat, a Christopher Columbus happy.

第一章 木屋: 平常的不幸是无法深深打动这颗年轻的心灵的，她期待着扑灭那些生前被人们忽视和否定的殉难者身上的烈火。有时候，她想象着用麦加香膏和柔和的曲调，或许能安抚卢梭愤世嫉俗的心灵。或者，她会把自己想象成拜伦爵士的妻子，凭直觉猜到他对现实的鄙视。她让自己像曼弗雷德的诗一样出色，并通过让他成为一名天主教徒来对付他的怀疑论。莫黛斯特还把莫里哀的忧郁归咎于十七世纪的女人。“每个才华横溢的男人身旁，”她问自己，“为什么就没有一个多情、美丽、富有的女子，心甘情愿地做他的奴隶，就像神秘的侍从莱拉那样？”读者们可以看到，她已完全理解了这位英国诗人（即拜伦）通过他的古勒奈尔之口所吟颂的“il pianto”（意大利语：眼泪）。莫黛斯特十分欣赏那位主动向小克雷比永求爱、并嫁给他的英国少女的行为。斯特恩和伊莱扎·德雷珀的故事曾在几个月里成为她的生活和快乐。她将自己想象成一个类似的爱情故事中的女主角，多次在脑海中扮演着伊莱扎这一伟大角色。那封令人欣喜的信中所表现出的敏感多情是如此迷人，令她热泪盈眶。据说，那些最机智的英国作家是不会为此流泪的。
Chapter I The Chalet: Commonplace miseries did not seriously touch this youthful soul, who longed to extinguish the fires of the martyrs ignored and rejected in their own day.Sometimes she imagined balms of Gilead, soothing melodies which might have allayed the savage misanthropy of Rousseau.Or she fancied herself the wife of Lord Byron; guessing intuitively his contempt for the real, she made herself as fantastic as the poetry of Manfred, and provided for his scepticism by making him a Catholic.Modeste attributed Moliere’s melancholy to the women of the seventeenth century.“Why is there not some one woman,” she asked herself, “loving, beautiful, and rich, ready to stand beside each man of genius and be his slave, like Lara, the mysterious page?”She had, as the reader perceives, fully understood “il pianto,” which the English poet chanted by the mouth of his Gulmare.Modeste greatly admired the behavior of the young Englishwoman who offered herself to Crebillon, the son, who married her.The story of Sterne and Eliza Draper was her life and her happiness for several months.She made herself ideally the heroine of a like romance, and many a time she rehearsed in imagination the sublime role of Eliza.The sensibility so charmingly expressed in that delightful correspondence filled her eyes with tears which, it is said, were lacking in those of the wittiest of English writers.

第一章 木屋: 有一段时间，莫黛斯特不仅用心揣摩文学作品，还用心揣摩她喜爱的作家的性格——哥尔德斯密斯，也就是《奥伯曼》的作者，还有夏尔·诺迪埃和马图林。这成了她生活的全部。其中那些最可怜、受苦最深的作家就如同她的神灵，她猜测着他们经受的磨难，想象自己投身到那种孕育着天才思想的贫穷中去，并把自己心爱的宝物倾囊拿出。这些为自身才华殉道的伟大男人们，她想象着能给他们物质上的安慰。这种高贵的怜悯，这种对辛苦工作者拼搏的直觉感知，这种对天才的崇拜，是萦绕于女人心灵中最高尚的想法。首先，它们是这个女人同上帝之间的秘密，因为它们是隐藏着的，它们本身没有任何引人注目之处，也不能满足任何虚荣——而虚荣正是法国人一切行为的巨大动力。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste existed for some time on a comprehension, not only of the works, but of the characters of her favorite authors,—Goldsmith, the author of Obermann, Charles Nodier, Maturin.The poorest and the most suffering among them were her deities; she guessed their trials, initiated herself into a destitution where the thoughts of genius brooded, and poured upon it the treasures of her heart; she fancied herself the giver of material comfort to these great men, martyrs to their own faculty.This noble compassion, this intuition of the struggles of toilers, this worship of genius, are among the choicest perceptions that flutter through the souls of women.They are, in the first place, a secret between the woman and God, for they are hidden; in them there is nothing striking, nothing that gratifies the vanity,—that powerful auxiliary to all action among the French.

第一章 木屋: 在她思想发展的第三个阶段，莫黛斯特有了一种强烈的欲望，她想要进入这些非凡之人中的一位的内心，去了解他的思想运作和天才的隐痛，不仅要弄明白他需要什么，还要弄明白他是什么。就在我们开始讲这个故事的时候，莫黛斯特的所有奇思妙想，她心灵的虚空之旅，对未知未来的探索，对生活的高贵态度，宁可在高雅环境中受苦、也不愿像她母亲那样在乡野生活的泥沼中挣扎的决心，还有她永不言败的誓言，捍卫父亲的家族荣誉、给全家带来欢乐——她内心世界的全部情感终于到达了顶点，找到了依托。莫黛斯特希望与这样一位男子为伴：他得是一位诗人，一位艺术家，在某个方面要超出常人。但她想自己选择这个人，并下定决心，只有在她细心考察、深入了解他之后，才能将自己的心、自己的生命、自己从情感束缚中迸发出来的无限柔情交给他。
Chapter I The Chalet: Out of this third period of the development of her ideas, there came to Modeste a passionate desire to penetrate to the heart of one of these abnormal beings; to understand the working of the thoughts and the hidden griefs of genius,—to know not only what it wanted but what it was.At the period when this story begins, these vagaries of fancy, these excursions of her soul into the void, these feelers put forth into the darkness of the future, the impatience of an ungiven love to find its goal, the nobility of all her thoughts of life, the decision of her mind to suffer in a sphere of higher things rather than flounder in the marshes of provincial life like her mother, the pledge she had made to herself never to fail in conduct, but to respect her father’s hearth and bring it happiness,—all this world of feeling and sentiment had lately come to a climax and taken shape.Modeste wished to be the friend and companion of a poet, an artist, a man in some way superior to the crowd of men.But she intended to choose him,—not to give him her heart, her life, her infinite tenderness freed from the trammels of passion, until she had carefully and deeply studied him.

第一章 木屋: 这美妙的浪漫故事，她从一开始便乐在其中。她的心灵被深深的静谧笼罩了。她的脸颊呈现出柔和的粉嫩，她变成了一位美丽而高贵的德国女人，就像诸位近来看到的那样。她是木屋的荣耀，是拉图奈尔夫人和迪迈一家的骄傲。莫黛斯特正过着一种双重生活。她谦卑恭顺、一心一意地打理着木屋里的一切生活琐事，以它们为缰绳，来引导她那充满诗意的理想生活。就像加尔都西会的隐修修士，他们有条不紊地为物质生活而辛勤劳动，从而让心灵在祈祷中自由驰骋。所有伟大的思想者，都会将自己束缚于某种机械的艰苦劳动，以更好地驾驭思想。斯宾诺莎曾磨过玻璃镜片，贝尔曾数过房顶上的瓦片，孟德斯鸠曾从事园艺。这样，身体被束缚住了，心灵就能安全地展翅翱翔了。
Chapter I The Chalet: She began this pretty romance by simply enjoying it.Profound tranquillity settled down upon her soul.Her cheeks took on a soft color; and she became the beautiful and noble image of Germany, such as we have lately seen her, the glory of the Chalet, the pride of Madame Latournelle and the Dumays.Modeste was living a double existence.She performed with humble, loving care all the minute duties of the homely life at the Chalet, using them as a rein to guide the poetry of her ideal life, like the Carthusian monks who labor methodically on material things to leave their souls the freer to develop in prayer.All great minds have bound themselves to some form of mechanical toil to obtain greater mastery of thought.Spinosa ground glasses for spectacles; Bayle counted the tiles on the roof; Montesquieu gardened.The body being thus subdued, the soul could spread its wings in all security.

第一章 木屋: 因此，米尼翁夫人是正确的，她读懂了女儿的心思。莫黛斯特恋爱了，她的爱是那种罕见的、很少被人理解的柏拉图式的爱情，这是一位少女最初的幻想，是所有情感中最为微妙的，是她内心的珍宝。她用未知的、模糊的、梦幻的圣杯开怀畅饮。她赞美那远在少女天堂里歌唱的青鸟的羽毛，那鸟儿可望而不可即，它掠过人们的视野，却没有枪能够打到。她喜爱那些魔幻般的色彩，那色彩仿佛闪闪发光的宝石，令人眼花缭乱，年轻人可以看到这一切，而当现实——那可怕的女巫，在市长和证人的陪同下出现时，他们就再也看不到了。生活在充满诗意的爱恋中，而又不见其情人——啊，多么甜美的陶醉！这是怎样的充满幻想的狂喜！一个关于飞翔的男子和展开的翅膀的幻想！
Chapter I The Chalet: Madame Mignon, reading her daughter’s soul, was therefore right.Modeste loved; she loved with that rare platonic love, so little understood, the first illusion of a young girl, the most delicate of all sentiments, a very dainty of the heart.She drank deep draughts from the chalice of the unknown, the vague, the visionary.She admired the blue plumage of the bird that sings afar in the paradise of young girls, which no hand can touch, no gun can cover, as it flits across the sight; she loved those magic colors, like sparkling jewels dazzling to the eye, which youth can see, and never sees again when Reality, the hideous hag, appears with witnesses accompanied by the mayor.To live the very poetry of love and not to see the lover—ah, what sweet intoxication! what visionary rapture! a chimera with flowing man and outspread wings!

第一章 木屋: 下面就是一件幼稚甚至是愚蠢的事情，它将决定这位年轻姑娘的未来生活。
Chapter I The Chalet: The following is the puerile and even silly event which decided the future life of this young girl.

第一章 木屋: 在一家书店的陈列窗前，莫黛斯特碰巧看到了一幅她喜爱的卡那利的石印肖像。大家都知道这些画像多么不真实——它们是利用那些名人个性来做卑劣的投机生意的产物，仿佛那些名人的面孔是公共财产。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste happened to see in a bookseller’s window a lithographic portrait of one of her favorites, Canalis.We all know what lies such pictures tell,—being as they are the result of a shameless speculation, which seizes upon the personality of celebrated individuals as if their faces were public property.

第一章 木屋: 在这幅素描画里，卡那利摆出一副拜伦式的姿态，让公众欣赏他那风中飘扬的黑发、裸露的脖颈，还有那每位吟游诗人都应有的深不可测的额头。维克多·雨果的额头让多少效仿者剃光了头，其数量比为拿破仑的荣誉战死沙场的早期元帅还要多。这幅卡那利画像（出于商业需要而显得富有诗意）吸引了莫黛斯特的目光。就在这一天，她注意到阿尔泰兹的一本最好的书也碰巧出版了。尽管这样说可能有损莫黛斯特的形象，我们还是不得不承认她在这位著名诗人和这位著名散文家之间犹豫了很久。这两位名人谁还是单身呢？——这正是问题所在。
Chapter I The Chalet: In this instance Canalis, sketched in a Byronic pose, was offering to public admiration his dark locks floating in the breeze, a bare throat, and the unfathomable brow which every bard ought to possess.Victor Hugo’s forehead will make more persons shave their heads than the number of incipient marshals ever killed by the glory of Napoleon.This portrait of Canalis (poetic through mercantile necessity) caught Modeste’s eye.The day on which it caught her eye one of Arthez’s best books happened to be published.We are compelled to admit, though it may be to Modeste’s injury, that she hesitated long between the illustrious poet and the illustrious prose-writer.Which of these celebrated men was free?—that was the question.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特开始同弗朗索瓦丝·科歇进行合作。她是可怜的贝蒂娜从勒阿弗尔带走、又带回来的一个仆人，现在，她受雇于米尼翁夫人和迪迈夫人，按天领工钱，就住在勒阿弗尔。莫黛斯特把她带到自己的房间里，向她保证自己永远都不会给父母带来任何伤痛，永远都不会越过一位少女行为规范的底线，而弗朗索瓦丝本人也将在米尼翁先生回来后过上优越的生活——条件是弗朗索瓦丝要为她做一件事，并严格保守秘密。到底是什么事呢？嗨，是一件小事——绝对无害于他人的小事。莫黛斯特要她的同伙做的事情，就是把一些信件投到勒阿弗尔的邮筒里，然后再拿回一些寄到弗朗索瓦丝·科歇名下的信件。协议达成了，莫黛斯特便给卡那利诗歌的出版商多里亚写了一封客气而简短的信，她抱着对那位伟大诗人的兴趣，向他询问了一些有关卡那利的细节，其中就包括他是否已经结婚。她请求出版商将答案以“留局待取”的形式寄给勒阿弗尔的弗朗索瓦丝小姐。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste began by securing the co-operation of Francoise Cochet, a maid taken from Havre and brought back again by poor Bettina, whom Madame Mignon and Madame Dumay now employed by the day, and who lived in Havre.Modeste took her to her own room and assured her that she would never cause her parents any grief, never pass the bounds of a young girl’s propriety, and that as to Francoise herself she would be well provided for after the return of Monsieur Mignon, on condition that she would do a certain service and keep it an inviolable secret.What was it?Why, a nothing—perfectly innocent.All that Modeste wanted of her accomplice was to put certain letters into the post at Havre and to bring some back which would be directed to herself, Francoise Cochet.The treaty concluded, Modeste wrote a polite note to Dauriat, publisher of the poems of Canalis, asking, in the interest of that great poet, for some particulars about him, among others if he were married.She requested the publisher to address his answer to Mademoiselle Francoise, “poste restante,” Havre.

第一章 木屋: 多里亚哪里会认真对待这封信，他和当时碰巧在办公室的四五个记者一起写了封回信，每个人都加上了一句自己的俏皮话。
Chapter I The Chalet: Dauriat, incapable of taking the epistle seriously, wrote a reply in presence of four or five journalists who happened to be in his office at the time, each of whom added his particular stroke of wit to the production.

第一章 木屋: 小姐：康斯坦·西尔·梅尔基奥尔·德卡那利男爵，法兰西学院成员，一八零零年出生于科雷兹的卡那利，身高五尺四寸、声望良好、接种过牛痘、出身清白、服过兵役、身体十分健康，在科雷兹有一小块祖传的地产，想结婚，但女方必须富有。
Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle,—Canalis (Baron of), Constant Cys Melchior, member of the French Academy, born in 1800, at Canalis (Correze), five feet four inches in height, of good standing, vaccinated, spotless birth, has given a substitute to the conscription, enjoys perfect health, owns a small patrimonial estate in the Correze, and wishes to marry, but the lady must be rich.

第一章 木屋: 他的盾形族徽由一条直线一分为二，一边为直纹红色，上有一把金色战斧，一边为黑色，上有三个银色贝壳，顶部是男爵花环，底部是两株绿色的落叶松。他家族的铭言是“金和铁”（不过和俄斐或其他黄金产地没什么关联）。
Chapter I The Chalet: He beareth per pale, gules an axe or, sable three escallops argent, surmounted by a baron’s coronet; supporters, two larches, vert.Motto: “Or et fer” (no allusion to Ophir or auriferous).

第一章 木屋: 第一位卡那利族人跟随第一批十字军去了圣地，这在奥弗涅编年史中有记载，由于家境贫穷，当时他身上只有一把斧头。而时至今日，贫穷的命运仍重重地压在这个家族身上。这位贵族男爵因打败了大量的异教徒而出名，最后，在当时还没有救护车的情况下，死于耶路撒冷附近的阿什凯隆平原。他死时身上没有金也没有铁，就像一只蠕虫那样一文不名。
Chapter I The Chalet: The original Canalis, who went to the Holy Land with the First Crusade, is cited in the chronicles of Auvergne as being armed with an axe on account of the family indigence, which to this day weighs heavily on the race.This noble baron, famous for discomfiting a vast number of infidels, died, without “or” or “fer,” as naked as a worm, near Jerusalem, on the plains of Ascalon, ambulances not being then invented.

第一章 木屋: 卡那利古堡（周围的地区生长着一些栗树）由两座废塔组成，一段长满了常春藤的围墙将这两座塔连接了起来。古堡每年要交二十二法郎的税款。
Chapter I The Chalet: The chateau of Canalis (the domain yields a few chestnuts) consists of two dismantled towers, united by a piece of wall covered by a fine ivy, and is taxed at twenty-two francs.

第一章 木屋: 信末署名者（出版商）还强调，德卡那利先生的每一卷诗集都是自己花一万法郎买来的，卡那利不会把他的贝壳或坚果白送给别人。
Chapter I The Chalet: The undersigned (publisher) calls attention to the fact that he pays ten thousand francs for every volume of poetry written by Monsieur de Canalis, who does not give his shells, or his nuts either, for nothing.

第一章 木屋: 这位科雷兹的抒情诗人现住在天堂-鱼贩子街二十九号，这对于一位天使派诗人来说，是一个十分合适的地方。他的信件的邮资都是已付的。
Chapter I The Chalet: The chanticler of the Correze lives in the rue de Paradis-Poissoniere, number 29, which is a highly suitable location for a poet of the angelic school.Letters must be post-paid.

第一章 木屋: 据说，圣日耳曼郊区的贵妇们经常走到天堂街去保护她们心中的神。国王查理十世对这位伟大的诗人评价很高，以至于相信他能够治理国家；最近，国王任命他为荣誉军团的长官，还有外交部行政法院主席（这一职位收入更多）。这些职位都没有妨碍这位伟大的天才从鼓励艺术和文学的基金中得到一份津贴。
Chapter I The Chalet: Noble dames of the faubourg Saint-Germain are said to take the path to Paradise and protect its god.The king, Charles X., thinks so highly of this great poet as to believe him capable of governing the country; he has lately made him officer of the Legion of honor, and (what pays him better) president of the court of Claims at the foreign office.These functions do not hinder this great genius from drawing an annuity out of the fund for the encouragement of the arts and belles letters.

第一章 木屋: 卡那利作品的最新版由迪多出版社用精致的羊皮纸印刷，规格为253mm×158mm，书中有比西欧、约瑟夫·布里多、西奈尔、索麦维尔等人绘制的插图，一共五卷，定价九法郎，包括邮资。
Chapter I The Chalet: The last edition of the works of Canalis, printed on vellum, royal 8vo, from the press of Didot, with illustrations by Bixiou, Joseph Bridau, Schinner, Sommervieux, etc., is in five volumes, price, nine francs post-paid.

第一章 木屋: 这封信就像一块砸在郁金香上的鹅卵石。一位诗人、行政法院主席，领着公职的薪水，还有津贴，戴着勋章，受到圣日耳曼郊区女人的爱慕——可游吟诗人不应该是带着满身泥泞徘徊于码头，心里充斥着悲伤和幻想，被工作压得喘不过气、而又装着满脑子的诗歌回到自己的阁楼上吗？然而，莫黛斯特看出来了那位满怀嫉妒的出版商的冷嘲热讽，他竟敢说：“我造就了卡那利，我造就了拿单！”另外，她重温了她偶像的诗歌——那些诗篇是那么地富有魅力、虚幻而伪善，就算只是为了解释莫黛斯特的这种迷恋，我们也有必要对这些诗篇稍作分析。
Chapter I The Chalet: This letter fell like a cobble-stone on a tulip.A poet, secretary of claims, getting a stipend in a public office, drawing an annuity, seeking a decoration, adored by the women of the faubourg Saint–Germain—was that the muddy minstrel lingering along the quays, sad, dreamy, worn with toil, and re-entering his garret fraught with poetry?However, Modeste perceived the irony of the envious bookseller, who dared to say, “I invented Canalis; I made Nathan!”Besides, she re-read her hero’s poems,—verses extremely seductive, insincere, and hypocritical, which require a word of analysis, were it only to explain her infatuation.

第一章 木屋: 卡那利与天使派领袖拉马丁的不同在于，前者有一种甜言蜜语的强调，如同照顾病人的护士一般，有一种靠不住的温情，一种讨喜的精妙措辞。如果说这位大声呐喊的领袖是一只鹰的话，那卡那利就是一只红白相间的火烈鸟。他是女人们寻求的那种朋友，一个能够理解她们、向她们解释她们自己的阐释者，一个可靠的知己。莫黛斯特用铅笔在最新版中迪多留出的宽大页边空白处写满了自己的感想，表达着她与这颗充满柔情和幻想的心灵的共鸣。卡那利没有得到生命的馈赠，他无法赋予他的作品生命，但他知道怎样慰藉人们的隐痛，比如莫黛斯特的隐痛。他用少女们自己的语言同她们交谈，他能够减轻鲜血淋漓的伤口的剧痛，抚慰悲哀的呻吟，甚至是痛哭流涕。他的天赋不在于激昂的词句，也不在于抚慰那些沉重的情感创伤，他只是满足于用一种和谐悦耳的、令人信赖的语调说道：“你们的痛苦我感同身受，我能理解你们，跟我来吧，让我们到小溪边、到柳树下一起哭一场。”于是她们就随他而去了！她们倾听着他空洞而响亮的诗句，就像婴儿倾听着奶妈的摇篮曲一样。卡那利同诺迪埃一样，通过他的机智、他的微笑、他那凋落的玫瑰花瓣——简言之，就是通过他那婴儿般的哲学，令读者陶醉不已。只不过这种天真烂漫在散文家诺迪埃笔下十分真实，在诗人卡那利笔下却有些矫揉造作。他很善于模仿我们青春年少时的语言，将我们带回幻想中的大草原。我们可以无情地对待鹰，要求它们有钻石般的品质和不朽的完美，但对于卡那利，我们却能接受他本来的面目，至于其他的就随它去吧。他像是个乖小伙子，天使派的装腔作势已经解释了他的目的。他就像一个聪明的女人，装作天真无邪，装作无辜，装作大吃一惊，简言之，就是装作受伤的天使，而且伪装得非常成功。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis may be distinguished from Lamartine, chief of the angelic school, by a wheedling tone like that of a sick-nurse, a treacherous sweetness, and a delightful correctness of diction.If the chief with his strident cry is an eagle, Canalis, rose and white, is a flamingo.In him women find the friend they seek, their interpreter, a being who understands them, who explains them to themselves, and a safe confidant.The wide margins given by Didot to the last edition were crowded with Modeste’s pencilled sentiments, expressing her sympathy with this tender and dreamy spirit.Canalis does not possess the gift of life; he cannot breathe existence into his creations; but he knows how to calm vague sufferings like those which assailed Modeste.He speaks to young girls in their own language; he can allay the anguish of a bleeding wound and lull the moans, even the sobs of woe.His gift lies not in stirring words, nor in the remedy of strong emotions, he contents himself with saying in harmonious tones which compel belief, “I suffer with you; I understand you; come with me; let us weep together beside the brook, beneath the willows.”And they follow him!They listen to his empty and sonorous poetry like infants to a nurse’s lullaby.Canalis, like Nodier, enchants the reader by an artlessness which is genuine in the prose writer and artificial in the poet, by his tact, his smile, the shedding of his rose-leaves, in short by his infantile philosophy.He imitates so well the language of our early youth that he leads us back to the prairie-land of our illusions.We can be pitiless to the eagles, requiring from them the quality of the diamond, incorruptible perfection; but as for Canalis, we take him for what he is and let the rest go.He seems a good fellow; the affectations of the angelic school have answered his purpose and succeeded, just as a woman succeeds when she plays the ingenue cleverly, and simulates surprise, youth, innocence betrayed, in short, the wounded angel.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特找回了她的第一印象，重获了对那颗心灵、对那张像贝尔纳丹·德圣皮埃尔一样使人着迷的面孔的信任。她没有再理出版商了。于是，大约在八月初的时候，她给这颗现代七星诗社里的明星、圣器室里的多拉写了下面这封信。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste, recovering her first impression, renewed her confidence in that soul, in that countenance as ravishing as the face of Bernardin de Saint-Pierre.She paid no further attention to the publisher.And so, about the beginning of the month of August she wrote the following letter to this Dorat of the sacristy, who still ranks as a star of the modern Pleiades.

第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利先生——先生，我曾多次想给您写信，为什么呢？您一定猜得到的——是为了告诉您我多么地崇拜您的才华。是的，我觉得我必须向您表达一位可怜的乡村女孩对您的倾慕，她独居一隅，唯一的快乐就是阅读您的作品。我读过勒内的作品，现在在读您的。忧伤让人沉湎于幻想。还有多少女人在向您传递她们内心神秘的敬仰之情呢？在这么多人当中，我被注意到的几率又有多大呢？这封信满载着我的热情，与那些已经给您造成困扰的香喷喷的信件相比，希望我的信对您更有意义些。对您而言，我没有其他人那样优雅大方，因为我不想透露姓名，但我仍希望能得到您的完全信任，仿佛您与我相识已久。
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis,—Many a time, monsieur, I have wished to write to you; and why?Surely you guess why,—to tell you how much I admire your genius.Yes, I feel the need of expressing to you the admiration of a poor country girl, lonely in her little corner, whose only happiness is to read your thoughts.I have read Rene, and I come to you.Sadness leads to reverie.How many other women are sending you the homage of their secret thoughts?What chance have I for notice among so many?This paper, filled with my soul,—can it be more to you than the perfumed letters which already beset you.I come to you with less grace than others, for I wish to remain unknown and yet to receive your entire confidence—as though you had long known me.

第一章 木屋: 请给我回信，并善待我吧。我不能许诺会让您知道我的姓名，尽管我并没有确切地说有一天我不会这样做。
Chapter I The Chalet: Answer my letter and be friendly with me.I cannot promise to make myself known to you, though I do not positively say I will not some day do so.

第一章 木屋: 还有什么要补充的呢？先生，请从这封信的字里行间读出我所作出的巨大努力吧，请答应我，向我伸出您的手——一位朋友的手，啊！一位真正的朋友。
Chapter I The Chalet: What shall I add?Read between the lines of this letter, monsieur, the great effort which I am making: permit me to offer you my hand,—that of a friend, ah! a true friend.

第一章 木屋: 第七章 一位天使派诗人
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter VII A Poet of the Angelic School

第一章 木屋: 所有的少女，无论浪漫与否，都能想象到莫黛斯特在接下来几天里的焦躁不安。空气中充满了火热的语言。树木仿佛羽毛一般。她感觉不到自己的身体，她在空中漂浮着，脚下的土地渐渐融化。怀着对邮局的热爱，她一路追随她那张小小的信笺，她感到很幸福，就像二十岁的我们第一次按自己的意愿行事时那样幸福。她着魔了，就像中世纪传说里的少女那样。她在脑海里勾勒出这位诗人的住所，他的书房，她看到他打开了自己写的信，然后便是她的种种假设。
Chapter I The Chalet: All young girls, romantic or otherwise, can imagine the impatience in which Modeste lived for the next few days.The air was full of tongues of fire.The trees were like a plumage.She was not conscious of a body; she hovered in space, the earth melted away under her feet.Full of admiration for the post-office, she followed her little sheet of paper on its way; she was happy, as we all are happy at twenty years of age, in the first exercise of our will.She was possessed, as in the middle ages.She made pictures in her mind of the poet’s abode, of his study; she saw him unsealing her letter; and then followed myriads of suppositions.

第一章 木屋: 一番诗情画意之后，我们有必要对这位诗人稍作介绍。卡那利矮小清瘦，颇具贵族气质，面如满月，脸色较黑，头很小，就像那些虚荣多于骄傲的人一样。他喜欢奢华、地位和排场。跟大部分人相比，钱对他来说更为重要。他对自己出身的自豪感甚至超过了对其才华的自豪感。如今，由于他过分夸耀他的祖先们，他们的价值已遭到了破坏——毕竟，卡那利家族不是纳瓦兰家族，不是卡迪央家族，也不是葛朗利厄家族。然而，他的自命不凡是天性使然。他拥有一双颇具东方气息、炯炯有神的眼睛，这是诗人所应具备的，他的举止也很文雅，声音洪亮。然而，他那招摇撞骗的天性几乎毁了所有这些优点，他天生就是个喜剧演员。如果他露出他的匀称的双脚，那是因为这一姿势已经成了他的习惯；如果他使用感叹词，那是因为那已成了他的一部分；如果他举止夸张、引人注目，那是因为他已经将这种行为变成了他的第二天性。这些缺点与他总体的仁慈作风及游侠精神相得益彰，而正是这种纯粹的、理想化的精神，将游侠骑士与普通骑士区分开来。卡那利没有足够的热情成为堂吉诃德，但他的思想过于崇高，在碰到一些问题和事情时，总是表现得比别人更高尚。他抓住一切有利可图的机会，让他的诗歌像暴风雨般地席卷全镇，这确实有损于他的诗人形象，因为他并不是没有头脑，而是他的才华阻碍了他发挥其智慧。他过分重视自己的名声，总想让自己看上去比实际更伟大。于是，正如我们常见的那样，他本人与他的思想产物完全不一致。这些天真纯朴、抚慰人心、充满柔情的抒情诗，这些犹如湖面一样纯净、平和、宁静的田园诗，这些如此具有女性特点的诗歌，它们的作者却是一个小小的野心家。他身穿一身纽扣紧扣的礼服，浑身散发出一种寻求政治权势的外交官气度，极具贵族气质，自命不凡，渴望金钱，沉溺于两方面的成就之中，戴着爱神木和月桂树的双重花环。政府职务的八千法郎薪俸，文学基金的三千法郎津贴，法兰西学院的两千法郎，还有祖传地产的三千法郎（扣除税款以及管理费之前）——他每年共有一万五千法郎的固定收入，再加上他的诗作，不管年头好坏，总有一万法郎的收入，总计两万五千法郎。然而，这笔收入对莫黛斯特心目中的英雄来说，却太不稳定、太不够花了，他每年一般要多花出五六千法郎。不过迄今为止，国王的个人金库和外交部的秘密基金已经补足了这些亏空。他为国王的加冕礼作了一首赞美诗，为此他得到了一整套银器，因为他拒绝拿赏钱，理由是卡那利家族成员有义务为国王效力。
Chapter I The Chalet: After sketching the poetry we cannot do less than give the profile of the poet.Canalis is a short, spare man, with an air of good-breeding, a dark-complexioned, moon-shaped face, and a rather mean head like that of a man who has more vanity than pride.He loves luxury, rank, and splendor.Money is of more importance to him than to most men.Proud of his birth, even more than of his talent, he destroys the value of his ancestors by making too much of them in the present day,—after all, the Canalis are not Navarreins, nor Cadignans, nor Grandlieus.Nature, however, helps him out in his pretensions.He has those eyes of Eastern effulgence which we demand in a poet, a delicate charm of manner, and a vibrant voice; yet a taint of natural charlatanism destroys the effect of nearly all these advantages; he is a born comedian.If he puts forward his well-shaped foot, it is because the attitude has become a habit; if he uses exclamatory terms they are part of himself; if he poses with high dramatic action he has made that deportment his second nature.Such defects as these are not incompatible with a general benevolence and a certain quality of errant and purely ideal chivalry, which distinguishes the paladin from the knight.Canalis has not devotion enough for a Don Quixote, but he has too much elevation of thought not to put himself on the nobler side of questions and things.His poetry, which takes the town by storm on all profitable occasions, really injures the man as a poet; for he is not without mind, but his talent prevents him from developing it; he is overweighted by his reputation, and is always aiming to make himself appear greater than he has the credit of being.Thus, as often happens, the man is entirely out of keeping with the products of his thought.The author of these naive, caressing, tender little lyrics, these calm idylls pure and cold as the surface of a lake, these verses so essentially feminine, is an ambitious little creature in a tightly buttoned frock-coat, with the air of a diplomat seeking political influence, smelling of the musk of aristocracy, full of pretension, thirsting for money, already spoiled by success in two directions, and wearing the double wreath of myrtle and of laurel.A government situation worth eight thousand francs, three thousand francs’ annuity from the literary fund, two thousand from the Academy, three thousand more from the paternal estate (less the taxes and the cost of keeping it in order),—a total fixed income of fifteen thousand francs, plus the ten thousand bought in, one year with another, by his poetry; in all twenty-five thousand francs,—this for Modeste’s hero was so precarious and insufficient an income that he usually spent five or six thousand francs more every year; but the king’s privy purse and the secret funds of the foreign office had hitherto supplied the deficit.He wrote a hymn for the king’s coronation which earned him a whole silver service,—having refused a sum of money on the ground that a Canalis owed his duty to his sovereign.

第一章 木屋: 但此时，按照记者们的说法，卡那利已经江郎才尽了。他感觉自己不能创作出任何新形式的诗歌，他的七弦竖琴没有七根弦，只有一根，而且用那一根弹得太久了，听众不允许他有其他的选择，他要么就把自己吊在这根弦上，要么就闭上他的嘴巴。德马尔赛不喜欢卡那利，他对卡那利的评价如有毒的箭头，刺中了这位诗人虚荣的要害。“卡那利总是让我想起一位勇士，”他说道，“在一次战役之后，弗雷德里克大帝召唤并夸奖了他，因为他的军号从不间断地嘀嘀哒哒吹着同一个曲调。”卡那利的理想是从政，并把他的马德里之行作为开端。当时德肖利厄公爵正任大使，而他是大使秘书，可巴黎人都传言说他其实是为了追随公爵夫人。有多少次，一句讽刺或是一次谈话就能决定一个人的一生。前内高卢共和国总统、皮埃蒙特最好的律师科拉，在他四十岁时，一位朋友说他对植物学一窍不通。他的自尊心受了伤害，当起了朱西厄第二，种植花草，并花十年的时间编辑出版了拉丁文著作《皮埃蒙特植物志》。“总有一天我要让德马尔赛拜我为师！”这位挫败的诗人想道，“毕竟，坎宁和夏多布里昂都是从政的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: But about this time Canalis had, as the journalists say, exhausted his budget.He felt himself unable to invent any new form of poetry; his lyre did not have seven strings, it had one; and having played on that one string so long, the public allowed him no other alternative but to hang himself with it, or to hold his tongue.De Marsay, who did not like Canalis, made a remark whose poisoned shaft touched the poet to the quick of his vanity.“Canalis,” he said, “always reminds me of that brave man whom Frederic the Great called up and commended after a battle because his trumpet had never ceased tooting its one little tune.”Canalis’s ambition was to enter political life, and he made capital of a journey he had taken to Madrid as secretary to the embassy of the Duc de Chaulieu, though it was really made, according to Parisian gossip, in the capacity of “attache to the duchess.”How many times a sarcasm or a single speech has decided the whole course of a man’s life.Colla, the late president of the Cisalpine republic, and the best lawyer in Piedmont, was told by a friend when he was forty years of age that he knew nothing of botany.He was piqued, became a second Jussieu, cultivated flowers, and compiled and published “The Flora of Piedmont,” in Latin, a labor of ten years.“I’ll master De Marsay some of these days!” thought the crushed poet; “after all, Canning and Chateaubriand are both in politics.”

第一章 木屋: 卡那利本想写一部伟大的政治诗作，但他还是害怕法国的出版社，它们对任何一位用四行亚历山大诗表达思想的作家，都会予以严厉批评。当今的所有诗人当中，只有雨果、泰奥菲勒·戈蒂埃和德维尼三个人赢得了诗人和散文家的双重荣誉，就像拉辛、伏尔泰、莫里哀和拉伯雷一样——这在法国文学中是一种罕见的盛名，获得它的人有权利享有诗人的最高头衔。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis would gladly have brought forth some great political poem, but he was afraid of the French press, whose criticisms are savage upon any writer who takes four alexandrines to express one idea.Of all the poets of our day only three, Hugo, Theophile Gautier, and De Vigny, have been able to win the double glory of poet and prose-writer, like Racine and Voltaire, Moliere, and Rabelais,—a rare distinction in the literature of France, which ought to give a man a right to the crowning title of poet.

第一章 木屋: 所以，这位圣日耳曼郊区的诗人努力将自己的小马车置于当今政府的保护伞下，此乃明智之举。当他成为外交部行政法院主席后，需要一位秘书——一位能够在很多情况下代替他、替他从出版商那里谋取利益、维护他在报纸上的名声、必要的时候在政治上帮助他的朋友——简言之，就是一个任他使唤的跟班。在巴黎，许多在艺术、科学和文学方面享有盛名的人都有一个或多个追捧者——也可以说是警卫队队长或管家。他们生活在名人的光辉下，这些担负着微妙使命的副官，在必要的情况下会拿自己的名誉拼一场。这些围着偶像做事的人不完全是他的仆人，然而也不能和他平起平坐，这些人英勇地保护着他，冲锋时在前，撤退时殿后，为他的事业忙碌着，而且只要他们的幻想尚存，或者尚未得到他们想要的一切，就会一直为他效忠。这些追随者当中，有些觉察出了他们的偶像的忘恩负义，另一些人感觉他们只是被利用的工具，还有许多人厌倦了这种生活。只有少数人仍满足于那种感觉和情感上的愉悦的对等，这是在与上级交往时所应追求的唯一回报——就像穆罕默德将阿里提升到与自己同等重要的位置时，阿里会收获一种满足感。
Chapter I The Chalet: So then, the bard of the faubourg Saint–Germain was doing a wise thing in trying to house his little chariot under the protecting roof of the present government.When he became president of the court of Claims at the foreign office, he stood in need of a secretary,—a friend who could take his place in various ways; cook up his interests with publishers, see to his glory in the newspapers, help him if need be in politics,—in short, a cat’s paw and satellite.In Paris many men of celebrity in art, science, and literature have one or more train-bearers, captains of the guard, chamberlains as it were, who live in the sunshine of their presence,—aides-decamp entrusted with delicate missions, allowing themselves to be compromised if necessary; workers round the pedestal of the idol; not exactly his servants, nor yet his equals; bold in his defence, first in the breach, covering all retreats, busy with his business, and devoted to him just so long as their illusions last, or until the moment when they have got all they wanted.Some of these satellites perceive the ingratitude of their great man; others feel that they are simply made tools of; many weary of the life; very few remain contented with that sweet equality of feeling and sentiment which is the only reward that should be looked for in an intimacy with a superior man,—a reward that contented Ali when Mohammed raised him to himself.

第一章 木屋: 他们当中的许多人都被虚荣所误导，觉得自己跟主人一样有能耐。莫黛斯特所构想的那种不求金钱、千金难买的单纯的忠诚是极少见的。然而，确实也有麦讷瓦尔那样的人，这样的人在巴黎比在其他地方可能还要多些。他们珍视在幕后默默操劳的生活，他们就像社交界这座隐修院中的本笃会修士。这些勇敢、温顺的心灵，通过他们的行动，在他们隐修的一生中，过着诗人们所说的诗意生活。从心灵上来讲，从温情上来讲，从他们的独立坚守、冥思苦想上来讲，他们自己就是诗人——跟那些名字写在书上、在满是韵文的文学沃土中成长的人一样，是真正的诗人。他们就像拜伦勋爵，像那些，唉，由于没有更好的生路而靠墨水——当今世上的灵泉之水——谋生的人。
Chapter I The Chalet: Many of these men, misled by vanity, think themselves quite as capable as their patron.Pure devotion, such as Modeste conceived it, without money and without price, and more especially without hope, is rare.Nevertheless there are Mennevals to be found, more perhaps in Paris than elsewhere, men who value a life in the background with its peaceful toil; these are the wandering Benedictines of our social world, which offers them no other monastery.These brave, meek hearts live, by their actions and in their hidden lives, the poetry that poets utter.They are poets themselves in soul, in tenderness, in their lonely vigils and meditations,—as truly poets as others of the name on paper, who fatten in the fields of literature at so much a verse; like Lord Byron, like all who live, alas, by ink, the Hippocrene water of today, for want of a better.

第一章 木屋: 一位行政法院的年轻律师，被卡那利的名气及政治前景所吸引，听从了按德肖利厄公爵夫人指示办事的德埃斯巴夫人的建议，成了这位诗人的秘书兼密友。诗人很乐意地接受了他，十分宠爱他，就像投机商爱抚他的第一个入股者一样。这种伙伴关系一开始很像友情。这个年轻人之前还跟一位内阁大臣有过同样的关系。那位大臣于一八二七年下台了，下台之前还细心地给他这位年轻秘书安排了外交部的一个职务。埃内斯特·德拉布里埃当时二十七岁，已经被授予荣誉军团勋章，但除了薪俸外没有其他收入。他很会办事，而且在首相内阁的四年当中学到了很多东西。他为人友善、和蔼、十分谦虚，内心淳朴，满怀美好的情感，不喜欢抛头露面。他热爱自己的国家，希望报效祖国，但恶名却令他困窘不堪。比起做内阁大臣的秘书，他更渴望做一位拿破仑式人物的秘书。他一成为卡那利的朋友兼秘书，便为卡那利做了很多事。但十八个月后，他便开始意识到，这个只在文学表达上富有诗意的人，其内心是极其荒芜的。俗话说得好：“穿上修道士服不一定能成修道士。”这一现象在文学界尤为突出。在文人中，天性跟才华完美结合的人是极其少见的。才华并不代表一个人本身。这种断裂现象令人惊异，其原因是一个未解的、甚至可能是无解的谜。大脑和大脑的各种产物（因为在艺术中，人的手就是其大脑的延续）相去甚远。各种产物在脑壳下开花结果，却完全独立于情感、感觉、公民美德、传统美德以及私人生活。此话固然不假，但也并非绝对。对一个人来说，没有什么是绝对正确的。可以肯定的是，浪荡子会磨灭自己的才华，酒鬼会浪费自己的才华。可反过来说，却没有人能够通过健康的生活方式来赋予自己才华。不过，我们差不多可以证明，爱情绘画大师维吉尔从没爱过狄东那样的女子，而模范公民卢梭，如果能过得像贵族一样，就会感到很自豪的。不过话又说回来，拉斐尔和米开朗琪罗就展示了天才和人格的完美结合。因此，从道义上来讲，才能之于男人，恰如美貌之于女人——不过是一种希冀罢了。所以，让我们加倍崇拜那些心灵和人格同其才能一样完美的人吧。
Chapter I The Chalet: Attracted by the fame of Canalis, also by the prospect of political interest, and advised thereto by Madame d’Espard, who acted in the matter for the Duchesse de Chaulieu, a young lawyer of the court of Claims became secretary and confidential friend of the poet, who welcomed and petted him very much as a broker caresses his first dabbler in the funds.The beginning of this companionship bore a very fair resemblance to friendship.The young man had already held the same relation to a minister, who went out of office in 1827, taking care before he did so to appoint his young secretary to a place in the foreign office.Ernest de La Briere, then about twenty-seven years of age, was decorated with the Legion of honor but was without other means than his salary; he was accustomed to the management of business and had learned a good deal of life during his four years in a minister’s cabinet.Kindly, amiable, and over-modest, with a heart full of pure and sound feelings, he was averse to putting himself in the foreground.He loved his country, and wished to serve her, but notoriety abashed him.To him the place of secretary to a Napoleon was far more desirable than that of the minister himself.As soon as he became the friend and secretary of Canalis he did a great amount of labor for him, but by the end of eighteen months he had learned to understand the barrenness of a nature that was poetic through literary expression only.The truth of the old proverb, “The cowl doesn’t make the monk,” is eminently shown in literature.It is extremely rare to find among literary men a nature and a talent that are in perfect accord.The faculties are not the man himself.This disconnection, whose phenomena are amazing, proceeds from an unexplored, possibly an unexplorable mystery.The brain and its products of all kinds (for in art the hand of man is a continuation of his brain) are a world apart, which flourishes beneath the cranium in absolute independence of sentiments, feelings, and all that is called virtue, the virtue of citizens, fathers, and private life.This, however true, is not absolutely so; nothing is absolutely true of man.It is certain that a debauched man will dissipate his talent, that a drunkard will waste it in libations; while, on the other hand, no man can give himself talent by wholesome living: nevertheless, it is all but proved that Virgil, the painter of love, never loved a Dido, and that Rousseau, the model citizen, had enough pride to had furnished forth an aristocracy.On the other hand Raphael and Michael Angelo do present the glorious conjunction of genius with the lines of character.Talent in men is therefore, in all moral points, very much what beauty is in women,—simply a promise.Let us, therefore, doubly admire the man in whom both heart and character equal the perfection of his genius.

第一章 木屋: 当埃内斯特发现他的诗人有一种野心勃勃的利己主义、一种最坏的利己主义时（因为某些形式的利己主义还是挺讨人喜欢的），他便想要离开卡那利，却又有些踌躇不决。天性诚实的人很难挣脱束缚，特别是当他们自愿地被束缚时。于是，莫黛斯特的信寄来时，这位秘书还是跟这位诗人在同一个屋檐下和睦相处。一般说来，在这种关系里，秘书总要不断压抑自己的情感，不断自我牺牲。拉布里埃承认卡那利在他面前很坦诚，从不掩饰什么。再加上卡那利一生都被人们看作是一位伟大的诗人，像马蒙泰尔一样受人赞美，他的缺点只是他光辉品质的反面而已。如果他不爱慕虚荣、狂妄自大，那么他可能永远都无法练就那声如洪钟的雄辩术，而这种雄辩术在政治生活中非常有用，甚至是必不可少的工具。他的冷酷无情在某些方面近乎正直和忠诚，他的虚荣卖弄之中也带有一丝慷慨大方。我们必须记住，结果是要有益社会的，而出于什么动机，则只有上帝才管得着。
Chapter I The Chalet: When Ernest discovered within his poet an ambitious egoist, the worst species of egoist (for there are some amiable forms of the vice), he felt a delicacy in leaving him.Honest natures cannot easily break the ties that bind them, especially if they have tied them voluntarily.The secretary was therefore still living in domestic relations with the poet when Modeste’s letter arrived,—in such relations, be it said, as involved a perpetual sacrifice of his feelings.La Briere admitted the frankness with which Canalis had laid himself bare before him.Moreover, the defects of the man, who will always be considered a great poet during his lifetime and flattered as Martmontel was flattered, were only the wrong side of his brilliant qualities.Without his vanity and his magniloquence it is possible that he might never have acquired the sonorous elocution which is so useful and even necessary an instrument in political life.His cold-bloodedness touched at certain points on rectitude and loyalty; his ostentation had a lining of generosity.Results, we must remember, are to the profit of society; motives concern God.

第一章 木屋: 但莫黛斯特的信寄到之后，埃内斯特再也无法为卡那利而欺骗自己了。两个人刚吃完早餐，正在诗人的书房里聊天。书房在庭院尽头的住宅底层，面向花园。
Chapter I The Chalet: But after the arrival of Modeste’s letter Ernest deceived himself no longer as to Canalis.The pair had just finished breakfast and were talking together in the poet’s study, which was on the ground-floor of a house standing back in a court-yard, and looked into a garden.

第一章 木屋: “你瞧！”卡那利说道，“我前几天跟德肖利厄夫人说我应该创作一首新诗，我知道人们对我的崇拜之情正在减少，因为我已经很长时间没收到匿名信了。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “There!” exclaimed Canalis, “I was telling Madame de Chaulieu the other day that I ought to bring out another poem; I knew admiration was running short, for I have had no anonymous letters for a long time.”

第一章 木屋: “这是一位无名女子写的吗？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Is it from an unknown woman?”

第一章 木屋: “无名？是的！——勒阿弗尔一位名叫德埃斯特的姑娘，明显是个假名。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Unknown? yes!—a D’Este, in Havre; evidently a feigned name.”

第一章 木屋: 卡那利把信递给拉布里埃。这首小诗，包含了所有隐藏的激情，简单地说，包含了可怜的莫黛斯特的心，而这颗心却被卡那利轻蔑地递了出去，那动作俨然一个被宠坏了的花花公子。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis passed the letter to La Briere.The little poem, with all its hidden enthusiasms, in short, poor Modeste’s heart, was disdainfully handed over, with the gesture of a spoiled dandy.

第一章 木屋: “这样真好，”律师说道，“拥有吸引这种情感的能力，使得一个可怜的女子摆脱天性、教育，以及世人给她划定的习俗，打破惯例。天才能赢得怎样的特权啊！像这样一封信，出自一位少女之手——一位真正的少女——没有隐藏的意义，只有真挚的热情——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “It is a fine thing,” said the lawyer, “to have the power to attract such feelings; to force a poor woman to step out of the habits which nature, education, and the world dictate to her, to break through conventions.What privileges genius wins!A letter such as this, written by a young girl—a genuine young girl—without hidden meanings, with real enthusiasm—”

第一章 木屋: “好吧，那又怎样呢？”卡那利说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Well, what?” said Canalis.

第一章 木屋: “哎呀，一个男人就算是像塔索那样饱受折磨，也会感觉得到了补偿。”拉布里埃喊道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Why, a man might suffer as much as Tasso and yet feel recompensed,” cried La Briere.

第一章 木屋: “我亲爱的朋友，收到第一封、甚至第二封这样的信时，他会有这种感觉，但收到第三十封时他会怎样？还有，假设你发现这些年轻的狂热追随者是些小荡妇呢？或者，想象一位诗人沿着光明大道奔跑着去寻找她，在路的尽头却发现一位年迈的英国女人，坐在地界石上向你伸出手！再或者，如果这位邮局天使其实是一个极其丑陋的、急需一位如意郎君的女孩呢？啊，我的朋友！那样你的心就欢腾不起来了。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “So he might, my dear fellow, by a first letter of that kind, and even a second; but how about the thirtieth?And suppose you find out that these young enthusiasts are little jades?Or imagine a poet rushing along the brilliant path in search of her, and finding at the end of it an old Englishwoman sitting on a mile-stone and offering you her hand!Or suppose this post-office angel should really be a rather ugly girl in quest of a husband?Ah, my boy! the effervescence then goes down.”

第一章 木屋: “我开始感觉到，”拉布里埃笑着说道，“荣誉里面有某种有毒的东西，就像一些艳丽的花儿有毒一样。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I begin to perceive,” said La Briere, smiling, “that there is something poisonous in glory, as there is in certain dazzling flowers.”

第一章 木屋: “还有，”卡那利接着说，“所有这些女人，即使她们头脑简单，也会有理想，而你是满足不了她们的。她们从来都不会对自己说诗人是爱慕虚荣的，就像我被指责爱慕虚荣那样。她们想象不出来，一个作家被她们那种狂热的兴奋摆布久了，脾气会变得多么坏、多么变幻莫测。她们希望他总是伟大的、高尚的，她们从来不会想到天才会是个病羔子，拿单会跟弗洛丽纳同居，德阿尔泰兹太胖，约瑟夫·勃里杜太瘦，贝朗热是瘸子，还有她们的爱神也会流鼻涕！像吕西安·德吕邦泼雷那样既是诗人又是美男子的人真是凤毛麟角。而我为什么要被这些溢美之词牵着鼻子走，最后被某个幻想破灭的女人用目光狠狠地泼一桶冷水呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: “And then,” resumed Canalis, “all these women, even when they are simple-minded, have ideals, and you can’t satisfy them.They never say to themselves that a poet is a vain man, as I am accused of being; they can’t conceive what it is for an author to be at the mercy of a feverish excitement, which makes him disagreeable and capricious; they want him always grand, noble; it never occurs to them that genius is a disease, or that Nathan lives with Florine; that D’Arthez is too fat, and Joseph Bridau is too thin; that Beranger limps, and that their own particular deity may have the snuffles!A Lucien de Rubempre, poet and cupid, is a phoenix.And why should I go in search of compliments only to pull the string of a shower-bath of horrid looks from some disillusioned female?”

第一章 木屋: “那么，真正的诗人，”拉布里埃说道，“就应该像上帝那样，隐藏在自己世界的中心，只能在他的创作中被人看到。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Then the true poet,” said La Briere, “ought to remain hidden, like God, in the centre of his worlds, and be only seen in his own creations.”

第一章 木屋: “那样的话，名誉的代价也太高了，”卡那利回答说。“生活中有美好的事物。至于那封信，”他一边端起一杯茶，一边补充道，“我可以肯定地告诉你，当一个美貌的贵族女子爱上一位诗人时，她不会像一位爱上了名演员的公爵夫人那样，躲在角落的包厢里，她会觉得她的美貌、她的财富、她的名声足以保护她，她敢于像英雄史诗里那样公开地说：‘我是仙女卡吕普索，我爱忒勒马科斯。’故作神秘和编造假名是小聪明的伎俩。而我已经很久不理会那些戴面具的人了——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Glory would cost too dear in that case,” answered Canalis.“There is some good in life.As for that letter,” he added, taking a cup of tea, “I assure you that when a noble and beautiful woman loves a poet she does not hide in the corner boxes, like a duchess in love with an actor; she feels that her beauty, her fortune, her name are protection enough, and she dares to say openly, like an epic poem: ‘I am the nymph Calypso, enamored of Telemachus.’Mystery and feigned names are the resources of little minds.For my part I no longer answer masks—”

第一章 木屋: “我会爱上一个来追寻我的女子。”拉布里埃喊道，“亲爱的卡那利，对于你所说的一切，我的回答是：一个追求卓越人物的女孩肯定不会是平凡之辈，那样的女孩会过于谨慎，过于爱面子，过于胆怯。只有一位明星，一位——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I should love a woman who came to seek me,” cried La Briere.“To all you say I reply, my dear Canalis, that it cannot be an ordinary girl who aspires to a distinguished man; such a girl has too little trust, too much vanity; she is too faint-hearted.Only a star, a—”

第一章 木屋: “——公主！”卡那利大笑起来，喊道，“只有公主才会屈尊于他。亲爱的朋友，那种事是百年不遇啊。那样的爱情就像是一百年才开一次的花朵。让我告诉你吧，那些年轻貌美而又富有的公主有其他事情要考虑，她们像奇花异草一样，被枯老灌木一般空虚而有教养的傻子团团围着。我的梦想，唉！我那水晶般的梦想，从此时起便成了镶着玫瑰花环的科雷兹河——哎！我不能谈起它——它早已在我脚下成为碎片了。不，不，所有的匿名信都是有所乞求的，而那是一种怎样的乞求呢？如果你认为她年轻漂亮，那你来给她写信吧，你会自己发现她有什么乞求。没有什么比得上经验。对我而言，从理智上讲，我不可能爱上每一个女人，就连阿波罗，至少是贝尔维迪宫的阿波罗，也是一个必须保重身体的柔弱的肺病患者。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “—princess!” cried Canalis, bursting into a shout of laughter; “only a princess can descend to him.My dear fellow, that doesn’t happen once in a hundred years.Such a love is like that flower that blossoms every century.Princesses, let me tell you, if they are young, rich, and beautiful, have something else to think of; they are surrounded like rare plants by a hedge of fools, well-bred idiots as hollow as elder-bushes!My dream, alas! the crystal of my dream, garlanded from hence to the Correze with roses—ah!I cannot speak of it—it is in fragments at my feet, and has long been so.No, no, all anonymous letters are begging letters; and what sort of begging?Write yourself to that young woman, if you suppose her young and pretty, and you’ll find out.There is nothing like experience.As for me, I can’t reasonably be expected to love every woman; Apollo, at any rate he of Belvedere, is a delicate consumptive who must take care of his health.”

第一章 木屋: “但是，当一个女人以这样一种方式给你写信的时候，在她的意识里，肯定有理由认为她能在温柔和美貌方面令其他任何一个女人黯然失色，”埃内斯特说道，“而且，我觉得你总会有点好奇吧——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “But when a woman writes to you in this way her excuse must certainly be in her consciousness that she is able to eclipse in tenderness and beauty every other woman,” said Ernest, “and I should think you might feel some curiosity—”

第一章 木屋: “啊，”卡那利说，“我年少无知的朋友，请允许我履行对美丽的公爵夫人的誓言吧，她是我全部的快乐。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah,” said Canalis, “permit me, my juvenile friend, to abide by the beautiful duchess who is all my joy.”

第一章 木屋: “你说得对，你说得对！”埃内斯特喊道。然而，这位年轻的秘书把莫黛斯特的信读了又读，努力猜测这位匿名写信人的想法。
Chapter I The Chalet: “You are right, you are right!” cried Ernest.However, the young secretary read and re-read Modeste’s letter, striving to guess the mind of its hidden writer.

第一章 木屋: 小姐，对优秀作品的赞美（姑且说我的作品是优秀的吧）含有某种高尚和真挚的意味，因此您不会被任何人嘲笑，而且，就是在最为严厉的法官面前，也可以证明您给我写信这一举动是正当合理的。
Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle,—The admiration for fine works (allowing that my books are such) implies something so lofty and sincere as to protect you from all light jesting, and to justify before the sternest judge the step you have taken in writing to me.

第一章 木屋: 但首先，即使是受之有愧，我也要感谢您的盛情之举给我带来的快乐，因为蹩脚的诗人和真正的诗人都确信自己作品的内在价值，一旦受到称赞，自尊心会立刻感到满足。一位素不相识的女士对我的信任，能够减轻他人对我的指责带来的剧痛，而我的报答就是给她以友情。这友情的最好证明，就是同她分享我个人经验的果实，哪怕这样有可能会让她最鲜明生动的幻想化为泡影。
Chapter I The Chalet: But first I must thank you for the pleasure which such proofs of sympathy afford, even though we may not merit them,—for the maker of verses and the true poet are equally certain of the intrinsic worth of their writings,—so readily does self-esteem lend itself to praise.The best proof of friendship that I can give to an unknown lady in exchange for a faith which allays the sting of criticism, is to share with her the harvest of my own experience, even at the risk of dispelling her most vivid illusions.

第一章 木屋: 小姐，一位少女最高贵的装饰便是纯净、圣洁、无可指责的生活之花。您在这个世界上是孤身一人吗？如果是，那就没什么可说的了。但如果您有一个家庭，有一位父亲或是母亲，想想看，您写信给一位素不相识的诗人，这封信将会给您的父母带来怎样的忧伤。并不是所有的作家都是天使，他们是有许多缺点的。有些人轻佻，有些人鲁莽，有些人浮夸，有些人野心勃勃，有些人沉迷酒色。相信我，不管您多么天真无邪，一个诗人多么具有骑士风度，您还是会在巴黎碰到许多堕落的行吟诗人，他们时刻准备唤起您的柔情，只为了有朝一日欺骗你的感情。那样的诗人不会像我这样，而是会以另外一种方式来解读您的信。他会曲解您的想法，而天真无邪的您对此是不会有所觉察的。有多少作家，就有多少种品格。您认为我能够理解您，这令我感到万分荣幸。但万一您落到一个伪君子、一个狂妄之徒的手里，他写的书可能是忧郁的，但他的生活却是一个永久的狂欢节，您会发现，由于您草率之举，竟撞见了一个思想邪恶的人，一个剧院后台的常客，或是某个同性恋胜地的英雄。您在长满铁线莲的凉亭下幻想诗人时，能闻到使手稿失去所有诗意的烟草味么？
Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle, the noblest adornment of a young girl is the flower of a pure and saintly and irreproachable life.Are you alone in the world?If you are, there is no need to say more.But if you have a family, a father or a mother, think of all the sorrow that might come to them from such a letter as yours addressed to a poet of whom you know nothing personally.All writers are not angels; they have many defects.Some are frivolous, heedless, foppish, ambitious, dissipated; and, believe me, no matter how imposing innocence may be, how chivalrous a poet is, you will meet with many a degenerate troubadour in Paris ready to cultivate your affection only to betray it.By such a man your letter would be interpreted otherwise than it is by me.He would see a thought that is not in it, which you, in your innocence, have not suspected.There are as many natures as there are writers.I am deeply flattered that you have judged me capable of understanding you; but had you, perchance, fallen upon a hypocrite, a scoffer, one whose books may be melancholy but whose life is a perpetual carnival, you would have found as the result of your generous imprudence an evil-minded man, the frequenter of green-rooms, perhaps a hero of some gay resort.In the bower of clematis where you dream of poets, can you smell the odor of the cigar which drives all poetry from the manuscript?

第一章 木屋: 让我们进一步说吧。您肯定生活在海边吧？那么您过的那种充满幻想而又孤独的生活怎么会使一位诗人感兴趣呢？他的使命就是去想象一切并描绘一切。有什么现实能比得上想象呢？诗人们心中的年轻女孩们是如此完美，没有哪位夏娃的女儿能同她们媲美。那么，像您这样一位接受良好教育、注定成为一名贤妻良母的少女，请您告诉我，如果您理解了生活在这个可怕都市里的诗人的那些焦躁不安，您将会得到什么？用一句话来定义这座都市就够了——这是一座爱情的地狱。
Chapter I The Chalet: But let us look still further.How could the dreamy, solitary life you lead, doubtless by the sea-shore, interest a poet, whose mission it is to imagine all, and to paint all?What reality can equal imagination?The young girls of the poets are so ideal that no living daughter of Eve can compete with them.And now tell me, what will you gain,—you, a young girl, brought up to be the virtuous mother of a family,—if you learn to comprehend the terrible agitations of a poet’s life in this dreadful capital, which may be defined by one sentence,—the hell in which men love.

第一章 木屋: 如果作为一位渴望知识的少女，想要活跃一下枯燥的生活，所以您才拿起笔给我写了这封信，那这一举动本身不就是堕落的表现吗？我该赋予您这封信怎样的意义呢？您是被排挤的某个社会团体的一分子吗？您想要寻找一位远方的朋友吗？或者，您是被自己外表的丑陋所折磨，但觉得自己仍有一颗能够给予并接受信任的高贵心灵？唉，唉，只能做一个令人心酸的结论了。您要么说得太多了，要么说得太少了；要么走得太远了，要么还不够远。要么我们就此结束通信，要么，如果您再继续写的话，告诉我比这封信里更多的内容。
Chapter I The Chalet: If the desire to brighten the monotonous existence of a young girl thirsting for knowledge has led you to take your pen in hand and write to me, has not the step itself the appearance of degradation?What meaning am I to give to your letter?Are you one of a rejected caste, and do you seek a friend far away from you?Or, are you afflicted with personal ugliness, yet feeling within you a noble soul which can give and receive a confidence?Alas, alas, the conclusion to be drawn is grievous.You have said too much, or too little; you have gone too far, or not far enough.Either let us drop this correspondence, or, if you continue it, tell me more than in the letter you have now written me.

第一章 木屋: 但是，小姐，如果您还年轻，如果您很漂亮，如果您有个家，有一个家庭，如果要把心中宝贵的香膏和甘松香油倾注出来，就像抹大拉的马利亚将其涂在耶稣脚上一样，那就让您自己被一位与您般配的男子所赢得吧，成为每一位纯洁的年轻姑娘都应该成为的人——一位好女人，一个家庭的贤妻良母。一位诗人，是一位姑娘能收获的最糟糕的战利品。他爱慕虚荣，锋芒毕露，会深深刺伤一个女人合情合理的自尊心，而且会抹杀毫无生活经验之人的的一片柔情。诗人的妻子应该在爱他很久之后再跟他结婚，她必须要训练自己拥有天使的仁慈，拥有容忍之心，拥有母性的所有美德。小姐，这些品质在一位年轻姑娘身上还只是萌芽。
Chapter I The Chalet: But, mademoiselle, if you are young, if you are beautiful, if you have a home, a family, if in your heart you have the precious ointment, the spikenard, to pour out, as did Magdalene on the feet of Jesus, let yourself be won by a man worthy of you; become what every pure young girl should be,—a good woman, the virtuous mother of a family.A poet is the saddest conquest that a girl can make; he is full of vanity, full of angles that will sharply wound a woman’s proper pride, and kill a tenderness which has no experience of life.The wife of a poet should love him long before she marries him; she must train herself to the charity of angels, to their forbearance, to all the virtues of motherhood.Such qualities, mademoiselle, are but germs in a young girl.

第一章 木屋: 这就是全部的事实——难道我不应该以此来回报您那令人醉心的恭维吗？如果嫁给伟大的名人是一件美好的事情，那也要记住，你很快就会发现，从一个人的各个方面来讲，伟人和常人没什么两样。因此，尽管人们对他寄予厚望，他却远远做不到那么完美。如果某个女人的美貌被过度夸大了，我们会这样评论她：“我还以为她比这漂亮得多呢。”对于他，也是一样。她没有为精灵给她画的肖像授权，我收到您的来信也是归功于这位精灵——它的名字叫做想象力。
Chapter I The Chalet: Hear the whole truth,—do I not owe it to you in return for your intoxicating flattery?If it is a glorious thing to marry a great renown, remember also that you must soon discover a superior man to be, in all that makes a man, like other men.He therefore poorly realizes the hopes that attach to him as a phoenix.He becomes like a woman whose beauty is over-praised, and of whom we say: “I thought her far more lovely.”She has not warranted the portrait painted by the fairy to whom I owe your letter,—the fairy whose name is Imagination.

第一章 木屋: 相信我，精神方面的品质只在看不见的地方生存、成长，而不是在日常生活中。诗人的妻子要忍受重负，她看到珠宝制造出来，却从来不戴它们。如果是地位的光辉吸引了您，那现在听我说，它带来的快乐是转瞬即逝的。当您发现有些东西远看很完美，事实上却有许多粗糙之处，当您到达光辉的顶峰，却觉得高处不胜寒，您就会很痛苦。此外，对于涉世未深、从未经历过真正苦难的女子来说，一旦她们看到她们曾崇拜的东西的内部构造，便会马上终止对它的赏识。
Chapter I The Chalet: Believe me, the qualities of the mind live and thrive only in a sphere invisible, not in daily life; the wife of a poet bears the burden; she sees the jewels manufactured, but she never wears them.If the glory of the position fascinates you, hear me now when I tell you that its pleasures are soon at an end.You will suffer when you find so many asperities in a nature which, from a distance, you thought equable, and such coldness at the shining summit.Moreover, as women never set their feet within the world of real difficulties, they cease to appreciate what they once admired as soon as they think they see the inner mechanism of it.

第一章 木屋: 我再谈谈我的最后一个看法，这并不是变相的请求，而是一位朋友的忠告。心灵的交流只能在彼此没有任何隐瞒的人之间才能发生。您能向一位素不相识的人袒露真正的自己吗？我不敢对此作出结论。
Chapter I The Chalet: I close with a last thought, in which there is no disguised entreaty; it is the counsel of a friend.The exchange of souls can take place only between persons who are resolved to hide nothing from each other.Would you show yourself for such as you are to an unknown man?I dare not follow out the consequences of that idea.

第一章 木屋: 小姐，请您屈尊接受我们对所有女性的敬意，哪怕是那些不知姓名且戴着面具的女性。
Chapter I The Chalet: Deign to accept, mademoiselle, the homage which we owe to all women, even those who are disguised and masked.

第一章 木屋: 这就是那封信，她一整天都把它贴身放在胸衣里，让它紧贴着怦怦跳动的心！她一直等到午夜才读这封信，思潮起伏、热切不安地等所有人睡着，等那庄严的寂静降临。为此，她还事先为诗人祈祷，在打开信之前已经（在想象中）把它读了上千遍。她想象过各种情形，唯独没想到的是这样一瓢冷水竟浇在了她那缥缈的幻想之上，并像氢氰酸腐蚀生命那样。将其溶解了。她除了吹熄蜡烛、缩进被子、把脸埋在床单里痛哭流泪，还能干什么呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: So this was the letter she had worn between her flesh and her corset above her palpitating heart throughout one whole day!For this she had postponed the reading until the midnight hour when the household slept, waiting for the solemn silence with the eager anxiety of an imagination on fire!For this she had blessed the poet by anticipation, reading a thousand letters ere she opened one,—fancying all things, except this drop of cold water falling upon the vaporous forms of her illusion, and dissolving them as prussic acid dissolves life.What could she do but hide herself in her bed, blow out her candle, bury her face in the sheets and weep?

第一章 木屋: 这一切都发生在七月初。但莫黛斯特一会儿就站了起来，她走过房间，并打开了窗户。她想透透气。鲜花的芳香，伴着夜晚的各种清新气息扑鼻而来。被月光点亮的大海如明镜一样闪闪发光。一只夜莺正在树上歌唱。“啊，那就是诗人！”莫黛斯特想，她的怒气立刻平息下来了。心酸的思虑在她的脑海里互相追逐着。她被伤到痛处了，她想把信再读一遍，便点亮了蜡烛。她研究了那些经过深思熟虑写下的字句，直到听到外面世界的呼吸声。
Chapter I The Chalet: All this happened during the first days of July.But Modeste presently got up, walked across the room and opened the window.She wanted air.The fragrance of the flowers came to her with the peculiar freshness of the odors of the night.The sea, lighted by the moon, sparkled like a mirror.A nightingale was singing in a tree.“Ah, there is the poet!” thought Modeste, whose anger subsided at once.Bitter reflections chased each other through her mind.She was cut to the quick; she wished to re-read the letter, and lit a candle; she studied the sentences so carefully studied when written; and ended by hearing the wheezing voice of the outer world.

第一章 木屋: “他是对的，而我错了。”她自言自语道，“但谁又会相信，在那位诗人光鲜的外表之下，我竟看到了莫里哀笔下的一位老者呢？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “He is right, and I am wrong,” she said to herself.“But who could ever believe that under the starry mantle of a poet I should find nothing but one of Moliere’s old men?”

第一章 木屋: 当一个女人或少女在犯罪时“当场被捕”，她会对目击者、肇事者或受害者恨之入骨。于是在真实的、率直的、桀骜不驯的莫黛斯特内心，产生了一种难以抑制的欲望，她想要战胜那位正直的人，将他置于某种致命的矛盾之中，这样便可以牙还牙。这位女孩，这个孩子——我们可以这样叫她，本是如此纯洁，她的大脑被误导了，一部分是由于她的阅读，一部分是由于她姐姐的苦难，而或许更多地是由于她在枯燥无味的生活中那危险的沉思——突然，一缕阳光掠过她的脸庞。她已经在这广阔的“怀疑”之海的岸边站了三个小时。这样的夜晚是终身难忘的。莫黛斯特径直走向她那张小小的中式桌子，那是她父亲送她的礼物。在那颗怦怦跳动的少女复仇之心的驱使下，写了一封信。
Chapter I The Chalet: When a woman or young girl is taken in the act, “flagrante delicto,” she conceives a deadly hatred to the witness, the author, or the object of her fault.And so the true, the single-minded, the untamed and untamable Modeste conceived within her soul an unquenchable desire to get the better of that righteous spirit, to drive him into some fatal inconsistency, and so return him blow for blow.This girl, this child, as we may call her, so pure, whose head alone had been misguided,—partly by her reading, partly by her sister’s sorrows, and more perhaps by the dangerous meditations of her solitary life,—was suddenly caught by a ray of sunshine flickering across her face.She had been standing for three hours on the shores of the vast sea of Doubt.Nights like these are never forgotten.Modeste walked straight to her little Chinese table, a gift from her father, and wrote a letter dictated by the infernal spirit of vengeance which palpitates in the hearts of young girls.

第一章 木屋: 先生，您自然是一位伟大的诗人，而且还是一位正直之士。您对一位差点踏入深渊的少女表现得如此真诚直率，那您是否也能毫不虚伪、开诚布公地回答下面这个问题呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: Monsieur,—You are certainly a great poet, and you are something more,—an honest man.After showing such loyal frankness to a young girl who was stepping to the verge of an abyss, have you enough left to answer without hypocrisy or evasion the following question?

Chapter I The Chalet: Would you have written the letter I now hold in answer to mine,—would your ideas, your language have been the same,—had some one whispered in your ear (what may prove true), Mademoiselle O. d’Este M. has six millions and does intend to have a dunce for a master?

第一章 木屋: 暂且认为这一假设成立吧。请您像对自己一样对我吧，什么都不要怕。我只有二十岁，但心智却不止二十，任何坦率之举都不会损害您在我心里的形象。当我从您的回信中读出您对我的信任时——如果您肯屈尊这样做——您会得到我对您第一封信的答复。
Chapter I The Chalet: Admit the supposition for a moment.Be with me what you are with yourself; fear nothing.I am wiser than my twenty years; nothing that is frank can hurt you in my mind.When I have read your confidence, if you deign to make it, you shall receive from me an answer to your first letter.

第一章 木屋: 我一直敬仰您的才华，它总是如此地令人赞叹。请允许我向您的细心和真诚致敬，这让我一直都是，
Chapter I The Chalet: Having admired your talent, often so sublime, permit me to do homage to your delicacy and your integrity, which force me to remain always,

第一章 木屋: 您卑微的仆人，欧·德埃斯特·莫
Chapter I The Chalet: Your humble servant, O. d’Este M.

第一章 木屋: 埃内斯特·德拉布里埃把信拿在手里，过了一会儿，便沿着林阴道散步去了。当风从四面吹来，他心乱如麻，仿佛一叶扁舟在暴风雨中摇曳。大部分年轻人，特别是真正的巴黎人，会用一句话解决这件事：“这个女孩有点轻佻。”但对于一个心灵高贵且真诚的年轻人来说，这种努力可以说是一种对真理的呼唤，唤醒了藏在每个人的良心深处的三位法官，让他忍不住立下誓言。荣誉、真理和正义站了起来，以他们的各种方式积极地呼喊。
Chapter I The Chalet: When Ernest de La Briere had held this letter in his hands for some little time he went to walk along the boulevards, tossed in mind like a tiny vessel by a tempest when the wind is blowing from all points of the compass.Most young men, specially true Parisians, would have settled the matter in a single phrase, “The girl is a little hussy.”But for a youth whose soul was noble and true, this attempt to put him, as it were, upon his oath, this appeal to truth, had the power to awaken the three judges hidden in the conscience of every man.Honor, Truth, and Justice, getting on their feet, cried out in their several ways energetically.

Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle,—You are not a D’Este.The name is a feigned one to conceal your own.Do I owe the revelations which you solicit to a person who is untruthful about herself?Question for question:Are you of an illustrious family? or a noble family? or a middle-class family?Undoubtedly ethics and morality cannot change; they are one: but obligations vary in the different states of life.Just as the sun lights up a scene diversely and produces differences which we admire, so morality conforms social duty to rank, to position.The peccadillo of a soldier is a crime in a general, and vice-versa.Observances are not alike in all cases.They are not the same for the gleaner in the field, for the girl who sews at fifteen sous a day, for the daughter of a petty shopkeeper, for the young bourgoise, for the child of a rich merchant, for the heiress of a noble family, for a daughter of the house of Este.A king must not stoop to pick up a piece of gold, but a laborer ought to retrace his steps to find ten sous; though both are equally bound to obey the laws of economy.A daughter of Este, who is worth six millions, has the right to wear a broad-brimmed hat and plume, to flourish her whip, press the flanks of her barb, and ride like an amazon decked in gold lace, with a lackey behind her, into the presence of a poet and say: “I love poetry; and I would fain expiate Leonora’s cruelty to Tasso!” but a daughter of the people would cover herself with ridicule by imitating her.To what class do you belong?Answer sincerely, and I will answer the question you have put to me.
