Chapter I The Chalet: Ah! you poor women of France, try to remain hidden if you can; try to weave the least little romance about your lives in the midst of a civilization which posts in the public streets the hours when the coaches arrive and depart; which counts all letters and stamps them twice over, first with the hour when they are thrown into the boxes, and next with that of their delivery; which numbers the houses, prints the tax of every tenant on a metal register at the doors (after verifying its particulars), and will soon possess one vast register of every inch of its territory down to the smallest parcel of land, and the most insignificant features of it,—a giant work ordained by a giant.Try, imprudent young ladies, to escape not only the eye of the police, but the incessant chatter which takes place in a country town about the veriest trifles,—how many dishes the prefect has at his dessert, how many slices of melon are left at the door of some small householder,—which strains its ear to catch the chink of the gold a thrifty man lays by, and spends its evenings in calculating the incomes of the village and the town and the department.It was mere chance that enabled Modeste to escape discovery through Ernest’s reconnoitring expedition,—a step which he already regretted; but what Parisian can allow himself to be the dupe of a little country girl?Incapable of being duped! that horrid maxim is the dissolvent of all noble sentiments in man.

第一章 木屋: 小姐：坦白讲，没错，如果我确定您家财万贯的话，我的表现必定有所不同。为什么呢？我找了找原因，是这样的。在我们的内心有一种与生俱来的情感，这种情感因社交生活而过度膨胀，促使我们去追求和占有幸福。大部分人将幸福和获得幸福的方法混为一谈，在他们眼里，金钱是幸福的首要因素。因此，我受到那种在所有时代都把财富当作信仰的社会情感所驱使，便会不遗余力地想要赢得您的芳心。至少我认为我会那样做。您不能指望一个年轻男人拥有如此的智慧，为了良知放弃感官的快乐。相反，看到猎物时，人内心隐藏的野性会驱使着他前进。如果我知道您很富有，我就不会那样教训您，而是会说一些恭维和奉承的话。我那样做还能赢得尊重吗？我表示怀疑。小姐，在那种情况下，成功可以免除罪过，但幸福呢？那就是另外一回事了。如果我以那样的方式赢得了妻子，我还能信任她吗？几乎可以肯定地说，我会再信任她了。您之于我的优势迟早会离间我们。您的丈夫，不管您把他想象得多么伟大，最后都会责备您让他蒙羞了。您自己迟早也会瞧不起他的。坚强的人会宽恕，但诗人会哀嚎。小姐，这就是我出于真诚而不得不对您作出的答复。
Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle,—Without hypocrisy or evasion, yes, if I had been certain that you possessed an immense fortune I should have acted differently.Why? I have searched for the reason; here it is.We have within us an inborn feeling, inordinately developed by social life, which drives us to the pursuit and to the possession of happiness.Most men confound happiness with the means that lead to it; money in their eyes is the chief element of happiness.I should, therefore, have endeavored to win you, prompted by that social sentiment which has in all ages made wealth a religion.At least, I think I should.It is not to be expected of a man still young that he can have the wisdom to substitute sound sense for the pleasure of the senses; within sight of a prey the brutal instincts hidden in the heart of man drive him on.Instead of that lesson, I should have sent you compliments and flatteries.Should I have kept my own esteem in so doing?I doubt it.Mademoiselle, in such a case success brings absolution; but happiness?That is another thing.Should I have distrusted my wife had I won her in that way?Most assuredly I should.Your advance on me would sooner or later have come between us.Your husband, however grand your fancy may make him, would have ended by reproaching you for having abased him.You, yourself, might have come, sooner or later, to despise him.The strong man forgives, but the poet whines.Such, mademoiselle, is the answer which my honesty compels me to make to you.

第一章 木屋: 现在，请听我说。您已经成功地迫使我深刻反省了——首先是对还不够熟悉的您，其次是对我自己也了解甚少的自己。您搅动了我内心许多隐藏的、人人都有的邪恶思想，但它们又生发出一些美好、善良的想法。所以，我向您致以我最热烈的赞美，就像在海上我们赞美灯塔一样，因为它为我们指明礁石，让我们免于遇险。这就是我要坦白的事情，因为就算拿世界上所有的财富交换，我都不会放弃您对我的尊敬，也不会放弃我对您的尊敬。
Chapter I The Chalet: And now, listen to me.You have the triumph of forcing me to reflect deeply,—first on you, whom I do not sufficiently know; next, on myself, of whom I knew too little.You have had the power to stir up many of the evil thoughts which crouched in my heart, as in all hearts; but from them something good and generous has come forth, and I salute you with my most fervent benedictions, just as at sea we salute the lighthouse which shows the rocks on which we were about to perish.Here is my confession, for I would not lose your esteem nor my own for all the treasures of earth.

第一章 木屋: 我期待着知道您的真实身份。我刚从勒阿弗尔回来，在那儿，我看到了弗朗索瓦丝·科歇，并跟着她到了安古维尔。您跟诗人所梦想的女人一样漂亮，但我不知道您是隐身于德埃鲁维尔小姐之后的维尔坎小姐，还是隐身于维尔坎小姐之后的德埃鲁维尔小姐。尽管在战场上采取任何手段都不为过，我还是为这样的窥探行为感到脸红，所以马上就停止了打听。您激起了我的好奇心。原谅我有点儿女人气，我相信，那是诗人的特权。
Chapter I The Chalet: I wished to know who you are.I have just returned from Havre, where I saw Francoise Cochet, and followed her to Ingouville.You are as beautiful as the woman of a poet’s dream; but I do not know if you are Mademoiselle Vilquin concealed under Mademoiselle d’Herouville, or Mademoiselle d’Herouville hidden under Mademoiselle Vilquin.Though all is fair in war, I blushed at such spying and stopped short in my inquiries.You have roused my curiosity; forgive me for being somewhat of a woman; it is, I believe, the privilege of a poet.

第一章 木屋: 既然我已经敞开了我的心扉，让您解读，那么您会相信，我下面要补充的话也是真诚的。尽管我对您只有匆匆一瞥，但这已足以改变我对您的行为的看法。您不仅仅是一位女子，您更像一个诗人，像一首诗。是的，您身上有着比美貌更宝贵的东西，您是艺术的理想美，是梦幻的理想美。一位甘于接受平庸命运的平凡少女作出您这样的举动，是要受到指责的。但如果她有我在您身上发现的那种天性，那就另说了。在那些被命运抛入这个星球的一代芸芸众生之中，总有一些独特的灵魂。如果您不甘于习俗对妇女命运的束缚，把您漫长的、富有诗意的幻想写在了这封信中；如果您被您高贵而聪明的头脑里的冲动驱使着，想要了解一个被您称作天才的男人的生活，并最终同一颗与您心灵相交的心灵建立起一种非比寻常的友谊，全然不顾世俗对您性别的束缚，那么，您肯定就是一个例外了。那么，限制着大众行为的合理法则对您来说也太狭隘了。但如果是这样，就更有力地印证了我第一封信里的话——您要不是做得太过了，要不就是做得还不够。
Chapter I The Chalet: Now that I have laid bare my heart and allowed you to read it, you will believe in the sincerity of what I am about to add.Though the glimpse I had of you was all too rapid, it has sufficed to modify my opinion of your conduct.You are a poet and a poem, even more than you are a woman.Yes, there is in you something more precious than beauty; you are the beautiful Ideal of art, of fancy.The step you took, blamable as it would be in an ordinary young girl, allotted to an every-day destiny, has another aspect if endowed with the nature which I now attribute to you.Among the crowd of beings flung by fate into the social life of this planet to make up a generation there are exceptional souls.If your letter is the outcome of long poetic reveries on the fate which conventions bring to women, if, constrained by the impulse of a lofty and intelligent mind, you have wished to understand the life of a man to whom you attribute the gift of genius, to the end that you may create a friendship withdrawn from the ordinary relations of life, with a soul in communion with your own, disregarding thus the ordinary trammels of your sex,—then, assuredly, you are an exception.The law which rightly limits the actions of the crowd is too limited for you.But in that case, the remark in my first letter returns in greater force,—you have done too much or not enough.

第一章 木屋: 您给了我帮助，迫使我去聆听自己的心声，请再次接受我对您的谢意。在法国有一个很普遍的谬论——婚姻应该是获得财富的一种方式，而您却纠正了我心中的这一错误观点。当我同良知进行斗争时，我听到一个神圣的声音呼唤着我。我庄重地发誓，要自己创造财富，在选择人生伴侣时不为种种贪婪的动机所左右。我还为您在我心里唤起的那该死的好奇心而自责。您没有六百万。在勒阿弗尔，拥有这样一笔财富的少女是不可能藏得住的；您立刻就会被成群结队的家世显赫的追求者发现，我看到他们在巴黎四处追求女继承人，而且已经派了一位显赫的王室侍从——一位年轻的公爵，到维尔坎府上去了。因此，相信我，我现在所表达的情感是抛开了所有浪漫或者现实的影响、在我脑海中形成的一个固定的生活准则。因此，请您像对待我第一封信那样，来理解并领会这封信的精神，以此向我证明，您有一颗即使违背了常规准则也值得被原谅的心灵。如果您注定是要过一种中产阶级的生活，就请遵守那将社会凝聚在一起的铁律吧。如果您的思想高于其他女性，那我赞赏您；但如果您屈从了您本应该压抑的冲动，那我同情您！伟大的家庭史诗《克拉丽莎·哈洛》里那绝妙的道德教训就是：正是那合情合理而又让人敬佩的爱情，让那可怜的受害者走向灭亡，因为那爱情是在家庭束缚的界限之外被构建、发展和追寻的。不管克拉丽莎的家庭多么残酷，甚至是愚蠢，它反对洛夫莱斯那样的浪子都是有道理的。家庭就是社会。请相信我，一位少女的荣誉，一位妇女的荣誉，必定在于总是将她最热烈的激情抑制在惯例允许的狭小限度内。如果我有一个女儿会成为德斯塔埃尔夫人那样的人，那我情愿她十五岁就死掉。假如您的女儿在名利场上百般炫耀，通过显露自己来博得众人的喝彩，一想到这里，难道您不会觉得痛苦吗？不管一个女人灵魂深处的诗意能够让她达到怎样的高度，她都必须在家庭的圣餐台上牺牲掉外在的优越。她的激情，她的天才，她对善的向往，一个女孩的全部诗情，都应该属于她所接受的男人，以及她带到这个世界上来的孩子。我想我在您身上看到了一种隐秘的欲望，您想要拓宽那束缚了所有女人的狭小的生活圈，并把爱情和激情注入到婚姻当中。啊！那是一个多么美丽的梦想啊！它不是没有可能的，只是会比较困难，但即使它实现了，在那些平庸之辈的眼里，它不也是——请原谅我用这个陈腐的字眼——“不可理喻”的吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: Accept once more my thanks for the service you have rendered me, that of compelling me to sound my heart.You have corrected in me the false idea, only too common in France, that marriage should be a means of fortune.While I struggled with my conscience a sacred voice spoke to me.I swore solemnly to make my fortune myself, and not be led by motives of cupidity in choosing the companion of my life.I have also reproached myself for the blamable curiosity you have excited in me.You have not six millions.There is no concealment possible in Havre for a young lady who possesses such a fortune; you would be discovered at once by the pack of hounds of great families whom I see in Paris on the hunt after heiresses, and who have already sent one, the grand equerry, the young duke, among the Vilquins.Therefore, believe me, the sentiments I have now expressed are fixed in my mind as a rule of life, from which I have abstracted all influences of romance or of actual fact.Prove to me, therefore, that you have one of those souls which may be forgiven for its disobedience to the common law, by perceiving and comprehending the spirit of this letter as you did that of my first letter.If you are destined to a middle-class life, obey the iron law which holds society together.Lifted in mind above other women, I admire you; but if you seek to obey an impulse which you ought to repress, I pity you.The all-wise moral of that great domestic epic “Clarissa Harlowe” is that legitimate and honorable love led the poor victim to her ruin because it was conceived, developed, and pursued beyond the boundaries of family restraint.The family, however cruel and even foolish it may be, is in the right against the Lovelaces.The family is Society.Believe me, the glory of a young girl, of a woman, must always be that of repressing her most ardent impulses within the narrow sphere of conventions.If I had a daughter able to become a Madame de Stael I should wish her dead at fifteen.Can you imagine a daughter of yours flaunting on the stage of fame, exhibiting herself to win the plaudits of a crowd, and not suffer anguish at the thought?No matter to what heights a woman can rise by the inward poetry of her soul, she must sacrifice the outer signs of superiority on the altar of her home.Her impulse, her genius, her aspirations toward Good, the whole poem of a young girl’s being, should belong to the man she accepts and the children whom she brings into the world.I think I perceive in you a secret desire to widen the narrow circle of the life to which all women are condemned, and to put love and passion into marriage.Ah! it is a lovely dream! it is not impossible; it is difficult, but if realized, may it not be to the despair of souls—forgive me the hackneyed word—“incompris”?

第一章 木屋: 如果您试图寻找一种柏拉图式的友谊，那以后它将会成为您的遗憾。如果您的信只是一个玩笑，请不要再写了。也许这个小小的浪漫故事会就此结束——是吗？它也还是有些成果的。我的责任感已被唤起了，而从您那方面讲，您已经学到了一些社交界的经验。把您的思想转回到真实生活中去吧，把您从文学中提取的激情注入到您女性的美德当中去吧。
Chapter I The Chalet: If you seek a platonic friendship it will be to your sorrow in after years.If your letter was a jest, discontinue it.Perhaps this little romance is to end here—is it?It has not been without fruit.My sense of duty is aroused, and you, on your side, will have learned something of Society.Turn your thoughts to real life; throw the enthusiasms you have culled from literature into the virtues of your sex.

第一章 木屋: 别了，小姐。请您尊重我吧，这是我的荣幸。见过了您——或者说见过了一个我自认为是您的人，我已经知道了您的来信是浑然天成的；一朵如此美丽的花朵转向了太阳——诗歌的太阳。是的，像爱鲜花、爱音乐、爱大海的壮阔、爱大自然的美丽那样去热爱诗歌吧，把它们当作心灵的饰品去爱吧，但是，请记住我有幸跟您讲过的诗人的品性。请当心，像您所说的那样，不要嫁给一个蠢材，要去试图寻找上帝为您创造的伴侣。请相信我，总会有人懂得欣赏您，并让您幸福。如果我很富有，如果您很贫穷，我愿意将我的心和我的财富都放到您的脚下，因为我相信您的心灵充满了宝藏和忠诚，我可以绝对放心地把我的生命和荣誉都交给您。
Chapter I The Chalet: Adieu, mademoiselle.Do me the honor to grant me your esteem.Having seen you, or one whom I believe to be you, I have known that your letter was simply natural; a flower so lovely turns to the sun—of poetry.Yes, love poetry as you love flowers, music, the grandeur of the sea, the beauties of nature; love them as an adornment of the soul, but remember what I have had the honor of telling you as to the nature of poets.Be cautious not to marry, as you say, a dunce, but seek the partner whom God has made for you.There are souls, believe me, who are fit to appreciate you, and to make you happy.If I were rich, if you were poor, I would lay my heart and my fortunes at your feet; for I believe your soul to be full of riches and of loyalty; to you I could confide my life and my honor in absolute security.

第一章 木屋: 再一次，再会了，再会了，金发夏娃最美丽的女儿。
Chapter I The Chalet: Once more, adieu, adieu, fairest daughter of Eve the fair.

第一章 木屋: 读了这封信，就像是在沙漠中饮下一滴甘泉，压在莫黛斯特心头的沉重的大山被举了起来：接着，她便看到了制定计划时所犯的错误，于是便改变了计划。她给了弗朗索瓦丝一些信封，地址是她自己的，这位仆人可以把从巴黎寄来的信放到信封里，然后再放到邮箱里。莫黛斯特决定收到来信时，亲自到木屋门口去迎接邮递员。
Chapter I The Chalet: The reading of this letter, swallowed like a drop of water in the desert, lifted the mountain which weighed heavily on Modeste’s heart: then she saw the mistake she had made in arranging her plan, and repaired it by giving Francoise some envelopes directed to herself, in which the maid could put the letters which came from Paris and drop them again into the box.Modeste resolved to receive the postman herself on the steps of the Chalet at the hour when he made his delivery.

第一章 木屋: 这封回信中，在卡那利光彩照人的幻象背后是可怜的拉布里埃的高贵心灵在跳动，它在莫黛斯特内心激起了五味杂陈、莫可名状的情感，如岸边更迭消涨的海浪。此刻，莫黛斯特凝望着广阔的大海，她在巴黎这片大海洋中捕获了一颗天使般的心灵，她发现高贵的心灵仍然可以与天才和谐共存，还有，最重要的是，她跟随了直觉的魔力之音，这一切大概都让她沉浸在喜悦之中。
Chapter I The Chalet: As to the feelings that this reply, in which the noble heart of poor La Briere beat beneath the brilliant phantom of Canalis, excited in Modeste, they were as multifarious and confused as the waves which rushed to die along the shore while with her eyes fixed on the wide ocean she gave herself up to the joy of having (if we dare say so) harpooned an angelic soul in the Parisian Gulf, of having divined that hearts of price might still be found in harmony with genius, and, above all, for having followed the magic voice of intuition.

第一章 木屋: 一股强大的动力即将赋予她的生命以生气。她牢笼的铁栅栏被打破了：这座漂亮木屋的门闩和插销——它们哪儿去了？她的思想插上了翅膀。
Chapter I The Chalet: A vast interest was now about to animate her life.The wires of her cage were broken: the bolts and bars of the pretty Chalet—where were they?Her thoughts took wings.

第一章 木屋: “啊，父亲！”她向外面的地平线望去，大声喊道，“回来吧，让我们富有，让我们幸福吧。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh, father!” she cried, looking out to the horizon.“Come back and make us rich and happy.”

第一章 木屋: 埃内斯特·德拉布里埃五天后收到的回信将会让读者了解到比任何详尽的专题论文还要多的东西。
Chapter I The Chalet: The answer which Ernest de La Briere received some five days later will tell the reader more than any elaborate disquisition of ours.

第一章 木屋: 第九章 隐形的力量
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter IX The Power of the Unseen

第一章 木屋: 致德卡纳利先生：
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis:

第一章 木屋: 我的朋友——请允许我这样称呼您——您让我欣喜不已；我真希望您正是这封信里所描绘的那样一个人，这是我第一次如此欣喜——哦，希望它不是最后一次！除了一位诗人，还会有谁能够如此细心周到地原谅并理解一位少女呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: My friend,—Suffer me to give you that name,—you have delighted me; I would not have you other than you are in this letter, the first—oh, may it not be the last!Who but a poet could have excused and understood a young girl so delicately?

第一章 木屋: 您来信的开头几行写得那么真诚，我愿意以同样的真诚与您交谈。首先，我要说，最幸运的是您并不认识我。我可以很高兴地向您保证，我既不是那个奇丑无比的维尔坎小姐，也不是那个极其高贵却形容枯槁的德埃鲁维尔小姐，她的年龄介于二十和四十之间，尚不能决定一次令人满意的约会。德埃鲁维尔红衣主教在教会历史上的辉煌，至少要比我们引以为唯一家族荣誉的红衣主教早上一个世纪——我说他是唯一的荣誉，是因为没有把中将，以及写了些中看不中用的小本杂诗集的修道院院长这类人算进去。
Chapter I The Chalet: I wish to speak with the sincerity that dictated the first lines of your letter.And first, let me say that most fortunately you do not know me.I can joyfully assure you than I am neither that hideous Mademoiselle Vilquin nor the very noble and withered Mademoiselle d’Herouville who floats between twenty and forty years of age, unable to decide on a satisfactory date.The Cardinal d’Herouville flourished in the history of the Church at least a century before the cardinal of whom we boast as our only family glory,—for I take no account of lieutenant-generals, and abbes who write trumpery little verses.

第一章 木屋: 还有，我不是住在华丽的维尔坎别墅里，感谢上帝，在我的血管里，连千万分之一滴那流淌在柜台背后冰冷的血液也没有。我有一半德国血统，一半法国南部血统，我的头脑同日耳曼人一样爱幻想，血液里又有着普罗旺斯人的活泼。从我父母两方面来看，我都有贵族血统。从母亲那一边来看，我与《欧洲王族家谱年鉴》的每一页都有关系。简言之，我的防范措施做得很好。以任何人的能力，甚至以法律的力量，都无法揭开我隐姓埋名的神秘面纱。我将继续隐姓埋名、不为人知。
Chapter I The Chalet: Moreover, I do not live in the magnificent villa Vilquin; there is not in my veins, thank God, the ten-millionth of a drop of that chilly blood which flows behind a counter.I come on one side from Germany, on the other from the south of France; my mind has a Teutonic love of reverie, my blood the vivacity of Provence.I am noble on my father’s and on my mother’s side.On my mother’s I derive from every page of the Almanach de Gotha.In short, my precautions are well taken.It is not in any man’s power, nor even in the power of the law, to unmask my incognito.I shall remain veiled, unknown.

第一章 木屋: 至于我的人格，还有诺曼人所讲的“个人财产”，请您放心好了。我至少同您那次拜访勒阿弗尔途中偶然看到的小姑娘（天真烂漫的她感到很幸福）一样漂亮；而且，虽然我散步时没有十个贵族之子伴我左右，我也不会认为自己是贫困潦倒之辈。我看过那些人为我上演的为人不齿的滑稽剧，不过是为了追求女继承人的百万家产。简言之，不要试图接近我，哪怕是同别人打赌。唉！尽管我像空气一样自由，但还是被监视和保护着——首先是被我自己，其次是被那些神经过敏且勇气十足的人们，如果您试图进入我的隐居处，他们会毫不犹豫地把刀刺进您的心脏。我说这些，不是为了激起您的勇气，或者激发您的好奇心。我相信，我不需要用这种刺激使您对我产生兴趣，让您爱上我。
Chapter I The Chalet: As to my person and as to my “belongings,” as the Normans say, make yourself easy.I am at least as handsome as the little girl (ignorantly happy) on whom your eyes chanced to light during your visit to Havre; and I do not call myself poverty-stricken, although ten sons of peers may not accompany me on my walks.I have seen the humiliating comedy of the heiress sought for her millions played on my account.In short, make no attempt, even on a wager, to reach me.Alas! though free as air, I am watched and guarded,—by myself, in the first place, and secondly, by people of nerve and courage who would not hesitate to put a knife in your heart if you tried to penetrate my retreat.I do not say this to excite your courage or stimulate your curiosity; I believe I have no need of such incentives to interest you and attach you to me.

第一章 木屋: 您的第一场说教在您的第二个版本中又大大地扩展了，我现在便就此作出回复。
Chapter I The Chalet: I will now reply to the second edition, considerably enlarged, of your first sermon.

第一章 木屋: 您希望我坦白吗？我看到您如此不信任我，并错把我当作科琳娜式的人物（其实我觉得她的那些即兴创作相当无聊），我便对自己说，很有可能是一群缪斯把轻率好奇的您带到了她们的圣谷之中，并请求您品尝她们的宿地帕那塞斯山的水果。啊，我的朋友！您跟我在一起是绝对安全的，我是热爱诗歌，但我的袖珍笔记本里没有短篇诗歌，而且我的长袜现在是、将来也永远是洁白无暇的。您将不会为一卷或者更多卷的《我心中的鲜花》而烦恼。最后，假若我哪天对您说了句“过来吧！”您现在知道了，您将不会看到一个老姑娘，不会的，也不会是一个又穷又丑的姑娘。
Chapter I The Chalet: Will you have a confession?I said to myself when I saw you so distrustful, and mistaking me for Corinne (whose improvisations bore me dreadfully), that in all probability dozes of Muses had already led you, rashly curious, into their valleys, and begged you to taste the fruits of their boarding-school Parnassus.Oh! you are perfectly safe with me, my friend; I may love poetry, but I have no little verses in my pocket-book, and my stockings are, and will remain, immaculately white.You shall not be pestered with the “Flowers of my Heart” in one or more volumes.And, finally, should it ever happen that I say to you the word “Come!” you will not find—you know it now—an old maid, no, nor a poor and ugly one.

第一章 木屋: 啊！我的朋友，您不知道，我对您跑到勒阿弗尔来感到多么遗憾！您已减少了您口中我的浪漫故事的魅力了。一个足够高贵、足够令人信任，且足够敏锐的男人——信赖我的信件，一步一步地走进我的心灵深处——怀着孩童般的单纯来赴我们的第一次约会，只有上帝才知道我为这样的男人所预留的财富，因为那样才符合我梦想中天才男人的天真纯朴。而现在，您已经损坏了我的财富！但我原谅您，您住在巴黎，而且，如您所说，诗人的内心也和普通男人一样。
Chapter I The Chalet: Ah! my friend, if you only knew how I regret that you came to Havre!You have lowered the charm of what you call my romance.God alone knew the treasure I was reserving for the man noble enough, and trusting enough, and perspicacious enough to come—having faith in my letters, having penetrated step by step into the depths of my heart—to come to our first meeting with the simplicity of a child: for that was what I dreamed to be the innocence of a man of genius.And now you have spoiled my treasure!But I forgive you; you live in Paris and, as you say, there is always a man within a poet.

第一章 木屋: 我告诉您这些，您会不会因此把我当作一个小女孩，在自己的花园里种满幻想呢？您，机智聪明的您，难道没有猜到，当德埃斯特小姐收到您那封迂腐的说教信时，她对自己说：“不，亲爱的诗人，我的第一封信不是一个游手好闲的小孩扔出去用来吓唬附近果树主人的小石子，而是一位坐在海中之石上的渔夫小心谨慎撒下的渔网，期望并等待着一次奇迹的收获。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Because I tell you this will you think me some little girl who cultivates a garden-full of illusions?You, who are witty and wise, have you not guessed that when Mademoiselle d’Este received your pedantic lesson she said to herself: “No, dear poet, my first letter was not the pebble which a vagabond child flings about the highway to frighten the owner of the adjacent fruit-trees, but a net carefully and prudently thrown by a fisherman seated on a rock above the sea, hoping and expecting a miraculous draught.”

第一章 木屋: 您所有有关家庭的美好说法，我都赞同。能够取悦我，而我又认为配得上我的男子，定会得到我的真心、我的生命。当然，这也需要我的父母同意才行，因为我既不会让他们伤心，也不会让他们毫不知情，幸运的是，我确信我能够左右他们，况且他们没有丝毫的偏见。的确，我觉得自己在各方面被保护得很好，我的梦想不含任何错觉。我已经用自己的双手建起了堡垒，而且还让那些视我如珍宝、无比忠诚地守护着我的人们把这座堡垒加固了。这倒不是说我在必要的时候不能公开保护自己，因为——这样说吧，境遇已经给我提供了一身防卫的盔甲，上面刻上了“蔑视”这个词。我对于一切精于算计的人和事——一切不纯洁、不公正，以及不是绝对高贵的人和事，都有着最深的痛恨。我崇拜美好的、理想的事物，却绝不空想，尽管在我内心深处，在我的梦中，我曾很爱空想。但我认清了很多事情的真相，甚至包括您给我讲过的那些社会及社交生活中的丑事。
Chapter I The Chalet: All that you say so beautifully about the family has my approval.The man who is able to please me, and of whom I believe myself worthy, will have my heart and my life,—with the consent of my parents, for I will neither grieve them, nor take them unawares: happily, I am certain of reigning over them; and, besides, they are wholly without prejudice.Indeed, in every way, I feel myself protected against any delusions in my dream.I have built the fortress with my own hands, and I have let it be fortified by the boundless devotion of those who watch over me as if I were a treasure,—not that I am unable to defend myself in the open, if need be; for, let me say, circumstances have furnished me with armor of proof on which is engraved the word “Disdain.”I have the deepest horror of all that is calculating,—of all that is not pure, disinterested, and wholly noble.I worship the beautiful, the ideal, without being romantic; though I HAVE been, in my heart of hearts, in my dreams.But I recognize the truth of the various things, just even to vulgarity, which you have written me about Society and social life.

第一章 木屋: 目前，我们还是，也只能是朋友。为什么要找一个看不见的朋友呢？您会问。我可能不认识您本人，但您的思想，您的心灵，我是知道的，它们让我感到快乐，而且我内心深处涌出了无穷无尽的想法，需要一个天才的男子做它们的知己。我不希望我内心的诗情被浪费掉，我会让它被您所知，就像它被上帝所知一样。一个真正的密友是多么珍贵啊，我们可以向他吐露一切！当一位少女思绪中从未公开过的片段飘向您，就像美丽的虫子拍打着翅膀飞向太阳，您肯定不会拒绝吧？我可以肯定，您之前从未碰到过这样美好的心灵财富——一位诚实女孩的诚实的知心话。请您倾听她天真无邪的絮语吧，请您接受她内心为您吟唱的歌曲吧。日后，如果我们的心灵结成了伴侣，如果我们的性情许可了我们的尝试，一位白发老仆将会在路边等您，并带您到一座别墅，一座真正的别墅，一座城堡，一座宫殿——我现在还不知道它会是什么样式、什么颜色，甚至不知道这一结论是否可能，但您会承认那一幕是富有诗意的，德埃斯特小姐也有着顺从的天性，对吗？她不是把自由留给了您吗？她猜疑过您，到巴黎的沙龙里去观察过您吗？她有没有将古时候游侠们自愿去探寻的那种高风险任务强加给您呢？没有，她想要的是一种精神上的、神秘的完美结合。当您不高兴了、受伤了、疲惫了，请到我这儿来吧。告诉我一切吧，什么都不要隐瞒，对于您所有的病痛，我都有镇痛香膏。亲爱的朋友，我年方二十，但我感觉自己有五十岁，而且，不幸的是，通过另一个人的经历，我已经领悟到了爱情所有的恐怖和快乐。我知道人心能藏匿怎样的卑鄙和丑恶，然而我自己是个坦诚的女孩。不，我没有任何幻想；但我有一些更好的东西，一些真实的东西——我有一些信念和一种信仰。您看！我已经开始与您倾心交谈了。
Chapter I The Chalet: For the time being we are, and we can only be, two friends.Why seek an unseen friend? you ask.Your person may be unknown to me, but your mind, your heart I know; they please me, and I feel an infinitude of thoughts within my soul which need a man of genius for their confidant.I do not wish the poem of my heart to be wasted; I would have it known to you as it is to God.What a precious thing is a true comrade, one to whom we can tell all!You will surely not reject the unpublished leaflets of a young girl’s thoughts when they fly to you like the pretty insects fluttering to the sun?I am sure you have never before met with this good fortune of the soul,—the honest confidences of an honest girl.Listen to her prattle; accept the music that she sings to you in her own heart.Later, if our souls are sisters, if our characters warrant the attempt, a white-haired old serving-man shall await you by the wayside and lead you to the cottage, the villa, the castle, the palace—I don’t know yet what sort of bower it will be, nor what its color, nor whether this conclusion will ever be possible; but you will admit, will you not? that it is poetic, and that Mademoiselle d’Este has a complying disposition.Has she not left you free?Has she gone with jealous feet to watch you in the salons of Paris?Has she imposed upon you the labors of some high emprise, such as paladins sought voluntarily in the olden time?No, she asks a perfectly spiritual and mystic alliance.Come to me when you are unhappy, wounded, weary.Tell me all, hide nothing; I have balms for all your ills.I am twenty years of age, dear friend, but I have the sense of fifty, and unfortunately I have known through the experience of another all the horrors and the delights of love.I know what baseness the human heart can contain, what infamy; yet I myself am an honest girl.No, I have no illusions; but I have something better, something real,—I have beliefs and a religion.See! I open the ball of our confidences.

第一章 木屋: 不管我嫁给谁——前提是我自己选择了他——他都可以安心睡大觉，或者到东印度去玩，回来的时候，他会看到我还在编织他临行前我开始编织的挂毯，而且从每一针每一线中他都可以读到以他为主人公谱写的诗篇。是的，我内心已经决定，永远都不会跟着我的丈夫去他不希望我去的地方。我将是他家里的女神。这就是我的人生信仰。但是，既然我之于这个男人，就如同生命之于身体，那我为什么不考验和挑选一下呢？一个男人会被生活束缚吗？一个会阻碍她所爱的男人的女人，会是什么样的呢？那会是一种疾病，一种病魔，而不是生活。说到生活，我指的是那种能将每时每刻都变成快乐的令人喜悦的健康状态。
Chapter I The Chalet: Whoever I marry—provided I choose him for myself—may sleep in peace or go to the East Indies sure that he will find me on his return working at the tapestry which I began before he left me; and in every stitch he shall read a verse of the poem of which he has been the hero.Yes, I have resolved within my heart never to follow my husband where he does not wish me to go.I will be the divinity of his hearth.That is my religion of humanity.But why should I not test and choose the man to whom I am to be like the life to the body?Is a man ever impeded by life?What can that woman be who thwarts the man she loves?—an illness, a disease, not life.By life, I mean that joyous health which makes each hour a pleasure.

第一章 木屋: 不过话说回来，您的信将永远是我的财富。好了，言归正传，您的信包含着我所渴望的东西，它表达了一种平淡的情感，这种情感之于家庭生活，就像是空气之于肺，是必不可少的，没有了这种情感，就没有什么幸福可言了。像诚实的男人那样行事，像诗人那样思考，像女人恋爱那样去爱，这就是我对朋友的期待，现在，这期待从幻想变成现实了。
Chapter I The Chalet: But to return to your letter, which will always be precious to me.Yes, jesting apart, it contains that which I desired, an expression of prosaic sentiments which are as necessary to family life as air to the lungs; and without which no happiness is possible.To act as an honest man, to think as a poet, to love as women love, that is what I longed for in my friend, and it is now no longer a chimera.

第一章 木屋: 再会了，我的朋友。我现在还很穷。这也是我要坚持隐姓埋名、不肯摘下面具、不肯走出坚不可摧的堡垒的原因之一。我在《讽刺剧》上读到了您最新的诗作——啊！真令人心花怒放，因为我对您灵魂深处的朴实与崇高已经略知一二。
Chapter I The Chalet: Adieu, my friend.I am poor at this moment.That is one of the reasons why I cling to my concealment, my mask, my impregnable fortress.I have read your last verses in the “Revue,”—ah! with what delight, now that I am initiated in the austere loftiness of your secret soul.

第一章 木屋: 知道了一个少女为您祈祷，知道了您是她唯一的思想——除了她的父母，没有任何人能与您相比，这会让您感到不悦吗？这些为您而写、只有您的双眼才能看到、每页说的都是您的信纸，会有任何理由让您拒绝吗？也给我写这样的信吧！我太缺乏女人气了，但您的知心话——只要是毫无保留并且真实的——将足以构成我的幸福。
Chapter I The Chalet: Will it make you unhappy to know that a young girl prays for you; that you are her solitary thought,—without a rival except in her father and mother?Can there be any reason why you should reject these pages full of you, written for you, seen by no eye but yours?Send me their counterpart.I am so little of a woman yet that your confidences—provided they are full and true—will suffice for your happiness.

第一章 木屋: 您的欧·德埃斯特·莫。
Chapter I The Chalet: O. d’Este M.

第一章 木屋: “天哪！我已坠入爱河了吗？”这位年轻文书发现自己读完信后，竟把它拿在手里呆了一个多小时，便大声喊道，“我该怎么做？她还以为自己是在给伟大的诗人写信呢！我还能继续欺骗下去吗？她是四十岁的女人，还是二十岁的女孩呢？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Good heavens! can I be in love already?” cried the young secretary, when he perceived that he had held the above letter in his hands more than an hour after reading it.“What shall I do?She thinks she is writing to the great poet!Can I continue the deception?Is she a woman of forty, or a girl of twenty?”

第一章 木屋: 埃内斯特现在已经被这无形的巨大深渊深深吸引了。看不见的东西是无穷无尽的朦胧，没有什么比这更吸引人了。在那昏暗的广漠中，火光闪现，深渊中的明沟暗壑显现出画家马丁笔下的绚烂色彩。对于一个卡那利那样的大忙人来说，这样的艳遇就像是一朵被山泉冲走的风信子，但这位年轻文书生活更为清闲，在他脑海中，这位迷人女孩始终与窗边那位金发美女有着千丝万缕的联系，她牢牢地攫住了他的心，就像是狐狸闯进家禽饲养场似的，在他规律的生活中引起了许多不安。拉布里埃任由自己被这位神秘的通信者所占有，并又给她的上一封信回了一封信，一封自命不凡且精心揣摩过的信，然而，激情开始通过一种愠怒在信中流露出来。
Chapter I The Chalet: Ernest was now fascinated by the great gulf of the unseen.The unseen is the obscurity of infinitude, and nothing is more alluring.In that sombre vastness fires flash, and furrow and color the abyss with fancies like those of Martin.For a busy man like Canalis, an adventure of this kind is swept away like a harebell by a mountain torrent, but in the more unoccupied life of the young secretary, this charming girl, whom his imagination persistently connected with the blonde beauty at the window, fastened upon his heart, and did as much mischief in his regulated life as a fox in a poultry-yard.La Briere allowed himself to be preoccupied by this mysterious correspondent; and he answered her last letter with another, a pretentious and carefully studied epistle, in which, however, passion begins to reveal itself through pique.

第一章 木屋: 小姐：您让自己占据了一位可怜诗人的心，潜意识里打算着如果他不是您所希望的那样，便离他而去，让他追悔莫及。可您却给他留下了短暂的完美印象（即使这只是他臆想出来的），还至少给了他幸福的预示，这样做难道是忠诚的吗？您在这封信里已经开始展现您高贵的内心，我当初还求您写信解释，实在是目光短浅。一个神秘女子，集这般过人的勇敢与创造力于一身，集如此丰富的想象与情感于一身，男人便很容易为之倾心。读了您的第一番知心话，有谁会不想认识您呢？就我而言，一想到您，就需要极力控制自己才能保持理性，因为您身上集中了所有能扰乱男人头脑或内心的一切。因此，我要充分利用您留给我的那一点点冷静，向您提出谦逊的劝告。
Chapter I The Chalet: Mademoiselle,—Is it quite loyal in you to enthrone yourself in the heart of a poor poet with a latent intention of abandoning him if he is not exactly what you wish, leaving him to endless regrets,—showing him for a moment an image of perfection, were it only assumed, and at any rate giving him a foretaste of happiness?I was very short-sighted in soliciting this letter, in which you have begun to unfold the elegant fabric of your thoughts.A man can easily become enamored with a mysterious unknown who combines such fearlessness with such originality, so much imagination with so much feeling.Who would not wish to know you after reading your first confidence?It requires a strong effort on my part to retain my senses in thinking of you, for you combine all that can trouble the head or the heart of man.I therefore make the most of the little self-possession you have left me to offer you my humble remonstrances.

第一章 木屋: 小姐，书信或多或少与写信人生活有联系，却也有或多或少的不真实。那些我们互相写的信只是我们在写信那一刻的情感表达，而不是我们生活的主旋律。虽然它们可能很美好，但我想问，难道您真的相信它们能代替我们在日常交流中对彼此表现出来的一面吗？人是双重的。有一种生活是看不见的，那就是心灵生活，书信能满足心灵生活。还有一种物质生活，人们更加注重它，唉，您这个年龄还意识不到。然而，这两种生活在您所追求的理想状态中必须要达到和谐统一，而我要顺带说一句，这是非常少见的。
Chapter I The Chalet: Do you really believe, mademoiselle, that letters, more or less true in relation to the life of the writers, more or less insincere,—for those which we write to each other are the expressions of the moment at which we pen them, and not of the general tenor of our lives,—do you believe, I say, that beautiful as they may be, they can at all replace the representation that we could make of ourselves to each other by the revelations of daily intercourse?Man is dual.There is a life invisible, that of the heart, to which letters may suffice; and there is a life material, to which more importance is, alas, attached than you are aware of at your age.These two existences must, however, be made to harmonize in the ideal which you cherish; and this, I may remark in passing, is very rare.

第一章 木屋: 一个既有教养又纯真的隐士，内心充满纯洁、自然、无私的敬意，仿佛来自天国的花朵，其色彩和芬芳能抚慰每一份悲痛、每一道伤口、每一次背叛（这在文人的生活里是司空见惯的），而我要用与您同样的强烈情感来感谢您。我用我的悲伤来交换您慷慨施舍的珍珠，但有了这诗意的交换又如何？下面您期望的是什么？我既没有拜伦爵士的天才，也没有他显赫的地位。而最重要的是，我没有他捏造的罪孽的光环，也没有他社交生活中虚情假意的悲哀。但在类似的情况下，您对他能有什么期待呢？他的友情？唉，像他那种只会骄傲自负的人，已经被每一种虚荣——只会阻碍友情的病态的、急躁的虚荣——所吞噬了。我比他还渺小上千倍呢，难道我就不会有乖戾的性格，让友情成为难以承受的重负吗？您献出了您的幻想，会得到什么回报呢？无非是对一种不完全属于您的生活的不满。您同我的约定真是愚蠢。让我告诉您为什么。首先，您设想的诗篇只是一个剽窃物。一个年轻的德国女孩——她不像您只有一半的德国血统，而是百分之百的德国人——怀着少女的狂热爱慕着歌德。她把歌德当成自己的朋友，自己的信仰，自己的上帝，同时，她也知道歌德结婚了。歌德夫人是一位可敬的德国女人，她用心照不宣的和善容忍着这位崇拜者，但这并没有治愈贝蒂娜。但事情最终是怎样的呢？这位年轻的迷恋者嫁给了一位比歌德更年轻、更帅气的男子。现在，我们俩私下说，假设有个少女自愿做一位天才的侍女，做与他心灵相交的另一半，而且到死都虔诚地崇拜他，就像大师们在神秘圣地的百叶窗上勾画出的圣人那样。他（歌德）去世后，她便开始离群索居的生活，就像博林布鲁克爵士的朋友那样——我是说，我们就会承认这位少女会得到永生，与诗人的荣誉融为一体，就像抹大拉的马利亚与我们主的十字架和成就融为一体那样。如果那样做是伟大的，那对于相反的情形，您会怎么看呢？歌德和拜伦爵士是诗情和自我主义的两尊巨像。由于我既不是歌德，也不是拜伦爵士，而只是几首得到好评的诗歌的创作者，我不能期望有幸被人顶礼膜拜。我也无意成为一位殉道者。我有抱负，也有雄心，我还年轻，还要去开创我的事业。让您看看我是怎样的人吧。国王的赏金以及他的大臣们的保护，给了我足够的生活财富。我的外表和举止非常普通。我跟任何一个没头脑的纨绔子弟一样，参加巴黎的各种社交晚会。如果我乘马车的话，我的车轮也不是滚动在坚实的地面上，而是由近期投放在国家基金里的不动产支撑着的。但如果我不富裕，我也无法坦然去过阁楼上的生活，辛苦劳作却默默无闻，不被人所理解。这种生活属于比我更有价值的人——比如德阿尔泰兹。
Chapter I The Chalet: The pure, spontaneous, disinterested homage of a solitary soul which is both educated and chaste, is one of those celestial flowers whose color and fragrance console for every grief, for every wound, for every betrayal which makes up the life of a literary man; and I thank you with an impulse equal to your own.But after this poetical exchange of my griefs for the pearls of your charity, what next? what do you expect?I have neither the genius nor the splendid position of Lord Byron; above all, I have not the halo of his fictitious damnation and his false social woes.But what could you have hoped from him in like circumstances?His friendship?Well, he who ought to have felt only pride was eaten up by vanity of every kind,—sickly, irritable vanity which discouraged friendship.I, a thousand-fold more insignificant than he, may I not have discordances of character, and make friendship a burden heavy indeed to bear?In exchange for your reveries, what will you gain?The dissatisfaction of a life which will not be wholly yours.The compact is madness.Let me tell you why.In the first place, your projected poem is a plagiarism.A young German girl, who was not, like you, semi-German, but altogether so, adored Goethe with the rash intoxication of girlhood.She made him her friend, her religion, her god, knowing at the same time that he was married.Madame Goethe, a worthy German woman, lent herself to this worship with a sly good-nature which did not cure Bettina.But what was the end of it all?The young ecstatic married a man who was younger and handsomer than Goethe.Now, between ourselves, let us admit that a young girl who should make herself the handmaid of a man of genius, his equal through comprehension, and should piously worship him till death, like one of those divine figures sketched by the masters on the shutters of their mystic shrines, and who, when Germany lost him, should have retired to some solitude away from men, like the friend of Lord Bolingbroke,—let us admit, I say, that the young girl would have lived forever, inlaid in the glory of the poet as Mary Magdalene in the cross and triumph of our Lord.If that is sublime, what say you to the reverse of the picture?As I am neither Goethe nor Lord Byron, the colossi of poetry and egotism, but simply the author of a few esteemed verses, I cannot expect the honors of a cult.Neither am I disposed to be a martyr.I have ambition, and I have a heart; I am still young and I have my career to make.See me for what I am.The bounty of the king and the protection of his ministers give me sufficient means of living.I have the outward bearing of a very ordinary man.I go to the soirees in Paris like any other empty-headed fop; and if I drive, the wheels of my carriage do not roll on the solid ground, absolutely indispensable in these days, of property invested in the funds.But if I am not rich, neither do I have the reliefs and consolations of life in a garret, the toil uncomprehended, the fame in penury, which belong to men who are worth far more than I,—D’Arthez, for instance.

第一章 木屋: 啊！您满怀青春的热情，幻想出种种迷人的场景，最后却发现是如此乏味的结局！我们就此停止来往吧。如果我有幸被您看做一位凡世的完人，那您对我来说就是一个光亮的尤物，一座灯塔，就像那些一闪而过的星星。希望没有任何东西会玷污我们生命的这段插曲。如果我们继续的话，我会爱上您，我会孕育一种疯狂的热情，它能摧毁一切障碍，能在一颗激情多于耐力的心上点燃火焰。然后，假设我成功地取悦了您呢？我们会以平常的、庸俗的方式结束我们的故事——结婚、组建家庭、生儿育女，贝莉丝和亨丽埃特·克里萨尔在一起了！——那可能吗？所以，还是再见吧。
Chapter I The Chalet: Ah! what prosaic conclusions will your young enthusiasm find to these enchanting visions.Let us stop here.If I have had the happiness of seeming to you a terrestrial paragon, you have been to me a thing of light and a beacon, like those stars that shine for a moment and disappear.May nothing ever tarnish this episode of our lives.Were we to continue it I might love you; I might conceive one of those mad passions which rend all obstacles, which light fires in the heart whose violence is greater than their duration.And suppose I succeeded in pleasing you? we should end our tale in the common vulgar way,—marriage, a household, children, Belise and Henriette Chrysale together!—could it be?Therefore, adieu.

第一章 木屋: 第十章 心灵的婚姻
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter X The Marriage of Souls

第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利先生：
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis:

第一章 木屋: 我的朋友：您的来信既给了我快乐，也给了我忧伤。但也许有一天，我们通信时将只会感到快乐。请充分地理解我的意思。心灵同上帝交流，并请求他赐予很多东西，可上帝默不作声。我试图在您身上找到上帝没有给我的答案。难道德古尔奈小姐和蒙田之间的友情就不能在我们之间再现吗？难道您不记得日内瓦的西斯蒙戴·德西斯蒙第一家了吗？听说那是人们所知道的最美好的家庭，与德佩斯凯尔侯爵同他的妻子有些相似，幸福地白头到老。啊！朋友，在一首交响乐中，两颗心，两张竖琴，遥相呼应，共同弹奏美妙的乐曲，这难道是不可能的吗？万物之中唯有人，能独自扮演竖琴、音乐家和观众三个角色。您看我像寻常女子那样，惴惴不安且好猜忌吗？我知道您出入交际场，遇到过巴黎最漂亮、最聪明的女人。难道我猜不到吗？一定是其中一条美人鱼垂青于您，用她那冰冷带鳞的双手拥抱您，在您心中激起那些乏味的想法，所以您的回答才如此让我伤心。生活中总有一些东西，要比巴黎女人卖弄风情的花环更漂亮。远在那些被称作“阿尔卑斯山之巅”的天才心中，生长着一种花朵，它是人类的光荣，天才们用他们高贵的头颅从天空汲取露水，给它以养分。我试图种植出那种花，并让它绽放，因为它那狂烈而又温和的芳香永远都不会消逝，它是永恒的。
Chapter I The Chalet: My Friend,—Your letter gives me as much pain as pleasure.But perhaps some day we shall find nothing but pleasure in writing to each other.Understand me thoroughly.The soul speaks to God and asks him for many things; he is mute.I seek to obtain in you the answers that God does not make to me.Cannot the friendship of Mademoiselle de Gournay and Montaigne be revived in us?Do you not remember the household of Sismonde de Sismondi in Geneva?The most lovely home ever known, as I have been told; something like that of the Marquis de Pescaire and his wife,—happy to old age.Ah! friend, is it impossible that two hearts, two harps, should exist as in a symphony, answering each other from a distance, vibrating with delicious melody in unison?Man alone of all creation is in himself the harp, the musician, and the listener.Do you think to find me uneasy and jealous like ordinary women?I know that you go into the world and meet the handsomest and the wittiest women in Paris.May I not suppose that some one of those mermaids has deigned to clasp you in her cold and scaly arms, and that she has inspired the answer whose prosaic opinions sadden me?There is something in life more beautiful than the garlands of Parisian coquetry; there grows a flower far up those Alpine peaks called men of genius, the glory of humanity, which they fertilize with the dews their lofty heads draw from the skies.I seek to cultivate that flower and make it bloom; for its wild yet gentle fragrance can never fail,—it is eternal.

第一章 木屋: 请您给我点面子，相信我没有任何低贱或庸俗之处。我知道您说的贝蒂娜指的是谁，如果我是她，我就永远都不会做冯阿尔尼姆夫人；如果我是拜伦爵士众多的爱慕者之一，我此刻就会在一座修道院里。您触及了我的伤心处。您还不了解我，但您以后会了解的。我敢不带任何虚荣地说，我觉得自己内心深处有一种崇高的东西。上帝已将我所说的生长在阿尔卑斯山巅的花朵植根在我的心灵里，而我不能将它种在我窗台上的陶土花盆里，眼看着它死去。不，那绚丽的花蕾，它的美是独一无二的，它的芳香是令人陶醉的，它不会堕入生活的庸俗之中！它是属于您的——您的，在任何人的目光使它凋零之前，永远都是您的！是的，我的诗人，我的思想是属于您的——所有那些秘密的、欢快的思想都属于您；我的心是您的，充满无限爱恋，没有任何保留。如果您本人不能让我满意，我绝不结婚。我可以活在心灵的生活中，存在于您的思想里、您的情感里。它们让我快乐，而我会一直保持现在的状态，做您的朋友。您的思想与情感是一种高贵的道德天性，我已经认识并体会到了，这对我就已足够了。这就是我全部的未来。一位年轻漂亮的侍女，有一天会成为一位诗人的老伴——又有点像他的母亲，或是女管家，指引他的判断，成为他财富的来源。想到这些，她都不会退缩，所以请不要嘲笑她。这个女孩——她是如此忠诚，对您这样的人是如此难能可贵——就是友情的化身，纯洁、无私的友情的化身。您可以告诉她所有事情，她会聆听着，时不时地点点头；她会在灯下边做编织活边等待，这样，被大雨淋湿或是内心烦扰的诗人回到家时，就能看到她。如果我不能成为一个永远依附于丈夫的幸福妻子，那我的命运将会是这样，想到这两种命运，我都会微笑。您觉得，如果德埃斯特小姐没给法国生下两三个孩子，而且永远都没有成为维尔坎夫人那样的人，法国会因此变得更糟糕吗？就我而言，我永远都不会成为一位老姑娘。我会通过照顾他人，通过秘密进入一个伟大男人的生活——我也会将自己的全部思想及人世间的努力展现给他，让自己成为一位母亲。
Chapter I The Chalet: Do me the honor to believe that there is nothing low or commonplace in me.Were I Bettina, for I know to whom you allude, I should never have become Madame von Arnim; and had I been one of Lord Byron’s many loves, I should be at this moment in a cloister.You have touched me to the quick.You do not know me, but you shall know me.I feel within me something that is sublime, of which I dare speak without vanity.God has put into my soul the roots of that Alpine flower born on the summits of which I speak, and I cannot plant it in an earthen pot upon my window-sill and see it die.No, that glorious flower-cup, single in its beauty, intoxicating in its fragrance, shall not be dragged through the vulgarities of life! it is yours—yours, before any eye has blighted it, yours forever!Yes, my poet, to you belong my thoughts,—all, those that are secret, those that are gayest; my heart is yours without reserve and with its infinite affection.If you should personally not please me, I shall never marry.I can live in the life of the heart, I can exist on your mind, your sentiments; they please me, and I will always be what I am, your friend.Yours is a noble moral nature; I have recognized it, I have appreciated it, and that suffices me.In that is all my future.Do not laugh at a young and pretty handmaiden who shrinks not from the thought of being some day the old companion of a poet,—a sort of mother perhaps, or a housekeeper; the guide of his judgment and a source of his wealth.This handmaiden—so devoted, so precious to the lives of such as you—is Friendship, pure, disinterested friendship, to whom you will tell all, who listens and sometimes shakes her head; who knits by the light of the lamp and waits to be present when the poet returns home soaked with rain, or vexed in mind.Such shall be my destiny if I do not find that of a happy wife attached forever to her husband; I smile alike at the thought of either fate.Do you believe France will be any the worse if Mademoiselle d’Este does not give it two or three sons, and never becomes a Madame Vilquin-something-or-other?As for me, I shall never be an old maid.I shall make myself a mother, by taking care of others and by my secret co-operation in the existence of a great man, to whom also I shall carry all my thoughts and all my earthly efforts.

第一章 木屋: 我对庸俗有着最深的痛恨。如果我享有自由，如果我很富有（我知道自己年轻漂亮），我绝不会委身于某个傻子，仅仅因为他是某法国贵族的儿子，也不会嫁给一个能在一夜之间把我和他自己都毁掉的商人。当然，我也不会嫁给那种在家里像个女人样的俊男，或是那种结婚后会让我一天脸红二十次的男人。在这一点上，请您放心好了。我父亲尊重我的愿望，他永远都不会反对我。如果我让我的诗人快乐，而且他也让我快乐，我们爱情的壮丽大厦将会被建造得无比高大，任何不幸都不可企及。我是一只小鹰，您将会从我的双眸中看出这一点。
Chapter I The Chalet: I have the deepest horror of commonplaceness.If I am free, if I am rich (and I know that I am young and pretty), I will never belong to any ninny just because he is the son of a peer of France, nor to a merchant who could ruin himself and me in a day, nor to a handsome creature who would be a sort of woman in the household, nor to a man of any kind who would make me blush twenty times a day for being his.Make yourself easy on that point.My father adores my wishes; he will never oppose them.If I please my poet, and he pleases me, the glorious structure of our love shall be built so high as to be inaccessible to any kind of misfortune.I am an eaglet; and you will see it in my eyes.

第一章 木屋: 我不会重复已经说过的话，但我会尽量用最少的字词来表达要旨，并向您坦言，如果我被爱情监禁起来，就像我现在出于父亲的意愿和嘱咐被监禁起来一样，那我会是最幸福的女人。啊！我的朋友，这是我第一次把愿望付诸实践，我们给我们之间的浪漫故事一个真实的结局好吗？请您听听我的理由：
Chapter I The Chalet: I shall not repeat what I have already said, but I will put its substance in the least possible number of words, and confess to you that I should be the happiest of women if I were imprisoned by love as I am now imprisoned by the wish and will of a father.Ah! my friend, may we bring to a real end the romance that has come to us through the first exercise of my will: listen to its argument:—

第一章 木屋: 一位想象力丰富的少女，被锁在塔楼里，只能用目光环顾面前的花园，可她却渴望着能够在花园里自由自在地奔跑，这渴望令她疲倦。她想出了一个拆开栅栏的方法，她从窗台上跳下，爬过花园的围墙，在邻居的草地上嬉戏——这是一出永恒的喜剧。是的，那个少女就是我的心灵，邻居的花园就是您的天才。难道这一切不是很自然吗？邻居的栅栏不知被谁的脚踩坏了，他不会因此而抱怨吗？我把这个问题留给我的诗人去回答。
Chapter I The Chalet: A young girl with a lively imagination, locked up in a tower, is weary with longing to run loose in the park where her eyes only are allowed to rove.She invents a way to loosen her bars; she jumps from the casement; she scales the park wall; she frolics along the neighbor’s sward—it is the Everlasting comedy.Well, that young girl is my soul, the neighbor’s park is your genius.Is it not all very natural?Was there ever a neighbor that did not complain that unknown feet broke down his trellises?I leave it to my poet to answer.

第一章 木屋: 但这位模仿莫里哀的傲慢的说理者是不是还需要更好的理由呢？好吧，理由来了。我亲爱的皆隆特，婚姻的建立往往是违背常理的。父母打听一位年轻小伙子的情况。这位由某朋友介绍或在舞厅里碰上的赖昂德，如果他不是一个小偷，名声方面也没什么明显的缺陷，如果他拥有必要的财富，如果他毕业于一所大学或法律学校，符合人们对于受教育的普遍看法，如果他衣着很有绅士风度，那他就会被允许见一见这位年轻姑娘。姑娘的母亲命令她要管住自己的舌头，不要让情感或内心的迹象显现在脸上，要保持着一位芭蕾舞演员完成一次竖趾旋转时的微笑。除了这些命令，父母还教导她关于袒露真性情的危险，并建议她不要摆出一副教养过好的样子，把人吓跑。如果一切问题都谈妥了，双方父母就会很和善地让这对新人相处一会儿。他们可以一起交谈或散步，但总是没有一点点自由，他们知道，他们已经被死板的规约绑在一起了。男子将心灵和身体好好打扮起来，年轻的姑娘也是这样。这部可悲的喜剧，混合着鲜花、首饰还有剧院派对，名字就叫做“献出您的殷勤。”它让我感到厌恶。我渴望的真正的婚姻要以长久的心灵结合为前提。在一位少女、一个女人的一生中，只有这一刻，深思、先见之明和经验对她来说才是必要的。她用她的自由和幸福做赌注，但她却不可以掷骰子，她冒了所有的险，却被迫做一个纯粹的旁观者。我有权利、有愿望、有能力去创造自己的不幸，我像我母亲那样行使这些权利。她被美所征服，遵从直觉的指引，嫁给了最善良大方、最心胸宽阔、最一往情深的男子。我知道您尚未结婚，是一个诗人，而且外表高贵。可以肯定地说，您的任何一位同行，哪怕他长得像阿波罗，但已经结婚了，我也不会选择他。如果说我的母亲被美所征服，而美也许是外形的内在流露，那我为什么不会被形与神的结合所吸引呢？通过您的书信来考察您，比起通过“接受您的殷勤”这一庸俗的体验，不是能更好地了解您吗？正如哈姆雷特所说，这是问题所在。
Chapter I The Chalet: But does the lofty reasoner after the fashion of Moliere want still better reasons?Well, here they are.My dear Geronte, marriages are usually made in defiance of common-sense.Parents make inquiries about a young man.If the Leander—who is supplied by some friend, or caught in a ball-room—is not a thief, and has no visible rent in his reputation, if he has the necessary fortune, if he comes from a college or a law-school and so fulfils the popular ideas of education, and if he wears his clothes with a gentlemanly air, he is allowed to meet the young lady, whose mother has ordered her to guard her tongue, to let no sign of her heart or soul appear on her face, which must wear the smile of a danseuse finishing a pirouette.These commands are coupled with instructions as to the danger of revealing her real character, and the additional advice of not seeming alarmingly well educated.If the settlements have all been agreed upon, the parents are good-natured enough to let the pair see each other for a few moments; they are allowed to talk or walk together, but always without the slightest freedom, and knowing that they are bound by rigid rules.The man is as much dressed up in soul as he is in body, and so is the young girl.This pitiable comedy, mixed with bouquets, jewels, and theatre-parties is called “paying your addresses.”It revolts me: I desire that actual marriage shall be the result of a previous and long marriage of souls.A young girl, a woman, has throughout her life only this one moment when reflection, second sight, and experience are necessary to her.She plays her liberty, her happiness, and she is not allowed to throw the dice; she risks her all, and is forced to be a mere spectator.I have the right, the will, the power to make my own unhappiness, and I use them, as did my mother, who, won by beauty and led by instinct, married the most generous, the most liberal, the most loving of men.I know that you are free, a poet, and noble-looking.Be sure that I should not have chosen one of your brothers in Apollo who was already married.If my mother was won by beauty, which is perhaps the spirit of form, why should I not be attracted by the spirit and the form united?Shall I not know you better by studying you in this correspondence than I could through the vulgar experience of “receiving your addresses”?This is the question, as Hamlet says.

第一章 木屋: 但是，亲爱的克里萨尔，我的做法至少有一个长处，那就是不会把我们本人束缚在一起。我知道爱情含有幻想的成分，而所有幻想都会有尽头。这就是为什么那些发誓相伴终生的情人当中，会有那么多人分手。爱情的考验在于两方面——痛苦和幸福。当两个人经过这些生活的双重考验，向彼此表现出了各自的缺点和优点，当他们真正了解了彼此的性格，那么，他们就可以携手一直走到坟墓了。我亲爱的阿尔冈特，谁告诉您我们之间刚刚开演的小戏剧是没有未来的？不管怎样，难道我们没有享受到通信的快乐吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: But my proceedings, dear Chrysale, have at least the merit of not binding us personally.I know that love has its illusions, and every illusion its tomorrow.That is why there are so many partings among lovers vowed to each other for life.The proof of love lies in two things,—suffering and happiness.When, after passing through these double trials of life two beings have shown each other their defects as well as their good qualities, when they have really observed each other’s character, then they may go to their grave hand in hand.My dear Argante, who told you that our little drama thus begun was to have no future?In any case shall we not have enjoyed the pleasures of our correspondence?

第一章 木屋: 我等着您的吩咐，殿下，我会用我全部的真心，
Chapter I The Chalet: I await your orders, monseigneur, and I am with all my heart,

第一章 木屋: 您的仆人，
Chapter I The Chalet: Your handmaiden,

第一章 木屋: 欧·德埃斯特·莫
Chapter I The Chalet: O. d’Este M.

第一章 木屋: 致欧·德埃斯特·莫小姐：您是一位巫师，一个精灵，我爱您！那就是您对我的希望，您这个最古灵精怪的女孩？或许，您仅仅是想让一位诗人作出什么蠢事，给您闲适的外省生活带来些消遣。如果是这样，您可就做了一件坏事。您的两封信里有足够的捣蛋意味，才使得我这个巴黎人的头脑里产生这样的怀疑。但我已经不是自己的主人了，我的人生、我的未来，都取决于您将给我的答复。请告诉我，如果您肯定能得到一种不顾一切社会习俗的无限柔情，您会不会动心——您是否会接受我追求您。我本人能否令您满意，对于这个问题，我相当焦虑和不确定。如果您的回复是肯定的，我会改变我的生活，我会告别所有那些我们愚蠢地称之为幸福的、令人厌倦的快乐。我亲爱的、美丽的匿名姑娘，幸福正是您所梦想的那样——一种情感的融合，一种心灵间的完美契合，一种高贵理想（比如上帝允许我们在俗世所拥有的理想）在我们必须循规蹈矩的日常生活琐事上打下的烙印，一种心灵的忠贞不渝，比我们所说的忠诚还要宝贵得多。我们可以这样说吗？当我们最终的目的是永恒的幸福、诗人的梦想、少女的梦想，还有诗情，我们就要作出牺牲。每一个高尚的智者，从他迈进生活的门槛时起，从他展开思想的翅膀时起，他就深思并爱护着内心的诗情，结果却眼看着这些诗情碰到低俗坚硬的绊脚石，摔得粉碎——对于大部分人来说，现实的脚马上会践踏到这如此少见的神秘之蛋。
Chapter I The Chalet: To Mademoiselle O. d’Este M.,—You are a witch, a spirit, and I love you!Is that what you desire of me, most original of girls?Perhaps you are only seeking to amuse your provincial leisure with the follies which are you able to make a poet commit.If so, you have done a bad deed.Your two letters have enough of the spirit of mischief in them to force this doubt into the mind of a Parisian.But I am no longer master of myself; my life, my future depend on the answer you will make me.Tell me if the certainty of an unbounded affection, oblivious of all social conventions, will touch you,—if you will suffer me to seek you.There is anxiety enough and uncertainty enough in the question as to whether I can personally please you.If your reply is favorable I change my life, I bid adieu to all the irksome pleasures which we have the folly to call happiness.Happiness, my dear and beautiful unknown, is what you dream it to be,—a fusion of feelings, a perfect accordance of souls, the imprint of a noble ideal (such as God does permit us to form in this low world) upon the trivial round of daily life whose habits we must needs obey, a constancy of heart more precious far than what we call fidelity.Can we say that we make sacrifices when the end in view is our eternal good, the dream of poets, the dream of maidens, the poem which, at the entrance of life when thought essays its wings, each noble intellect has pondered and caressed only to see it shivered to fragments on some stone of stumbling as hard as it is vulgar?—for to the great majority of men, the foot of reality steps instantly on that mysterious egg so seldom hatched.

第一章 木屋: 我不能跟您说更多关于我的事，不能说我过去的生活，也不能说我的性格。还有另一个人和我之间近乎父子之情的情感，也不能告诉您。但您已经大大地改变了这一情感——它对我生活的影响可以解释我为什么用“牺牲”这个词。您已经让我变得即使不是忘恩负义、也是心不在焉了，这样您满意了吗？唉，您说吧！只要您说一句话，我就会爱您，直到闭上双眼死去，就像德佩斯凯尔爱他的妻子那样，像罗密欧爱朱丽叶那样，忠贞不渝地爱您。我们的生活，至少对我而言，将会是但丁所说的“无忧无虑的天伦之乐”，在《天堂篇》——一首比他的《地狱篇》优秀得多的诗歌——里，但丁认为这种快乐是天堂的基本元素。像您一样，我在久久的冥想中跟一个梦中人绕着圈子，奇怪的是，在这冥想中，我怀疑的不是自己，而是您。是的，亲爱的，我觉得我的内心有力量去爱，无止尽地爱——从容漫步，笑容满面，挽着我心上人的手，一直走到坟墓，不会有一片乌云遮住我们心灵的阳光。是的，我敢于面对我们彼此的晚年，看到我们像那位德高望重的意大利历史学家一样白发苍苍，还总是怀着同样的柔情，只是随着生命的不同阶段有着不同的心灵体验。听我说，我不能再只做您的朋友了。尽管您说克里萨尔、皆隆特和阿尔冈特在我身上复活，但我还没那么老气横秋，一位蒙着面纱的女子用她可爱的双手将酒杯举到我的嘴边，喝着酒杯里的酒，我怎能没有一种强烈的愿望，想要脱掉她化妆舞会的外衣，摘掉她的面具，看看她的脸。您要不就别再给我写信了，要不就给我希望。要不让我见见您，要不就让我走。我一定要跟您说再见了吗？您会允许我在信尾署名，
Chapter I The Chalet: I cannot speak to you any more of myself; not of my past life, nor of my character, nor of an affection almost maternal on one side, filial on mine, which you have already seriously changed—an effect upon my life which must explain my use of the word “sacrifice.”You have already rendered me forgetful, if not ungrateful; does that satisfy you?Oh, speak!Say to me one word, and I will love you till my eyes close in death, as the Marquis de Pescaire loved his wife, as Romeo loved Juliet, and faithfully.Our life will be, for me at least, that “felicity untroubled” which Dante made the very element of his Paradiso,—a poem far superior to his Inferno.Strange, it is not myself that I doubt in the long reverie through which, like you, I follow the windings of a dreamed existence; it is you.Yes, dear, I feel within me the power to love, and to love endlessly,—to march to the grave with gentle slowness and a smiling eye, with my beloved on my arm, and with never a cloud upon the sunshine of our souls.Yes, I dare to face our mutual old age, to see ourselves with whitening heads, like the venerable historian of Italy, inspired always with the same affection but transformed in soul by our life’s seasons.Hear me, I can no longer be your friend only.Though Chrysale, Geronte, and Argante relive, you say, in me, I am not yet old enough to drink from the cup held to my lips by the sweet hands of a veiled woman without a passionate desire to tear off the domino and the mask and see the face.Either write me no more, or give me hope.Let me see you, or let me go.Must I bid you adieu?Will you permit me to sign myself,

第一章 木屋: 您的朋友吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: Your Friend?

第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利先生：您多会奉承人啊！严肃的安塞尔姆这么快就变成帅气的赖昂德了！我应该把这一变化归于什么原因呢？归于我的白纸黑字吗？归于那些想法吗？那些想法之于我绽放的内心，就像炭笔画的玫瑰之于花园里真正的玫瑰。抑或是因为您想起了以为是我的那位少女？她的外表和我相比，就像是侍女之于女主人了。我们的角色互换了？我变得理智，您变得异想天开？但是好了，不开玩笑了。
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis,—What flattery! with what rapidity is the grave Anselme transformed into a handsome Leander!To what must I attribute such a change? to this black which I put upon this white? to these ideas which are to the flowers of my soul what a rose drawn in charcoal is to the roses in the garden?Or is it to a recollection of the young girl whom you took for me, and who is personally as like me as a waiting-woman is like her mistress?Have we changed roles?Have I the sense? have you the fancy?But a truce with jesting.

第一章 木屋: 您的来信让我尝到了心灵的欣喜若狂，这是我第一次了解到除了家庭情感之外的快乐。一位诗人说过，比起那些神秘的感应在我们内心锻造出的神赐般的关系，这些常人心中如此强烈的血缘关系又算什么呢？让我感谢您吧——不，我们不能为这些事情而感谢彼此——但是，上帝会为您给我的幸福而保佑您的，您也为您带给我心灵的快乐而高兴吧。您向我解释了社会生活中一些明显的不公之处。有一种东西，我叫不上名字，它闪闪发光，刚健有力，是只属于男人的荣耀。上帝禁止我们女人戴上它的光环，但他让爱成为我们的命运，给了我们柔情来抚慰被他的光芒炙烤着的额头。我感觉到了我的使命，而您现在已确定了这使命。
Chapter I The Chalet: Your letter has made me know the elating pleasures of the soul; the first that I have known outside of my family affections.What, says a poet, are the ties of blood which are so strong in ordinary minds, compared to those divinely forged within us by mysterious sympathies?Let me thank you—no, we must not thank each other for such things—but God bless you for the happiness you have given me; be happy in the joy you have shed into my soul.You explain to me some of the apparent injustices in social life.There is something, I know not what, so dazzling, so virile in glory, that it belongs only to man; God forbids us women to wear its halo, but he makes love our portion, giving us the tenderness which soothes the brow scorched by his lightnings.I have felt my mission, and you have now confirmed it.

第一章 木屋: 有时候，我的朋友，清晨时分我会怀着一种无以言表的甜蜜起床，一种温柔而神圣的宁静，让我仿佛置身天堂。我的第一个想法就像是祝福。我称这些早晨为我小小的德国式梦醒，与我那充满了英勇行动、战斗、罗马游乐会和热情诗歌的南方式日落形成了对照。好啦，读了您这封充满躁动不安的急切的来信，我觉得内心精神饱满，和每次置身天堂般的梦醒一模一样。每次那样醒来时，我都热爱着身边的空气和大自然，并幻想着我注定会为我心爱的人死去。您有一首诗——《少女之歌》，描绘了种种甜蜜的时刻，比如温柔的欢乐，迫切的愿望，这是我最喜欢的一首诗。您想要我把全部的恭维用一句话表达吗？——那好吧，我觉得您配得上我！
Chapter I The Chalet: Sometimes, my friend, I rise in the morning in a state of inexpressible sweetness; a sort of peace, tender and divine, gives me an idea of heaven.My first thought is then like a benediction.I call these mornings my little German wakings, in opposition to my Southern sunsets, full of heroic deeds, battles, Roman fetes and ardent poems.Well, after reading your letter, so full of feverish impatience, I felt in my heart all the freshness of my celestial wakings, when I love the air about me and all nature, and fancy that I am destined to die for one I love.One of your poems, “The Maiden’s Song,” paints these delicious moments, when gaiety is tender, when aspiration is a need; it is one of my favorites.Do you want me to put all my flatteries into one?—well then, I think you worthy to be me!

第一章 木屋: 您的信尽管很短，但能让我读到您的内心。是的，我已经猜到了您狂乱的挣扎，您被激起的好奇心，您的各种打算，但我对您还不够了解，也就不能满足您的愿望。听我说，亲爱的——正因为我身处神秘之中，才可以使用这个词，让您看到我的内心深处。听我说：一旦我们见面，我们彼此的了解就要结束了！您愿意与我立下一个约定吗？上次的约定让您吃亏了吗？但请您记住，它让您赢得了我的尊敬，而且，我的朋友，在赢得尊敬的同时您还赢得了钦佩，这是一个伟大的协议。以下是我们新的约定：用几句话跟我说说您的生活，然后告诉我您每天在巴黎做什么，不要有任何保留，就像是在跟某个老朋友聊天一样。好啦，您那样做了之后，我自己也会向前迈一步——我答应您，我会跟您见面。这是一个很好的协议。
Chapter I The Chalet: Your letter, though short, enables me to read within you.Yes, I have guessed your tumultuous struggles, your piqued curiosity, your projects; but I do not yet know you well enough to satisfy your wishes.Hear me, dear; the mystery in which I am shrouded allows me to use that word, which lets you see to the bottom of my heart.Hear me: if we once meet, adieu to our mutual comprehension!Will you make a compact with me?Was the first disadvantageous to you?But remember it won you my esteem, and it is a great deal, my friend, to gain an admiration lined throughout with esteem.Here is the compact: write me your life in a few words; then tell me what you do in Paris, day by day, with no reservations, and as if you were talking to some old friend.Well, having done that, I will take a step myself—I will see you, I promise you that.And it is a great deal.

第一章 木屋: 亲爱的，这不是什么阴谋诡计，没有任何风险。而且，我要直白地警告您，不会有你们男人所说的风流韵事发生。它关系到我的一生，而且还不止如此——想到我的思绪成群地飞向您，我就感到有些自责——它还关系到我父亲和我母亲的一生。我深爱着他们，而且我的选择必须让他们高兴，他们应该在您身上找到儿子的感觉。
Chapter I The Chalet: This, dear, is no intrigue, no adventure; no gallantry, as you men say, can come of it, I warn you frankly.It involves my life, and more than that,—something that causes me remorse for the many thoughts that fly to you in flocks—it involves my father’s and my mother’s life.I adore them, and my choice must please them; they must find a son in you.

第一章 木屋: 请告诉我，您那非凡的思想，上帝赋予了它天使的翅膀，却没能让它总是平易近人——它能在多大程度上屈从家庭的枷锁，忍受家庭生活中琐碎的烦心事呢？那是我已经思考过的一个主题。啊！尽管在走向您之前，我对自己的内心说：去吧！向前走吧！但我真正走向您的时候，我内心的颤抖和悸动并没有减少一分一毫；还有，我并没有回避必须面对的路途坎坷，还有攀登高山的艰难。我在长久长久的冥想中思考着所有的事情。像您这样的名人，一旦感受到爱情，便也深知您在对方心里激起的爱有多深。你们的生活中经历过许多次艳遇——尤其是您，您把心灵的柔情梦幻结集出版，让女人们争相购买。难道这一切我都不知道吗？然而，我还是对自己喊道：“前进吧！”因为我对人类伟大巅峰的地理研究，远远超过了您所料想的程度。您跟我说过，那巅峰是高处不胜寒的。您不是说过，歌德和拜伦是自我主义和诗情的两座巨像吗？啊，我的朋友，您也犯了一个思想肤浅的人们易犯的错误。但在您身上，这个错误也许是由于您的慷慨大度、故作谦虚，或者是想避开我的愿望吧。头脑庸俗的人可能会错把辛勤劳作的结果当作人格发展的产物，但您一定不能这样想。无论是拜伦爵士、歌德、瓦尔特·司各特、居维叶，还是任何的发明家，他们都不属于自己，而是其思想的奴隶。而且这种神秘的力量要比女人的嫉妒还厉害，它吮吸着他们的血液，它让他们继续存活，却让我们因它而死。这种隐秘的存在方式，其结果从形式上看很像自我主义。但若一个人放弃了自我，给他那个时代的人带来快乐、指引或者辉煌，有谁敢说他是一个自我主义者呢？当一位母亲把所有的东西都贡献给她的孩子时，她是自私的吗？好吧，只是那些贬低天才的人没有看到天才多产的母性罢了。诗人的生活就是要不断牺牲，以至于他需要一个强健的体魄来享有哪怕是生活中平凡的快乐。因此，当他像莫里哀那样，在生活中最为辛酸的危急关头想要过上感情生活的时候，他会陷入怎样的悲伤之中。对我来说，一想起莫里哀的私人生活，就感到他的喜剧多么可怕。
Chapter I The Chalet: Tell me, to what extent can the superb spirits of your kind, to whom God has given the wings of his angels, without always adding their amiability,—how far can they bend under a family yoke, and put up with its little miseries?That is a text I have meditated upon.Ah! though I said to my heart before I came to you, Forward! Onward! it did not tremble and palpitate any the less on the way; and I did not conceal from myself the stoniness of the path nor the Alpine difficulties I had to encounter.I thought of all in my long, long meditations.Do I not know that eminent men like you have known the love they have inspired quite as well as that which they themselves have felt; that they have had many romances in their lives,—you particularly, who send forth those airy visions of your soul that women rush to buy?Yet still I cried to myself, “Onward!” because I have studied, more than you give me credit for, the geography of the great summits of humanity, which you tell me are so cold.Did you not say that Goethe and Byron were the colossi of egoism and poetry?Ah, my friend, there you shared a mistake into which superficial minds are apt to fall; but in you perhaps it came from generosity, false modesty, or the desire to escape from me.Vulgar minds may mistake the effect of toil for the development of personal character, but you must not.Neither Lord Byron, nor Goethe, nor Walter Scott, nor Cuvier, nor any inventor, belongs to himself, he is the slave of his idea.And this mysterious power is more jealous than a woman; it sucks their blood, it makes them live, it makes them die for its sake.The visible developments of their hidden existence do seem, in their results, like egotism; but who shall dare to say that the man who has abnegated self to give pleasure, instruction, or grandeur to his epoch, is an egoist?Is a mother selfish when she immolates all things to her child?Well, the detractors of genius do not perceive its fecund maternity, that is all.The life of a poet is so perpetual a sacrifice that he needs a gigantic organization to bear even the ordinary pleasures of life.Therefore, into what sorrows may he not fall when, like Moliere, he wishes to live the life of feeling in its most poignant crises; to me, remembering his personal life, Moliere’s comedy is horrible.

第一章 木屋: 天才的慷慨大方对我来说看上去近乎神圣，而我将您列入这所谓的自我主义者的高贵家族之中。啊！如果我发现我现在最爱的心灵之花，原来是一个自私自利、野心勃勃、冷酷无情之人，您不知道我将会忍受何等漫长的痛苦啊。我在十六岁之前就碰到过失望的事情。如果我在二十岁的时候领悟到名誉无非是谎言，发现一个人用他的作品表达出隐藏在我内心的情感、却不能自己感受这些情感，那我会怎么样呢？噢！我的朋友，您知道我会变成什么样吗？我带您进入到我心灵的幽深之处好吗？我本该去我父亲那儿，对他说：“给我找一个您中意的女婿吧，我放弃我的个人意愿——把我嫁给您中意的人吧。”而那个人可能会是一个公证人、银行家、守财奴、傻子、蠢蛋，像雨天一样令人讨厌，像经院的门房一样平庸，或是一个工厂主，一个有勇无谋的士兵——他会发现我是一个多么温顺体贴的仆人。但那是一场多么可怕的自杀啊！我的心灵就永远不会在心爱的阳光那让人生机勃勃的光芒下绽放。我不会向我的父亲、母亲或孩子透露这个女子的自杀。而此刻，她正抖落脚镣，从双眼中射出电光，拍着她那渴望的翅膀向您飞去。您看，她就在那儿，在您的书桌角上，像颂歌女神波吕许谟尼亚一样，呼吸着您周围的气息，用好奇的眼光打量着她身边的事物。有时候，我的丈夫会带我到田野里去散步，在那里，看到那辉煌壮丽的清晨，我会独自一人悄悄地抹眼泪。而且，在我的心底，或某个隐秘的抽屉里，我会保留一些珍宝，用来抚慰被爱情、悲伤、诗意的心灵所伤害的女孩——但是，啊！我有您，我相信您，我的朋友。那信任纠正了我所有的思绪和幻想，甚至是最不切实际的幻想，有时候——您看，我多坦率——我真希望我已经身处我们刚刚开始谱写的这本书之中了。我感觉自己的情感是如此坚定，我的内心充满了爱的力量，理智又让我如此忠贞不渝，我还有如此的英勇精神，去完成我出生之时就被赋予的义务——如果爱最终真的会变成义务。
Chapter I The Chalet: The generosity of genius seems to me half divine; and I place you in this noble family of alleged egoists.Ah! if I had found self-interest, ambition, a seared nature where I now can see my best loved flowers of the soul, you know not what long anguish I should have had to bear.I met with disappointment before I was sixteen.What would have become of me had I learned at twenty that fame is a lie, that he whose books express the feelings hidden in my heart was incapable of feeling them himself?Oh! my friend, do you know what would have become of me?Shall I take you into the recesses of my soul?I should have gone to my father and said, “Bring me the son-inlaw whom you desire; my will abdicates,—marry me to whom you please.”And the man might have been a notary, banker, miser, fool, dullard, wearisome as a rainy day, common as the usher of a school, a manufacturer, or some brave soldier without two ideas,—he would have had a resigned and attentive servant in me.But what an awful suicide! never could my soul have expanded in the life-giving rays of a beloved sun.No murmur should have revealed to my father, or my mother, or my children the suicide of the creature who at this instant is shaking her fetters, casting lightnings from her eyes, and flying towards you with eager wing.See, she is there, at the angle of your desk, like Polyhymnia, breathing the air of your presence, and glancing about her with a curious eye.Sometimes in the fields where my husband would have taken me to walk, I should have wept, apart and secretly, at sight of a glorious morning; and in my heart, or hidden in a bureau-drawer, I might have kept some treasure, the comfort of poor girls ill-used by love, sad, poetic souls,—but ah!I have you, I believe in you, my friend.That belief straightens all my thoughts and fancies, even the most fantastic, and sometimes—see how far my frankness leads me—I wish I were in the middle of the book we are just beginning; such persistency do I feel in my sentiments, such strength in my heart to love, such constancy sustained by reason, such heroism for the duties for which I was created,—if indeed love can ever be transmuted into duty.

第一章 木屋: 如果您能跟我来到这华丽的隐居地——我幻想我们在这里是幸福的，如果您了解我的计划和打算，您会脱口说出“荒唐”这个可怕的词语，而我也会因给一个诗人写诗而受到残酷的惩罚。是的，过去二十年中，大自然让我生长在一片沃土之上，让我光彩照人，我希望成为一股泉水，像那片沃土那样取之不尽。我想用魅力来驱走厌腻。我愿意为我的朋友勇敢无畏，就像大部分女人为这个世界而勇敢无畏一样。我想把幸福变得多种多样。我想将智慧注入柔情之中，将情趣注入忠诚之中。我满怀雄心，要将过去的情敌都消灭掉，要用一个妻子的温柔，用她引以为豪的忘我精神来驱走所有外界的悲伤，终生照料我们的窝——就像鸟儿只能花上几个星期的时间去照料它们的窝一样。
Chapter I The Chalet: If you were able to follow me to the exquisite retreat where I fancy ourselves happy, if you knew my plans and projects, the dreadful word “folly!” might escape you, and I should be cruelly punished for sending poetry to a poet.Yes, I wish to be a spring of waters inexhaustible as a fertile land for the twenty years that nature allows me to shine.I want to drive away satiety by charm.I mean to be courageous for my friend as most women are for the world.I wish to vary happiness.I wish to put intelligence into tenderness, and to give piquancy to fidelity.I am filled with ambition to kill the rivals of the past, to conjure away all outside griefs by a wife’s gentleness, by her proud abnegation, to take a lifelong care of the nest,—such as birds can only take for a few weeks.

第一章 木屋: 请告诉我，您现在还觉得我的第一封信该受责备吗？神秘的希望之风将我吹向了您，就像暴风雨将幼小的玫瑰树带到木窗户前一样。我将您的信捧在胸口，在您的信中，您像您的祖先参加十字军东征时那样呼喊道：“这是上帝的意愿。”

第一章 木屋: 啊！但您会喊道：“真是个话匣子！”可相反，我身边所有的人都说：“小姐真是沉默寡言。”

第一章 木屋: 《人间喜剧》的作者从别人那里得到的上述信件，在那些人看来都是原创的，但是，他们对这种角逐、这种两人头脑之间的笔战的兴趣，可能不会被他人所认同。每一百个读者里面，可能有八十个都会对这种唇枪舌剑感到厌倦。在每一个立宪制的国家，都应该少数遵从多数，因此，我们不再透露埃内斯特和莫黛斯特在九月份写的另外十一封信了。如果以后，这大多数人当中有哪一位殷勤讨好，想看这些信，希望那时我们能想办法将它们安插到合适的地方去。
Chapter I The Chalet: The foregoing letters seemed very original to the persons from whom the author of the “Comedy of Human Life” obtained them; but their interest in this duel, this crossing of pens between two minds, may not be shared.For every hundred readers, eighty might weary of the battle.The respect due to the majority in every nation under a constitutional government, leads us, therefore, to suppress eleven other letters exchanged between Ernest and Modeste during the month of September.If, later on, some flattering majority should arise to claim them, let us hope that we can then find means to insert them in their proper place.

第一章 木屋: 这个姑娘的心地很讨人喜欢，思想却很有锋芒。在这一思想的鼓舞下，这位可怜文书具有真正骑士风度的情感在这些隐匿的书信中得到了自由的表达。也许，这些信看上去要比实际更美好，因为人的想象会沉醉在两颗心灵自由交流的那种感觉之中。埃内斯特的整个生活现在都包裹在这些甜蜜的纸片之中，它们之于他，就像钞票之于守财奴。同时，在莫黛斯特心里，一种深深的爱代替了她扰乱一个名人生活的那种快乐，这种爱虽是远距离的，却仍成了她生活的重心。埃内斯特的心灵正好与卡那利的名气互补。唉！往往两个男人加起来才能成就一个完美的情人，就像在文学作品中，我们通过集合几个相似人物的特性来塑造一种典型人物。多少次，我们听到一个女人在自己的沙龙里进行亲密的交谈后说道：
Chapter I The Chalet: Urged by a mind that seemed as aggressive as the heart was lovable, the truly chivalrous feelings of the poor secretary gave themselves free play in these suppressed letters, which seem, perhaps, more beautiful than they really are, because the imagination is charmed by a sense of the communion of two free souls.Ernest’s whole life was now wrapped up in these sweet scraps of paper; they were to him what banknotes are to a miser; while in Modeste’s soul a deep love took the place of her delight in agitating a glorious life, and being, in spite of distance, its mainspring.Ernest’s heart was the complement of Canalis’s glory.Alas! it often takes two men to make a perfect lover, just as in literature we compose a type by collecting the peculiarities of several similar characters.How many a time a woman has been heard to say in her own salon after close and intimate conversations:—

第一章 木屋: “这个人是我心灵的理想伴侣，而单从感官上讲，另一个人则是我的梦中情人。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Such a one is my ideal as to soul, and I love the other who is only a dream of the senses.”

第一章 木屋: 下面是莫黛斯特写的最后一封信，它让我们一窥两位有情人通过这段曲折的通信之路到达的魔力之岛。
Chapter I The Chalet: The last letter written by Modeste, which here follows, gives us a glimpse of the enchanted isle to which the meanderings of this correspondence had led the two lovers.

第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利先生：您下个星期天到勒阿弗尔来吧，去教堂。早礼拜之后，您就围着教堂中殿转上一两圈，然后走出去，不要跟任何人讲话，但请您在扣眼里别上一朵白玫瑰。之后就回巴黎去吧，您将在那里得到我的答复。我先跟您说好，我的答复不一定是您所期望的那样，因为，正如我跟你说过的，我对未来还没有把握。但如果还没有见过您，我就答应了您，那我岂不是真的疯了、傻了？在我见过您之后，我可以拒绝您而不伤害您，我可以肯定您不会看到我。
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis,—Be at Havre next Sunday; go to church; after the morning service, walk once or twice round the nave, and go out without speaking to any one; but wear a white rose in your button-hole.Then return to Paris, where you shall receive an answer.I warn you that this answer will not be what you wish; for, as I told you, the future is not yet mine.But should I not indeed be mad and foolish to say yes without having seen you?When I have seen you I can say no without wounding you; I can make sure that you shall not see me.

第一章 木屋: 这封信是在迪迈和莫黛斯特之间那场无果的较量的前一天晚上送出去的。这位幸福的姑娘正焦急不安地等待着星期天，那天，她的双眼将对她的心灵和行为进行辩护，或者判罪——那是任何一个女人一生中的庄重时刻，三个月的心灵密切交流此刻变得如此浪漫，只有最有想象力的少女才能想象得到。每个人，除了她的母亲，都把这种因期待而表现出的迟钝麻木当作了天真无邪的平静。无论家规和宗教戒律有多么强有力的束缚，总会有克拉丽莎和朱莉那样的女孩，她们的心灵就像斟满的酒杯，在某种精神压力下酒便会溢出杯外。莫黛斯特出色地用她那原始的力量抑制着热情洋溢的青春活力，并保持着端庄的娴静。坦白说，对她而言，她姐姐的记忆比任何社会传统都有力得多。她有钢铁般的意志，决心不给她的父亲母亲带来任何悲伤。可她的内心却是怎样地跌宕起伏啊！怪不得一位母亲能揣测到这些。
Chapter I The Chalet: This letter had been sent off the evening before the day when the abortive struggle between Dumay and Modeste had taken place.The happy girl was impatiently awaiting Sunday, when her eyes were to vindicate or condemn her heart and her actions,—a solemn moment in the life of any woman, and which three months of close communion of souls now rendered as romantic as the most imaginative maiden could have wished.Every one, except the mother, had taken this torpor of expectation for the calm of innocence.No matter how firmly family laws and religious precepts may bind, there will always be the Clarissas and the Julies, whose souls like flowing cups overlap the brim under some spiritual pressure.Modeste was glorious in the savage energy with which she repressed her exuberant youthful happiness and remained demurely quiet.Let us say frankly that the memory of her sister was more potent upon her than any social conventions; her will was iron in the resolve to bring no grief upon her father and her mother.But what tumultuous heavings were within her breast! no wonder that a mother guessed them.

第一章 木屋: 第二天，大约中午的时候，莫黛斯特和迪迈夫人带着米尼翁夫人，坐在花丛中的一条凳子上晒太阳。这位失明的女人将她苍白憔悴的脸转向大海，她呼吸着大海的气息，抓住她身边的女儿的手。盘问女儿之前，母亲在原谅和规劝之间犹豫不决，因为她理解少女的爱情，而且跟那位冒牌的卡那利一样，她也觉得莫黛斯特的天性与众不同。
Chapter I The Chalet: On the following day Modeste and Madame Dumay took Madame Mignon about mid-day to a seat in the sun among the flowers.The blind woman turned her wan and blighted face toward the ocean; she inhaled the odors of the sea and took the hand of her daughter who remained beside her.The mother hesitated between forgiveness and remonstrance ere she put the important question; for she comprehended the girl’s love and recognized, as the pretended Canalis had done, that Modeste was exceptional in nature.

第一章 木屋: “上帝保佑你父亲能及时回来！如果他耽搁太久，就只剩下你一个人爱他了。莫黛斯特，再一次答应我，永远都不要离开他。”她用一个母亲宠爱的口吻说道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “God grant that your father return in time!If he delays much longer he will find none but you to love him.Modeste, promise me once more never to leave him,” she said in a fond maternal tone.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特把母亲的双手托到自己唇边，轻轻亲吻它们，并回答道：“需要我再说一遍吗？”

第一章 木屋: “啊，我的孩子！是我自己要求你这样做的。我离开了我的父亲，跟随我的丈夫，而我的父亲却孤身一人，我是她唯一的孩子。因为这一点，上帝才如此惩罚我吗？我对你的要求就是按照你父亲的心愿嫁人，从内心里珍爱他，不要为了你自己的幸福牺牲他，要把他当作你家庭的中心。在我失明前，我把我的全部遗嘱写给了他，我知道他会实现它们的。我嘱咐他把财产完整地保留在自己手里，不是说我不信任你，等等，我的莫黛斯特，但是谁能信任一位女婿呢？啊！我的女儿，看着我，我说得有道理吗？一瞥青睐便定我终身。美貌总是骗人的东西，对我而言这是实话，但在你身上甚至也是同样。我可怜的孩子，向我发誓，你会让你的父亲打探清楚你所爱的人——如果碰巧真有这样一个男人的话，看看他的品性、习惯、内心，以及他以往的生活。”

第一章 木屋: 致让·迪迈先生：
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur Jean Dumay:

第一章 木屋: 我亲爱的迪迈——继给你带去这封信的那艘船之后，我也将很快回来，除非航行中有什么变故。事实上，我本应该坐上这艘船，但我不想离开自己的船，我已经习惯了自己的船。
Chapter I The Chalet: My Dear Dumay,—I shall quickly follow, barring the chances of the voyage, the vessel which carries this letter.In fact, I should have taken it, but I did not wish to leave my own ship to which I am accustomed.

第一章 木屋: 我跟你说过，没有消息就是好消息。但这封信开头的话应该能令你高兴。我至少赚了七百万。我将这些财产带回，大部分是靛蓝染料，三分之一是可靠的伦敦有价证券，还有三分之一是十足的纯金子。在你汇款的帮助下，我很快赚到了我头脑里预定的金额，比我预想中快得多。我想挣到两百万，给我女儿，也保证自己生活舒适。
Chapter I The Chalet: I told you that no new was to be good news.But the first words of this letter ought to make you a happy man.I have made seven millions at the least.I am bringing back a large part of it in indigo, one third in safe London securities, and another third in good solid gold.Your remittances helped me to make the sum I had settled in my own mind much sooner than I expected.I wanted two millions for my daughters and a competence for myself.

第一章 木屋: 我跟广州最大的那些商号做鸦片买卖，所有这些商号都要比我富上十倍。你在欧洲没法想象这些富有的东印度商人是什么样。我去了小亚细亚，低价购得鸦片，然后就去了广州，把货转卖给操纵这一行的公司。我最后一次远航是去菲律宾群岛，在那儿，我用鸦片换取了上等的靛蓝染料。事实上，我可能比我说的还多赚了五十万，因为我在给靛蓝染料估价时，只算了成本。我身体一直都很好，一点儿小病都没有。这是因为，我在为自己的孩子们工作。第二年起，我就有了一艘载重七百吨的漂亮的小双桅船，船名就叫“米尼翁号”。船是橡木制成的，双层板，由铜钉固定，所有的内部设施也根据我的需要进行了改造。其实，她也是一笔额外的财产。
Chapter I The Chalet: I have been engaged in the opium trade with the largest houses in Canton, all ten times richer than ever I was.You have no idea, in Europe, what these rich East India merchants are.I went to Asia Minor and purchased opium at low prices, and from thence to Canton where I delivered my cargoes to the companies who control the trade.My last expedition was to the Philippine Islands where I exchanged opium for indigo of the first quality.In fact, I may have half a million more than I stated, for I reckoned the indigo at what it cost me.I have always been well in health; not the slightest illness.That is the result of working for one’s children.Since the second year I have owned a pretty little brig of seven hundred tons, called the “Mignon.”She is built of oak, double-planked, and copper-fastened; and all the interior fittings were done to suit me.She is, in fact, an additional piece of property.

第一章 木屋: 海上生活，加上生意需要养成的勤劳习惯，让我保持了健康的体魄。告诉你这一切，跟告诉我的两个女儿和亲爱的妻子是一样的。我想，那个拐走我的贝蒂娜的可恶家伙肯定在得知我破产后便抛弃了她，而我将在木屋见到我那可怜的迷途羔羊。我三个亲爱的女人和我的迪迈！在过去的三年里，我无时无刻不想着你们四个人。现在，你是一个富人了，迪迈。除去我自己的财产，你的股份总计达五十六万法郎，因此我随信给你汇了一张支票，请你亲自带着它去蒙日诺银号兑现，我在纽约就跟他们充分交待过了。
Chapter I The Chalet: A sea-life and the active habits required by my business have kept me in good health.To tell you all this is the same as telling it to my two daughters and my dear wife.I trust that the wretched man who took away my Bettina deserted her when he heard of my ruin; and that I shall find the poor lost lamb at the Chalet.My three dear women and my Dumay!All four of you have been ever present in my thoughts for the last three years.You are a rich man, now, Dumay.Your share, outside of my own fortune, amounts to five hundred and sixty thousand francs, for which I send you herewith a check, which can only be paid to you in person by the Mongenods, who have been duly advised from New York.

第一章 木屋: 短短的几个月之后，我就会再次见到你们所有人，所有人都会好好的，我相信。我亲爱的迪迈，我给你写这封信，是因为我希望暂时将我的财产保密。因此，我相信你会乐意为我亲爱的天使们做好准备，迎接我的归来。我已经厌倦了经商，而且决定离开勒阿弗尔。我想赎回拉巴斯蒂庄园，并限定其继承权，这样便有了一份每年至少收入一万法郎的不动产。然后，我会去请求国王，准许我的一位女婿继承我的姓氏和头衔。你知道的，我可怜的迪迈，家财万贯的致命名声给我们带来了多么可怕的不幸——我一个女儿的声誉因此失去了。所以，我决心不让别人知道我现在拥有的财产。我不会在勒阿弗尔登岸，而是在马赛。我会通过在巴黎的蒙日诺商号将靛蓝卖掉，并商量赎回拉巴斯蒂庄园。我会把钱存到法兰西银行，然后回到木屋，对外只说我有大笔钱压在货物上。人们会以为我的女儿们只有二十到三十万法郎的财产。现在，我生活的目标就是选择值得继承我的头衔和地产、并同我们一起生活的女婿。但是，两个女婿都得像你我一样，正直、忠诚、可靠，而且要绝对地值得尊敬。

Chapter I The Chalet: At this moment Modeste, happy as she was in the return of her father, was, nevertheless, pacing her room disconsolate as Perrette on seeing her eggs broken.She had hoped her father would bring back a much larger fortune than Dumay had mentioned.Nothing could satisfy her new-found ambition on behalf of her poet less than at least half the six millions she had talked of in her second letter.Trebly agitated by her two joys and the grief caused by her comparative poverty, she seated herself at the piano, that confidant of so many young girls, who tell out their wishes and provocations on the keys, expressing them by the notes and tones of their music.Dumay was talking with his wife in the garden under the windows, telling her the secret of their own wealth, and questioning her as to her desires and her intentions.Madame Dumay had, like her husband, no other family than the Mignons.Husband and wife agreed, therefore, to go and live in Provence, if the Comte de La Bastie really meant to live in Provence, and to leave their money to whichever of Modeste’s children might need it most.

第一章 木屋: 在当前处境带给她的灵感之下，莫黛斯特给她的音乐加入了一些诗节，我们这里不得不提到它们——尽管它们已被收录到多里亚提到的卡那利诗集第二卷里——因为，为了使这些诗节能配合她的音乐，那如同伟大歌手的歌声一样、充满无以言表的感情魅力的音乐，莫黛斯特信手修改了它们，这种随意的修改方式可能会让卡那利的崇拜者们大吃一惊，因为他们的诗人是以精于修饰著称的，有时甚至精细得有点过头。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste, under the inspiration of her present situation, was putting to music certain stanzas which we are compelled to quote here—albeit they are printed in the second volume of the edition Dauriat had mentioned—because, in order to adapt them to her music, which had the inexpressible charm of sentiment so admired in great singers, Modeste had taken liberties with the lines in a manner that may astonish the admirers of a poet so famous for the correctness, sometimes too precise, of his measures.

Chapter I The Chalet: Hunchbacks are extraordinary creations, due entirely to society for, according to Nature’s plan, feeble or aborted beings ought to perish.The curvature or distortion of the spinal column creates in these outwardly deformed subjects as it were a storage-battery, where the nerve currents accumulate more abundantly than under normal conditions,—where they develop, and whence they are emitted, so to say, in lightning flashes, to energize the interior being.From this, forces result which are sometimes brought to light by magnetism, though they are far more frequently lost in the vague spaces of the spiritual world.It is rare to find a deformed person who is not gifted with some special faculty,—a whimsical or sparkling gaiety perhaps, an utter malignity, or an almost sublime goodness.Like instruments which the hand of art can never fully waken, these beings, highly privileged though they know it not, live within themselves, as Butscha lived, provided their natural forces so magnificently concentrated have not been spent in the struggle they have been forced to maintain, against tremendous odds, to keep alive.This explains many superstitions, the popular legends of gnomes, frightful dwarfs, deformed fairies,—all that race of bottles, as Rabelais called them, containing elixirs and precious balms.

Chapter I The Chalet: Butscha, therefore, had very nearly found the key to the puzzle.With all the anxious solicitude of a hopeless lover, a vassal ever ready to die,—like the soldiers alone and abandoned in the snows of Russia, who still cried out, “Long live the Emperor,”—he meditated how to capture Modeste’s secret for his own private knowledge.So thinking, he followed his patrons to the Chalet that evening, with a cloud of care upon his brow: for he knew it was most important to hide from all these watchful eyes and ears the net, whatever it might be, in which he should entrap his lady.It would have to be, he thought, by some intercepted glance, some sudden start or quiver, as when a surgeon lays his finger on a hidden sore.That evening Gobenheim did not appear, and Butscha was Dumay’s partner against Monsieur and Madame Latournelle.During the few moment’s of Modeste’s absence, about nine o’clock, to prepare for her mother’s bedtime, Madame Mignon and her friends spoke openly to one another; but the poor clerk, depressed by the conviction of Modeste’s love, which had now seized upon him as upon the rest, seemed as remote from the discussion as Gobenheim had been the night before.

第一章 木屋: “他到了法定年龄，二十五岁半了。孩子，我也会资助你买下事务所，这对我来说也算是还了一笔债。”公证人说道。

第一章 木屋: 就在莫黛斯特打开客厅的门时，比查正在亲吻米尼翁夫人的手，他的脸已被泪水浸湿。
