第一章 木屋: “你们对我的黑侏儒做什么了？”她问道，“谁惹他不高兴了？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “What are you doing to my Black Dwarf?” she demanded.“Who is making him unhappy?”

第一章 木屋: “啊！米尼翁小姐，我们这些在不幸的摇篮中长大的不幸之人，哪里为悲伤哭过？我把他们当作真正的亲人来爱，而他们刚刚对我也表现出了同样的疼爱。我要成为一名公证人了，我会富起来。哈！哈！贫穷的比查可能变成富有的比查。您不知道我这个早产儿有多大胆。”他哭道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah! Mademoiselle Mignon, do we luckless fellows, cradled in misfortune, ever weep for grief?They have just shown me as much affection as I could feel for them if they were indeed my own relations.I’m to be a notary; I shall be rich.Ha! ha! the poor Butscha may become the rich Butscha.You don’t know what audacity there is in this abortion,” he cried.

第一章 木屋: 说着，他使劲地拍了一下胸脯，又瞄了一眼莫黛斯特，便站到了壁炉前面去。他那匆匆一瞥，就像从那半闭的厚眼皮间溜出的一道光。在这个突如其来的小插曲中，他发现了一个询问他的女王心思的机会。迪迈有一会儿以为这位文书敢追求莫黛斯特，他很快同其他人交换了眼色，大家都明白他的意思，开始以一种担心又好奇的心情看着这个小个子。
Chapter I The Chalet: With that he gave himself a resounding blow on the cavity of his chest and took up a position before the fireplace, after casting a glance at Modeste, which slipped like a ray of light between his heavy half-closed eyelids.He perceived, in this unexpected incident, a chance of interrogating the heart of his sovereign.Dumay thought for a moment that the clerk dared to aspire to Modeste, and he exchanged a rapid glance with the others, who understood him, and began to eye the little man with a species of terror mingled with curiosity.

第一章 木屋: “我，也有，我的梦想。”比查说，他的目光一直没离开莫黛斯特。
Chapter I The Chalet: “I, too, have my dreams,” said Butscha, not taking his eyes from Modeste.

第一章 木屋: 这位少女眼睑低垂，这一动作对那位年轻人来说，已是某种暗示了。
Chapter I The Chalet: The young girl lowered her eyelids with a movement that was a revelation to the young man.

第一章 木屋: “您喜欢浪漫故事，”他对她说，“在这个快乐的时刻，请让我告诉您我的故事，然后您要告诉我，我为我的生活设想的这个故事结局是否可能。跟其他人相比，钱财将给我带来更大的幸福，因为我能想象到的最高幸福就是让我所爱的人富有。小姐，您懂得那么多事情，请告诉我，一个男人，不管他的外表是帅气还是丑陋，仅凭他的心灵就能叫别人爱上他，这有可能吗？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “You love romance,” he said, addressing her.“Let me, in this moment of happiness, tell you mine; and you shall tell me in return whether the conclusion of the tale I have invented for my life is possible.To me wealth would bring greater happiness than to other men; for the highest happiness I can imagine would be to enrich the one I loved.You, mademoiselle, who know so many things, tell me if it is possible for a man to make himself beloved independently of his person, be it handsome or ugly, and for his spirit only?”

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特抬起眼睛看着比查。她尖锐的目光里充满质问，因为她跟迪迈一样，怀疑比查的动机。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste raised her eyes and looked at Butscha.It was a piercing and questioning glance; for she shared Dumay’s suspicion of Butscha’s motive.

第一章 木屋: “如果我富有了，我会找一个漂亮而贫穷的女孩，一个像我一样被抛弃过、受过苦、了解什么是痛苦的女孩。我会给她写信，安慰她，还要做她的守护神。她会读懂我的心，我的灵魂，她会拥有双份财富，我的两份财富——我温柔地奉献出的金钱，还有我光彩照人的思想，因为出生时，命运给了我丑陋的身体，没有给我外在的光彩。但我会继续隐藏自己，就像被科学家苦苦探寻的一个原因那样。上帝自己说不定也不起眼。那么，这位少女自然会十分好奇，她将希望见到我，但我会告诉她我是一个丑陋的魔鬼，我会把自己形容得极其可怕。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Let me be rich, and I will seek some beautiful poor girl, abandoned like myself, who has suffered, who knows what misery is.I will write to her and console her, and be her guardian spirit; she shall read my heart, my soul; she shall possess by double wealth, my two wealths,—my gold, delicately offered, and my thought robed in all the splendor which the accident of birth has denied to my grotesque body.But I myself shall remain hidden like the cause that science seeks.God himself may not be glorious to the eye.Well, naturally, the maiden will be curious; she will wish to see me; but I shall tell her that I am a monster of ugliness; I shall picture myself hideous.”

第一章 木屋: 听了这些话，莫黛斯特把目光瞥向比查，专注地打量他。如果她大声问：“你知道我恋情的哪些事？”那她的事就再清楚不过了。
Chapter I The Chalet: At these words Modeste gave Butscha a glance that looked him through and through.If she had said aloud, “What do you know of my love?” she could not have been more explicit.

第一章 木屋: “如果我有幸因内心的诗情得到爱慕，如果有一天，这样的爱情能让一个女子认为我只是有一点儿畸形而已，我问您，小姐，难道我不会比最英俊的男人还要幸福吗？——就像一个天才的男人被某个您这样的天使爱着那样幸福。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “If I have the honor of being loved for the poem of my heart, if some day such love may make a woman think me only slightly deformed, I ask you, mademoiselle, shall I not be happier than the handsomest of men,—as happy as a man of genius beloved by some celestial being like yourself.”

第一章 木屋: 少女羞红的脸颊几乎告诉了驼子所有他想知道的事情。
Chapter I The Chalet: The color which suffused the young girl’s face told the cripple nearly all he sought to know.

第一章 木屋: “那么，如果那样，”他接着说，“如果我们让所爱的人变得富有，如果我们让他们从精神上感到快乐，而不考虑长相，难道这不是争取爱慕的方式吗？不管怎样，这是您可怜的侏儒的梦想——昨天的梦想，因为今天，您的母亲答应资助我盘下一家事务所，这给了我通向未来财富的钥匙。但在我成为另一个哥本海姆之前，我很想知道这一梦想能否真正实现。小姐，您，怎么说呢？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Well, if that be so,” he went on, “if we enrich the one we love, if we please the spirit and withdraw the body, is not that the way to make one’s self beloved?At any rate it is the dream of your poor dwarf,—a dream of yesterday; for today your mother gives me the key to future wealth by promising me the means of buying a practice.But before I become another Gobenheim, I seek to know whether this dream could be really carried out.What do you say, mademoiselle, you?”

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特太震惊了，以至于她都没有注意到这个问题。这位爱慕者的圈套设计得要比老兵迪迈那个好得多，因为这位可怜的姑娘已经无言以对了。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste was so astonished that she did not notice the question.The trap of the lover was much better baited than that of the soldier, for the poor girl was rendered speechless.

Chapter I The Chalet: “You want to realize the story of Beauty and the Beast,” said Modeste at length; “but you forget that the Beast turned into Prince Charming.”

第一章 木屋: 说完这些，比查又坐回到他的位子上，假装镇定地跟另外三个玩惠斯特牌的人说：“该谁出牌了？”但是，他在心里忧愁地对自己嘀咕道：“她想凭自己的人格赢得爱慕，她在跟某个冒充大人物的人通信，这一切进展到什么程度了呢？”

第一章 木屋: “亲爱的妈妈，差不多十点钟了。”莫黛斯特说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Dear mamma, it is nearly ten o’clock,” said Modeste.

Chapter I The Chalet: “No, monsieur, none.”

Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur Butscha!”

Chapter I The Chalet: “Yes, mademoiselle,” he answered proudly.“Ah! I never expected,” he continued in a low tone, “that the grub could be of service to a star,—but so it is.Would you rather that your mother and Monsieur Dumay and Madame Latournelle had guessed your secret than one, excluded as it were from life, who seeks to be to you one of those flowers that you cut and wear for a moment?They all know you love; but I, I alone, know how.Use me as you would a vigilant watch-dog; I will obey you, protect you, and never bark; neither will I condemn you.I ask only to be of service to you.Your father has made Dumay keeper of the hen-roost, take Butscha to watch outside,—poor Butscha, who doesn’t ask for anything, not so much as a bone.”

Chapter I The Chalet: “Listen to me, mademoiselle,” said Butscha, interrupting Modeste respectfully.“I will go and take a walk on the seashore, for you don’t want me to go to church today; that’s what it is.”

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特看着她的小矮人，完全愣住了。

Chapter I The Chalet: “Mademoiselle, you have wrapped your face in cotton-wool and a silk handkerchief, but there’s nothing the matter with you; and you have put that thick veil on your bonnet to see some one yourself without being seen.”

第一章 木屋: “去吧，那样我就会信任你。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Go, and I will trust you.”

Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter XIII A Full-Length Portrait of Monsieur De La Briere

第一章 木屋: 在男人的一生中，还有比第一次约会更令人高兴的时刻吗？隐藏在心底的情感第一次迸发出来，这种情感还能重新来过吗？像埃内斯特·德拉布里埃一样，当我们寻找最锋利的剃须刀、最漂亮的衬衫、洁白无暇的领结以及最好的衣服时，所感受到的那种无名的快乐，能够重温吗？由于这些衣着与那一至高无上的时刻息息相关，我们便将它们奉若神明。与女人一样，我们内心也摇曳着诗意的幻想。等到男女双方都猜透这一切的那一天，这些幻想就自己张开翅膀飞走了。这些事情，不正如生长在森林腹地的野果之花，苦涩而甜美吗？不正如沐浴在宝贵阳光中的快乐吗？不正如卡那利在《少女之歌》中说到的，那株紫罗兰睁开眼睛看到内心的自我时的快乐吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: Is there in the life of man a more delightful moment than that of a first rendezvous?Are the sensations then hidden at the bottom of our hearts and finding their first expression ever renewed?Can we feel again the nameless pleasures that we felt when, like Ernest de La Briere, we looked up our sharpest razors, our finest shirt, an irreproachable collar, and our best clothes?We deify the garments associated with that all-supreme moment.We weave within us poetic fancies quite equal to those of the woman; and the day when either party guesses them they take wings to themselves and fly away.Are not such things like the flower of wild fruits, bitter-sweet, grown in the heart of a forest, the joy of the scant sun-rays, the joy, as Canalis says in the “Maiden’s Song,” of the plant itself whose eyes unclosing see its own image within its breast?

第一章 木屋: 这样的情感正发生在拉布里埃身上。从中我们大概能看出，跟其他生来艰辛操劳的人一样，他还从来没被爱过。他前一天晚上到达勒阿弗尔之后，就真像个风情万种的女子一样，马上上床睡觉，以便消除所有疲劳的痕迹。而现在，洗过澡之后，他穿上了精心设计的服饰，从而展现他最突出的一面。也许，这正是展示一幅他的全身像的最佳时刻，即使只是为了证明莫黛斯特将要给他写的最后一封信言之有理。
Chapter I The Chalet: Such emotions, now taking place in La Briere, tend to show that, like other poor fellows for whom life begins in toil and care, he had never yet been loved.Arriving at Havre overnight, he had gone to bed at once, like a true coquette, to obliterate all traces of fatigue; and now, after taking his bath, he had put himself into a costume carefully adapted to show him off to the best advantage.This is, perhaps, the right moment to exhibit a full-length portrait of him, if only to justify the last letter that Modeste was still to write to him.

第一章 木屋: 埃内斯特出生于图卢兹一个良好的家庭，跟先前保护过他的那位大臣沾点亲。他举止颇有教养，这来自于婴儿时期便开始的良好教育。处理公务养成的习惯让他显得沉稳镇静，却并非书生气——尽管过早沉稳的人自然会带些书生气。他中等个头，细腻甜美的脸庞征服了所有见过他的人，肤色尽管不够红润，但至少是暖色调的。他还留着小胡子和马萨林式的帝髯。若不是有这一男性的证据，他简直就像个男扮女装的年轻姑娘了。他的脸部轮廓和嘴唇线条是那么精致，两排牙齿整齐得像是假的，透明的象牙白色是那么女性化。除这些类似女性的特征之外，他的说话方式也跟面部表情一样柔和，跟土耳其式眼睑下的蓝色双眸一样温柔。这样你就很容易明白为什么那位大臣有时候称这位年轻秘书为“德拉布里埃小姐”了。他饱满干净的额头，恰到好处地镶嵌在浓密的黑发之中，如梦幻一般，与那张整体充满忧郁的脸庞浑然一体。他的上眼皮有着突起的棱角，虽然轮廓十分漂亮，但还是遮住了目光，并在眼皮下垂的时候，平添了几分忧伤的表现——如果我们可以这样说的话。他全身上下都散发着这种内在的疑虑或黯然——用一个词表达就是谦虚。按照绘画的逻辑，他那鹅蛋型的脸还应该更长些，在他收得太快的下巴和因头发太长而显得不够高的额头之间，应该有更大的空间，这样一说，也许大家就能对他的相貌有更直观的了解。简言之，他的脸长得太紧凑了。辛劳的工作已经在他的眉宇间刻上了皱纹，他的眉毛有点太粗了，而且像那些生性好嫉妒的人似的，眉毛离得过近。虽然拉布里埃当时比较瘦，但他还是属于三十岁后会突然长一身肉的那种人。
Chapter I The Chalet: Born of a good family in Toulouse, and allied by marriage to the minister who first took him under his protection, Ernest had that air of good-breeding which comes of an education begun in the cradle; and the habit of managing business affairs gave him a certain sedateness which was not pedantic,—though pedantry is the natural outgrowth of premature gravity.He was of ordinary height; his face, which won upon all who saw him by its delicacy and sweetness, was warm in the flesh-tints, though without color, and relieved by a small moustache and imperial a la Mazarin.Without this evidence of virility he might have resembled a young woman in disguise, so refined was the shape of his face and the cut of his lips, so feminine the transparent ivory of a set of teeth, regular enough to have seemed artificial.Add to these womanly points a habit of speech as gentle as the expression of the face; as gentle, too, as the blue eyes with their Turkish eyelids, and you will readily understand how it was that the minister occasionally called his young secretary Mademoiselle de La Briere.The full, clear forehead, well framed by abundant black hair, was dreamy, and did not contradict the character of the face, which was altogether melancholy.The prominent arch of the upper eyelid, though very beautifully cut, overshadowed the glance of the eye, and added a physical sadness,—if we may so call it,—produced by the droop of the lid over the eyeball.This inward doubt or eclipse—which is put into language by the word modesty—was expressed in his whole person.Perhaps we shall be able to make his appearance better understood if we say that the logic of design required greater length in the oval of his head, more space between the chin, which ended abruptly, and the forehead, which was reduced in height by the way in which the hair grew.The face had, in short, a rather compressed appearance.Hard work had already drawn furrows between the eyebrows, which were somewhat too thick and too near together, like those of a jealous nature.Though La Briere was then slight, he belonged to the class of temperaments which begin, after they are thirty, to take on an unexpected amount of flesh.

第一章 木屋: 在学习法国历史的学生看来，这位年轻人颇有点像气度高贵、深不可测的路易十三——那位历史人物有着莫名的忧郁与谦逊，皇冠下的脸苍白无血色；爱好战争的风险和狩猎的劳累，但讨厌工作；害怕他的夫人，到了对她敬而远之的程度；对什么都漠不关心，以至于任由他的朋友被砍头——他的脸就像一个难解之谜，唯一的解释就是他因替父亲报复母亲而感到懊悔。他是一个信天主教的哈姆雷特呢，还是仅仅只是一个患了不治之症的病人呢？不过，啃食着国王生命要害的不死之虫在埃内斯特身上，只是表现为缺乏自信心——一个没听女人说过“啊，我多么爱你啊！”的男人的胆怯，还有最重要的一点，就是毫无目的的自我奉献精神。随着他主人所在的内阁的倒台，这个可怜的小伙子听到了王朝的丧钟。此后，他便倒在了一块被美丽的青苔所覆盖的顽石上，那顽石的名字就叫卡那利。因此，他仍在寻找爱的能力，这种宠臣寻找主人的精神，却赋予了他国王发现宠臣时的那种外在表现。这种感情的游戏，再加上这个年轻人脸上一种总体的忧伤气质，使他的脸庞漂亮得超出了自己的想象，因为他总是不高兴女人们把他归类为“抑郁的美男子”——一个已过时的类型，因为在当今这个时代，每个男人都努力自吹自擂，让自己高人一等。
Chapter I The Chalet: The young man would have seemed to a student of French history a very fair representative of the royal and almost inconceivable figure of Louis XIII.,—that historical figure of melancholy modesty without known cause; pallid beneath the crown; loving the dangers of war and the fatigues of hunting, but hating work; timid with his mistress to the extent of keeping away from her; so indifferent as to allow the head of his friend to be cut off,—a figure that nothing can explain but his remorse for having avenged his father on his mother.Was he a Catholic Hamlet, or merely the victim of incurable disease?But the undying worm which gnawed at the king’s vitals was in Ernest’s case simply distrust of himself,—the timidity of a man to whom no woman had ever said, “Ah, how I love thee!” and, above all, the spirit of self-devotion without an object.After hearing the knell of the monarchy in the fall of his patron’s ministry, the poor fellow had next fallen upon a rock covered with exquisite mosses, named Canalis; he was, therefore, still seeking a power to love, and this spaniel-like search for a master gave him outwardly the air of a king who has met with his.This play of feeling, and a general tone of suffering in the young man’s face made it more really beautiful than he was himself aware of; for he had always been annoyed to find himself classed by women among the “handsome disconsolate,”—a class which has passed out of fashion in these days, when every man seeks to blow his own trumpet and put himself in the advance.

第一章 木屋: 缺乏自信的埃内斯特，把他目前的希望寄托在他穿的时髦衣服上了。为了这次一切都取决于第一印象的神圣会面，他穿了一条黑裤子，一双擦得锃亮的靴子，一件黄绿色的背心，露出做工精细、钉有乳白色纽扣的衬衣，打着一条黑色领带，身穿一件蓝色小礼服，背部和肩膀处十分贴身，像是用某种新式方法粘到身上去的。他的扣眼里系着荣誉军团的饰带。他戴着一双佛罗伦萨青铜色的小山羊皮手套，大小非常合适，左手拿着手杖和帽子，摆出一副“伟大的君主”（指路易十四）般的姿态和风度。按照这一神圣地点的要求，他露出了光亮的额头，让阳光照在他精心梳理过的头发上。弥撒开始前，他站在教堂门廊上，从那里可以端详整个教堂和所有基督徒——特别是女基督徒——看着她们把手指浸在圣水里。
Chapter I The Chalet: The self-distrustful Ernest now rested his immediate hopes on the fashionable clothes he intended to wear.He put on, for this sacred interview, where everything depended on a first impression, a pair of black trousers and carefully polished boots, a sulphur-colored waistcoat, which left to sight an exquisitely fine shirt with opal buttons, a black cravat, and a small blue surtout coat which seemed glued to his back and shoulders by some newly-invented process.The ribbon of the Legion of honor was in his buttonhole.He wore a well-fitting pair of kid gloves of the Florentine bronze color, and carried his cane and hat in the left hand with a gesture and air that was worthy of the Grand Monarch, and enabled him to show, as the sacred precincts required, his bare head with the light falling on his carefully arranged hair.He stationed himself before the service began in the church porch, from whence he could examine the church, and the Christians—more particularly the female Christians—who dipped their fingers in the holy water.

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特走进教堂时，内心的一个声音冲她喊道：“就是他！”那礼服，以及这位年轻人的整个气质，的确体现出巴黎人的本质，那饰带、那手套、那手杖，还有他发间的香气，都不是勒阿弗尔的。于是，当拉布里埃转过身来审视高大威严的拉图奈尔夫人、公证人以及裹得严严实实的（这个表达是专用于女人的）莫黛斯特时，这个可怜的孩子虽然已有充分的思想准备，但当她看到敞开的门里透进来的大片日光照亮这个富有诗意的人儿时，心头还是感到猛的一击。她肯定没搞错。一朵白玫瑰几乎遮住了他的荣誉军团饰带。他还能认出他那戴了一顶旧帽子、蒙着双重面纱的匿名女王吗？莫黛斯特很害怕爱情异常敏锐的洞察力，于是她开始像个老妇人一样弯着腰走路。
Chapter I The Chalet: An inward voice cried to Modeste as she entered, “It is he!”That surtout, and indeed the whole bearing of the young man were essentially Parisian; the ribbon, the gloves, the cane, the very perfume of his hair were not of Havre.So when La Briere turned about to examine the tall and imposing Madame Latournelle, the notary, and the bundled-up (expression sacred to women) figure of Modeste, the poor child, though she had carefully tutored herself for the event, received a violent blow on her heart when her eyes rested on this poetic figure, illuminated by the full light of day as it streamed through the open door.She could not be mistaken; a small white rose nearly hid the ribbon of the Legion.Would he recognize his unknown mistress muffled in an old bonnet with a double veil?Modeste was so in fear of love’s clairvoyance that she began to stoop in her walk like an old woman.

第一章 木屋: 整个弥撒过程中，埃内斯特一直都站在门廊里，却没看到一个能实现他梦想的女子。而莫黛斯特则不能自已地浑身发抖，一直到弥撒差不多结束。她领略到的快乐，除了她自己没有人能够描述。终于，她听到了走廊地面上一个男子的脚步声。此时弥撒已经结束了，拉布里埃正在教堂里绕着圈子。教堂里只剩下那些一丝不苟的虔诚教徒，他开始对他们进行细致透彻的分析。埃内斯特从一个女人身边走过时，注意到这个戴着面纱的女人手里的祈祷书在剧烈地颤抖。由于只有她一个人是蒙着脸的，埃内斯特便起了疑心。接着，这位情人的眼睛又扫到了莫黛斯特的衣服，这衣着引起了他的注意，证实了他的怀疑。他跟着拉图奈尔夫妇离开了教堂，并远远地跟着他们到了王政街，看到莫黛斯特陪着他们一起进了一所房子。按照惯例，莫黛斯特要跟她的朋友一直呆到做晚祷的时候。埃内斯特打量了一下这座门口饰有盾形标志的小房子，接着又打听了房主的名字。别人告诉他，房子的主人是拉图奈尔先生，勒阿弗尔的首席公证人。埃内斯特沿着王政街溜达着，想往房子里瞅上一眼。这时，莫黛斯特看到了他，于是她说自己病得厉害，不能去做晚祷了。这样，可怜的埃内斯特的辛苦就白费了。他不敢到安古维尔去转悠，而且，他也把服从命令当作维护自己颜面所必须做的事，于是便回到了巴黎。在回巴黎之前，他还写了一封信。弗朗索瓦丝·科歇第二天准时把这封信交给了莫黛斯特，信封上盖的是勒阿弗尔的邮戳。
Chapter I The Chalet: Ernest remained in the porch throughout the service without seeing any woman who realized his hopes.Modeste, on her part, could not control the trembling of her limbs until Mass was nearly over.She was in the grasp of a joy that none but she herself could depict.At last she heard the foot-fall of a gentleman on the pavement of the aisle.The service over, La Briere was making a circuit of the church, where no one now remained but the punctiliously pious, whom he proceeded to subject to a shrewd and keen analysis.Ernest noticed that a prayer-book shook violently in the hands of a veiled woman as he passed her; as she alone kept her face hidden his suspicions were aroused, and then confirmed by Modeste’s dress, which the lover’s eye now scanned and noted.He left the church with the Latournelles and followed them at a distance to the rue Royale, where he saw them enter a house accompanied by Modeste, whose custom it was to stay with her friends till the hour of vespers.After examining the little house, which was ornamented with scutcheons, he asked the name of the owner, and was told that he was Monsieur Latournelle, the chief notary in Havre.As Ernest lounged along the rue Royale hoping for a glimpse into the house, Modeste caught sight of him, and thereupon declared herself too ill to go to vespers.Poor Ernest thus had his trouble for his pains.He dared not wander about Ingouville; moreover, he made it a point of honor to obey orders, and he therefore went back to Paris, previously writing a letter which Francoise Cochet duly delivered on the morrow with the Havre postmark.

Chapter I The Chalet: “There is no need to question Dumay,” said Butscha.“Your father lost, as you know, about four millions when he went away, and he has doubtless recovered them.He would of course give Dumay ten per cent of his profits; the worthy man admitted the other day how much it was, and my master and I think that in that case the colonel’s fortune must amount to six or seven millions—”

第一章 木屋: “啊，爸爸！”莫黛斯特双手交叉在胸前，仰望天空，大声喊道，“你这是给了我两次生命啊！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh, papa!” cried Modeste, crossing her hands on her breast and looking up to heaven, “twice you have given me life!”

第一章 木屋: “啊，小姐！”比查说，“您爱上了一位诗人。那种人可跟那喀索斯似的，多多少少都有点自恋啊。他知道该怎么爱您吗？一个擅长吟诗颂词、总是忙于遣词造句的人，一定是个乏味的人。小姐，一位诗人并不等于一首诗篇，就像一粒种子并不等于一朵花。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, mademoiselle!” said Butscha, “you love a poet.That kind of man is more or less of a Narcissus.Will he know how to love you?A phrase-maker, always busy in fitting words together, must be a bore.Mademoiselle, a poet is no more poetry than a seed is a flower.”

第一章 木屋: “比查，我从来都没见过那么英俊的男子。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Butscha, I never saw so handsome a man.”

第一章 木屋: “美貌是一种面纱，通常是用来掩藏瑕疵的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Beauty is a veil which often serves to hide imperfections.”

第一章 木屋: “他的心灵最像天堂里的天使了——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “He has the most angelic heart of heaven—”

第一章 木屋: “我向上帝祈祷，但愿您是对的，”小矮人双掌合十说，“——还有，但愿您会幸福！那个人会跟您一样，拥有一个叫让·比查的仆人。我不会当公证人了，我放弃，我要研究科学。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I pray God you may be right,” said the dwarf, clasping his hands, “—and happy!That man shall have, as you have, a servant in Jean Butscha.I will not be notary; I shall give that up; I shall study the sciences.”

第一章 木屋: “为什么？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Why?”

第一章 木屋: “啊，小姐，为了培养您的孩子呀，如果您肯屈尊让我做他们的家庭教师。但是，唉！但愿您肯听我几句建议。让我接手这件事吧，让我深入调查这个人的生活和习惯——弄清他是否善良，是否脾气好，是否温柔，是否拥有好丈夫的品格、值得尊重，是否能真心实意地爱您，把您置于一切之上，甚至是他自己的才华之上——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, mademoiselle, to train up your children, if you will deign to make me their tutor.But, oh! if you would only listen to some advice.Let me take up this matter; let me look into the life and habits of this man,—find out if he is kind, or bad-tempered, or gentle, if he commands the respect which you merit in a husband, if he is able to love utterly, preferring you to everything, even his own talent—”

第一章 木屋: “如果我已经爱上他了，这样做还有什么意义呢？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “What does that signify if I love him?”

第一章 木屋: “啊，也对！”小矮人喊道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, true!” cried the dwarf.

第一章 木屋: 此刻，米尼翁夫人正对她的朋友们说道——
Chapter I The Chalet: At that instant Madame Mignon was saying to her friends,—

第一章 木屋: “我女儿今天早晨看到了她爱的人。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My daughter saw the man she loves this morning.”

第一章 木屋: “那么，肯定就是那个穿着黄绿色背心、让你好生疑惑的人了，拉图奈尔，”他的妻子说。“那个年轻人在他的扣眼里插了一支漂亮的白玫瑰。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Then it must have been that sulphur waistcoat which puzzled you so, Latournelle,” said his wife.“The young man had a pretty white rose in his buttonhole.”

第一章 木屋: “啊！”这位母亲叹息道，“那是他们相认的标志。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah!” sighed the mother, “the sign of recognition.”

第一章 木屋: “而且他还戴着荣誉军团军官的徽章。是个有魅力的年轻人。但我们都在自欺欺人啊，莫黛斯特从没掀起过她的面纱，而且她的衣服臃肿得像个乞丐女——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And he also wore the ribbon of an officer of the Legion of honor.He is a charming young man.But we are all deceiving ourselves; Modeste never raised her veil, and her clothes were huddled on like a beggar-woman’s—”

第一章 木屋: “还有，她说她生病了，”公证人大声说，“但现在她把那些包头的东西都摘掉了，看上去跟往常一样健康啊。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And she said she was ill,” cried the notary; “but she has taken off her mufflings and is just as well as she ever was.”

第一章 木屋: “真是令人费解！”迪迈说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “It is incomprehensible!” said Dumay.

第一章 木屋: “一点儿也不费解，”公证人说，“事情现在已经一清二楚了。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Not at all,” said the notary; “it is now as clear as day.”

第一章 木屋: “孩子，”莫黛斯特回到客厅里，后面跟着比查，她一进来米尼翁夫人就问道，“今天早晨你在教堂有没有看见一个穿着入时、扣眼里插着一支白玫瑰的年轻人？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My child,” said Madame Mignon to Modeste, as she came into the room, followed by Butscha, “did you see a well-dressed young man at church this morning, with a white rose in his button-hole?”

第一章 木屋: “我看到他了，”比查看到大家神情都有些紧张，觉得莫黛斯特很可能会中圈套，就赶紧说道，“他叫葛兰杜，著名的建筑师，镇上正跟他商量修复教堂的事。他刚从巴黎过来，早晨我在去圣阿德雷斯的路上，看到他正在考察教堂的外部情况。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I saw him,” said Butscha quickly, perceiving by everybody’s strained attention that Modeste was likely to fall into a trap.“It was Grindot, the famous architect, with whom the town is in treaty for the restoration of the church.He has just come from Paris, and I met him this morning examining the exterior as I was on my way to Sainte-Adresse.”

第一章 木屋: “噢，他是个建筑师吗？让我好生奇怪。”莫黛斯特说道，比查已经为她赢得了镇定下来的时间。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh, an architect, was he? he puzzled me,” said Modeste, for whom Butscha had thus gained time to recover herself.

第一章 木屋: 迪迈斜着眼看着比查。莫黛斯特已经完全警醒，恢复了她那高深莫测的镇定。迪迈的怀疑现在已经完全被激发了，他决定第二天早晨就到镇长办公室去确认一下那位建筑师今天是不是真来勒阿弗尔了。另一方面，比查也同样坚决地要去巴黎调查有关卡那利的事。
Chapter I The Chalet: Dumay looked askance at Butscha.Modeste, fully warned, recovered her impenetrable composure.Dumay’s distrust was now thoroughly aroused, and he resolved to go the mayor’s office early in the morning and ascertain if the architect had really been in Havre the previous day.Butscha, on the other hand, was equally determined to go to Paris and find out something about Canalis.

第一章 木屋: 哥本海姆来玩牌了，他的出现减轻并压制了所有人的燥动情绪。莫黛斯特焦躁不安地等着母亲就寝时间的到来。她想写信，但只有夜里才能写。全世界都入睡后，她的爱指引她写下了这封信——
Chapter I The Chalet: Gobenheim came to play whist, and by his presence subdued and compressed all this fermentation of feelings.Modeste awaited her mother’s bedtime with impatience.She intended to write, but never did so except at night.Here is the letter which love dictated to her while all the world was sleeping:—

第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利先生：啊！我的朋友，我心爱的人儿！那些摆在橱窗里的画像真是虚假透顶啊！而我，竟然把那幅可怕的石版画当作我的快乐！——一想到爱上了一个如此英俊的人，我就自卑。不，那些巴黎女人不可能笨到这种程度，看不到您能实现他们的美梦。什么您受到冷落！什么您没人爱！您告诉我的您孤独而又暗淡的生活，还有您渴望找到一位偶像——到如今都没有找到的偶像——我一个字都不相信了。先生，您是被爱腻了，您那如木兰叶一样洁白光亮的额头就说明了这一点，而我才是真正被忽略的——我算什么呢？啊！您为什么要唤醒我的生命呢？有一刻，我感觉肉体的重负仿佛正在离开我，我的灵魂已经打破了俘虏它的水晶罩，遍及了我整个身心，有形之物的冷漠已经不复存在，大自然中的所有东西都发出声音与我交谈。古老的教堂在闪闪发光。教堂的拱形顶，就像一座意大利大教堂那样发出金色和天蓝色的光芒，在我的头顶闪耀。天使为殉道者们唱的美妙歌曲从管风琴中流淌而出，平息了他们的痛苦。勒阿弗尔那粗糙不平的路面对我的脚来说，就像是一片华丽的草地，大海用怜悯的嗓音与我交谈，就像一位我从未真正理解的老朋友。我清楚地看到，自己花园里的玫瑰长久以来是如何崇拜我、向我示爱，我从教堂回来时，它们就抬起头，朝我微笑。我听到着您的名字“梅尔基奥尔”在钟状的花朵中回响，我看到了它被写在云朵上。是的，是的，我活了，我正活着，谢谢您——我的诗人，您比那个冷酷、传统的拜伦爵士英俊多了，他的脸就像英国的天气一样阴沉。您的一瞥，您那东方眼神的一瞥，便刺穿了我的双层面纱，将您的血液注入到了我的心脏，又流入我的头和双脚。啊！那不是母亲给予我们的那种生命。在您疼痛的那一刻，我也会感到疼痛——我的生命只通过您的思想而存在。我现在明白了音乐那神奇的力量有什么作用，是天使创造了音乐来表达爱情。啊，我的梅尔基奥尔，同时拥有天才和美貌也太过分了，应该让每个人出生时只能选择其一。
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur de Canalis,—Ah! my friend, my well-beloved!What atrocious falsehoods those portraits in the shop-windows are!And I, who made that horrible lithograph my joy!—I am humbled at the thought of loving one so handsome.No; it is impossible that those Parisian women are so stupid as not to have seen their dreams fulfilled in you.You neglected! you unloved!I do not believe a word of all that you have written me about your lonely and obscure life, your hunger for an idol,—sought in vain until now.You have been too well loved, monsieur; your brow, white and smooth as a magnolia leaf, reveals it; and it is I who must be neglected,—for who am I?Ah! why have you called me to life?I felt for a moment as though the heavy burden of the flesh was leaving me; my soul had broken the crystal which held it captive; it pervaded my whole being; the cold silence of material things had ceased; all things in nature had a voice and spoke to me.The old church was luminous.It’s arched roof, brilliant with gold and azure like those of an Italian cathedral, sparkled above my head.Melodies such as the angels sang to martyrs, quieting their pains, sounded from the organ.The rough pavements of Havre seemed to my feet a flowery mead; the sea spoke to me with a voice of sympathy, like an old friend whom I had never truly understood.I saw clearly how the roses in my garden had long adored me and bidden me love; they lifted their heads and smiled as I came back from church.I heard your name, “Melchior,” chiming in the flower-bells; I saw it written on the clouds.Yes, yes, I live, I am living, thanks to thee,—my poet, more beautiful than that cold, conventional Lord Byron, with a face as dull as the English climate.One glance of thine, thine Orient glance, pierced through my double veil and sent thy blood to my heart, and from thence to my head and feet.Ah! that is not the life our mother gave us.A hurt to thee would hurt me too at the very instant it was given,—my life exists by thy thought only.I know now the purpose of the divine faculty of music; the angels invented it to utter love.Ah, my Melchior, to have genius and to have beauty is too much; a man should be made to choose between them at his birth.

第一章 木屋: 您给了我宝贵的温柔和热情，特别是上个月，想到这些，我就会问自己是不是在做梦。不，我不是在做梦，但您隐藏了某些秘密，什么样的女人能把您交出来给我？除非是她死了。啊！嫉妒已经随着爱情——我不敢相信的爱情——步入了我的内心。我当初怎能想象到这熊熊爱火？而现在——真奇怪，真莫名，真讨厌！——我情愿您长得丑些。
Chapter I The Chalet: When I think of the treasures of tenderness and affection which you have given me, and more especially for the last month, I ask myself if I dream.No, but you hide some mystery; what woman can yield you up to me and not die?Ah! jealousy has entered my heart with love,—love in which I could not have believed.How could I have imagined so mighty a conflagration?And now—strange and inconceivable revulsion!—I would rather you were ugly.

第一章 木屋: 回家之后，我干了哪些蠢事啊！黄色的大丽花让我想起了您的背心，白色的玫瑰都是我亲爱的朋友。我用属于您的目光向它们致意，好像整个我都属于您一样。那紧裹着一位绅士双手的手套的颜色，您沿着教堂中殿留下的脚步——一切、一切都印在了我的记忆里，以至于再过六十年，这寻常日子里最精确的细节，都还会历历在目——包括空气中的颜色，闪烁在某根石柱上的光线。我会听到被您的脚步打断的祷告；我会呼吸到圣坛上的焚香；我永远都会感觉到我们头顶那双神父般的手，您在结尾祈福时经过我的身边，那双手就是在为我们祝福。这样看来，善良的马塞兰神父已经为我们证婚了！这个新世界充满了出人意料的激情，在这里我感觉到了超乎俗世的快乐，我把它告诉您，把它奉还给那如阳光般慷慨、把快乐注入我内心的人儿，也只有这种快乐，才能与您给我的快乐相提并论。亲爱的，我不再需要面纱了，不再需要伪装了。回到我这儿来吧，唉，快点来吧。我现在就高高兴兴地摘掉面具。
Chapter I The Chalet: What follies I committed after I came home!The yellow dahlias reminded me of your waistcoat, the white roses were my loving friends; I bowed to them with a look that belonged to you, like all that is of me.The very color of the gloves, moulded to hands of a gentleman, your step along the nave,—all, all, is so printed on my memory that sixty years hence I shall see the veriest trifles of this day of days,—the color of the atmosphere, the ray of sunshine that flickered on a certain pillar; I shall hear the prayer your step interrupted; I shall inhale the incense of the altar; forever I shall feel above our heads the priestly hands that blessed us both as you passed by me at the closing benediction.The good Abbe Marcelin married us then!The happiness, above that of earth, which I feel in this new world of unexpected emotions can only be equalled by the joy of telling it to you, of sending it back to him who poured it into my heart with the lavishness of the sun itself.No more veils, no more disguises, my beloved.Come back to me, oh, come back soon.With joy I now unmask.

第一章 木屋: 您一定听说过勒阿弗尔的米尼翁家族吧？唉，经过一次不可弥补的不幸，我成了家族的唯一女嗣。但是，奥弗涅骑士的后裔，您可不要瞧不起我们，米尼翁·德拉巴斯蒂的家徽是不会让卡那利的家徽蒙羞的。我们的家徽是红色直纹加上一道黑色对角斜纹，斜纹上有四个金环纹章；盾形徽章分为四等块，每一块有一个表示主教的金十字；徽章的上部的饰章是一顶红衣主教帽子，两旁由领结状的图案支撑。亲爱的，我会信守我们家族的铭言：“Una fides, unus Dominus!”——真正的信仰，唯一的主人。
Chapter I The Chalet: You have no doubt heard of the house of Mignon in Havre?Well, I am, through an irreparable misfortune, its sole heiress.But you are not to look down upon us, descendant of an Auvergne knight; the arms of the Mignon de La Bastie will do no dishonor to those of Canalis.We bear gules, on a bend sable four bezants or; quarterly four crosses patriarchal or; a cardinal’s hat as crest, and the fiocchi for supports.Dear, I will be faithful to our motto: “Una fides, unus Dominus!”—the true faith, and one only Master.

第一章 木屋: 我的朋友，我做了这么多，又在此说了这么多，您或许会觉得我的假名有点讽刺。我叫莫黛斯特。所以，我署名“欧·德埃斯特·莫”，是没有欺骗您的。至于我们的财产，我也没有骗您，我相信，我们的财产数目足以让您变得高贵。我知道，钱对您来说只是一个无关紧要的因素，因此，说起钱财，我是毫无保留的。让我告诉您，我是多么高兴，我们的财产能让我给我们的幸福带来行动的自由——当我们想旅游时，我能说：“来吧，让我们乘一辆舒适的马车，肩并肩坐着，不用担心钱的问题”——简言之，我多么高兴能跟国王说：“您要求贵族拥有的财产，我有。”这样，莫黛斯特·米尼翁就能为您效劳，她的金钱将会有最高贵的用途。
Chapter I The Chalet: Perhaps, my friend, you will find some irony in my name, after all that I have done, and all that I herein avow.I am named Modeste.Therefore I have not deceived you by signing “O. d’Este M.”Neither have I misled you about our fortune; it will amount, I believe, to the sum which rendered you so virtuous.I know that to you money is a consideration of small importance; therefore I speak of it without reserve.Let me tell you how happy it makes me to give freedom of action to our happiness,—to be able to say, when the fancy for travel takes us, “Come, let us go in a comfortable carriage, sitting side by side, without a thought of money”—happy, in short, to tell the king, “I have the fortune which you require in your peers.”Thus Modeste Mignon can be of service to you, and her gold will have the noblest of uses.

第一章 木屋: 至于您的仆人她本人——您确实已见过她一次，就在她的窗户旁。是的，“金发夏娃最美丽的女儿”正是您不知名的少女，但今天的莫黛斯特，与许久以前的她，是多么不一样啊！以前的莫黛斯特是在她的寿衣里的，而如今的莫黛斯特——我跟您说明白了吗？——已经从您那得到了生命的精髓。我们的爱情是纯洁的，而且会得到认可，我的父亲正带着财富与成功回来，他会批准这一爱情。正是这份爱，用它有力而又稚嫩的手将我从沉睡的坟墓里唤起。您已将我唤醒，就像太阳唤醒花朵那样。您所爱之人的双眼，不再属于那个因无知而胆大包天的小莫黛斯特了——不，幸福太耀眼了，我把眼帘闭上了。今天，我倒担心自己永远都配不上这命运了。国王满载荣誉而归，我的君主现在有了一个臣女，她请求他原谅自己的冒昧，就像欺骗了德格拉蒙先生的赌徒带着作弊的骰子一样。
Chapter I The Chalet: As to your servant herself,—you did see her once, at her window.Yes, “the fairest daughter of Eve the fair” was indeed your unknown damozel; but how little the Modeste of today resembles her of that long past era!That one was in her shroud, this one—have I made you know it?—has received from you the life of life.Love, pure, and sanctioned, the love my father, now returning rich and prosperous, will authorize, has raised me with its powerful yet childlike hand from the grave in which I slept.You have wakened me as the sun wakens the flowers.The eyes of your beloved are no longer those of the little Modeste so daring in her ignorance,—no, they are dimmed with the sight of happiness, and the lids close over them.Today I tremble lest I can never deserve my fate.The king has come in his glory; my lord has now a subject who asks pardon for the liberties she has taken, like the gambler with loaded dice after cheating Monsieur de Grammont.

第一章 木屋: 我珍爱的诗人！我将是您的米尼翁——我远比歌德的米尼翁幸福，因为您将把我留在我自己的领土——您的心上。就在我写下这篇我们婚约的誓词时，维尔坎花园里的一只夜莺替您作了回答。啊，它的歌喉是如此纯净，如此清晰，如此饱满，像一份天使传报书，让我的心里充满了快乐和爱意。快告诉我，它的歌声没有对我撒谎。

第一章 木屋: 像埃内斯特·德拉布里埃这样真正谦逊的人，特别是那些知道自己的价值、也知道自己既没人爱也没人欣赏的人，一定能理解这位年轻文书阅读莫黛斯特的来信时，沉浸在何等无边的快乐中。他那年轻、纯真、爱捣蛋的情人，先是觉得他心灵高尚、有才智，现在又觉得他长得英俊，这难道是真的吗？这种夸奖是至高无上的夸奖。为什么呢？毫无疑问，美，是大师在倾注了其心血的作品上的签名，是天意的显露。而在不美的地方看到美，用一种内在的洞察力来创造美——这难道不是爱情的最高境界吗？于是，这可怜的年轻人就像一个受到嘉许的作家一样欣喜若狂，大声喊道：“我终于有人爱了！”一个女人，不管她是少女、妻子还是寡妇，当她说出“你很英俊”这令人陶醉的几个字时，就算是虚情假意，男人也会朝着这剂隐秘的毒药打开他们厚厚的脑壳。从此，他就被一条永久的绳索系在这位可爱的奉承者身上，系在这位或真心或假意的法官身上，她成了他独特的世界，而他，则渴望她不断的证词，而且，即使他是一个戴着皇冠的王子，也永远不会感到厌倦。埃内斯特自豪地在他的房间里走来走去，在镜子前半侧面、正面、侧面来回照，试着给自己挑毛病，但是，一个恶魔般令人信服的声音对他低声说：“莫黛斯特是对的。”他拿起她写的信，又读了一遍，他看到了那金发夏娃最漂亮的女儿，他跟她说着话。然而，就在狂喜之中，一个可怕的念头涌了上来：
Chapter I The Chalet: Truly modest minds, like that of Ernest de La Briere, but especially those who, knowing their own value, also know that they are neither loved nor appreciated, can understand the infinite joy to which the young secretary abandoned himself on reading Modeste’s letter.Could it be that after thinking him lofty and witty in soul, his young, his artless, his tricksome mistress now thought him handsome?This flattery is the flattery supreme.And why?Beauty is, undoubtedly, the signature of the master to the work into which he has put his soul; it is the divine spirit manifested.And to see it where it is not, to create it by the power of an inward look,—is not that the highest reach of love?And so the poor youth cried aloud with all the rapture of an applauded author, “At last I am beloved!”When a woman, be she maid, wife, or widow, lets the charming words escape her, “Thou art handsome,” the words may be false, but the man opens his thick skull to their subtle poison, and thenceforth he is attached by an everlasting tie to the pretty flatterer, the true or the deceived judge; she becomes his particular world, he thirsts for her continual testimony, and he never wearies of it, even if he is a crowned prince.Ernest walked proudly up and down his room; he struck a three-quarter, full-face, and profile attitude before the glass; he tried to criticise himself; but a voice, diabolically persuasive, whispered to him, “Modeste is right.”He took up her letter and re-read it; he saw his fairest of the fair; he talked with her; then, in the midst of his ecstacy, a dreadful thought came to him:—

第一章 木屋: “她以为我是卡那利，而且她拥有上百万财产！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “She thinks me Canalis, and she has a million of money!”

第一章 木屋: 他的幸福顿时垮掉了，就像一个梦游症患者走到屋顶上，听到一个声音，醒来了，然后摔到地上，粉身碎骨。
Chapter I The Chalet: Down went his happiness, just as a somnambulist, having attained the peak of a roof, hears a voice, awakes, and falls crushed upon the pavement.

第一章 木屋: “没有了荣誉的光环，我在她的眼中就会是丑陋无比的，”他大叫道，“我这是把自己置于一个多么疯狂的境地啊！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Without the halo of fame I shall be hideous in her eyes,” he cried; “what a maddening situation I have put myself in!”

第一章 木屋: 拉布里埃确实如我们读到的信中那样，他的心太高贵、太纯洁，事关荣誉的事情，他会毫不犹豫。他立刻决定，如果莫黛斯特的父亲在巴黎的话，就去找他，并向他坦白一切，还要让卡那利知道他们巴黎式的玩笑所带来的严重后果。对于他这样生性敏感的人来说，莫黛斯特的大笔财富本身就是一个决定性因素。他甚至不允许别人怀疑他热情洋溢的信件是想骗取一笔“嫁妆”，那些信对他而言是如此真诚。在去尚特雷纳街找银行主蒙日诺的路上，他的眼里噙满了泪水。这位银行主的财产和生意关系网，有一部分也是那位帮埃内斯特事业起步的大臣帮忙的结果。
Chapter I The Chalet: La Briere was too much the man of his letters which we have read, his heart was too noble and pure to allow him to hesitate at the call of honor.He at once resolved to find Modeste’s father, if he were in Paris, and confess all to him, and to let Canalis know the serious results of their Parisian jest.To a sensitive nature like his, Modeste’s large fortune was in itself a determining reason.He could not allow it to be even suspected that the ardor of the correspondence, so sincere on his part, had in view the capture of a “dot.”Tears were in his eyes as he made his way to the rue Chantereine to find the banker Mongenod, whose fortune and business connections were partly the work of the minister to whom Ernest owed his start in life.

第一章 木屋: 就在拉布里埃向蒙日诺商号老板询问他深爱之人父亲的情况、获取对身处尴尬境地的他有所帮助的信息时，卡那利的书房里发生了戏剧性的一幕。这一幕，读者从那位前中尉匆忙离开勒阿弗尔就可以预见得到了。
Chapter I The Chalet: At the hour when La Briere was inquiring about the father of his beloved from the head of the house of Mongenod, and getting information that might be useful to him in his strange position, a scene was taking place in Canalis’s study which the ex-lieutenant’s hasty departure from Havre may have led the reader to foresee.

第一章 木屋: 迪迈就像一位真正的帝国军校的士兵，去巴黎的一路上，他那布列塔尼人的血液一直在沸腾。他觉得诗人应该是一个干瘦、可怜、无足轻重的家伙——是一个醉心于遣词造句的小丑，住在阁楼里，穿着每条衣缝都已发白的黑衣服，脚上的靴子有时连鞋跟都没有，身上的亚麻布衣不堪入目，手指上沾过的墨水比肥皂多得多。简单地说，就是一个除了偶尔像比查那样坐在桌前奋笔疾书之外，怎么看都像从月球滚来的人。但是，当这位布列塔尼人走进诗人那漂亮宅第的院子，他看见一个马夫正在洗马车，还透过一间富丽堂皇的餐厅的窗户里，看到一个穿得像银行家的贴身男仆。马夫朝男仆指了指迪迈，而男仆则把这个陌生人上下打量了一番，回答说男爵先生不能见客。这一切都给他心头和脑海沸腾的思绪重重泼了一瓢冷水。“男爵先生今天要出席国务院的一个会议。”那仆人补充道。
Chapter I The Chalet: Like a true soldier of the imperial school, Dumay, whose Breton blood had boiled all the way to Paris, considered a poet to be a poor stick of a fellow, of no consequence whatever,—a buffoon addicted to choruses, living in a garret, dressed in black clothes that were white at every seam, wearing boots that were occasionally without soles, and linen that was unmentionable, and whose fingers knew more about ink than soap; in short, one who looked always as if he had tumbled from the moon, except when scribbling at a desk, like Butscha.But the seething of the Breton’s heart and brain received a violent application of cold water when he entered the courtyard of the pretty house occupied by the poet and saw a groom washing a carriage, and also, through the windows of a handsome dining-room, a valet dressed like a banker, to whom the groom referred him, and who answered, looking the stranger over from head to foot, that Monsieur le baron was not visible.“There is,” added the man, “a meeting of the council of state today, at which Monsieur le baron is obliged to be present.”

第一章 木屋: “这真的是诗人卡那利先生的宅邸吗？”迪迈说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Is this really the house of Monsieur Canalis,” said Dumay, “a writer of poetry?”

第一章 木屋: “德卡那利男爵先生，”仆人回答道，“就是你所说的伟大诗人，但他也是外交部行政法院的主席。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur le baron de Canalis,” replied the valet, “is the great poet of whom you speak; but he is also the president of the court of Claims attached to the ministry of foreign affairs.”

第一章 木屋: 迪迈本是来扇那个无足轻重的小文人耳光的，却发现面对的是一个高级政府官员。仆人请他去客厅里等候，这间客厅又引起了他的无限遐思。客厅里有一件仆人忘在椅子上的黑色外套，上面的荣誉军团勋章闪闪发光。这时候，他的目光被一只漂亮而又光彩夺目的镀银杯所吸引，杯子上刻着“夫人赠”几个字。然后，他又看到面前的一只塞夫尔花瓶的底座上刻着“王太子妃赠”。
Chapter I The Chalet: Dumay, who had come to box the ears of a scribbling nobody, found himself confronted by a high functionary of the state.The salon where he was told to wait offered, as a topic for his meditations, the insignia of the Legion of honor glittering on a black coat which the valet had left upon a chair.Presently his eyes were attracted by the beauty and brilliancy of a silver-gilt cup bearing the words “Given by Madame.”Then he beheld before him, on a pedestal, a Sevres vase on which was engraved, “The gift of Madame la Dauphine.”

第一章 木屋: 这些无言的告诫让迪迈恢复了理智。与此同时，那位仆人去问他的主人是否愿意接见一个专程从勒阿弗尔赶来见他的人——一个叫迪迈的陌生人。
Chapter I The Chalet: These mute admonitions brought Dumay to his senses while the valet went to ask his master if he would receive a person who had come from Havre expressly to see him,—a stranger named Dumay.

第一章 木屋: “什么样的人？”卡那利问。
Chapter I The Chalet: “What sort of a man?” asked Canalis.

第一章 木屋: “穿着体面，戴着荣誉军团勋章。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “He is well-dressed, and wears the ribbon of the Legion of honor.”

第一章 木屋: 卡那利做了一个同意的手势，仆人便退下了，然后回去通报道：“迪迈先生到。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis made a sign of assent, and the valet retreated, and then returned and announced, “Monsieur Dumay.”

第一章 木屋: 当迪迈听到自己的名字，当他走进一件华丽而又雅致的书房，站在卡那利面前，脚下的地毯比米尼翁家任何一条都气派得多，当他看到正摆弄着华丽晨衣上的流苏的卡那利投来打量的眼神时，迪迈完全惊呆了，竟让这位伟大的诗人抢先说话了。
Chapter I The Chalet: When he heard himself announced, when he was actually in presence of Canalis, in a study as gorgeous as it was elegant, with his feet on a carpet far handsomer than any in the house of Mignon, and when he met the studied glance of the poet who was playing with the tassels of a sumptuous dressing-gown, Dumay was so completely taken aback that he allowed the great poet to have the first word.

第一章 木屋: “我怎么有幸得到您的拜访呢，先生？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “To what do I owe the honor of your visit, monsieur?”

第一章 木屋: “先生。”迪迈还站着，就开了口。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” began Dumay, who remained standing.

第一章 木屋: “如果您有好多话要说，”卡那利打断他，说道，“那就请坐吧。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “If you have a good deal to say,” interrupted Canalis, “I must ask you to be seated.”

第一章 木屋: 接着，卡那利自己一屁股坐到一张伏尔泰式手扶椅上，翘起二郎腿，上面那条腿抬到眼睛那么高，目不转睛地看着迪迈。按照迪迈军队里的俗话，他像是“被捅了一刺刀”。
Chapter I The Chalet: And Canalis himself plunged into an armchair a la Voltaire, crossed his legs, raised the upper one to the level of his eye and looked fixedly at Dumay, who became, to use his own martial slang, “bayonetted.”

第一章 木屋: “我听着呢，先生，”诗人说，“我的时间很宝贵——大臣们正在等我。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I am listening, monsieur,” said the poet; “my time is precious,—the ministers are expecting me.”

第一章 木屋: “先生，”迪迈说，“我会长话短说的。您引诱了——以什么方式，我不知道——一位勒阿弗尔的年轻小姐，她年轻、漂亮，而且很富有，是两个贵族家庭最后的、也是唯一的希望，而我是来问您这样做的意图何在。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” said Dumay, “I shall be brief.You have seduced—how, I do not know—a young lady in Havre, young, beautiful, and rich; the last and only hope of two noble families; and I have come to ask your intentions.”

第一章 木屋: 在过去的三个月里，卡那利一直忙着他自己的要紧事，努力成为一位荣誉军团的指挥官，并被派到德国某个宫廷去当大使。他已经完全忘记了莫黛斯特写的信。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis, who had been busy during the last three months with serious matters of his own, and was trying to get himself made commander of the Legion of honor and minister to a German court, had completely forgotten Modeste’s letter.”

第一章 木屋: “我！”他大叫一声。
Chapter I The Chalet: “I!” he exclaimed.

第一章 木屋: “是您！”迪迈重复道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “You!” repeated Dumay.

第一章 木屋: “先生，”卡那利笑着回答说，“我根本不知道您在讲什么，就好像您在讲希伯来语一样。我引诱了一位少女！我，一位——”一丝高傲的微笑从他脸上掠过，“算了吧，算了吧，先生，我拥有自己的果园和花园，里面有最好的熟桃子，我不会幼稚到去偷篱笆外的果子的。所有的巴黎人都知道我的心思在哪儿。很有可能，在勒阿弗尔会有某位少女对我的诗歌充满了热情——其实那些诗根本不配，那我倒一点儿也不会奇怪，这再正常不过了。您瞧！那个漂亮的乌木小匣子，装饰着珠母，边上镶着蕾丝一样精致的铁边。它原来是教皇利奥十世的，后来德肖利厄公爵夫人从西班牙国王得到它，又转送给了我。我用它来装生活在欧洲每个角落的夫人和少女们写给我的信。唉！我可以肯定地对您说，我对这些心灵的花朵有着最崇高的敬意，它们都是在充满激情的时刻被采摘下来送给我的，值得拥有所有的敬意。是的，对我来说，内心的冲动是最高贵、最令人赞叹的东西！其他人——嘲笑者——用这些信点烟，或者给他们的老婆当卷发纸，但我，我是单身，先生，我很仔细地把这些朴实的礼品——它们是如此纯洁、如此无私——保存在它们的神龛里。事实上，我是怀着一种崇敬之情将它们保护起来，而且，到我临死的时候，会叫人当着我的面把它们烧掉。人们可能会认为这很可笑，但我不在乎。我懂得感恩，这些热爱的证据使我能够承受文学生活的种种批评和烦恼。当我受到藏身于某家日报下的敌人的背后攻击时，我就看看那个匣子，心想——在这个广阔的世界上，到处都有一些心灵，它们的伤口被我治愈、抚慰，或者包扎起来！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” answered Canalis, smiling; “I know no more of what you are talking about than if you had said it in Hebrew.I seduce a young girl!I, who—” and a superb smile crossed his features.“Come, come, monsieur, I’m not such a child as to steal fruit over the hedges when I have orchards and gardens of my own where the finest peaches ripen.All Paris knows where my affections are set.Very likely there may be some young girl in Havre full of enthusiasm for my verses,—of which they are not worthy; that would not surprise me at all; nothing is more common.See! look at that lovely coffer of ebony inlaid with mother-of-pearl, and edged with that iron-work as fine as lace.That coffer belonged to Pope Leo X., and was given to me by the Duchesse de Chaulieu, who received it from the king of Spain.I use it to hold the letters I receive from ladies and young girls living in every quarter of Europe.Oh!I assure you I feel the utmost respect for these flowers of the soul, cut and sent in moments of enthusiasm that are worthy of all reverence.Yes, to me the impulse of a heart is a noble and sublime thing!Others—scoffers—light their cigars with such letters, or give them to their wives for curl-papers; but I, who am a bachelor, monsieur, I have too much delicacy not to preserve these artless offerings—so fresh, so disinterested—in a tabernacle of their own.In fact, I guard them with a species of veneration, and at my death they will be burned before my eyes.People may call that ridiculous, but I do not care.I am grateful; these proofs of devotion enable me to bear the criticisms and annoyances of a literary life.When I receive a shot in the back from some enemy lurking under cover of a daily paper, I look at that casket and think,—here and there in this wide world there are hearts whose wounds have been healed, or soothed, or dressed by me!”

第一章 木屋: 中尉被这位伟大演员慷慨激昂、富有诗意的陈述惊呆了，眼睛睁得大大的。他惊讶的表情可逗坏了诗人。
Chapter I The Chalet: This bit of poetry, declaimed with all the talent of a great actor, petrified the lieutenant, whose eyes opened to their utmost extent, and whose astonishment delighted the poet.

第一章 木屋: “出于我对您身份的完全尊重，”这只开屏的孔雀接着说道，“我允许您打开那个匣子，找一找您那位年轻小姐的信。但我知道我是对的，那些名字我都记得，我敢肯定是您搞错了——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I will permit you,” continued the peacock, spreading his tail, “out of respect for your position, which I fully appreciate, to open that coffer and look for the letter of your young lady.Though I know I am right, I remember names, and I assure you you are mistaken in thinking—”

第一章 木屋: “一个可怜的孩子卷进了这个巴黎的漩涡，就变成这样了！”迪迈大声说道，“她是父母的宝贝，是朋友们的开心果，是所有人的希望，被所有人宠爱，是一个家族的骄傲！为了她，六个忠心耿耿的人情愿用他们的生命和财产，在她和悲伤之间筑起一座堡垒。先生，”迪迈停了一下说道，“您是一位伟大的诗人，而我只是一个可怜的军人。我为国家在部队服役十五年，许多颗子弹曾在我面前呼啸而过，我都成功躲过了，我到过西伯利亚，在那儿做过俘虏，俄国佬把我扔到篷车里，上帝知道我受过什么罪。我看见成千上万的战友死去——但您，您让我凉到了骨髓里，这是我之前从未尝过的滋味。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And this is what a poor child comes to in this gulf of Paris!” cried Dumay,—“the darling of her parents, the joy of her friends, the hope of all, petted by all, the pride of a family, who has six persons so devoted to her that they would willingly make a rampart of their lives and fortunes between her and sorrow.Monsieur,” Dumay remarked after a pause, “you are a great poet, and I am only a poor soldier.For fifteen years I served my country in the ranks; I have had the wind of many a bullet in my face; I have crossed Siberia and been a prisoner there; the Russians flung me on a kibitka, and God knows what I suffered.I have seen thousands of my comrades die,—but you, you have given me a chill to the marrow of my bones, such as I never felt before.”

I’ll make a poem on it, and perhaps the chance will come again.Heavens! the luck of that little La Briere,—strutting about in my lustre—plagiarism!I’m the cast and he’s to be the statue, is he?It is the old fable of Bertrand and Raton.Six millions, a beauty, a Mignon de La Bastie, an aristocratic divinity loving poetry and the poet!And I, who showed my muscle as man of the world, who did those Alcide exercises to silence by moral force the champion of physical force, that old soldier with a heart, that friend of this very young girl, whom he’ll now go and tell that I have a heart of iron!—I, to play Napoleon when I ought to have been seraphic!Good heavens!True, I shall have my friend.Friendship is a beautiful thing.I have kept him, but at what a price!Six millions, that’s the cost of it; we can’t have many friends if we pay all that for them.”

第一章 木屋: “爸爸，在事实的法庭面前，这还是一件悬而未决的案子。心灵与父母之命之间的斗争，会永远继续下去的。”

第一章 木屋: 这个可怜的女孩儿攀上高山去寻找她雄鹰的巢穴，却丢脸地摔到了下面泥泞的沼泽中，用当今一位作家诗意的语言形容，就是“在感受过脚下柔软的鞋底后，就不能再踏上现实的碎玻璃了。”想象力在那脆弱的胸怀里汇集了全部的女子气质，从纯真少女暗藏的紫罗兰色的幻想，到对肉欲的热望——这想象力把她引到了魔法花园，那里，唉，有一番辛酸的景象！现在，她从地上跳起来，看到的不是幻想中无比壮丽的鲜花，而是黑色曼陀罗那毛茸茸的、扭曲缠绕的根茎。”莫黛斯特突然发现，她被人从爱情的神秘高峰拉到了一条笔直平坦、两边都是沟渠的路上——简单地说，就是平常生活中的平常路。怎样充满热情、意气风发的心灵，这样摔一跤后不会伤痕累累、破碎不堪呢？她都把自己的思想撒到了什么人的脚下啊？重新回到木屋的莫黛斯特已不再是两个小时前离开的那个莫黛斯特了，就如同走在街上的女演员不再是舞台上的女演员一样。她陷入了一种麻木的沮丧状态，看起来很可怜。阳光暗了下来，大自然也戴上了面纱，就连花儿也不再跟她说话了。跟所有具有极端倾向的少女一样，她端着幻灭的酒杯，酩酊大醉。她同现实搏斗，不愿把头伸进家庭和习俗的枷锁里，她感觉那枷锁太重、太硬、太压抑了。她不愿倾听父母的安慰，她让自己的心经受最痛苦的折磨，从中尝到了一种残忍的快乐。
Chapter I The Chalet: The poor girl had fallen humiliated from the alp she had scaled in search of her eagle’s nest, into the mud of the swamp below, where (to use the poetic language of an author of our day) “after feeling the soles of her feet too tender to tread the broken glass of reality,Imagination—which in that delicate bosom united the whole of womanhood, from the violet-hidden reveries of a chaste young girl to the passionate desires of the sex—had led her into enchanted gardens where, oh, bitter sight!she now saw, springing from the ground, not the sublime flower of her fancy, but the hairy, twisted limbs of the black mandragora.”Modeste suddenly found herself brought down from the mystic heights of her love to a straight, flat road bordered with ditches,—in short the work-day path of common life.What ardent, aspiring soul would not have been bruised and broken by such a fall?Whose feet were these at which she had shed her thoughts?The Modeste who re-entered the Chalet was no more the Modeste who had left it two hours earlier than an actress in the street is like an actress on the boards.She fell into a state of numb depression that was pitiful to see.The sun was darkened, nature veiled itself, even the flowers no longer spoke to her.Like all young girls with a tendency to extremes, she drank too deeply of the cup of disillusion.She fought against reality, and would not bend her neck to the yoke of family and conventions; it was, she felt, too heavy, too hard, too crushing.She would not listen to the consolations of her father and mother, and tasted a sort of savage pleasure in letting her soul suffer to the utmost.

第一章 木屋: 这句话说明了悲伤忧愁的她在短短的时间里，从现实的贫瘠草原上跋涉了多少路程。由过度奢望引起的悲伤是一种疾病——有时这种悲伤是致命的。从生理学上讲，没有什么有效的方法能弄清思想是通过什么途径、以什么方式创造出同毒药一般的内在紊乱，也无法弄清绝望怎样影响食欲、破坏幽门、改变最顽强的生命的所有生理状况。这就是莫黛斯特所处的状况。短短三天里，她就表现出了忧郁的病态模样，她不唱歌，也没有谁能让她微笑。那两位朋友迟迟不来，夏尔·米尼翁有点不安了，便想去接他们。这时，到了第五天晚上，他从拉图奈尔那里得到消息说他们动身了。
Chapter I The Chalet: The words indicate the distance she travelled in a short space of time and in gloomy sadness across the barren plain of reality.Sadness, when caused by the overgrowth of hope, is a disease,—sometimes a fatal one.It would be no mean object for physiology to search out in what ways and by what means Thought produces the same internal disorganization as poison; and how it is that despair affects the appetite, destroys the pylorus, and changes all the physical conditions of the strongest life.Such was the case with Modeste.In three short days she became the image of morbid melancholy; she did not sing, she could not be made to smile.Charles Mignon, becoming uneasy at the non-arrival of the two friends, thought of going to fetch them, when, on the evening of the fifth day, he received news of their movements through Latournelle.

第一章 木屋: 卡那利想到这门有钱的婚事就万分欣喜，他决心不放过任何可以帮他击败拉布里埃的机会，然而也会不给拉布里埃机会责备他违反了友谊的原则。诗人觉得，要让一位少女瞧不起一个情人，最好的办法就是让他以低微的身份出现在她面前。于是，他表现出很自然的样子，以呼吸海边空气为由，建议和拉布里埃一起在安古维尔租一幢乡间小别墅，住上一个月。拉布里埃开始并没觉得这个建议有什么不妥，就答应了。卡那利立刻声称自己会支付所有费用，并派他的贴身男仆去勒阿弗尔，让他去见拉图奈尔先生，请他帮忙找房子——他很清楚这位公证人会把所有的细节都告诉米尼翁一家。正如我们所料想的，埃内斯特和卡那利曾就这场艳遇的各个方面交谈过，而且唠叨的埃内斯特已经给了他的情敌许多有用的提示。男仆很清楚他主人的意愿，一丝不苟地执行了它们。他大肆宣扬这位伟大诗人的到来，说他的身体被文学和政治上的双重辛劳给压垮了，医生建议他通过呼吸海边空气来恢复健康。这位大人物想租一套房子，说至少要有多少多少个房间，因为除了他自己——贴身男仆热尔曼·博内，卡那利还会带上一个秘书、一个厨师、两个仆人。卡那利挑选了一辆漂亮的马车，打算租用一个月，而热尔曼要找两匹好马，除了能拉马车，还得骑着舒服——因为据他所说，男爵先生和他的秘书还从事骑马运动。小个子拉图奈尔陪他去看了各种各样的房子，热尔曼当着他的面说了很多有关秘书的事。有两三处房子没看中，正是因为没有合适的房间给德拉布里埃先生。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis, excessively delighted at the idea of a rich marriage, was determined to neglect nothing that might help him to cut out La Briere, without, however, giving La Briere a chance to reproach him for having violated the laws of friendship.The poet felt that nothing would lower a lover so much in the eyes of a young girl as to exhibit him in a subordinate position; and he therefore proposed to La Briere, in the most natural manner, to take a little country-house at Ingouville for a month, and live there together on pretence of requiring sea-air.As soon as La Briere, who at first saw nothing amiss in the proposal, had consented, Canalis declared that he should pay all expenses, and he sent his valet to Havre, telling him to see Monsieur Latournelle and get his assistance in choosing the house,—well aware that the notary would repeat all particulars to the Mignons.Ernest and Canalis had, as may well be supposed, talked over all the aspects of the affair, and the rather prolix Ernest had given a good many useful hints to his rival.The valet, understanding his master’s wishes, fulfilled them to the letter; he trumpeted the arrival of the great poet, for whom the doctors advised sea-air to restore his health, injured as it was by the double toils of literature and politics.This important personage wanted a house, which must have at least such and such a number of rooms, as he would bring with him a secretary, cook, two servants, and a coachman, not counting himself, Germain Bonnet, the valet.The carriage, selected and hired for a month by Canalis, was a pretty one; and Germain set about finding a pair of fine horses which would also answer as saddle-horses,—for, as he said, monsieur le baron and his secretary took horseback exercise.Under the eyes of little Latournelle, who went with him to various houses, Germain made a good deal of talk about the secretary, rejecting two or three because there was no suitable room for Monsieur de La Briere.

第一章 木屋: “放心吧，”拉图奈尔在第六天对米尼翁说道，“男爵的贴身男仆已经花了七百法郎租下了阿莫里夫人在桑维克的别墅，里面配有全套家具。男仆已经给他的主人写信说可以出发了，等他到的时候一切就都准备好了。所以，这两位先生星期天就会到这儿了。我还收到了一封比查的来信，信不长，内容如下：‘我亲爱的主人——我要到星期天才能回去。在这段时间里，我有些非常重要的事要调查，它们关系到您所关心之人的幸福。’”

第一章 木屋: 两人即将到来的消息并没有让莫黛斯特走出忧郁，她的挫败感和内心的困惑还是很严重。她并不像她父亲所认为的那样爱卖弄风情。其实，有一种可爱的卖弄风情是可以被允许的，那就是心灵上的卖弄风情，可以被看作是爱情上的彬彬有礼。夏尔·米尼翁在责备他女儿的时候，没能区分开想取悦他人的单纯愿望和精神层面的爱情——对爱情的渴望，对博得他人赞美的渴望。跟法兰西帝国每一位真正的中校一样，他在这些匆匆读过的信件里，看到的只是一个自己扑到诗人怀里的姑娘。但在那些我们为了节省笔墨而不得不略去的信件里，一个更好的法官会赞赏莫黛斯特用高贵、亲切的矜持代替了她最开始的几封信中那盛气凌人、漫不经心的语气。然而，这位父亲只有一点是非常正确的。我们读过的莫黛斯特那最后一封信，话说得确实就像婚事已成定局的样子。所以，一想起那封信，她就羞愧不已。父亲逼着她去面对一个她曾经坦诚相交、现在却配不上她的人，她觉得父亲太过严厉，太过残忍了。她问过迪迈同诗人的面谈，哄骗着他说出了每一个细节。她认为卡那利并不像中尉所说的那样粗野、残忍。一想到这位文坛唐璜那装着一千零一封女人来信的漂亮小匣子，她就微笑起来。她真的很想跟她父亲说：“我不是唯一一个给他写信的人，那些女精英们也给这位诗人的桂冠送去了她们的叶片。”
Chapter I The Chalet: The announcement of this arrival did not rouse Modeste from her gloom; the sense of her fall and the bewilderment of her mind were still too great, and she was not nearly as much of a coquette as her father thought her to be.There is, in truth, a charming and permissible coquetry, that of the soul, which may claim to be love’s politeness.Charles Mignon, when scolding his daughter, failed to distinguish between the mere desire of pleasing and the love of the mind,—the thirst for love, and the thirst for admiration.Like every true colonel of the Empire he saw in this correspondence, rapidly read, only the young girl who had thrown herself at the head of a poet; but in the letters which we were forced to lack of space to suppress, a better judge would have admired the dignified and gracious reserve which Modeste had substituted for the rather aggressive and light-minded tone of her first letters.The father, however, was only too cruelly right on one point.Modeste’s last letter, which we have read, had indeed spoken as though the marriage were a settled fact, and the remembrance of that letter filled her with shame; she thought her father very harsh and cruel to force her to receive a man unworthy of her, yet to whom her soul had flown, as it were, bare.She questioned Dumay about his interview with the poet, she inveigled him into relating its every detail, and she did not think Canalis as barbarous as the lieutenant had declared him.The thought of the beautiful casket which held the letters of the thousand and one women of this literary Don Juan made her smile, and she was strongly tempted to say to her father: “I am not the only one to write to him; the elite of my sex send their leaves for the laurel wreath of the poet.”

第一章 木屋: 在介绍我们故事中的一个新角色之前，讲讲这些琐事是有必要的，当然，这有悖亚里士多德和贺拉斯文学准则。但是，考虑到这个姗姗来迟的人物身材极为矮小，他的肖像和传记也不会太长。这位马厩大总管在这里所占的篇幅，不会比他在历史上所占的长。埃鲁维尔公爵先生，是前任诺曼底省长流亡国外期间的老来子，一七九九年生于维也纳。公爵的父亲是位老元帅，一八一四年同国王一起回国，一八一九年去世，死前没能给他儿子完婚。他只给儿子留下了埃鲁维尔大城堡、猎园、一些附属建筑，以及一座好不容易才赎回的田庄，所有这些地产的年租金收入约一万五千法郎。路易十八授予这位儿子马厩大总管之职，到了查理十世时期，他又享受到给法国破落贵族的一万二千法郎日常津贴。但对于这样一个家族来说，这两万七千法郎的年收入加上马厩大总管的薪俸，又算什么呢？当然，在巴黎，这位年轻的公爵用的是国王的马车，而且在卢浮宫圣托马斯街的王室马厩附近有一座公馆，他的薪俸可供他在巴黎城内过冬之用，而那两万七千法郎则是夏天在诺曼底的费用。这位贵族人物至今还是单身，这不能怪他自己，而要怪他那位不精通拉封丹寓言故事的姑姑。德埃鲁维尔小姐极度的矫揉造作完全是为了追赶当今的时代精神，因为再显赫的家族如果没有钱来支撑，也很难赢得法国高等贵族的女嗣的芳心。而那些高等贵族自己也窘迫不已，因为根据新法律中平均分配财产的规定，他们的儿子也得由他们供养。要让年轻的埃鲁维尔公爵娶到老婆，就必须要讨好那些大银行家家族，但这位傲慢自大的德埃鲁维尔家小姐说话尖酸刻薄，把这些人都给得罪了。王政复辟的头几年里，从一八一七年到一八二五年，德埃鲁维尔小姐虽然在寻求百万人家，却也拒绝了许多人家。其中就有银行家蒙日诺的女儿，后来，德方丹先生很满意地娶了她。

all of which returned a rental of about fifteen thousand francs a year.Louis XVIII. gave the post of grand equerry to the son, who, under Charles X., received the usual pension of twelve thousand francs which was granted to the pauper peers of France.But what were these twenty-seven thousand francs a year and the salary of grand equerry to such a family?In Paris, of course, the young duke used the king’s coaches, and had a mansion provided for him in the rue Saint-Thomas-du-Louvre, near the royal stables; his salary paid for his winters in the city, and his twenty-seven thousand francs for the summers in Normandy.If this noble personage was still a bachelor he was less to blame than his aunt, who was not versed in La Fontaine’s fables.Mademoiselle d’Herouville made enormous pretensions wholly out of keeping with the spirit of the times; for great names, without the money to keep them up, can seldom win rich heiresses among the higher French nobility, who are themselves embarrassed to provide for their sons under the new law of the equal division of property.To marry the young Duc d’Herouville, it was necessary to conciliate the great banking-houses; but the haughty pride of the daughter of the house alienated these people by cutting speeches.During the first years of the Restoration, from 1817 to 1825, Mademoiselle d’Herouville, though in quest of millions, refused, among others, the daughter of Mongenod the banker, with whom Monsieur de Fontaine afterwards contented himself.

第一章 木屋: 最后，完全由于她自己的过失，错过了许多替她侄子完婚的好机会。可她还在考虑纽沁根家族的财产是不是来路不正，她要不要成全德纽沁根夫人想让自己女儿成为公爵夫人的野心。国王急于让德埃鲁维尔家族恢复昔日的光彩，差一点儿就成全了这门亲事，而当事情搞砸后，他公开批评了德埃鲁维尔小姐的愚蠢做法。就这样，这位姑姑将她的侄子置于了可笑的境地中，而这位侄子自己也确实挺荒谬。当伟大事物消逝时，它们会留下碎片，拉伯雷称之为“掉下来的渣渣”。而这个世纪的法国贵族给我们留下了太多这样的碎片。无论是牧师还是贵族，在这段悠长的风俗史中都没有什么好抱怨的。那些伟大而辉煌的社会必需品已经被很好地呈现出来了，但如果我们不公正地在这里描述一下贵族们如今的没落，尽管我们已经在其他地方这样做过了——如莫尔索伯爵的形象（见《幽谷百合》）、“朗热女公爵”，还有极具贵族气质的德埃斯巴侯爵——那我们当然应该宣布放弃历史学家这一高尚头衔。那么，那个孕育了英雄和勇士的、光荣的埃鲁维尔家族，给国家输送了著名的元帅，给教会输送了几个红衣主教，给瓦罗亚王朝输送了许多伟大领袖，给路易十四输送了好多骑士，最后会没落成到只剩一个孱弱的、比比查还矮小的男嗣呢？在巴黎的不止一个沙龙里，当我们听到法兰西最伟大家族的名字被通报，却看到进来的是一个瘦弱干瘪、身材矮小、几乎只剩最后一口气的年轻人，或一个未老先衰的人，或一个很难从他身上看到昔日荣光的稀奇古怪的人，我们都会问自己这样的问题。路易十五王朝的荒淫无度，那个宿命而自我的时代的纵酒狂欢，造就了软弱无能的一代。在他们身上，高贵的品质都已消失，只剩下那套举止——表面形式，那也是我们的贵族保留下来的唯一遗产。蓬巴杜夫人统治期间留下的后遗症，多多少少也能解释路易十六及其王朝的覆灭。
Chapter I The Chalet: At last, having lost several good opportunities to establish her nephew, entirely through her own fault, she was just considering whether the property of the Nucingens was not too basely acquired, or whether she should lend herself to the ambition of Madame de Nucingen, who wished to make her daughter a duchess.The king, anxious to restore the d’Herouvilles to their former splendor, had almost brought about this marriage, and when it failed he openly accused Mademoiselle d’Herouville of folly.In this way the aunt made the nephew ridiculous, and the nephew, in his own way, was not less absurd.When great things disappear they leave crumbs, “frusteaux,” Rabelais would say, behind them; and the French nobility of this century has left us too many such fragments.Neither the clergy nor the nobility have anything to complain of in this long history of manners and customs.Those great and magnificent social necessities have been well represented; but we ought surely to renounce the noble title of historian if we are not impartial, if we do not here depict the present degeneracy of the race of nobles, although we have already done so elsewhere,—in the character of the Comte de Mortsauf (in “The Lily of the Valley”), in the “Duchesse de Langeais,” and the very nobleness of the nobility in the “Marquis d’Espard.”How then could it be that the race of heroes and valiant men belonging to the proud house of Herouville, who gave the famous marshal to the nation, cardinals to the church, great leaders to the Valois, knights to Louis XIV., was reduced to a little fragile being smaller than Butscha?That is a question which we ask ourselves in more than one salon in Paris when we hear the greatest names of France announced, and see the entrance of a thin, pinched, undersized young man, scarcely possessing the breath of life, or a premature old one, or some whimsical creature in whom an observer can with great difficulty trace the signs of a past grandeur.The dissipations of the reign of Louis XV., the orgies of that fatal and egotistic period, have produced an effete generation, in which manners alone survive the nobler vanished qualities,—forms, which are the sole heritage our nobles have preserved.The abandonment in which Louis XVI. was allowed to perish may thus be explained, with some slight reservations, as a wretched result of the reign of Madame de Pompadour.

第一章 木屋: 这位马厩大总管是个不错的年轻人，蓝眼睛，面色苍白，倒也不是没有一些高贵的思想，但他那纤瘦矮小的身材，加上他姑姑带他到维尔坎家还有其他地方去求婚的愚蠢之举，使他极度缺乏自信。由于一个畸形之人的所作所为，埃鲁维尔家族已经受到过绝嗣的威胁了（见“哲理研究”部分《被诅咒的孩子》）。那位大元帅——家族中对被路易十三封为公爵的成员的专门称呼——八十岁的时候才结婚。这位年轻的公爵喜欢女人，但把她们放到了太高的位置上，过于尊重她们。事实上，他崇拜她们，而只有跟他不尊重的人在一起，他才感觉自在。这种性格导致他过着一种双重生活。他在圣日耳曼近郊的沙龙里——你也可以说是女人们的会客室里——对那些女人顶礼膜拜，但又到水性杨花的女人那里寻求补偿。这些习惯，加上他弱小的身材，一副苦脸，还有心醉神迷地向上翻的蓝眼睛，更增加了他身上已有的可笑之处——上帝赋予他这些可笑之处，真是不公平，因为他充满才智、心思细腻，但他的才智从来不发光，只有在他感觉自在的时候才会表现出来。据说，女演员范妮·博普雷是他花了大钱结交的最亲密的朋友，她称他为“一瓶瓶塞塞得太紧、会弄坏你所有开瓶器的好酒。”这位马厩大总管对美丽的摩弗里纽斯公爵夫人就只有爱慕的份儿了。她说过一句让大总管彻底崩溃的话，不幸的是，这句话还像所有这类精辟的恶毒话一样，被人们口口相传。
Chapter I The Chalet: The grand equerry, a fair young man with blue eyes and a pallid face, was not without a certain dignity of thought; but his thin, undersized figure, and the follies of his aunt who had taken him to the Vilquins and elsewhere to pay his court, rendered him extremely diffident.The house of Herouville had already been threatened with extinction by the deed of a deformed being (see the “Enfant Maudit” in “Philosophical Studies”).The grand marshal, that being the family term for the member who was made duke by Louis XIII., married at the age of eighty.The young duke admired women, but he placed them too high and respected them too much; in fact, he adored them, and was only at his ease with those whom he could not respect.This characteristic caused him to lead a double life.He found compensation with women of easy virtue for the worship to which he surrendered himself in the salons, or, if you like, the boudoirs, of the faubourg Saint-Germain.Such habits and his puny figure, his suffering face with its blue eyes turning upward in ecstasy, increased the ridicule already bestowed upon him,—very unjustly bestowed, as it happened, for he was full of wit and delicacy; but his wit, which never sparkled, only showed itself when he felt at ease.Fanny Beaupre, an actress who was supposed to be his nearest friend (at a price), called him “a sound wine so carefully corked that you break all your corkscrews.”The beautiful Duchesse de Maufrigneuse, whom the grand equerry could only worship, annihilated him with a speech which, unfortunately, was repeated from mouth to mouth, like all such pretty and malicious sayings.

Chapter I The Chalet: The two rivals, still intimate friends, intended to pay their first visit at the Chalet on the evening of the day succeeding their arrival.They had spent Sunday and part of Monday in unpacking and arranging Madame Amaury’s house for a month’s stay.The poet, always calculating effects, wished to make the most of the probable excitement which his arrival would cause in Havre, and which would of course echo up to the Mignons.Therefore, in his role of a man needing rest, he did not leave the house.La Briere went twice to walk past the Chalet, though always with a sense of despair, for he feared to displease Modeste, and the future seemed to him dark with clouds.The two friends came down to dinner on Monday dressed for the momentous visit.La Briere wore the same clothes he had so carefully selected for the famous Sunday; but he now felt like the satellite of planet, and resigned himself to the uncertainties of his situation.Canalis, on the other hand, had carefully attended to his black coat, his orders, and all those little drawing-room elegancies, which his intimacy with the Duchesse de Chaulieu and the fashionable world of the faubourg had brought to perfection.He had gone into the minutiae of dandyism, while poor La Briere was about to present himself with the negligence of a man without hope.Germain, as he waited at dinner could not help smiling to himself at the contrast.After the second course, however, the valet came in with a diplomatic, that is to say, uneasy air.

Canalis in his moral being was a sort of Narcissus.When a woman of a certain age wishes to attach a man forever, she begins by deifying his defects, so as to cut off all possibility of rivalry; for a rival is never, at the first approach, aware of the super-fine flattery to which the man is accustomed.Coxcombs are the product of this feminine manoeuvre, when they are not fops by nature.Canalis, taken young by the handsome duchess, vindicated his affectations to his own mind by telling himself that they pleased that “grande dame,” whose taste was law.Such shades of character may be excessively faint, but it is improper for the historian not to point them out.For instance, Melchior possessed a talent for reading which was greatly admired, and much injudicious praise had given him a habit of exaggeration, which neither poets nor actors are willing to check, and which made people say of him (always through De Marsay) that he no longer declaimed, he bellowed his verses; lengthening the sounds that he might listen to himself.In the slang of the green-room, Canalis “dragged the time.”He was fond of exchanging glances with his hearers, throwing himself into postures of self-complacency and practising those tricks of demeanor which actors call “balancoires,”—the picturesque phrase of an artistic people.Canalis had his imitators, and was in fact the head of a school of his kind.This habit of declamatory chanting slightly affected his conversation, as we have seen in his interview with Dumay.The moment the mind becomes finical the manners follow suit, and the great poet ended by studying his demeanor, inventing attitudes, looking furtively at himself in mirrors, and suiting his discourse to the particular pose which he happened to have taken up.He was so preoccupied with the effect he wished to produce, that a practical joke, Blondet, had bet once or twice, and won the wager, that he could nonplus him at any moment by merely looking fixedly at his hair, or his boots, or the tails of his coats.

Chapter I The Chalet: “I shall always consider it a triumph,” resumed the poet, observing that everybody wished for an explanation, “to have stirred to mention one of those men of iron whom Napoleon had the eye to find and make the supporting piles on which he tried to build an empire, too colossal to be lasting: for such structures time alone is the cement.But this triumph—why should I be proud of it?—I count for nothing.It was the triumph of ideas over facts.Your battles, my dear Monsieur Dumay, your heroic charges, Monsieur le comte, nay, war itself was the form in which Napoleon’s idea clothed itself.Of all of these things, what remains?The sod that covers them knows nothing; harvests come and go without revealing their resting-place; were it not for the historian, the writer, futurity would have no knowledge of those heroic days.Therefore your fifteen years of war are now ideas and nothing more; that which preserves the Empire forever is the poem that the poets make of them.A nation that can win such battles must know how to sing them.”
