第一章 木屋: “啊，那完了！”埃内斯特回答说，“她爱你，或者说，如果你想的话，她将会爱上你。在这场战争中，你的名气就打赢了一半。好吧，你现在就可以按你自己的方式来打胜仗了。你以后可以一个人去那儿了。莫黛斯特看不起我，她这样做是对的，而我找不到任何理由让自己遭罪，去观望、赞美、向往、爱慕我永远都不能拥有的东西。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, that ends it!” replied Ernest.“She loves you, or she will love you if you desire it.Your fame won half the battle.Well, you may now have it all your own way.You shall go there alone in future.Modeste despises me; she is right to do so; and I don’t see any reason why I should condemn myself to see, to love, desire, and adore that which I can never possess.”

第一章 木屋: 卡那利说了几句安慰的话，话里掺杂着借用凯撒大帝名言带来的自我满足感，之后便透露他想跟德肖利厄公爵夫人断绝关系。拉布里埃完全无法将谈话继续下去，以欣赏美丽的夜景为借口下了车，像着了魔似的跑去了海边，在那里一直呆到十点多。他半疯半癫地快步走来走去，前言不搭后语地大声说话，有时候又傻站着或呆坐着，都没有注意到值班的两名海关人员的不安。他之前爱的是莫黛斯特的机智、才华，以及她那咄咄逼人的率直，现在，又在十天前将他带到勒阿弗尔教堂的全部理由之上，加上了对莫黛斯特美貌的爱慕——也就是毫无理由、无法解释的爱。
Chapter I The Chalet: After a few consoling remarks, dashed with his own satisfaction at having made a new version of Caesar’s phrase, Canalis divulged a desire to break with the Duchesse de Chaulieu.La Briere, totally unable to keep up the conversation, made the beauty of the night an excuse to be set down, and then rushed like one possessed to the seashore, where he stayed till past ten, in a half-demented state, walking hurriedly up and down, talking aloud in broken sentences, sometimes standing still or sitting down, without noticing the uneasiness of two custom-house officers who were on the watch.After loving Modeste’s wit and intellect and her aggressive frankness, he now joined adoration of her beauty—that is to say, love without reason, love inexplicable—to all the other reasons which had drawn him ten days earlier, to the church in Havre.

第一章 木屋: 他回到了木屋，两条比利牛斯狗朝他狂吠，他不得不放弃了凝望莫黛斯特窗户的快乐。在爱情上，这类事情之于一个情人，并不比作品的最后一层色彩之于一位画家的意义更大。然而，正是这些举动构成了爱情的全部，就像看不见的艰辛构成了艺术的全部。正是从这些艰辛之中，产生了伟大的画家和真正的情人，女人和公众最终会爱慕他们，但有时候为时已晚。
Chapter I The Chalet: He returned to the Chalet, where the Pyrenees hounds barked at him till he was forced to relinquish the pleasure of gazing at Modeste’s windows.In love, such things are of no more account to the lover than the work which is covered by the last layer of color is to an artist; yet they make up the whole of love, just as the hidden toil is the whole of art.Out of them arise the great painter and the true lover whom the woman and the public end, sometimes too late, by adoring.

第一章 木屋: “好吧！”他大声叫道，“我要留下，我要忍受折磨，我要只为自己而爱她，默默地爱着她。莫黛斯特将会是我的太阳，我的生命，我会借她的气息而呼吸，以她的快乐为快乐，以她的痛苦为痛苦，哪怕她成了那个自我主义者卡那利的妻子。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Well then!” he cried aloud, “I will stay, I will suffer, I will love her for myself only, in solitude.Modeste shall be my sun, my life; I will breathe with her breath, rejoice in her joys and bear her griefs, be she even the wife of that egoist, Canalis.”

第一章 木屋: “这才是我所说的一往情深，先生，”路边的灌木丛里发出了一个声音，“哈哈，怎么全世界的人都爱上了德拉巴斯蒂小姐呢？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “That’s what I call loving, monsieur,” said a voice which came from a shrub by the side of the road.“Ha, ha, so all the world is in love with Mademoiselle de La Bastie?”

第一章 木屋: 接着，比查突然出现了，看着拉布里埃。借着月光，拉布里埃看到了这个小矮子，他遏制住自己的怒火，向前走了几步，没有回答。
Chapter I The Chalet: And Butscha suddenly appeared and looked at La Briere.La Briere checked his anger when, by the light of the moon, he saw the dwarf, and he made a few steps without replying.

第一章 木屋: “在一个连队作战的士兵，应该成为好战友，”比查说道，“您不喜欢卡那利，我也不喜欢他。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Soldiers who serve in the same company ought to be good comrades,” remarked Butscha.“You don’t love Canalis; neither do I.”

第一章 木屋: “他是我的朋友。”埃内斯特回答说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “He is my friend,” replied Ernest.

第一章 木屋: “哈，您就是那个小秘书？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ha, you are the little secretary?”

第一章 木屋: “您要明白，先生，我不是任何人的秘书。我很荣幸在国家最高法院做法律顾问。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “You are to know, monsieur, that I am no man’s secretary.I have the honor to be of counsel to a supreme court of this kingdom.”

第一章 木屋: “我很荣幸向德拉布里埃先生致意，”比查说，“我本人很荣幸成为勒阿弗尔首席顾问拉图奈尔的首席文书，而我的地位要比您有优势。是的，我很高兴在过去四年里，几乎每天晚上都能见到德拉巴斯蒂小姐，而且我将来还会像国王的奴仆住在杜伊勒利宫一样，住在她的附近。即使有人将俄国的王位送给我，我也会这样回答：‘我太爱阳光了。’先生，难道这不是在告诉您，我对她的关切超过了对我自己的关切吗？我正带着最光荣的目的关注着她的幸福。德肖利厄公爵夫人的侍女爱上了热尔曼先生，她不高兴那位迷人的贴身男仆外出呆在勒阿弗尔，如果她在给女主人梳头的时候说起这些，您认为那傲慢的公爵夫人会向德卡那利夫人的幸福投来友好的目光吗——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I have the honor to salute Monsieur de La Briere,” said Butscha.“I myself have the honor to be head clerk to Latournelle, chief councillor of Havre, and my position is a better one than yours.Yes, I have had the happiness of seeing Mademoiselle Modeste de La Bastie nearly every evening for the last four years, and I expect to live near her, as a king’s servant lives in the Tuileries.If they offered me the throne of Russia I should answer, ‘I love the sun too well.’Isn’t that telling you, monsieur, that I care more for her than for myself?I am looking after her interests with the most honorable intentions.Do you believe that the proud Duchesse de Chaulieu would cast a favorable eye on the happiness of Madame de Canalis if her waiting-woman, who is in love with Monsieur Germain, not liking that charming valet’s absence in Havre, were to say to her mistress while brushing her hair—”

第一章 木屋: “您是从谁那儿知道这一切的？”拉布里埃打断比查，说道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Who do you know about all this?” said La Briere, interrupting Butscha.

第一章 木屋: “我本来只是公证人的文书，”比查答道，“但是，难道您没看见我的驼背吗？它里面满是才智，先生。我成了菲洛塞娜·雅克曼小姐的表哥，这位小姐出生于翁弗勒尔，而我母亲也出生在那儿，也姓雅克曼——在翁弗勒尔，雅克曼家族有八个分支。于是，我的表妹就在一笔极为不可信的财富的诱惑下，告诉了我许多事情。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “In the first place, I am clerk to a notary,” answered Butscha.“But haven’t you seen my hump?It is full of resources, monsieur.I have made myself cousin to Mademoiselle Philoxene Jacmin, born at Honfleur, where my mother was born, a Jacmin,—there are eight branches of the Jacmins at Honfleur.So my cousin Philoxene, enticed by the bait of a highly improbable fortune, has told me a good many things.”

第一章 木屋: “公爵夫人有报复心？”拉布里埃说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “The duchess is vindictive?” said La Briere.

第一章 木屋: “菲洛塞娜跟我说，她的报复心像皇后一样强。公爵只是她名义上的丈夫而已，对此，她从来都没原谅过公爵。”比查回答说，“她敢爱敢恨。她的性格、她的口味、她的穿着、她的信仰、还有她的行为习惯，所有这些我都了解，因为菲洛塞娜把她的内心和外表都剖析给我看了。我还专程去剧院看了她，而且一点儿都不后悔花了十法郎——我不是说那戏剧好看。要不是我那所谓的表妹告诉我公爵夫人已经五十岁了，我还真以为她顶多三十岁。那位公爵夫人，她可一点儿不显老！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Vindictive as a queen, Philoxene says; she has never yet forgiven the duke for being nothing more than her husband,” replied Butscha.“She hates as she loves.I know all about her character, her tastes, her toilette, her religion, and her manners; for Philoxene stripped her for me, soul and corset.I went to the opera expressly to see her, and I didn’t grudge the ten francs it cost me—I don’t mean the play.If my imaginary cousin had not told me the duchess had seen her fifty summers, I should have thought I was over-generous in giving her thirty; she has never known a winter, that duchess!”

第一章 木屋: “是的，”拉布里埃说，“她是一块浮雕宝石——因为是石头，所以保存完好。要是公爵夫人发现卡那利在这儿做什么，那卡那利就惨了。而且先生，我希望您这番侦查工作就此打住，这不是一个诚实的人应该做的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Yes,” said La Briere, “she is a cameo—preserved because it is stone.Canalis would be in a bad way if the duchess were to find out what he is doing here; and I hope, monsieur, that you will go no further in this business of spying, which is unworthy of an honest man.”

第一章 木屋: “先生，”比查自豪地说，“对我而言，莫黛斯特就是我的国家。我没有侦查，我只是预见，我是在做预防措施。公爵夫人会在适当的时候出现在这里，要不然她就会安静地呆在她现在的地方，这都要根据我的判断。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” said Butscha, proudly; “for me Modeste is my country.I do not spy; I foresee, I take precautions.The duchess will come here if it is desirable, or she will stay tranquilly where she is, according to what I judge best.”
“You?”

第一章 木屋: “那怎么做呢，请问？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And how, pray?”

第一章 木屋: “哈，就是这样！”这个小驼子拔起一根草，说道，“看这里！这株草以为人们建造了宫殿给它住，它挤在间隔最窄的大理石块中间生长，并把石块掀翻，就像大量民众拥进封建的大厦里将其掀翻一样。微小生命的力量可以潜入任何地方，这种力量要比大炮背后的强大势力厉害得多。我是发誓要让莫黛斯特幸福、并为她而出卖自己荣誉的三个仆人之一。再见，先生。如果您真的爱德拉巴斯蒂小姐，请忘掉这次谈话，并同我握握手，因为我觉得您是有良心的。我迫不及待地要来木屋看看，我到这里时，她刚好熄灯。我看见狗对您吼叫，又听到了您说的话，这就是为什么我冒昧地说我们是在同一团队里作战——忠诚之团。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ha, that’s it!” said the little hunchback, plucking a blade of grass.“See here! this herb believes that men build palaces for it to grow in; it wedges its way between the closest blocks of marble, and brings them down, just as the masses forced into the edifice of feudality have brought it to the ground.The power of the feeble life that can creep everywhere is greater than that of the mighty behind their cannons.I am one of three who have sworn that Modeste shall be happy, and we would sell our honor for her.Adieu, monsieur.If you truly love Mademoiselle de La Bastie, forget this conversation and shake hands with me, for I think you’ve got a heart.I longed to see the Chalet, and I got here just as SHE was putting out her light.I saw the dogs rush at you, and I overheard your words, and that is why I take the liberty of saying we serve in the same regiment—that of loyal devotion.”

第一章 木屋: “先生，”拉布里埃握着驼子的手说，“您能不能行行好，告诉我莫黛斯特小姐在写信给卡那利之前，有没有真心爱过什么人？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” said La Briere, wringing the hunchback’s hand, “would you have the friendliness to tell me if Mademoiselle Modeste ever loved any one WITH LOVE before she wrote to Canalis?”

第一章 木屋: “哎呀！”比查的声音变了，惊呼道，“这种想法是一种侮辱。就算是现在，又有谁知道她是否真的爱谁呢？她了解自己吗？她迷恋天才，迷恋那个贩卖诗歌的商人，迷恋那个文学江湖骗子的心灵和才智。不过，她会考察他的，我们都会考察他，而且我知道怎样让一个人的真正性格从堂皇的行为举止的龟壳下显露出来——我们很快就会看到他那野心勃勃、自大虚荣的小脑袋了！”比查搓着手，大声说道，“所以，除非是小姐对他迷恋得要死——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh!” exclaimed Butscha in an altered voice; “that thought is an insult.And even now, who knows if she really loves? does she know herself?She is enamored of genius, of the soul and intellect of that seller of verses, that literary quack; but she will study him, we shall all study him; and I know how to make the man’s real character peep out from under that turtle-shell of fine manners,—we’ll soon see the petty little head of his ambition and his vanity!” cried Butscha, rubbing his hands.“So, unless mademoiselle is desperately taken with him—”

第一章 木屋: “唉！小姐看见他时，就满心爱慕，好像他是什么不可思议的东西似的。”拉布里埃叫道，流露出他内心的嫉妒。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh! she was seized with admiration when she saw him, as if he were something marvellous,” exclaimed La Briere, letting the secret of his jealousy escape him.

第一章 木屋: “如果他是一个忠诚、正直的小伙子，而且爱小姐，如果他真配得上小姐，如果他宣布放弃他的公爵夫人，”比查说——“那我会想办法对付公爵夫人！嘿，我亲爱的先生，沿这条路走，您十分钟就能到家。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “If he is a loyal, honest fellow, and loves her; if he is worthy of her; if he renounces his duchess,” said Butscha,—“then I’ll manage the duchess!Here, my dear sir, take this road, and you will get home in ten minutes.”

第一章 木屋: 但是，他们一分开，比查就又转过身叫住了可怜的埃内斯特。埃内斯特是个真正的钟情之人，就是让他呆在那儿一整晚谈论莫黛斯特，他也很乐意。
Chapter I The Chalet: But as they parted, Butscha turned back and hailed poor Ernest, who, as a true lover, would gladly have stayed there all night talking of Modeste.

第一章 木屋: “先生，”比查说，“我还未曾有幸见到我们伟大的诗人。我很好奇，想观察一下那个了不起的家伙大显身手时的样子。帮我个忙，明天晚上带他来木屋，并尽可能呆得久一点儿，因为要让一个人露出本来面目，一个多小时可不够。我会第一个看出他是不是爱莫黛斯特小姐，能不能爱莫黛斯特小姐，或者究竟会不会爱莫黛斯特小姐。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur,” said Butscha, “I have not yet had the honor of seeing our great poet.I am very curious to observe that magnificent phenomenon in the exercise of his functions.Do me the favor to bring him to the Chalet tomorrow evening, and stay as long as possible; for it takes more than an hour for a man to show himself for what he is.I shall be the first to see if he loves, if he can love, or if he ever will love Mademoiselle Modeste.”

第一章 木屋: “您太年轻了，不能——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “You are very young to—”

第一章 木屋: “——当专家，”比查直接打断拉布里埃，“哈，先生，畸形儿生下来就有一百岁。另外，一个长期生病的病人，知道的东西比医生都要多，他了解疾病，而就连最好的医生也未必懂得。那么，当一个男人从内心珍爱着一个女人，而女人却因为他的丑陋或畸形而看不起他，情况也会如此。他最后会十分懂得爱情，变得魅力非凡，就像病人恢复健康一样。只有蠢才才无可救药。我从六岁开始就无父无母，现在已经二十五岁了。公共慈善机构是我的母亲，国王代理官就是我的父亲。唉哟！别担心，”看到埃内斯特的手势，他补充道，“尽管处境尴尬，可我还是活得风生水起。唔，自从六年前一个女人的眼神第一次告诉我，说我没权利去爱，我就爱上了女人，并且研究女人。我从长相丑陋的开始，因为解决问题要从关键入手嘛。于是我研究了主人的妻子，当然，对于我的第一次研究来说，她简直是个天使。也许我不该这样做，但我是情不自禁的。我让她经过我的蒸馏器，你猜我发现了什么？那是一个埋藏在她心底的想法：‘我并没有他们想象得那么丑陋’。虽然她很虔诚，但如果一个男人利用这个想法，也有可能将她带到深渊边上。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “—to be a professor,” said Butscha, cutting short La Briere.“Ha, monsieur, deformed folks are born a hundred years old.And besides, a sick man who has long been sick, knows more than his doctor; he knows the disease, and that is more than can be said for the best of doctors.Well, so it is with a man who cherishes a woman in his heart when the woman is forced to disdain him for his ugliness or his deformity; he ends by knowing so much of love that he becomes seductive, just as the sick man recovers his health; stupidity alone is incurable.I have had neither father nor mother since I was six years old; I am now twenty-five.Public charity has been my mother, the procureur du roi my father.Oh! don’t be troubled,” he added, seeing Ernest’s gesture; “I am much more lively than my situation.Well, for the last six years, ever since a woman’s eye first told me I had no right to love, I do love, and I study women.I began with the ugly ones, for it is best to take the bull by the horns.So I took my master’s wife, who has certainly been an angel to me, for my first study.Perhaps I did wrong; but I couldn’t help it.I passed her through my alembic and what did I find? this thought, crouching at the bottom of her heart, ‘I am not so ugly as they think me’; and if a man were to work upon that thought he could bring her to the edge of the abyss, pious as she is.”

第一章 木屋: “那你研究过莫黛斯特吗？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And have you studied Modeste?”

第一章 木屋: “我想我已经告诉过你了，”比查回答说，“我的生命属于她，就像法兰西属于国王一样。您现在明白了您所谓的我在巴黎的侦查吗？除了我，没有人能真正了解在这个可爱人儿的内心和灵魂深处，有着怎样的高贵，怎样的骄傲，怎样的忠诚，怎样的神秘魅力，怎样亘古不变的善良，怎样真实的信仰、欢乐、才智、细腻、学识以及谦恭有礼！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I thought I told you,” replied Butscha, “that my life belongs to her, just as France belongs to the king.Do you now understand what you called my spying in Paris?No one but me really knows what nobility, what pride, what devotion, what mysterious grace, what unwearying kindness, what true religion, gaiety, wit, delicacy, knowledge, and courtesy there are in the soul and in the heart of that adorable creature!”

第一章 木屋: 比查掏出手帕擦了擦眼睛，而拉布里埃则久久地握住他的手。
Chapter I The Chalet: Butscha drew out his handkerchief and wiped his eyes, and La Briere pressed his hand for a long time.

第一章 木屋: “我活在她生命的阳光下，那阳光来自她身上，被我吸收，我们就这样被联系在一起——就像大自然通过光和语言，与上帝连在一起一样。再见了，先生，我有生以来从未这样说过话，但看到您站在她的窗下，我从心底感觉到您就像我一样爱着她。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I live in the sunbeam of her existence; it comes from her, it is absorbed in me; that is how we are united,—as nature is to God, by the Light and by the Word.Adieu, monsieur; never in my life have I talked in this way; but seeing you beneath her windows, I felt in my heart that you loved her as I love her.”

第一章 木屋: 没等这位可怜的情人回答，比查就离开了他。比查的话在他的心头贴上了一剂难以言喻的止痛膏。埃内斯特决定同他交个朋友，并未怀疑这位文书跟自己费口舌的主要目的，是不是为了跟某个与卡那利有关的人通通气。埃内斯特当天晚上思潮汹涌，为以后的行动下着决心，做着计划，翻来覆去好不容易才睡着。而卡那利则睡着征服者的安稳觉，那是除了正直之人的安稳觉之外最甜美的睡眠。
Chapter I The Chalet: Without waiting for an answer Butscha quitted the poor lover, into whose heart his words had put an inexpressible balm.Ernest resolved to make a friend of him, not suspecting that the chief object of the clerk’s loquacity was to gain communication with some one connected with Canalis.Ernest was rocked to sleep that night by the ebb and flow of thoughts and resolutions and plans for his future conduct, whereas Canalis slept the sleep of the conqueror, which is the sweetest of slumbers after that of the just.

第一章 木屋: 第二天早餐时，两个朋友达成协议第二天晚上去木屋，并决定尝尝玩外省惠斯特牌的乐趣。为了打发白天的时间，他们吩咐备好热尔曼花高价买来的马，开始环游这片对他们来说就像中国那样陌生的乡村，以期有所发现，因为对法兰西的法国人来说，最陌生的恰恰是法兰西本身。
Chapter I The Chalet: At breakfast next morning, the friends agreed to spend the evening of the following day at the Chalet and initiate themselves into the delights of provincial whist.To get rid of the day they ordered their horses, purchased by Germain at a large price, and started on a voyage of discovery round the country, which was quite as unknown to them as China; for the most foreign thing to Frenchmen in France is France itself.

第一章 木屋: 考虑到自己现在是个倒霉的、遭人鄙视的情人，埃内斯特进行了一些思考，跟莫黛斯特的第一封信给他带来的思考过程有些类似。尽管说伤痛会助长美德，但这也只能在有美德的人身上发生。那种良心的大扫除，只有天性纯洁的人才会去做。拉布里埃发誓要以斯巴达人的沉默来忍受他的痛苦，要行为正当，不做卑鄙之事；而卡那利则为那笔丰厚的嫁妆所着迷，他告诉自己，要利用一切手段将那位女嗣给迷住。自私自利和正直忠诚，正是这两种性格各自的主基调。因此，在效果往往十分奇特的道德法则的作用下，两人分别采取了与他们各自本性相反的手段。自私自利的人披上了自我克制的外衣；总是替他人着想的人反而到傲慢的阿文丁山上避难去了。这种现象在政治生活中经常见到。人们总是表里不一，而公众有时则不能辨别哪面是真、哪面是假。
Chapter I The Chalet: By dint of reflecting on his position as an unfortunate and despised lover, Ernest went through something of the same process as Modeste’s first letter had forced upon him.Though sorrow is said to develop virtue, it only develops it in virtuous persons; that cleaning-out of the conscience takes place only in persons who are by nature clean.La Briere vowed to endure his sufferings in Spartan silence, to act worthily, and give way to no baseness; while Canalis, fascinated by the enormous “dot,” was telling himself to take every means of captivating the heiress.Selfishness and devotion, the key-notes of the two characters, therefore took, by the action of a moral law which is often very odd in its effects, certain measures that were contrary to their respective natures.The selfish man put on self-abnegation; the man who thought chiefly of others took refuge on the Aventinus of pride.That phenomenon is often seen in political life.Men frequently turn their characters wrong side out, and it sometimes happens that the public is unable to tell which is the right side.

第一章 木屋: 晚饭后，两个朋友听到了马厩大总管到达的消息。当天晚上，他便由拉图奈尔引见到木屋。有一次，德埃鲁维尔小姐故意派一个男仆去请公证人见她，而不直接派她的侄子去，这件事伤到了可敬的公证人。这次特别的造访本来会让公证人在有生之年念念不忘，可这么一来，他就根本没去。所以，当马厩大总管提出驾马车带他去木屋时，拉图奈尔简慢地说，他要先去接他夫人。看到这个小个子愠怒的样子，公爵猜到是有某个错误需要自己弥补，便彬彬有礼地说道：
Chapter I The Chalet: After dinner the two friends heard of the arrival of the grand equerry, who was presented at the Chalet the same evening by Latournelle.Mademoiselle d’Herouville had contrived to wound that worthy man by sending a footmen to tell him to come to her, instead of sending her nephew in person; thus depriving the notary of a distinguished visit he would certainly have talked about for the rest of his natural life.So Latournelle curtly informed the grand equerry, when he proposed to drive him to the Chalet, that he was engaged to take Madame Latournelle.Guessing from the little man’s sulky manner that there was some blunder to repair, the duke said graciously:—

第一章 木屋: “如果您允许，我会很高兴和您一起去接拉图奈尔夫人。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Then I shall have the pleasure, if you will allow me, of taking Madame Latournelle also.”

第一章 木屋: 德埃鲁维尔小姐傲慢地耸了耸肩，但公爵没管她，跟着公证人离开了房间。拉图奈尔夫人看到这辆华丽的马车停在家门口，看到男仆穿着皇室的号衣，放下踏板，高兴得都快疯了。听说马厩大总管是来接她的，她激动得连自己的手套和阳伞都找不到了，平日里滑稽的言行、神奇的派头，也都消失不见了。然而，一上马车，她一面有些疑惑地向小个子公爵表示谢意和寒暄，一面又突然从她善良的内心里闪出了一个念头，说道：

第一章 木屋: “公爵先生把我当成了东西，这已经是我的荣幸了，”比查说，“一个穷文书通常连东西都算不上。”

第一章 木屋: 虽然文书是笑着说这话的，但公爵还是涨红了脸，没有回答。大人物跟比他们社会地位低的人开玩笑是要受指责的。玩笑是一种游戏，而游戏就预设了平等。为了防止这种短暂平等引起的不便，游戏者在游戏结束之后，有权装作互不相识。
Chapter I The Chalet: Though this was said with a laugh, the duke colored and did not answer.Great people are to blame for joking with their social inferiors.Jesting is a game, and games presuppose equality; it is to obviate any inconvenient results of this temporary equality that players have the right, after the game is over, not to recognize each other.

第一章 木屋: 马厩大总管这次造访的借口是他要来谈一件大事，也就是如何开发利用两条河的河口同海岸之间的一大块空地，这块空地国务院刚刚批给埃鲁维尔家族的。事情有点麻烦，涉及到筑防洪堤，在堤上建双电桥，还要排干三四百英亩的泥沙，挖渠沟，铺车道。公爵解释完这块地的状况后，夏尔·米尼翁指出，一定要等还在活动的泥土在自然条件下变稳定、变结实之后，才能动手。
Chapter I The Chalet: The visit of the grand equerry had the ostensible excuse of an important piece of business; namely, the retrieval of an immense tract of waste land left by the sea between the mouths of the two rivers, which tract had just been adjudged by the Council of State to the house of Herouville.The matter was nothing less than putting flood-gates with double bridges, draining three or four hundred acres, cutting canals, and laying out roadways.When the duke had explained the condition of the land, Charles Mignon remarked that time must be allowed for the soil, which was still moving, to settle and grow solid in a natural way.

第一章 木屋: “时间让您的家族富了起来，这是天意。公爵先生，仅靠时间就可以完成这一工程，”他总结道，“最好等五十年后再来开拓这块地。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Time, which has providentially enriched your house, Monsieur le duc, can alone complete the work,” he said, in conclusion.“It would be prudent to let fifty years elapse before you reclaim the land.”

第一章 木屋: “别把话说死了吧，伯爵先生，”公爵说，“请到埃鲁维尔来亲自看看情况吧。”

第一章 木屋: 夏尔·米尼翁回答说，每个资本家都要花时间冷静地调查这类事情。这也就给了公爵常到木屋来的借口。第一次见面，莫黛斯特就给这位年轻人留下了深刻的印象。他说他的姐姐和姑姑早就听说过许多有关莫黛斯特的事情，想和她认识，并希望她能赏脸跟她父亲一起去他家里做客。听了这话，伯爵便提议邀请德埃鲁维尔全家在他搬回公馆的那天过来共进晚餐，亲自向两位女士介绍他的女儿。公爵接受了邀请。蓝色腰带，贵族头衔，特别是贵族绅士那心醉神迷的眼神，对莫黛斯特起到了一定的作用，但她在马车装备、高贵气质和谈吐方面表现得更有优势。公爵很不情愿地告辞了，得到了每晚都到木屋来的邀请——邀请的理由是，大家认为查理十世的朝臣一天晚上不玩牌就会受不了。
Chapter I The Chalet: Charles Mignon replied that every capitalist should take time to examine into such matters with a cool head, thus giving the duke a pretext for his visits to the Chalet.The sight of Modeste made a lively impression on the young man, and he asked the favor of receiving her at Herouville with her father, saying that his sister and his aunt had heard much of her, and wished to make her acquaintance.On this the count proposed to present his daughter to those ladies himself, and invited the whole party to dinner on the day of his return to the villa.The duke accepted the invitation.The blue ribbon, the title, and above all, the ecstatic glances of the noble gentleman had an effect upon Modeste; but she appeared to great advantage in carriage, dignity, and conversation.The duke withdrew reluctantly, carrying with him an invitation to visit the Chalet every evening,—an invitation based on the impossibility of a courtier of Charles X. existing for a single evening without his rubber.

第一章 木屋: 因此，莫黛斯特第二天晚上要见到她那三位追求者齐聚一堂了。尽管少女们想法各异，尽管情感的逻辑会引导她们为自己的选择牺牲一切，但看到身边围着好几个相互竞争的追求者——要么是杰出的人物，要么是著名的人物，要么名门之后——都争相表现自己，讨好她们，这对于她们的小小自恋来说终归是极大的满足。单独来看，三个人当中的每一个都能满足最挑剔的家庭。看着这三个想法各异的人展开斗争，真是一种乐趣。虽然总地来说，这样的情形让莫黛斯特很头疼，但她事后也承认，在这样的乐趣面前，就连她之前在信中所表达的情感也没那么重要了。然而，她遭受的那次可怕的伤痛——尽管此时，她已经开始学着把这次伤痛看成一次小小的失望——给她带来了厌世情绪，让她没精神享受奢侈的自恋。所以，当她的父亲笑着对她说：“怎么样，莫黛斯特，你想做公爵夫人吗？”她嘲讽地鞠了一躬，回答道：
Chapter I The Chalet: The following evening, therefore, Modeste was to see all three of her lovers.No matter what young girls may say, and though the logic of the heart may lead them to sacrifice everything to preference, it is extremely flattering to their self-love to see a number of rival adorers around them,—distinguished or celebrated men, or men of ancient lineage,—all endeavoring to shine and to please.Suffer as Modeste may in general estimation, it must be told she subsequently admitted that the sentiments expressed in her letters paled before the pleasure of seeing three such different minds at war with one another,—three men who, taken separately, would each have done honor to the most exacting family.Yet this luxury of self-love was checked by a misanthropical spitefulness, resulting from the terrible wound she had received,—although by this time she was beginning to think of that wound as a disappointment only.So when her father said to her, laughing, “Well, Modeste, do you want to be a duchess?” she answered, with a mocking curtsey,—

第一章 木屋: 据他们说，这场谈话是在发牌和出牌的间隙中断断续续进行的。话题很快主要转向了德埃鲁维尔公爵的优点，小个子拉图奈尔、小个子迪迈和小个子比查都觉得他长得很好看。要不是先前我们已经讨论过在婚姻大事上使计是否合法，读者很可能会觉得，后面对比查焦心等待着的那个夜晚的描述，有些过于冗长了。
Chapter I The Chalet: This conversation was carried on by fits and starts, as they say, in the intervals of cutting and dealing the cards; and it soon turned chiefly on the merits of the Duc d’Herouville, who was thought very good-looking by little Latournelle, little Dumay, and little Butscha.Without the foregoing discussion on the lawfulness of matrimonial tricks, the reader might possibly find the forthcoming account of the evening so impatiently awaited by Butscha, somewhat too long.

第一章 木屋: 著名的外科医生德普兰第二天上午到了，他只呆了一个小时左右，跟派人去勒阿弗尔要马和套车的工夫差不多。检查完米尼翁夫人的眼睛之后，他便判断夫人可以恢复视力，并决定一个月后找个合适的时间做手术。这一重要的诊断是当着木屋所有成员的面进行的，他们胆战心惊地站在那儿，等着听这位科学泰斗的判决。这位著名的科学院院士一面借着窗户透进来的明亮光线检查她的眼睛，一面问了这位失明的太太十几个简单的问题。令莫黛斯特惊讶的是，这么一个大名人竟会如此珍惜时间。她看到旅行马车里装满了这位伟大的外科医生打算在旅途中读的书，因为他是前一天晚上离开巴黎的，晚上的时间都用来睡觉和赶路了。对于米尼翁夫人的回答，德普兰作出了迅速、清晰的判断，加上他简洁的语调、果断的举止，让莫黛斯特第一次真正意识到天才该是什么样。她察觉到了卡那利那样的二流人物跟人中之杰德普兰之间的巨大差别。一个天才，在意识到自己的才能、巩固了自己的声望之后，会找到自己的一片舞台，在那里，他能够施展、发挥他那理所当然的骄傲，而不妨碍其他人。而且，他会一直忙于处理周围的人和事，没时间搞时髦天才的花样。那些时髦天才，他们迫不及待地将转瞬即逝的一季庄稼收割起来，他们虚荣、自私、小气、苛刻，就像一座海关，对经手的所有东西都要征税。
Chapter I The Chalet: Desplein, the famous surgeon, arrived the next morning, and stayed only long enough to send to Havre for fresh horses and have them put-to, which took about an hour.After examining Madame Mignon’s eyes, he decided that she could recover her sight, and fixed a suitable time, a month later, to perform the operation.This important consultation took place before the assembled members of the Chalet, who stood trembling and expectant to hear the verdict of the prince of science.That illustrious member of the Academy of Sciences put about a dozen brief questions to the blind woman as he examined her eyes in the strong light from a window.Modeste was amazed at the value which a man so celebrated attached to time, when she saw the travelling-carriage piled with books which the great surgeon proposed to read during the journey; for he had left Paris the evening before, and had spent the night in sleeping and travelling.The rapidity and clearness of Desplein’s judgment on each answer made by Madame Mignon, his succinct tone, his decisive manner, gave Modeste her first real idea of a man of genius.She perceived the enormous difference between a second-rate man, like Canalis, and Desplein, who was even more than a superior man.A man of genius finds in the consciousness of his talent and in the solidity of his fame an arena of his own, where his legitimate pride can expand and exercise itself without interfering with others.Moreover, his perpetual struggle with men and things leave them no time for the coxcombry of fashionable genius, which makes haste to gather in the harvests of a fugitive season, and whose vanity and self-love are as petty and exacting as a custom-house which levies tithes on all that comes in its way.

Chapter I The Chalet: “Perhaps we ought first of all to define the man of genius,” replied Canalis.“One of the conditions of genius is invention,—invention of a form, a system, a force.Napoleon was an inventor, apart from his other conditions of genius.He invented his method of making war.Walter Scott is an inventor, Linnaeus is an inventor, Geoffrey Saint-Hilaire and Cuvier are inventors.Such men are men of genius of the first rank.They renew, increase, or modify both science and art.But Desplein is merely a man whose vast talent consists in properly applying laws already known; in observing, by means of a natural gift, the limits laid down for each temperament, and the time appointed by Nature for an operation.He has not founded, like Hippocrates, the science itself.He has invented no system, as did Galen, Broussais, and Rasori.He is merely an executive genius, like Moscheles on the piano, Paganini on the violin, or Farinelli on his own larynx,—men who have developed enormous faculties, but who have not created music.You must permit me to discriminate between Beethoven and la Catalani: to one belongs the immortal crown of genius and of martyrdom, to the other innumerable five-franc pieces; one we can pay in coin, but the world remains throughout all time a debtor to the other.Each day increases our debt to Moliere, but Baron’s comedies have been overpaid.”

to think, thou shalt lift thyself to Me.’We have as much need of the life of the soul as of the life of the body,—hence, there are two utilities.It is true we cannot be shod by books or clothed by poems.An epic song is not, if you take the utilitarian view, as useful as the broth of a charity kitchen.The noblest ideas will not sail a vessel in place of canvas.It is quite true that the cotton-gin gives us calicoes for thirty sous a yard less than we ever paid before; but that machine and all other industrial perfections will not breathe the breath of life into a people, will not tell futurity of a civilization that once existed.Art, on the contrary, Egyptian, Mexican, Grecian, Roman art, with their masterpieces—now called useless!—reveal the existence of races back in the vague immense of time, beyond where the great intermediary nations, denuded of men of genius, have disappeared, leaving not a line nor a trace behind them!The works of genius are the ‘summum’ of civilization, and presuppose utility.Surely a pair of boots are not as agreeable to your eyes as a fine play at the theatre; and you don’t prefer a windmill to the church of Saint-Ouen, do you?Well then, nations are imbued with the same feelings as the individual man, and the man’s cherished desire is to survive himself morally just as he propagates himself physically.The survival of a people is the work of its men of genius.At this very moment France is proving, energetically, the truth of that theory.She is, undoubtedly, excelled by England in commerce, industry, and navigation, and yet she is, I believe, at the head of the world,—by reason of her artists, her men of talent, and the good taste of her products.There is no artist and no superior intellect that does not come to Paris for a diploma.There is no school of painting at this moment but that of France; and we shall reign far longer and perhaps more securely by our books than by our swords.In La Briere’s system, on the other hand, all that is glorious and lovely must be suppressed,—woman’s beauty, music, painting, poetry.Society will not be overthrown, that is true, but, I ask you, who would willingly accept such a life?All useful things are ugly and forbidding.A kitchen is indispensable, but you take care not to sit there; you live in the salon, which you adorn, like this, with superfluous things.Of what use, let me ask you, are these charming wall-paintings, this carved wood-work?There is nothing beautiful but that which seems to us useless.We called the sixteenth century the Renascence with admirable truth of language.That century was the dawn of a new era.Men will continue to speak of it when all remembrance of anterior centuries had passed away,—their only merit being that they once existed, like the million beings who count as the rubbish of a generation.”

第一章 木屋: “我请问您，”比查抨击卡那利，“根据您的说法，天才要在艺术领域自我进化，可这种艺术真的存在吗？这难道不是人类社会的一个堂皇的谎言,不是一种错觉吗？当我透过卧室窗户能看到一幅更美的、上帝自己创造的风景画时，还会想要一幅诺曼底风景画吗？我们的梦想有着比《伊利亚特》更为壮丽的诗篇。只需一点点钱，我就可以在瓦洛涅、卡朗丹、普罗旺斯和阿尔勒找到许多跟提香笔下的维纳斯一样漂亮的美人儿。《司法公报》上刊登的故事，写作手法与瓦尔特·司各特的小说略有不同，但悲惨的结局却是以鲜血、而非墨水写就的。幸福和美德存在于艺术和天才之上，高于艺术和天才。”

第一章 木屋: “小姐，您别介意，”卡那利对她笑着说道，“我们既没被打倒，也没陷入矛盾之中。每一件艺术作品，不管是文学、音乐、绘画、雕塑，或者建筑，都同其他所有的商业产品一样，包含着一种积极的社会功用。艺术是卓越的商业，简言之，艺术预示着商业。一位作家靠他的一本书，就把一万法郎收入囊中，而出书还需要造纸厂、铸造厂、印刷厂、销售商——换句话说，就需要雇用成千上万个人。演奏一部贝多芬的交响乐，或罗西尼的歌剧，也需要人的臂膀、器械，以及制造商。耗资巨大的纪念碑就是一个几近残酷的例子。总之，我可以说天才的作品是以极其高昂的代价为基础的，因而必然是对劳动者有用的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Mademoiselle, do not mind them,” said Canalis, smiling upon her, “we are neither beaten, nor caught in a contradiction.Every work of art, let it be in literature, music, painting, sculpture, or architecture, implies a positive social utility, equal to that of all other commercial products.Art is pre-eminently commerce; presupposes it, in short.An author pockets ten thousand francs for his book; the making of books means the manufactory of paper, a foundry, a printing-office, a bookseller,—in other words, the employment of thousands of men.The execution of a symphony of Beethoven or an opera by Rossini requires human arms and machinery and manufactures.The cost of a monument is an almost brutal case in point.In short, I may say that the works of genius have an extremely costly basis and are, necessarily, useful to the workingman.”

第一章 木屋: “脚正不怕鞋歪，我的军人，”诗人笑着回答说，“但让我告诉您，在精神生活和现实生活中都拥有很多情感，是很有可能的。我这位好朋友拉布里埃，他疯狂地陷入了爱情之中。”卡那利看着莫黛斯特，摆出一副慷慨的姿态，继续说道，“我呢，当然也和他一样爱得强烈——至少我觉得是这样，除非我是在欺骗自己——不过，我能赋予我的爱情一种文学形式，与这份爱和谐统一。但我不敢说，小姐，”他摆出一种过分做作的风度，转向莫黛斯特，补充道，“我明天是不会没有灵感的。”

第一章 木屋: 米尼翁夫人说了句什么话，卡那利便就天主教信仰和拥有一位虔诚妻子的幸福发表了一番慷慨激昂的演说。比查听了，便对拉图奈尔小声说道：“真是个见风使舵的家伙！”

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特的眼睛好像被蒙住了。卡那利的演说艺术，加上她事先便打定主意要密切关注卡那利，使她看不到比查正在细致地观察卡那利的演说。比查注意到卡那利的演讲中缺乏纯真质朴，真情实感被强调语气所取代，还有许多奇怪的不连贯，便在心里严厉地批判了他一番。卡那利说话过程中，有好几次让米尼翁先生、迪迈、比查和拉图奈尔觉得他的话彻底缺乏逻辑。而莫黛斯特却很是崇拜他的机灵，并一面把他拽进幻想的迷宫，一面对自己说：“他爱我！”比查和这出舞台剧的其他观众一样，对于所有自我主义者共同的显著缺点吃惊不已。而卡那利也和许多习惯于长篇大论的人一样，将自己的缺点暴露无遗。也许他事先就明白了对方的意思，也许他根本就没在听，也许他有着一边听别人讲话一边思考其他问题的本事，但可以肯定的是，梅尔基奥尔在谈话时总是一副心不在焉的样子，这打乱了别人的想法，也伤了别人的自尊。不听别人讲话不仅仅是一种不礼貌，也是不尊重他人的一种体现。卡那利把这个习惯表现得太过分了，因为他常常忘了回答需要回答的话，并且不经过平常的礼貌过渡，便一意孤行地转移到他自己想说的任何话题上去。尽管一个声名显赫的人的鲁莽之举，能被他人平静接受，但它却在许多人的心里种下了仇恨和报复的种子，而在那些同等地位的人心里，它甚至会毁掉友情。如果梅尔基奥尔碰巧被迫听了别人的话，他又会犯另一个错误：他只是听听，但从来不发表意见。虽然这可能不会那么令人难堪，但它会表现为一种半妥协的样子，同样会令听者不满、不高兴。在社交中，没有什么能比给予一点点专注带来更多的好处了。“谁听话，就让谁听见”，这不仅仅是一句福音箴言，还是一桩极好的投机买卖。如果你遵循这句话，人们就会原谅你做的一切，甚至是恶行。卡那利费尽心机，急于讨好莫黛斯特，可虽然他对莫黛斯特万分顺从，却还是在其他人面前现出了真面目。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste’s eyes were blindfolded as it were; Canalis’s elocution and the close attention which she was predetermined to pay to him prevented her from seeing that Butscha was carefully noting the declamation, the want of simplicity, the emphasis that took the place of feeling, and the curious incoherencies in the poet’s speech which led the dwarf to make his rather cruel comment.At certain points of Canalis’s discourse, when Monsieur Mignon, Dumay, Butscha, and Latournelle wondered at the man’s utter want of logic, Modeste admired his suppleness, and said to herself, as she dragged him after her through the labyrinth of fancy, “He loves me!”Butscha, in common with the other spectators of what we must call a stage scene, was struck with the radiant defect of all egoists, which Canalis, like many men accustomed to perorate, allowed to be too plainly seen.Whether he understood beforehand what the person he was speaking to meant to say, whether he was not listening, or whether he had the faculty of listening when he was thinking of something else, it is certain that Melchior’s face wore an absent-minded look in conversation, which disconcerted the ideas of others and wounded their vanity.Not to listen is not merely a want of politeness, it is a mark of disrespect.Canalis pushed this habit too far; for he often forgot to answer a speech which required an answer, and passed, without the ordinary transitions of courtesy, to the subject, whatever it was, that preoccupied him.Though such impertinence is accepted without protest from a man of marked distinction, it stirs a leaven of hatred and vengeance in many hearts; in those of equals it even goes so far as to destroy a friendship.If by chance Melchior was forced to listen, he fell into another fault; he merely lent his attention, and never gave it.Though this may not be so mortifying, it shows a kind of semi-concession which is almost as unsatisfactory to the hearer and leaves him dissatisfied.Nothing brings more profit in the commerce of society than the small change of attention.He that heareth let him hear, is not only a gospel precept, it is an excellent speculation; follow it, and all will be forgiven you, even vice.Canalis took a great deal of trouble in his anxiety to please Modeste; but though he was compliant enough with her, he fell back into his natural self with the others.

Chapter I The Chalet: The game opened with the baron and the duke, Gobenheim and Latournelle as partners.Modeste took a seat near the poet, to Ernest’s deep disappointment; he watched the face of the wayward girl, and marked the progress of the fascination which Canalis exerted over her.La Briere had not the gift of seduction which Melchior possessed.Nature frequently denies it to true hearts, who are, as a rule, timid.This gift demands fearlessness, an alacrity of ways and means that might be called the trapeze of the mind; a little mimicry goes with it; in fact there is always, morally speaking, something of the comedian in a poet.There is a vast difference between expressing sentiments we do not feel, though we may imagine all their variations, and feigning to feel them when bidding for success on the theatre of private life.And yet, though the necessary hypocrisy of a man of the world may have gangrened a poet, he ends by carrying the faculties of his talent into the expression of any required sentiment, just as a great man doomed to solitude ends by infusing his heart into his mind.

第一章 木屋: “啊，小姐，”此刻，卡那利正在用爱抚的语调回答莫黛斯特的一句揶揄，“请不要认为情绪多变会在任何程度上削弱情感的力量。诗人甚至要比其他人更需要坚定、忠诚的爱情。您一定不要忌妒那些被称作缪斯的女人。一个终日忙碌的男人，他的妻子是幸福的。如果您听到女人们抱怨自己那身无一官半职或因过于富有而无所事事的丈夫给她们带来了沉重的负担，那您就会明白，一位巴黎女人最大的幸福就是自由——即掌管自己家庭的权利。如今，我们作家以及身兼公职的人会把权利留给自己的妻子。我们不会沦落到实行小人物的那种暴政，我们有更有意义的事要做。如果我结婚了——我向您保证，就目前来说，这还是一个遥远的大灾难——我会希望的我妻子享受一位主妇所享受的精神自由，也许那才是她魅力的真正来源。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, mademoiselle,” Canalis was at this moment saying, in a caressing voice, replying to a roguish remark of Modeste, “do not think that a multiplicity of emotions can in any way lessen the strength of feelings.Poets, even more than other men, must needs love with constancy and faith.You must not be jealous of what is called the Muse.Happy is the wife of a man whose days are occupied.If you heard the complaints of women who have to endure the burden of an idle husband, either a man without duties, or one so rich as to have nothing to do, you would know that the highest happiness of a Parisian wife is freedom,—the right to rule in her own home.Now we writers and men of functions and occupations, we leave the sceptre to our wives; we cannot descend to the tyranny of little minds; we have something better to do.If I ever marry,—which I assure you is a catastrophe very remote at the present moment,—I should wish my wife to enjoy the same moral freedom that a mistress enjoys, and which is perhaps the real source of her attraction.”

Chapter I The Chalet: She left La Briere and took Madame Dumay’s arm to re-enter the house.A few moments later all the actors in this domestic scene reassembled in the salon, and were a good deal surprised to see Modeste sitting beside the Duc d’Herouville and coquetting with him like an accomplished Parisian woman.She watched his play, gave him the advice he wanted, and found occasion to say flattering things by ranking the merits of noble birth with those of genius and beauty.Canalis thought he knew the reason of this change; he had tried to pique Modeste by calling marriage a catastrophe, and showing that he was aloof from it; but like others who play with fire, he had burned his fingers.Modeste’s pride and her present disdain frightened him, and he endeavored to recover his ground, exhibiting a jealousy which was all the more visible because it was artificial.Modeste, implacable as an angel, tasted the sweets of power, and, naturally enough, abused it.The Duc d’Herouville had never known such a happy evening; a woman smiled on him!At eleven o’clock, an unheard-of hour at the Chalet, the three suitors took their leave,—the duke thinking Modeste charming, Canalis believing her excessively coquettish, and La Briere heart-broken by her cruelty.

第一章 木屋: 连续八天，这位女嗣对她三位追求者的态度仍跟那天晚上一样，于是，尽管莫黛斯特的反常和善变时不时地给了德埃鲁维尔公爵一丝希望，但诗人看上去还是占了上风。莫黛斯特对父亲毫不恭敬，在他面前任性妄为，对失明的母亲也没了耐心，从前她以尽孝为乐，现在却好像不愿意服侍母亲似的——这似乎是任性的天性和从小被娇惯的结果。莫黛斯特做得太过分时，便又回过头来坦然地自责，将自己的鲁莽无礼和轻率归因于自主独立的性情。她告诉公爵和卡那利，说她不喜欢事事顺从，而且声称顺从是她婚姻的障碍，以此来探查她的追求者们的天性，就像那些挖洞找金属、煤矿、凝灰岩，或者水的人一样。
Chapter I The Chalet: For eight days the heiress continued to be to her three lovers very much what she had been during that evening; so that the poet appeared to carry the day against his rivals, in spite of certain freaks and caprices which from time to time gave the Duc d’Herouville a little hope.The disrespect she showed to her father, and the great liberties she took with him; her impatience with her blind mother, to whom she seemed to grudge the little services which had once been the delight of her filial piety,—seemed the result of a capricious nature and a heedless gaiety indulged from childhood.When Modeste went too far, she turned round and openly took herself to task, ascribing her impertinence and levity to a spirit of independence.She acknowledged to the duke and Canalis her distaste for obedience, and professed to regard it as an obstacle to her marriage; thus investigating the nature of her suitors, after the manner of those who dig into the earth in search of metals, coal, tufa, or water.

第一章 木屋: “我亲爱的莫黛斯特，”埃莱娜·德埃鲁维尔将她的新朋友带到一边，说，“法兰西王国有上千个男爵，正如巴黎有上百个能与他相提并论的诗人。他才不算什么大人物呢，就连我这个因为没有嫁妆而被迫去当修女的可怜姑娘，都不会看上他。您是不知道，一个被德肖利厄公爵夫人控制了十年的年轻人会是个什么样子。除了一个六十岁老太太，恐怕没有别人受得了这位伟大诗人的那些小毛病，据说他还总是对此抱怨不休——他的习惯在路易十四看来已经变得令人难以忍受了。真的，他的妻子遭的罪会比公爵夫人还多，因为他会一直呆在妻子身边。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My dear Modeste,” said Helene d’Herouville, leading her new friend apart, “there are a thousand barons in the kingdom, just as there are a hundred poets in Paris, who are worth as much as he; he is so little of a great man that even I, a poor girl forced to take the veil for want of a ‘dot,’ I would not take him.You don’t know what a young man is who has been for ten years in the hands of a Duchesse de Chaulieu.None but an old woman of sixty could put up with the little ailments of which, they say, the great poet is always complaining,—a habit in Louis XIV. that became a perfectly insupportable annoyance.It is true the duchess does not suffer from it as much as a wife, who would have him always about her.”

第一章 木屋: 接着，埃莱娜·德埃鲁维尔便施展了一种众所周知的女人特有的花招，将对德肖利厄公爵夫人心怀嫉妒的女人们常常散布的、关于诗人的所有诽谤都低声说了一遍。这个小插曲在女人间的谈话中是很常见的，它将告诉我们，追求者们是怎样激烈地争夺莫黛斯特的财产的。
Chapter I The Chalet: Then, practising a well-known manoeuvre peculiar to her sex, Helene d’Herouville repeated in a low voice all the calumnies which women jealous of the Duchesse de Chaulieu were in the habit of spreading about the poet.This little incident, common as it is in the intercourse of women, will serve to show with what fury the hounds were after Modeste’s wealth.

第一章 木屋: 十天之中，对于德拉巴斯蒂小姐的三位追求者，木屋的人们的看法也大有变化。这种变化对卡那利十分不利，它出自对人的本性的思考，任何名人都应该为此停下来反思。如果我们记得人们追求签名的热情，那就没人能否认，公众的好奇心是被名声大大地激发起来的。很明显，在大多数外省人的头脑里，对于巴黎名人怎样打领带、怎样走在林荫大道上、怎样目中无人地站在那里，或者怎样吃肉排，从来都没有形成一个确切的认识，因为他们一旦看到一个穿着时髦，或者名噪一时（尽管总是令人羡慕的）的人物，他们就会叫道：“快看啊！”“真古怪！”继而发出一连串蔑视的惊呼声。总之，任何一种名气，哪怕是适得其所的名气，它所带来的神秘魅力都不会持久。尤其是对那些好忌妒或者好挖苦人的肤浅之人来说，这只是一种闪电般转瞬即逝、永不再来的感觉。这样看来，名声就像太阳一样，从远处看是火热光亮的，而当你靠近它时，却发现它像山巅一样冰冷。也许，一个人只有对他的同类人来说才是真正伟大的，也许，他身上固有的缺陷在同类人的眼中，会比在那些庸俗的崇拜者眼中消失得更快。一位诗人如果想在平常生活中讨人喜欢，就要摆出各种虚假的风度，就像那些善于用彬彬有礼的举止和讨人喜欢的言语掩盖自己卑劣品质的人一样。这位圣日耳曼近郊的诗人，没有选择在这条社会公理面前低头，不久，他便感觉到一种外省人的无礼冷漠已经代替了前几个晚上那种盲目的迷恋。过度卖弄才华和智慧，对这些可敬的心灵产生的影响，就和满店的玻璃制品对眼睛产生的效果差不多。换句话说，卡那利热情机智的能言善辩很快就让人们感到厌倦，用他们自己的话来说，他们“更关注实实在在的东西。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Ten days saw a great change in the opinions at the Chalet as to the three suitors for Mademoiselle de La Bastie’s hand.This change, which was much to the disadvantage of Canalis, came about through considerations of a nature which ought to make the holders of any kind of fame pause, and reflect.No one can deny, if we remember the passion with which people seek for autographs, that public curiosity is greatly excited by celebrity.Evidently most provincials never form an exact idea in their own minds of how illustrious Parisians put on their cravats, walk on the boulevards, stand gaping at nothing, or eat a cutlet; because, no sooner do they perceive a man clothed in the sunbeams of fashion or resplendent with some dignity that is more or less fugitive (though always envied), than they cry out, “Look at that!” “How queer!” and other depreciatory exclamations.In a word, the mysterious charm that attaches to every kind of fame, even that which is most justly due, never lasts.It is, and especially with superficial people who are envious or sarcastic, a sensation which passes off with the rapidity of lightning, and never returns.It would seem as though fame, like the sun, hot and luminous at a distance, is cold as the summit of an alp when you approach it.Perhaps man is only really great to his peers; perhaps the defects inherent in his constitution disappear sooner to the eyes of his equals than to those of vulgar admirers.A poet, if he would please in ordinary life, must put on the fictitious graces of those who are able to make their insignificances forgotten by charming manners and complying speeches.The poet of the faubourg Saint-Germain, who did not choose to bow before this social dictum, was made before long to feel that an insulting provincial indifference had succeeded to the dazed fascination of the earlier evenings.The prodigality of his wit and wisdom had produced upon these worthy souls somewhat the effect which a shopful of glass-ware produces on the eye; in other words, the fire and brilliancy of Canalis’s eloquence soon wearied people who, to use their own words, “cared more for the solid.”

第一章 木屋: 诗人很快就被迫表现得跟常人一样，碰到了意想不到的绊脚石。而拉布里埃在同一块地盘上，则已经赢得了那些开始认为他很沉闷的可敬之人的选票。他们觉得需要通过偏爱名人的朋友，来对自己进行补偿。心地最善良的人们会被这样的想法所影响。这位淳朴、率直的年轻人没有伤害过任何人的自尊。他们更深入地了解他之后，便发现他心地善良、谦恭礼让、沉默安静、处事谨慎，而且很有教养。德埃鲁维尔公爵从政治角度考虑，认为拉布里埃远在卡那利之上。诗人性情多变、野心勃勃，像塔索一样焦躁不安，他喜欢奢侈、豪华，还欠了债；而年轻的律师则性情温和、生活节制，乐于助人且不张扬，期待回报却不乞求回报，而且还存有积蓄。
Chapter I The Chalet: Forced after a while to behave like an ordinary man, the poet found an unexpected stumbling-block on ground where La Briere had already won the suffrage of the worthy people who at first had thought him sulky.They felt the need of compensating themselves for Canalis’s reputation by preferring his friend.The best of men are influenced by such feelings as these.The simple and straightforward young fellow jarred no one’s self-love; coming to know him better they discovered his heart, his modesty, his silent and sure discretion, and his excellent bearing.The Duc d’Herouville considered him, as a political element, far above Canalis.The poet, ill-balanced, ambitious, and restless as Tasso, loved luxury, grandeur, and ran into debt; while the young lawyer, whose character was equable and well-balanced, lived soberly, was useful without proclaiming it, awaited rewards without begging for them, and laid by his money.

第一章 木屋: 而且，卡那利还以一种特殊的方式向那些观察着他的中产阶级们展示自己。这两三天来，他已经表现出不耐烦的样子，流露出沮丧的神情，陷入了看上去毫无理由的忧郁状态，以及诗人们的神经质自然而然导致的那些情绪波动。这些怪里怪气（我们用的是外省字眼）是他的不安造成的，他感觉随着时间的流逝，越来越无法向德肖利厄夫人解释他的所作所为了。他知道应该给她写封信，但就是下不了决心。所有的这些情绪波动，都被温和的美国女子和高尚的拉图奈尔夫人细心地观察和评论着，她们不止一次地同米尼翁夫人谈论过这个话题。卡那利感觉到了这些谈论的影响，但却无法对其进行解释。大家对他的态度变了，周围人的脸上也不再有前几天那种着迷的表情了，而与此同时，埃内斯特显然正在被人们所接受。
Chapter I The Chalet: Canalis had moreover laid himself open in a special way to the bourgeois eyes that were watching him.For two or three days he had shown signs of impatience; he had given way to depression, to states of melancholy without apparent reason, to those capricious changes of temper which are the natural results of the nervous temperament of poets.These originalities (we use the provincial word) came from the uneasiness that his conduct toward the Duchesse de Chaulieu which grew daily less explainable, caused him.He knew he ought to write to her, but could not resolve on doing so.All these fluctuations were carefully remarked and commented on by the gentle American, and the excellent Madame Latournelle, and they formed the topic of many a discussion between these two ladies and Madame Mignon.Canalis felt the effects of these discussions without being able to explain them.The attention paid to him was not the same, the faces surrounding him no longer wore the entranced look of the earlier days; while at the same time Ernest was evidently gaining ground.

第一章 木屋: 在过去两天里，诗人只极力引诱莫黛斯特一个人，并且利用每一个跟她独处的时刻，在他心爱的人周围用热烈的情话编织罗网。莫黛斯特满面娇羞地听着这些不着边际的甜言蜜语，喜悦之情在两位德埃鲁维尔小姐一展无遗。两位小姐看到这种情形，极其不安，便马上使出女人在这种情况下常用的“ultima ratio”，也即污蔑诽谤，这种污蔑诽谤往往是很有成效的。因此，大家都入席就餐时，诗人看到他的偶像眉宇间乌云密布。他知道德埃鲁维尔小姐的狠毒不容许他浪费任何时间，便决定一找到机会同莫黛斯特单独在一起，便马上自荐做她的丈夫。
Chapter I The Chalet: For the last two days the poet had endeavored to fascinate Modeste only, and he took advantage of every moment when he found himself alone with her, to weave the web of passionate language around his love.Modeste’s blush, as she listened to him on the occasion we have just mentioned, showed the demoiselles d’Herouville the pleasure with which she was listening to sweet conceits that were sweetly said; and they, horribly uneasy at the sight, had immediate recourse to the “ultima ratio” of women in such cases, namely, those calumnies which seldom miss their object.Accordingly, when the party met at the dinner-table the poet saw a cloud on the brow of his idol; he knew that Mademoiselle d’Herouville’s malignity allowed him to lose no time, and he resolved to offer himself as a husband at the first moment when he could find himself alone with Modeste.

第一章 木屋: 晚宴十分丰盛，招待得极为周到。席间，公爵又明显较卡那利占了上风。莫黛斯特前一天晚上刚刚收到她的骑装和其他骑马装备，便说到骑马外出郊游。说着说着，就提到了她想看看围猎，这是她到目前为止还没享受过的乐趣。公爵立刻提议为她在离勒阿弗尔几里格远的皇家森林里准备一次围猎。他想靠着他同猎队长德卡迪央亲王的亲密关系，借机向莫黛斯特展现一个皇家般的盛大排场，让她一窥宫廷生活的诱人之处，引诱她通过和他结婚来得到这一切。公爵和他的两位德埃鲁维尔小姐互相交换了眼神，明摆着是在说：“女嗣是我们的了！”诗人觉察到了他们的眼神，便更加笃定他必须马上得到某种情感上的保证，因为他只剩下个人的名声可依靠了。另一方面，莫黛斯特见德埃鲁维尔一家的决定超出了她的打算，几乎被吓到了。饭后，大家一起到花园里散步，她很明显地跟梅尔基奥尔保持着距离。出于完全可以理解的少女的好奇心，她故意让卡那利怀疑埃莱娜是不是在她面前说了什么毁谤的话。但看到卡那利发怒了，她便请求他只字不提那些话，他也答应了。
Chapter I The Chalet: During the dinner, which was magnificent and admirably well served, the duke obtained a signal advantage over Canalis.Modeste, who had received her habit and other equestrian equipments the night before, spoke of taking rides about the country.A turn of the conversation led her to express the wish to see a hunt with hounds, a pleasure she had never yet enjoyed.The duke at once proposed to arrange a hunt in one of the crown forests, which lay a few leagues from Havre.Thanks to his intimacy with the Prince de Cadignan, Master of the Hunt, he saw his chance of displaying an almost regal pomp before Modeste’s eyes, and alluring her with a glimpse of court fascinations, to which she could be introduced by marriage.Glances were exchanged between the duke and the two demoiselles d’Herouville, which plainly said, “The heiress is ours!” and the poet, who detected them, and who had nothing but his personal splendors to depend on, determined all the more firmly to obtain some pledge of affection at once.Modeste, on the other hand, half-frightened at being thus pushed beyond her intentions by the d’Herouvilles, walked rather markedly apart with Melchior, when the company adjourned to the park after dinner.With the pardonable curiosity of a young girl, she let him suspect the calumnies which Helene had poured into her ears; but on Canalis’s exclamation of anger, she begged him to keep silence about them, which he promised.

第一章 木屋: “这些恶语中伤，”他说，“在上流社会被认为是公平的。您生性正直，因而为它们感到惊讶，可我却对它们嗤之以鼻，甚至感到高兴。这两位小姐肯定是觉得公爵的利益面临极大的威胁，才会出此下策。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “These stabs of the tongue,” he said, “are considered fair in the great world.They shock your upright nature; but as for me, I laugh at them; I am even pleased.These ladies must feel that the duke’s interests are in great peril, when they have recourse to such warfare.”

第一章 木屋: 卡那利最大限度地利用了莫黛斯特给他的优势，一面感谢莫黛斯特给了他信任，让他贸然从中窥到了爱情的曙光，一面用热情、殷切以及巧妙地表露出的激情来为自己辩护。这样一来，莫黛斯特发现自己突然向诗人妥协了，正如她害怕自己会向马厩大总管妥协那样。卡那利感觉有必要立即行动，便直接表白了。他吐出各种山盟海誓，言语中透着应景的诗意，像一轮明月般光芒四射。他用了大量典故，盛赞心上人的美貌，以及她晚礼服的亮丽。这位急切的情人无所不用其极，借用了夜色、树叶、天空、大地，乃至大自然本身，来粉饰这伪装的激情。他大谈特谈自己的公正无私，还用自己优美的风格，将狄德罗著名的感叹“索菲和一千五百法郎！”以及说烂了的“草屋里的爱情”翻新了一遍。这是每一个对岳父的财产了如指掌的情人都会的一套。
Chapter I The Chalet: Making the most of the advantage Modeste had thus given him, Canalis entered upon his defence with such warmth, such eagerness, and with a passion so exquisitely expressed, as he thanked her for a confidence in which he could venture to see the dawn of love, that she found herself suddenly as much compromised with the poet as she feared to be with the grand equerry.Canalis, feeling the necessity of prompt action, declared himself plainly.He uttered vows and protestations in which his poetry shone like a moon, invoked for the occasion, and illuminating his allusions to the beauty of his mistress and the charms of her evening dress.This counterfeit enthusiasm, in which the night, the foliage, the heavens and the earth, and Nature herself played a part, carried the eager lover beyond all bounds; for he dwelt on his disinterestedness, and revamped in his own charming style, Diderot’s famous apostrophe to “Sophie and fifteen hundred francs!” and the well-worn “love in a cottage” of every lover who knows perfectly well the length of the father-inlaw’s purse.

Chapter I The Chalet: An hour later Ernest had ridden out of Havre.He reached Paris in twelve hours, where his first act was to secure a place in the mail-coach for Havre on the following evening.Then he went to three of the chief jewellers in Paris and compared all the whip-handles that they could offer; he was in search of some artistic treasure that was regally superb.He found one at last, made by Stidmann for a Russian, who was unable to pay for it when finished,—a fox-head in gold, with a ruby of exorbitant value; all his savings went into the purchase, the cost of which was seven thousand francs.Ernest gave a drawing of the arms of La Bastie, and allowed the shop-people twenty hours to engrave them.The handle, a masterpiece of delicate workmanship, was fitted to an india-rubber whip and put into a morocco case lined with velvet, on which two M.’s interlaced were stamped in gold.

第一章 木屋: “而且挤掉他的东家！”小矮人向卡那利瞥了一眼，大声说道。卡那利的傲慢都在这碳酸水的咕噜声中湮没了。“我很少会知恩图报，而且很会耍手段，我会骑到您头上去的。哈哈，一位诗人背着一个驼子！那种情形我见到过，经常见到——在书架上。好了，别那样看着我，好像我在表演吞剑似的。我亲爱的伟大天才，您是个上等人，您知道感恩是傻子们才用的词，人们将它收到词典里，但它并不存在于人们心中。只有在某座山上——既不是品都斯山，也不是帕纳赛斯山——誓言才有价值。我的女东家一手把我带大，您认为我欠她很多。上帝保佑，全城的人已经用赞美、尊敬和倾慕偿还她了——那些可是最值钱的东西啊。而我是不会认同任何只能助长自恋的善行的。人们用他们的善行做交易，让借方感激——如此而已。至于阴谋诡计嘛，那可是我的神祗。怎么？”他见卡那利做了一个手势，便惊呼道，“难道您不崇拜那种让一个诡计多端的人战胜天才的能力吗？它能最细致地观察对方的癖好、弱点，并机智地抓住快乐的时刻。您去问问，外交手腕的最大成就是不是诡计战胜武力的结果？如果我是您的秘书，男爵先生，您很快就会当上首相，因为那样对我有利啊。您想不想让我示范一下我在那方面的才能？那好，您听着，您疯狂地爱着莫黛斯特小姐，而且您这样做无可非议。这位少女拥有我最崇高的敬意，她是一个真正的巴黎人。有时候，我们外省也有些真正的巴黎人降生。唔，莫黛斯特正是一个有助于男人事业的女人。她有这个，”他把手腕在空中一转，大声说道，“但您有一个危险的竞争对手，就是公爵。如果我在三天内让他滚出勒阿弗尔，您给我什么报酬？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “And oust his chief!” cried the dwarf flinging a look at Canalis whose insolence was lost in the gurgling of carbonic acid gas.“I’ve little enough gratitude and quite enough scheming to get astride of your shoulders.Ha, ha, a poet carrying a hunchback! that’s been seen, often seen—on book-shelves.Come, don’t look at me as if I were swallowing swords.My dear great genius, you’re a superior man; you know that gratitude is the word of fools; they stick it in the dictionary, but it isn’t in the human heart; pledges are worth nothing, except on a certain mount that is neither Pindus nor Parnassus.You think I owe a great deal to my master’s wife, who brought me up.Bless you, the whole town has paid her for that in praises, respect, and admiration,—the very best of coin.I don’t recognize any service that is only the capital of self-love.Men make a commerce of their services, and gratitude goes down on the debit side,—that’s all.As to schemes, they are my divinity.What?” he exclaimed, at a gesture of Canalis, “don’t you admire the faculty which enables a wily man to get the better of a man of genius? it takes the closest observation of his vices, and his weaknesses, and the wit to seize the happy moment.Ask diplomacy if its greatest triumphs are not those of craft over force?If I were your secretary, Monsieur le baron, you’d soon be prime-minister, because it would be my interest to have you so.Do you want a specimen of my talents in that line?Well then, listen; you love Mademoiselle Modeste distractedly, and you’ve good reason to do so.The girl has my fullest esteem; she is a true Parisian.Sometimes we get a few real Parisians born down here in the provinces.Well, Modeste is just the woman to help a man’s career.She’s got that in her,” he cried, with a turn of his wrist in the air.“But you’ve a dangerous competitor in the duke; what will you give me to get him out of Havre within three days?”

第一章 木屋: “——因此，我回到家，将它们思考一遍之后，就再没被它们所误导了。我只是惊讶，您的聪明跟您的性格和面容是如此和谐一致。您别紧张，我从未怀疑过您假装的表里不一会掩盖那天使般的坦率。不，您的思想，您所受的教育，丝毫都没有减少我们对一个妻子所要求的宝贵的天真无邪。您确实适合做一位诗人、一位外交官、一位思想家、一个注定要历尽生活沉浮之人的妻子，而我对您的钦佩，恰恰和我对您的依恋是同样多。我现在恳求您——如果您昨天接受了一位男子对您的爱，而不是耍他，他的虚荣会变成自豪，他的缺点会在您神圣的影响下变成优点——我恳求您，不要激起他身上那种会发展成恶习的激情。嫉妒在我的心灵里是一种有毒元素，而您已经向我显示出它的力量。它是可怕的，它会毁坏一切——哦！我不是说奥赛罗式的嫉妒。”他注意到了莫黛斯特的手势，便接着说道，“不，不，我的思想是我自己的，我对此一直深信不疑。您知道我对您的爱，以及这份爱带给我的幸福——尽管这幸福只有一点点。”（他伤心地摇了摇头。）“在所有的国度里，人们都把爱情比作孩子，因为它幻想着这个世界是属于自己的，并只能这样幻想。然而，大自然却亲自给这种情感设定了限制。它是个死婴。一个温柔、母性的心灵猜透并抚慰了我内心压抑的痛苦——因为一位感觉到并知道自己已经经历过爱情之欢的女人，在为他人疗伤时，会变得如天使一般。公爵夫人从未让我在感情方面遭受过痛苦。十年来，没有一个字，没有一个眼神，让我受伤！跟一般人相比，我更看重言语、思想和眼神。如果一个眼神对我来说是一笔无价之宝，那么最细微的怀疑都是致命的毒药，它会立即发作，我的爱也就死了。与大部分人相反，我不认为爱情的欢乐在于忐忑、期望和等待——我觉得爱情只能存在于完美的、婴孩般的、无穷的安全之中。女人乐于用她们的风情万种让我们经历一番痛苦的历练，那是一种我不会屈从的卑微的幸福：对我来说，爱情要么是天堂，要么是地狱。如果它是地狱的话，我丝毫都不会接受。对天堂那蔚蓝的天空，我内心感觉到深深的眷恋。在未来的生活里，我能够毫无保留地献身，没有秘密，也没有怀疑或者欺骗，而我要求对方也如此。也许，我的这些疑虑冒犯了您。但是，请记住，我只是在谈论我自己——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “—and therefore when I returned home and thought them over, they never misled me.I only marvelled at a cleverness so in harmony with your character and your countenance.Do not be uneasy, I never doubted that your assumed duplicity covered an angelic candor.No, your mind, your education, have in no way lessened the precious innocence which we demand in a wife.You are indeed a wife for a poet, a diplomatist, a thinker, a man destined to endure the chances and changes of life; and my admiration is equalled only by the attachment I feel to you.I now entreat you—if yesterday you were not playing a little comedy when you accepted the love of a man whose vanity will change to pride if you accept him, one whose defects will become virtues under your divine influence—I entreat you do not excite a passion which, in him, amounts to vice.Jealousy is a noxious element in my soul, and you have revealed to me its strength; it is awful, it destroys everything—Oh! I do not mean the jealousy of an Othello,” he continued, noticing Modeste’s gesture.“No, no; my thoughts were of myself: I have been so indulged on that point.You know the affection to which I owe all the happiness I have ever enjoyed,—very little at the best” (he sadly shook his head).“Love is symbolized among all nations as a child, because it fancies the world belongs to it, and it cannot conceive otherwise.Well, Nature herself set the limit to that sentiment.It was still-born.A tender, maternal soul guessed and calmed the painful constriction of my heart,—for a woman who feels, who knows, that she is past the joys of love becomes angelic in her treatment of others.The duchess has never made me suffer in my sensibilities.For ten years not a word, not a look, that could wound me!I attach more value to words, to thoughts, to looks, than ordinary men.If a look is to me a treasure beyond all price, the slightest doubt is deadly poison; it acts instantaneously, my love dies.I believe—contrary to the mass of men, who delight in trembling, hoping, expecting—that love can only exist in perfect, infantile, and infinite security.The exquisite purgatory, where women delight to send us by their coquetry, is a base happiness to which I will not submit: to me, love is either heaven or hell.If it is hell, I will have none of it.I feel an affinity with the azure skies of Paradise within my soul.I can give myself without reserve, without secrets, doubts or deceptions, in the life to come; and I demand reciprocity.Perhaps I offend you by these doubts.Remember, however, that I am only talking of myself—”

第一章 木屋: 致德肖利厄公爵夫人：
Chapter I The Chalet: To Madame la Duchesse de Chaulieu:

第一章 木屋: 我亲爱的埃莱奥诺尔——没有收到我的来信，你一定颇感意外吧。不过，我呆在这个地方，不完全是由于我的健康的缘故。我一直在帮我们年轻的朋友拉布里埃的忙。这个可怜的小伙子，他爱上了一个叫莫黛斯特·德拉巴斯蒂的小姐，她是一个面色苍白、地位低微、身材单薄的小姑娘。顺便说一下，她有喜爱文学的癖好，还称自己为诗人，以此来为她种种无聊的任性妄为和想入非非申辩。你是知道埃内斯特的——他太容易上钩了，所以我也就不放心丢下他一个人。德拉巴斯蒂小姐想对你的梅尔基奥尔卖弄风情，而且一心要成为你的情敌。但她双臂干瘦，而且跟大部分少女一样，胸部不丰满；还有，她的头发就跟德罗什菲德夫人的一样，暗淡无光泽；她的眼睛很小、阴暗无神，还很多疑。我制止了——可能过于粗暴地——这位不知自重的小姐的卖弄风情。不过，正是爱情，我对你的爱情，要求我那样做。世上所有的女人，跟我有什么关系呢——跟你相比，她们算得上什么呢？
Chapter I The Chalet: My dear Eleonore,—You have doubtless been surprised at not hearing from me; but the stay I am making in this place is not altogether on account of my health.I have been trying to do a good turn to our little friend La Briere.The poor fellow has fallen in love with a certain Mademoiselle Modeste de La Bastie, a rather pale, insignificant, and thread-papery little thing, who, by the way, has the vice of liking literature, and calls herself a poet to excuse the caprices and humors of a rather sullen nature.You know Ernest,—he is so easy to catch that I have been afraid to leave him to himself.Mademoiselle de La Bastie was inclined to coquet with your Melchior, and was only too ready to become your rival, though her arms are thin, and she has no more bust than most girls; moreover, her hair is as dead and colorless as that of Madame de Rochefide, and her eyes small, gray, and very suspicious.I put a stop—perhaps rather brutally—to the attentions of Mademoiselle Immodeste; but love, such as mine for you, demanded it.What care I for all the women on earth,—compared to you, what are they?

第一章 木屋: 和我呆在一起打发时光，也就是围在这位女嗣身边的那些人，都是十足的小市民样，几乎让我作呕。可怜可怜我吧，想想看！我晚上都跟公证人、公证人夫人、账房管家和外省的放债人呆在一起——啊！这跟我在格勒内勒街的夜晚真是天壤之别。她的父亲刚从中国回来，他所谓的财产，把那个不知疲倦的追求者马厩大总管引到勒阿弗尔来了。大总管垂涎她那几百万财产，据说是为了排干他的沼泽地。国王还不知道，他给公爵的那些荒地是个多么要命的礼物。公爵阁下还没有发现这位小姐只有一笔小小的财产，还嫉妒我，而拉布里埃在我这个瞎子般的朋友的掩护下，正悄悄向他的偶像逼近。
Chapter I The Chalet: The people with whom I pass my time, and who form the circle round the heiress, are so thoroughly bourgeois that they almost turn my stomach.Pity me; imagine!I pass my evenings with notaries, notaresses, cashiers, provincial money-lenders—ah! what a change from my evenings in the rue de Grenelle.The alleged fortune of the father, lately returned from China, has brought to Havre that indefatigable suitor, the grand equerry, hungry after the millions, which he wants, they say, to drain his marshes.The king does not know what a fatal present he made the duke in those waste lands.His Grace, who has not yet found out that the lady had only a small fortune, is jealous of me; for La Briere is quietly making progress with his idol under cover of his friend, who serves as a blind.

第一章 木屋: 尽管浪漫多情的埃内斯特已为她神魂颠倒，但我这个诗人却主要考虑实质的东西，而且我已经在做一些打探，结果证明我们的朋友前途暗淡。如果我的天使愿意赦免我们一些的小罪过，她就会把银行家蒙日诺请来，用她特有的巧妙手段去盘问他，看莫黛斯特的父亲到底有多少财产。米尼翁先生原来是皇家卫队的骑兵中校，他在过去七年里都是蒙日诺银号的客户。据说，他会给他女儿二十万法郎做嫁妆，但在代表埃内斯特出价之前，我迫切地想了解事情的真相。这件事一办好，我马上就回巴黎去。我知道一个办法，能让事情都有利于我们年轻的情人——只要过继他岳父的头衔即可，而且，我想，由于埃内斯特的竭诚服务，还有你、我，以及公爵给他的帮助，没有谁能比他更顺理成章地得到这一恩赐。凭埃内斯特的兴趣爱好，他自然会在我去巴登之后接替我的职位，领一年两万五千法郎的薪俸。一个终身职衔和一个老婆——这个倒霉的家伙会在巴黎生活得很开心的！
Chapter I The Chalet: Notwithstanding Ernest’s romantic ecstasies, I myself, a poet, think chiefly of the essential thing, and I have been making some inquiries which darken the prospects of our friend.If my angel would like absolution for some of our little sins, she will try to find out the facts of the case by sending for Mongenod, the banker, and questioning him, with the dexterity that characterizes her, as to the father’s fortune?Monsieur Mignon, formerly colonel of cavalry in the Imperial guard, has been for the last seven years a correspondent of the Mongenods.It is said that he gives his daughter a “dot” of two hundred thousand francs, and before I make the offer on Ernest’s behalf I am anxious to get the rights of the story.As soon as the affair is arranged I shall return to Paris.I know a way to settle everything to the advantage of our young lover,—simply by the transmission of the father-inlaw’s title, and no one, I think, can more readily obtain that favor than Ernest, both on account of his own services and the influence which you and I and the duke can exert for him.With his tastes, Ernest, who of course will step into my office when I go to Baden, will be perfectly happy in Paris with twenty-five thousand francs a year, a permanent place, and a wife—luckless fellow!

第一章 木屋: 啊，最最亲爱的，我多么想念格勒内勒大街啊！我离开半个月了！分离没有扼杀我的爱，而是带回了初恋时的全部热情，而且你也许比我更清楚，让我的爱情永不停止的原因是什么——就是进了坟墓，我的骨头还是会爱你的！啊！我无法忍受这种分别。要是我被迫再在这儿呆十天，那我就会回巴黎一次，呆上短短的几个小时。
Chapter I The Chalet: Ah, dearest, how I long for the rue de Grenelle!Fifteen days of absence! when they do not kill love, they revive all the ardor of its earlier days, and you know, better than I, perhaps, the reasons that make my love eternal,—my bones will love thee in the grave!Ah! I cannot bear this separation.If I am forced to stay here another ten days, I shall make a flying visit of a few hours to Paris.

第一章 木屋: 公爵为我谋到我们想要的东西了吗？而你，我最最亲爱的人儿，你明年会喝到巴登的山泉水吗？这位“忧郁美男子”的喁喁私语，跟我们爱情的欢声笑语——如此真实，十年不变！——相比，让我对婚姻产生了一种极大的蔑视。我从来都没有如此近距离接触过这类事情。啊，最最亲爱的！世人称之为“失足”的东西，会比法律更紧密地将两个人连在一起——不是吗？
Chapter I The Chalet: Has the duke obtained for me the thing we wanted; and shall you, my dearest life, be ordered to drink the Baden waters next year?The billing and cooing of the “handsome disconsolate,” compared with the accents of our happy love—so true and changeless for now ten years!—have given me a great contempt for marriage.I had never seen the thing so near.Ah, dearest! what the world calls a “false step” brings two beings nearer together than the law—does it not?

第一章 木屋: 后面两页的中心思想是对往事的追忆和强烈的愿望，有点过于亲密，就不好公开了。
Chapter I The Chalet: The concluding idea served as a text for two pages of reminiscences and aspirations a little too confidential for publication.

第一章 木屋: 就在卡那利将这封信投进邮筒的前一天晚上，比查，也就是假冒的让·雅克曼，收到了他的假表妹菲罗塞娜的信。这样，他的回信就比诗人的信早了十二个小时寄出。公爵夫人半个月来极为不安，又被梅尔基奥尔的杳无音信伤透了心，于是她命菲罗塞娜写一封信给她表哥，信的内容由她亲自口述。而比查的回信过于直白，伤到了她五十岁人的自尊心。她一读完信，就派人请来银行家蒙日诺，并细致询问了米尼翁先生的确切财产。爱莱奥诺尔发现自己因为几百万而被人背叛、抛弃，气愤、仇恨，以及冷酷的报复情绪突然发作。菲罗塞娜敲了敲那间奢华卧房的门，走进去时发现她的女主人泪眼婆娑——这是她服侍女主人十五年来从未有过的情况。她站在那里，目瞪口呆。
Chapter I The Chalet: The evening before the day on which Canalis put the above epistle into the post, Butscha, under the name of Jean Jacmin, had received a letter from his fictitious cousin, Philoxene, and had mailed his answer, which thus preceded the letter of the poet by about twelve hours.Terribly anxious for the last two weeks, and wounded by Melchior’s silence, the duchess herself dictated Philoxene’s letter to her cousin, and the moment she had read the answer, rather too explicit for her quinquagenary vanity, she sent for the banker and made close inquiries as to the exact fortune of Monsieur Mignon.Finding herself betrayed and abandoned for the millions, Eleonore gave way to a paroxysm of anger, hatred, and cold vindictiveness.Philoxene knocked at the door of the sumptuous room, and entering found her mistress with her eyes full of tears,—so unprecedented a phenomenon in the fifteen years she had waited upon her that the woman stopped short stupefied.

第一章 木屋: “十分钟就把十年的幸福给毁了。”她听公爵夫人说道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “We expiate the happiness of ten years in ten minutes,” she heard the duchess say.

第一章 木屋: “夫人，一封勒阿弗尔来的信。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “A letter from Havre, madame.”

第一章 木屋: 埃莱奥诺尔读着诗人的信，都没有注意到菲罗塞娜在场。菲罗塞娜见公爵夫人读着读着，脸上又恢复了平静，便感到更为惊讶了。递一根手杖粗细的棍子给一个将要被淹死的人，他就会将其视为一条平安大道。埃莱奥诺尔读过那四页爱情与交易、谎言与真相相互交织的信之后，幸福的她相信卡那利是真心诚意的。就在早些时候，她还让丈夫去阻止对梅尔基奥尔的任命，趁时间还来得及。现在，她又被一种近乎伟大的宽宏大量精神左右了。
Chapter I The Chalet: Eleonore read the poet’s prose without noticing the presence of Philoxene, whose amazement became still greater when she saw the dawn of fresh serenity on the duchess’s face as she read further and further into the letter.Hold out a pole no thicker than a walking-stick to a drowning man, and he will think it a high-road of safety.The happy Eleonore believed in Canalis’s good faith when she had read through the four pages in which love and business, falsehood and truth, jostled each other.She who, a few moments earlier, had sent for her husband to prevent Melchior’s appointment while there was still time, was now seized with a spirit of generosity that amounted almost to the sublime.

第一章 木屋: “可怜的小伙子！”她心想，“他一点儿不老实的想法都没有，他还是跟第一天那样爱我，他告诉了我全部情况——菲罗塞娜！”她注意到女仆正站在她附近假装收拾梳妆台，便叫道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Poor fellow!” she thought; “he has not had one faithless thought; he loves me as he did on the first day; he tells me all—Philoxene!” she cried, noticing her maid, who was standing near and pretending to arrange the toilet-table.

第一章 木屋: “公爵夫人有何吩咐？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Madame la duchesse?”

第一章 木屋: “把镜子给我，孩子！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “A mirror, child!”

第一章 木屋: 埃莱奥诺尔揽镜自照，看见额头上延伸着一道道刀割般的皱纹。她叹了口气，在那叹惜声中，她感觉自己要向爱情告别了。她抛开所有女人的小心眼儿，想到了一个颇具男子气概的大胆主意——这个想法让她自我陶醉了好一会儿，或许也可以解释俄国的塞米勒米斯为什么宽宏大量地将她年轻漂亮的情敌嫁给了马莫诺夫。
Chapter I The Chalet: Eleonore looked at herself, saw the fine razor-like lines traced on her brow, which disappeared at a little distance; she sighed, and in that sigh she felt she bade adieu to love.A brave thought came into her mind, a manly thought, outside of all the pettiness of women,—a thought which intoxicates for a moment, and which explains, perhaps, the clemency of the Semiramis of Russia when she married her young and beautiful rival to Momonoff.

第一章 木屋: “既然他没有对我不忠，他倒可以把那个姑娘和她的几百万弄到手，”她想道，——“前提是米尼翁小姐的确像他所说的那样丑。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Since he has not been faithless, he shall have the girl and her millions,” she thought,—“provided Mademoiselle Mignon is as ugly as he says she is.”

Chapter I The Chalet: Three raps, circumspectly given, announced the duke, and his wife went herself to the door to let him in.

第一章 木屋: “啊！你好些了，我亲爱的。”他假装欢喜地叫道，凡是拍马屁的人都会这一套，而傻瓜见了就要上当了。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah! I see you are better, my dear,” he cried, with the counterfeit joy that courtiers assume so readily, and by which fools are so readily taken in.

第一章 木屋: “我亲爱的亨利，”她回答说，“你为什么还没有把梅尔基奥尔的任命弄好呢？——你已经在内阁里为国王效力了那么多，而你也知道，这内阁是只能呆一年的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My dear Henri,” she answered, “why is it you have not yet obtained that appointment for Melchior,—you who sacrificed so much to the king in taking a ministry which you knew could only last one year.”

第一章 木屋: 公爵瞥了一眼菲罗塞娜，她用一个别人几乎察觉不到的手势，示意梳妆台上有封勒阿弗尔的来信。
Chapter I The Chalet: The duke glanced at Philoxene, who showed him by an almost imperceptible sign the letter from Havre on the dressing-table.

第一章 木屋: “你到巴登去会烦死的，而且回来会跟梅尔基奥尔闹翻的。”公爵说。
Chapter I The Chalet: “You would be terribly bored at Baden and come back at daggers drawn with Melchior,” said the duke.

第一章 木屋: “请问为什么呀？”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Pray why?”

第一章 木屋: “哎呀，你们会总在一起的。”这位前任外交官高兴地说道，那副好脾气的样子让人看了好笑。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Why, you would always be together,” said the former diplomat, with comic good-humor.

第一章 木屋: “唉，不，”她说，“我就要让他结婚了。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh, no,” she said; “I am going to marry him.”

第一章 木屋: “如果德埃鲁维尔的话可信，那我们亲爱的卡那利在这方面就不需要你的帮助了。”公爵笑着说道，“昨天，葛朗利厄把马厩大总管给他写的信给我念了几页。毫无疑问，这些话是大总管的姑妈指使他针对你而写的，因为德埃鲁维尔小姐总是在为她的侄子谋嫁妆，她又知道葛朗利厄几乎每天晚上都要和我玩惠斯特牌。善良的小德埃鲁维尔想让德卡迪央亲王去诺曼底组织一次皇家围猎，而且让他尽量说服国王到场。这样，这位小姐看到如此盛大的活动是为她举办的，就会飘飘然起来。总之，查理十世说两句话，这件事就成了。德埃鲁维尔说这个女孩子漂亮得无人能比——”
Chapter I The Chalet: “If we can believe d’Herouville, our dear Canalis stands in no need of your help in that direction,” said the duke, smiling.“Yesterday Grandlieu read me some passages from a letter the grand equerry had written him.No doubt they were dictated by the aunt for the express purpose of their reaching you, for Mademoiselle d’Herouville, always on the scent of a ‘dot,’ knows that Grandlieu and I play whist nearly every evening.That good little d’Herouville wants the Prince de Cadignan to go down and give a royal hunt in Normandy, and endeavor to persuade the king to be present, so as to turn the head of the damozel when she sees herself the object of such a grand affair.In short, two words from Charles X. would settle the matter.D’Herouville says the girl has incomparable beauty—”

第一章 木屋: “那样更好了，”公爵回答说，“我敢保证摩弗里纽斯公爵夫人会帮你说服她从罗斯尼城堡过去的。如果她去的话，那国王就不会不高兴别人用他围猎的随从和装备了。别去勒阿弗尔了，亲爱的，”公爵慈父般地补充道，“那样你会露馅的。听我说，我觉得有个更好的计划。加斯帕尔的罗桑布赖城堡就在布罗托纳森林对面，为什么不暗示他邀请那帮人呢？”
