第一章 木屋: 致德卡那利男爵先生：
Chapter I The Chalet: To Monsieur le Baron de Canalis:—

第一章 木屋: 我亲爱的诗人——德拉巴斯蒂小姐十分漂亮；蒙日诺已经向我证实，她的父亲有几百万。我确实曾想过让您同她结婚，因此，您对我的不信任让我很不高兴。要是您在去勒阿弗尔的时候就打算让拉布里埃跟她结婚，那就奇怪了，您在走之前竟然什么都没跟我说过。还有，像我这么一个爱着急的朋友，您为什么会忘记给她写信呢？您的信晚来了一小会儿，我之前已经见过银行家了。您只是个孩子，梅尔基奥尔，而您还跟我们玩花样。这样不对。公爵自己也对您的行为十分恼火，他觉得您的行为有损绅士风度，这也有损您母亲的名誉。
Chapter I The Chalet: My dear poet,—Mademoiselle de La Bastie is very beautiful; Mongenod has proved to me that her father has millions.I did think of marrying you to her; I am therefore much displeased at your want of confidence.If you had any intention of marrying La Briere when you went to Havre it is surprising that you said nothing to me about it before you started.And why have you omitted writing to a friend who is so easily made anxious as I?Your letter arrived a trifle late; I had already seen the banker.You are a child, Melchior, and you are playing tricks with us.It is not right.The duke himself is quite indignant at your proceedings; he thinks you less than a gentleman, which casts some reflections on your mother’s honor.

第一章 木屋: 现在，我准备亲眼去看看到底是怎么回事。我相信，我会有幸陪夫人去参加由德埃鲁维尔公爵提议、为德拉巴斯蒂小姐举办的围猎。我会想办法让您被邀去罗桑布赖，因为聚会很可能会在德韦纳伊公爵的庄园里举行。
Chapter I The Chalet: Now, I intend to see things for myself.I shall, I believe, have the honor of accompanying Madame to the hunt which the Duc d’Herouville proposes to give for Mademoiselle de La Bastie.I will manage to have you invited to Rosembray, for the meet will probably take place in Duc de Verneuil’s park.

第一章 木屋: 请相信，我亲爱的诗人，我终身仍是，
Chapter I The Chalet: Pray believe, my dear poet, that I am none the less, for life,

第一章 木屋: 您的朋友，埃莱奥诺尔·德莫
Chapter I The Chalet: Your friend, Eleonore de M.

第一章 木屋: “得了，埃内斯特，你看看！”卡那利大叫道，将这封信扔过餐桌，让它飞到埃内斯特的鼻子下，“这是那个女人写给我的第两千封情书，可里面连个‘你’字都没有。大名鼎鼎的埃莱奥诺尔从来都没这样客气过。结婚吧，试试你的运气！世界上最坏的婚姻也比这种束缚要强。啊，我是从月亮上掉下来的最伟大的尼柯代默！莫黛斯特有几百万，可我已经失去了她，因为我们如今是在极地，不能在回到三天前的热带了！唔，我更迫切地希望你能战胜马厩大总管了，因为我告诉公爵夫人我来这里只是为了你，因此，我会尽力帮助你的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “There, Ernest, just look at that!” cried Canalis, tossing the letter at Ernest’s nose across the breakfast-table; “that’s the two thousandth love-letter I have had from that woman, and there isn’t even a ‘thou’ in it.The illustrious Eleonore has never compromised herself more than she does there.Marry, and try your luck!The worst marriage in the world is better than this sort of halter.Ah, I am the greatest Nicodemus that ever tumbled out of the moon!Modeste has millions, and I’ve lost her; for we can’t get back from the poles, where we are today, to the tropics, where we were three days ago!Well, I am all the more anxious for your triumph over the grand equerry, because I told the duchess I came here only for your sake; and so I shall do my best for you.”

第一章 木屋: “哎，梅尔基奥尔，莫黛斯特得有多么高贵、多么伟大、多么成熟的品格，才能抵挡住宫廷的荣誉、以及公爵为她精心安排的气派场面的诱惑啊，我不敢相信有那么完美的人——不过，如果她还是她信中的那个莫黛斯特的话，也许还有希望！”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Alas, Melchior, Modeste must needs have so noble, so grand, so well-balanced a nature to resist the glories of the Court, and all these splendors cleverly displayed for her honor and glory by the duke, that I cannot believe in the existence of such perfection,—and yet, if she is still the Modeste of her letters, there might be hope!”

第一章 木屋: “好了，好了，你这个年轻的卜尼法斯，你是个幸福的小伙子，能用你那青涩稚嫩的眼神看待这个世界和你的情人！”卡那利一边叫着，一边到花园里踱步去了。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Well, well, you are a happy fellow, you young Boniface, to see the world and your mistress through green spectacles!” cried Canalis, marching off to pace up and down the garden.

第一章 木屋: 两边撒的谎都被拆穿了，这位诗人不知所措了。
Chapter I The Chalet: Caught between two lies, the poet was at a loss what to do.

第一章 木屋: “按规矩出牌，你就输了！”没过多久，他坐在亭子里大叫道，“每个有理智的人都会像我四天前那样做的，发现自己陷入圈套了，就要逃出来。这种时候，人们是不会去解网结的，只会破网而出！好了，镇定、冷静，表现出高贵的、被冒犯的样子。荣誉要求我这样做；英国式的强硬态度才是赢回她的唯一办法。毕竟，就算我最终不得不退出，我也总能回到原来的幸福，十年的忠诚是不可能没有任何回报的。埃莱奥诺尔会给我安排一门好亲事的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Play by rule, and you lose!” he cried presently, sitting down in the kiosk.“Every man of sense would have acted as I did four days ago, and got himself out of the net in which I saw myself.At such times people don’t disentangle nets, they break through them!Come, let us be calm, cold, dignified, affronted.Honor requires it; English stiffness is the only way to win her back.After all, if I have to retire finally, I can always fall back on my old happiness; a fidelity of ten years can’t go unrewarded.Eleonore will arrange me some good marriage.”

第一章 木屋: 第二十六章 真正的爱情
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter XXVI True Love

第一章 木屋: 这次围猎注定不仅仅是一场猎犬的聚会，而是一次由中校的几百万财产和莫黛斯特的美貌所激起的感情大会战。而在等待围猎的过程中，情敌们也休战了。在为这场林中盛会做必要准备的这几天里，米尼翁公馆的客厅里呈现出了一幅和睦家庭的平静画面。卡那利不再扮演那个被莫黛斯特敏锐的洞察力所伤害的情人角色了，而是希望表现得彬彬有礼。他放下了自命不凡的姿态，也不再表现他的能言善辩，而是变成了所有聪明人放弃了装腔作势后的样子，十分有魅力。他同哥本海姆谈论金融，同中校谈论战争，同米尼翁夫人谈论德国，还同拉图奈尔夫人谈论家务——试图让他们所有人的偏爱都转移到拉布里埃身上。德埃鲁维尔公爵把地盘让给了他的两个情敌，因为他要去罗桑布赖和韦纳伊公爵商量，确保皇家猎队队长卡迪央亲王的命令得以执行。然而，整个事态的发展仍不乏喜剧元素。卡那利对马厩大总管的殷勤流露出鄙视态度，而两位德埃鲁维尔小姐每晚都在公馆度过，不停地夸夸其谈，莫黛斯特就被夹在了这两股火力之间。卡那利让莫黛斯特意识到，她不但不会在猎场上成为女主角，而且几乎不会被注意到。夫人将会在卡迪央亲王的儿媳德摩弗里纽斯公爵夫人、德肖利厄公爵夫人，以及其他宫廷贵妇的陪同下参加围猎，在这些人当中，莫黛斯特是不会引起任何轰动的；毫无疑问，驻扎在鲁昂的部队军官们也会被邀请，等等。而另一边，埃莱娜已经把她当作自己的弟媳妇了，她不停地告诉她的新朋友，会把她介绍给夫人；毫无疑问，德韦纳伊公爵会邀请她和她的父亲在罗桑布赖小住；如果中校想得到国王的恩赐——比如说，一个贵族头衔——这可是千载难逢的机会，因为国王有可能会在第三天出现；漂亮的宫廷贵妇德肖利厄公爵夫人、德莫弗里纽斯公爵夫人、德勒农库-肖利厄公爵夫人，以及其她女士都想见见她，她们的热情接待会让她十分高兴的。事实上，这场小小战事的发展、反复，以及各种计谋，的确非常有趣——这一切把迪迈一家、拉图奈尔一家、哥本海姆和比查给乐坏了，他们私下里聚在一起，说着有关这些贵族的坏话，对他们的一切卑鄙行为进行仔细研究和挖苦评论。
Chapter I The Chalet: The hunt was destined to be not only a meet of the hounds, but a meeting of all the passions excited by the colonel’s millions and Modeste’s beauty; and while it was in prospect there was truce between the adversaries.During the days required for the arrangement of this forestrial solemnity, the salon of the villa Mignon presented the tranquil picture of a united family.Canalis, cut short in his role of injured love by Modeste’s quick perceptions, wished to appear courteous; he laid aside his pretensions, gave no further specimens of his oratory, and became, what all men of intellect can be when they renounce affectation, perfectly charming.He talked finances with Gobenheim, and war with the colonel, Germany with Madame Mignon, and housekeeping with Madame Latournelle,—endeavoring to bias them all in favor of La Briere.The Duc d’Herouville left the field to his rivals, for he was obliged to go to Rosembray to consult with the Duc de Verneuil, and see that the orders of the Royal Huntsman, the Prince de Cadignan, were carried out.And yet the comic element was not altogether wanting.Modeste found herself between the depreciatory hints of Canalis as to the gallantry of the grand equerry, and the exaggerations of the two Mesdemoiselles d’Herouville, who passed every evening at the villa.Canalis made Modeste take notice that, instead of being the heroine of the hunt, she would be scarcely noticed.Madame would be attended by the Duchesse de Maufrigneuse, daughter-inlaw of the Prince de Cadignan, by the Duchesse de Chaulieu, and other great ladies of the Court, among whom she could produce no sensation; no doubt the officers in garrison at Rouen would be invited, etc.Helene, on the other hand, was incessantly telling her new friend, whom she already looked upon as a sister-inlaw, that she was to be presented to Madame; undoubtedly the Duc de Verneuil would invite her father and herself to stay at Rosembray; if the colonel wished to obtain a favor of the king,—a peerage, for instance,—the opportunity was unique, for there was hope of the king himself being present on the third day; she would be delighted with the charming welcome with which the beauties of the Court, the Duchesses de Chaulieu, de Maufrigneuse, de Lenoncourt-Chaulieu, and other ladies, were prepared to meet her.It was in fact an excessively amusing little warfare, with its marches and countermarches and stratagems,—all of which were keenly enjoyed by the Dumays, the Latournelles, Gobenheim, and Butscha, who, in conclave assembled, said horrible things of these noble personages, cruelly noting and intelligently studying all their little meannesses.

第一章 木屋: 不过，德埃鲁维尔一方所作的承诺由一份充满溢美之辞的请帖的到来得到了证实。请帖是德韦纳伊公爵和猎队队长给德拉巴斯蒂伯爵先生和他的女儿发来的，邀请他们去罗桑布赖小住，并于十一月十七、十八、十九和二十号这几天参加一场大型狩猎活动。
Chapter I The Chalet: The promises on the d’Herouville side were, however, confirmed by the arrival of an invitation, couched in flattering terms, from the Duc de Verneuil and the Master of the Hunt to Monsieur le Comte de La Bastie and his daughter, to stay at Rosembray and be present at a grand hunt on the seventh, eighth, ninth, and tenth, of November following.

第一章 木屋: 拉布里埃心里充满了不祥的预感，热切渴望着和莫黛斯特呆在一起。这种辛酸的快乐，只有那些感到要与所爱之人分离、而且是命中注定要分离的情人，才能了解。快乐的火花，混杂着对“我失去了她”这个主题的忧思，让那些观察他的人更觉得有趣了，因为他的脸、他的整个人，都沉浸在那深沉的情感中。一首活生生的哀歌，被一双眼睛赋予了生命，它在人群中自由漫步，发出无韵的叹息，再没有什么比这更有诗意了。
Chapter I The Chalet: La Briere, full of dark presentiments, craved the presence of Modeste with an eagerness whose bitter joys are known only to lovers who feel that they are parted, and parted fatally from those they love.Flashes of joy came to him intermingled with melancholy meditations on the one theme, “I have lost her,” and made him all the more interesting to those who watched him, because his face and his whole person were in keeping with his profound feeling.There is nothing more poetic than a living elegy, animated by a pair of eyes, walking about, and sighing without rhymes.

第一章 木屋: 终于，德埃鲁维尔公爵来安排莫黛斯特起程了。过了塞纳河之后，她要坐上公爵的四轮马车，由两位德埃鲁维尔小姐陪同前往。公爵十分客气，他也邀请卡那利和拉布里埃参加聚会，同时，正如向中校保证过的那样，他也向他们保证，已经特别关照过为他们准备狩猎用马。中校邀请这三位追求者在出发的那天早晨共进早餐。于是，卡那利便开始实施他过去几天在脑子里思考成熟的一项计划，也就是悄悄地夺回莫黛斯特，背弃公爵夫人、拉布里埃和公爵。一个外交毕业生，眼看自己形势不利，是不会坐以待毙的。另一方面，拉布里埃已经下定决心跟莫黛斯特永别了。因此，每个追求者都像被告在审判宣布之前作最后陈词一样，等着说出最后一句话，因为他们都感觉到三个星期来的争斗已经接近尾声了。出发的前一天晚上，晚饭过后，中校挽住他女儿的手臂，让她感觉到有必要作出决定了。
Chapter I The Chalet: The Duc d’Herouville arrived at last to arrange for Modeste’s departure; after crossing the Seine she was to be conveyed in the duke’s caleche, accompanied by the Demoiselles d’Herouville.The duke was charmingly courteous, he begged Canalis and La Briere to be of the party, assuring them, as he did the colonel, that he had taken particular care that hunters should be provided for them.The colonel invited the three lovers to breakfast on the morning of the start.Canalis then began to put into execution a plan that he had been maturing in his own mind for the last few days; namely, to quietly reconquer Modeste, and throw over the duchess, La Briere, and the duke.A graduate of diplomacy could hardly remain stuck in the position in which he found himself.On the other hand La Briere had come to the resolution of bidding Modeste an eternal farewell.Each suitor was therefore on the watch to slip in a last word, like the defendant’s counsel to the court before judgment is pronounced; for all felt that the three weeks’ struggle was approaching its conclusion.After dinner on the evening before the start was to be made, the colonel had taken his daughter by the arm and made her feel the necessity of deciding.

Chapter I The Chalet: “Forgive me—I thought you despised me.”

第一章 木屋: 然后，她又离他而去了。但这一次，尽管她说的话很无情，拉布里埃还是感觉像是在云中漫步，脚下的大地变软了，树木开满了鲜花，天空是玫瑰色的，空气是蔚蓝色的，就像置身结局圆满的那些精灵童话剧中的婚姻神殿。在这种情况下，每个女人都是一位两面神杰纳斯，不用转过身去就可以看到身后的事情。因此，莫黛斯特在她情人的脸上看到了像比查那样的不容置疑的爱情症候——这在一个女子的希望中当然是“ne plus ultra”的事情。另外，拉布里埃把她的评价看得极重，这让莫黛斯特内心充满了无限的甜蜜。
Chapter I The Chalet: And she left him again.But this time, in spite of her harshness, La Briere thought he walked on air; the earth softened under his feet, the trees bore flowers; the skies were rosy, the air cerulean, as they are in the temples of Hymen in those fairy pantomimes which finish happily.In such situations every woman is a Janus, and sees behind her without turning round; and thus Modeste perceived on the face of her lover the indubitable symptoms of a love like Butscha’s,—surely the “ne plus ultra” of a woman’s hope.Moreover, the great value which La Briere attached to her opinion filled Modeste with an emotion that was inestimably sweet.

第一章 木屋: “小姐，”卡那利离开中校，拦住莫黛斯特说道，“尽管您对我的感情不屑一顾，但我要将一个我已经忍受很久的污点抹去，为我的荣誉正名。这是我到勒阿弗尔五天后，德肖利厄公爵夫人给我写的一封信。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Mademoiselle,” said Canalis, leaving the colonel and waylaying Modeste, “in spite of the little value you attach to my sentiments, my honor is concerned in effacing a stain under which I have suffered too long.Here is a letter which I received from the Duchesse de Chaulieu five days after my arrival in Havre.”

第一章 木屋: 他让莫黛斯特看了我们已经看过的那封信的头几行，公爵夫人在信的开头说她已经见过了蒙日诺，并希望让她的诗人同莫黛斯特结婚。然后，他把那一段话撕了下来，把纸片放到了她的手里。
Chapter I The Chalet: He let Modeste read the first lines of the letter we have seen, which the duchess began by saying that she had seen Mongenod, and now wished to marry her poet to Modeste; then he tore that passage from the body of the letter, and placed the fragment in her hand.

第一章 木屋: “其余的部分我不能让您看，”他一边说着，一边将信纸放到口袋里，“但我把这几行交给您自行处理，以便您核实笔迹。一个可以指责我情感卑鄙的少女，也完全有可能怀疑这是某种串通，某种诡计。啊，莫黛斯特，”他带着哭腔说道，“您的诗人，德肖利厄夫人的诗人，他内心的诗意并不比他思想中的少。您就要见到公爵夫人了，请到那时再对我作出判断吧。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “I cannot let you read the rest,” he said, putting the paper in his pocket; “but I confide these few lines to your discretion, so that you may verify the writing.A young girl who could accuse me of ignoble sentiments is quite capable of suspecting some collusion, some trickery.Ah, Modeste,” he said, with tears in his voice, “your poet, the poet of Madame de Chaulieu, has no less poetry in his heart than in his mind.You are about to see the duchess; suspend your judgment of me till then.”

第一章 木屋: 他丢下有些迷惑不解的莫黛斯特，走了。
Chapter I The Chalet: He left Modeste half bewildered.

Chapter I The Chalet: “Oh, dear!” she said to herself; “it seems they are all angels—and not marriageable; the duke is the only one that belongs to humanity.”

第一章 木屋: “可怜的亲爱的比查！”莫黛斯特叫道，她被这种母性般的关怀感动得流泪了。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Poor, dear Butscha!” cried Modeste, moved to tears by this maternal care.

Chapter I The Chalet: Butscha went skipping off like a man who has just heard of the death of a rich uncle.

第一章 木屋: “我亲爱的爸爸，”莫黛斯特回到客厅里说道，“我想要那只漂亮的马鞭——您看能不能请求拉布里埃先生用您那幅凡奥斯塔德的油画来交换。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “My dear father,” said Modeste, returning to the salon; “I should like to have that beautiful whip,—suppose you were to ask Monsieur de La Briere to exchange it for your picture by Van Ostade.”

第一章 木屋: 这幅画是中校从雷根斯堡一位市民那里买来的，是他征战生涯的唯一纪念品。他站在画前，向埃内斯特提出这个建议，而莫黛斯特一直暗暗地注视着埃内斯特。他匆忙离开房间时，她对自己说道：“他会参加狩猎的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste looked furtively at Ernest, while the colonel made him this proposition, standing before the picture which was the sole thing he possessed in memory of his campaigns, having bought it of a burgher at Rabiston; and she said to herself as La Briere left the room precipitately, “He will be at the hunt.”

第一章 木屋: 真是一件稀奇的事。莫黛斯特的三位情人都去了罗桑布赖，每个人心中都充满了希望，并为她的许多完美之处心醉神迷。
Chapter I The Chalet: A curious thing happened.Modeste’s three lovers each and all went to Rosembray with their hearts full of hope, and captivated by her many perfections.

第一章 木屋: 议会投票决定拨十亿法郎，用以补偿流亡贵族地产的出售。德韦纳伊公爵最近用他得到的这一份钱买下了罗桑布赖这份地产，它的城堡远近闻名，壮丽程度只有麦斯尼埃或巴勒鲁瓦的城堡才能与之媲美。经过一条植有四排古老榆树的宽阔林荫道，就到了这座气势宏伟、高贵壮丽的建筑，接着，来访者们便进入了一个与凡尔赛宫庭院相似的上坡大庭院，华贵的铁栅栏，两栋门房小屋，装点着几排种在大盆中的大橘树。城堡面向庭院，主建筑的两边各有一座凹进去的入口。城堡的凸出部分有两排大窗户，每排十九扇，装饰着雕花拱顶和镶钻窗格，窗与窗之间由一根根凹槽壁柱分开，柱顶上带有楣构，意大利式的屋顶隐于其中。屋顶上竖立着几根石烟囱，上面雕饰着武器图案。罗桑布赖是路易十四时代一位叫作科坦的农庄主建造的。面向花园的一面与面向庭院的一面不同，中间的凸起部分较窄，五扇窗户中间间隔着壁柱，窗户上竖立着一面壮丽的山墙。农庄主科坦的唯一女嗣科坦小姐结婚后，这座庄园便归马里尼家族所有了。马里尼家族又让夸瑟沃在山墙上雕刻了一幅日出图。下面是两个天使，正在展开一幅卷轴，卷轴上刻着歌颂伟大君王的铭言，“Sol nobis benignus.”
Chapter I The Chalet: Rosembray,—an estate lately purchased by the Duc de Verneuil, with the money which fell to him as his share of the thousand millions voted as indemnity for the sale of the lands of the emigres,—is remarkable for its chateau, whose magnificence compares only with that of Mesniere or of Balleroy.This imposing and noble edifice is approached by a wide avenue of four rows of venerable elms, from which the visitor enters an immense rising court-yard, like that at Versailles, with magnificent iron railings and two lodges, and adorned with rows of large orange-trees in their tubs.Facing this court-yard, the chateau presents, between two fronts of the main building which retreat on either side of this projection, a double row of nineteen tall windows, with carved arches and diamond panes, divided from each other by a series of fluted pilasters surmounted by an entablature which hides an Italian roof, from which rise several stone chimneys masked by carved trophies of arms.Rosembray was built, under Louis XIV., by a “fermier-general” named Cottin.The facade toward the park differs from that on the court-yard by having a narrower projection in the centre, with columns between five windows, above which rises a magnificent pediment.The family of Marigny, to whom the estates of this Cottin were brought in marriage by Mademoiselle Cottin, her father’s sole heiress, ordered a sunrise to be carved on this pediment by Coysevox.Beneath it are two angels unwinding a scroll, on which is cut this motto in honor of the Grand Monarch, “Sol nobis benignus.”

第一章 木屋: 沿着大回旋梯和扶手梯，就到了平台上，从上面可以看到一座巨大的鱼塘，其长度和宽度可以与凡尔赛的大运河相媲美。池塘的源头是一片草地，足以比得上最好的英国草坪。池塘边摆满了花坛和花篮，此时正开满秋季的各种鲜艳花朵。水塘两侧各有一座法式花园，铺展着方方正正的花坛和长长的笔直小径，就像是用勒诺特尔密码写出的美妙篇章。整座花园的后沿与大约三十英亩的林地接壤。站在平台上，视野尽头是一片属于罗桑布赖的森林，毗邻的两片森林一片属于王室，另一片属于国家。恐怕很难再找到一片比这更为壮观的景色了。
Chapter I The Chalet: From the portico, reached by two grand circular and balustraded flights of steps, the view extends over an immense fish-pond, as long and wide as the grand canal at Versailles, beginning at the foot of a grass-plot which compares well with the finest English lawns, and bordered with beds and baskets now filled with the brilliant flowers of autumn.On either side of the piece of water two gardens, laid out in the French style, display their squares and long straight paths, like brilliant pages written in the ciphers of Lenotre.These gardens are backed to their whole length by a border of nearly thirty acres of woodland.From the terrace the view is bounded by a forest belonging to Rosembray and contiguous to two other forests, one of which belongs to the Crown, the other to the State.It would be difficult to find a nobler landscape.

第一章 木屋: 第二十七章 少女的复仇
Chapter I The Chalet: Chapter XXVII A Girl’s Revenge

第一章 木屋: 莫黛斯特的到来在林阴道上引起了一定的轰动。只见一辆有法国国王侍从跟随的马车，由马厩大总管、中校、卡那利和拉布里埃骑马陪同，在身穿礼服的骑马侍从的引导下，出现在了人们的视线中，后面跟着六个仆人——其中有黑人和黑白混血儿——还有中校的敞篷四轮马车，载着两名贴身女仆和行李。马车是由四匹马拉的，还依照马厩大总管的特别命令，换上了穿着十分雅致的左马驭者。人们服侍大总管常常要比服侍国王更周到。至于莫黛斯特，她进去后看着这座小型的凡尔赛宫，那些大贵族的华丽服饰让她眼花缭乱。她突然想起马上要跟那些大名鼎鼎的公爵夫人们见面，便开始担心会表现得笨拙、土气，或者像个女暴发户。事实上，她已经无法镇定下来，并对要求这次狩猎后悔不已。
Chapter I The Chalet: Modeste’s arrival at Rosembray made a certain sensation in the avenue when the carriage with the liveries of France came in sight, accompanied by the grand equerry, the colonel, Canalis, and La Briere on horseback, preceded by an outrider in full dress, and followed by six servants,—among whom were the Negroes and the mulatto,—and the britzka of the colonel for the two waiting-women and the luggage.The carriage was drawn by four horses, ridden by postilions dressed with an elegance specially commanded by the grand equerry, who was often better served than the king himself.As Modeste, dazzled by the magnificence of the great lords, entered and beheld this lesser Versailles, she suddenly remembered her approaching interview with the celebrated duchesses, and began to fear that she might seem awkward, or provincial, or parvenue; in fact, she lost her self-possession, and heartily repented having wished for a hunt.

第一章 木屋: 不过，幸好在马车停下的时候，莫黛斯特看到的是一位戴着卷成小卷的金黄色假发的老人。他那安详、丰满、平滑的脸上带着慈父般的微笑和修道士般的快活，半遮半掩的目光显得近乎高贵。这便是罗桑布赖的主人德韦纳伊公爵。公爵夫人是一位极其虔诚的女人，她是一位富有的、已故法院院长的独生女。她身材消瘦、腰板笔直，是四个孩子的母亲，与拉图奈尔夫人颇有几分相似——如果我们能在想象之中将公证人妻子用真正的修道院长般的风度气质修饰一下。
Chapter I The Chalet: Fortunately, however, as the carriage drew up, Modeste saw an old man, in a blond wig frizzed into little curls, whose calm, plump, smooth face wore a fatherly smile and an expression of monastic cheerfulness which the half-veiled glance of the eye rendered almost noble.This was the Duc de Verneuil, master of Rosembray.The duchess, a woman of extreme piety, the only daughter of a rich and deceased chief-justice, spare and erect, and the mother of four children, resembled Madame Latournelle,—if the imagination can go so far as to adorn the notary’s wife with the graces of a bearing that was truly abbatial.

第一章 木屋: “啊，上午好，亲爱的奥尔唐斯！”两个因生性高傲而颇有共鸣的女人一见面，德埃鲁维尔小姐便热情地亲吻了公爵夫人，说道，“让我来向您和亲爱的公爵介绍我们的小天使，德拉巴斯蒂小姐。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “Ah, good morning, dear Hortense!” said Mademoiselle d’Herouville, kissing the duchess with the sympathy that united their haughty natures; “let me present to you and to the dear duke our little angel, Mademoiselle de La Bastie.”

第一章 木屋: “久仰大名，小姐，”公爵夫人说道，“我们都迫不及待地要接待您了。”
Chapter I The Chalet: “We have heard so much of you, mademoiselle,” said the duchess, “that we were in haste to receive you.”

第一章 木屋: “今天才认识您，真是遗憾。”德韦纳伊公爵彬彬有礼地赞美道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “And regret the time lost,” added the Duc de Verneuil, with courteous admiration.

第一章 木屋: “这是德拉巴斯蒂伯爵先生。”马厩大总管拉着中校的手臂，将他介绍给公爵和公爵夫人，语气和动作里都带着尊敬的意味。
Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur le Comte de La Bastie,” said the grand equerry, taking the colonel by the arm and presenting him to the duke and duchess, with an air of respect in his tone and gesture.

第一章 木屋: “欢迎您，伯爵先生！”德韦纳伊先生说，“您可拥有不少珍宝啊。”他看着莫黛斯特，补充道。
Chapter I The Chalet: “I am glad to welcome you, Monsieur le comte!” said Monsieur de Verneuil.“You possess more than one treasure,” he added, looking at Modeste.

第一章 木屋: 公爵夫人挽着莫黛斯特的胳膊，带她走进了一间大客厅，十几个女人正聚在壁炉前。聚会的所有男客都跟公爵呆在平台上，只有卡那利除外，他毕恭毕敬地走到风姿绰约的埃莱奥诺尔身边。德肖利厄公爵夫人坐在绣花绷旁，正在教德韦纳伊小姐怎么给花绣上颜色。
Chapter I The Chalet: The duchess took Modeste under her arm and led her into an immense salon, where a dozen or more women were grouped about the fireplace.The men of the party remained with the duke on the terrace, except Canalis, who respectfully made his way to the superb Eleonore.The Duchesse de Chaulieu, seated at an embroidery-frame, was showing Mademoiselle de Verneuil how to shade a flower.

第一章 木屋: 德肖利厄夫人看了莫黛斯特一眼，那目光冰冷、高傲、轻蔑，莫黛斯特就是在弄针插时被针刺穿手指，也不会感觉到比这更尖锐的刺痛。一时间，她眼里只看见了那个女人，而且看穿了她。这些迷人的女人们，我们出于激情，将她们奉若神明，可要想知道她们有多残忍，就必须要看她们彼此的相处了。莫黛斯特脸上情不自禁流露出的那种傻乎乎的崇拜之情，可以消除除埃莱奥诺尔之外任何人对她的戒备。要不是她知道公爵夫人的年龄，她会以为她只有三十六呢。不过，还有其他更让她惊讶的事情等着她呢。
Chapter I The Chalet: If Modeste had run a needle through her finger when handling a pin-cushion she could not have felt a sharper prick than she received from the cold and haughty and contemptuous stare with which Madame de Chaulieu favored her.For an instant she saw nothing but that one woman, and she saw through her.To understand the depths of cruelty to which these charming creatures, whom our passions deify, can go, we must see women with each other.Modeste would have disarmed almost any other than Eleonore by the perfectly stupid and involuntary admiration which her face betrayed.Had she not known the duchess’s age she would have thought her a woman of thirty-six; but other and greater astonishments awaited her.

第一章 木屋: 诗人是撞上了一位贵妇人的怒火了。这种怒火就像最凶恶的狮身人面像，脸上是喜气洋洋的，其余部分都是凶神恶煞的。一位情妇表面彬彬有礼、实则冷若冰霜的怒火，在钢铁盔甲的保护下，就连国王本人也奈何不得。卡那利竭力想抓住这钢铁盔甲，但他的手指却在那光滑的表面上打了滑，就像他的话在公爵夫人心上打了滑一样。而公爵夫人优雅的面容、优雅的话语、优雅的风度，隐藏着她盛怒的钢铁，尽管温度已经降到了零下二十五度，所有的观察者却都发现不了。莫黛斯特美得让人叹为观止，穿得跟迪亚娜·德摩弗里纽斯一样漂亮，她的外表已经将埃莱奥诺尔思考时所积累的一连串火药点燃了。

第一章 木屋: 他不得不站起来，一边是绣花绷，靠近窗户，而另一边是壁炉，莫黛斯特和德韦纳伊公爵夫人坐在沙发上。他站在绣花绷和壁炉中间，一动不动。这个野心勃勃的家伙瞥了埃莱奥诺尔一眼，痛苦的念头顿时涌上心头。要是听从了莫黛斯特的使唤，他跟他的保护人之间的一切就结束了，而且是永远结束。要是不听她的使唤，就等于公开声明他的仆人身份，也就要错过他二十五天来那些卑鄙勾当所换来的时机，而且有违最简单的礼节和客套。事情越是愚蠢，公爵夫人越是急切地催促着他去干。莫黛斯特的美貌和财富同埃莱奥诺尔的权势和影响力相互抗争，使得卡那利在人性和荣誉之间犹豫不决，这就跟斗牛士在竞技场上面临的危险一样可怕。卡那利心跳不止，简直要得动脉瘤了。一个人也许只有在赌桌前，眼看就要决定自己是发财还是破产时，才会有这种感觉。
Chapter I The Chalet: Forced to rise, he remained standing half-way between the embroidery frame, which was near a window, and the fireplace where Modeste was seated with the Duchesse de Verneuil on a sofa.What bitter reflections came into his ambitious mind, as he caught a glance from Eleonore.If he obeyed Modeste all was over, and forever, between himself and his protectress.Not to obey her was to avow his slavery, to lose the chances of his twenty-five days of base manoeuvring, and to disregard the plainest laws of decency and civility.The greater the folly, the more imperatively the duchess exacted it.Modeste’s beauty and money thus pitted against Eleonore’s rights and influence made this hesitation between the man and his honor as terrible to witness as the peril of a matador in the arena.A man seldom feels such palpitations as those which now came near causing Canalis an aneurism, except, perhaps, before the green table, where his fortune or his ruin is about to be decided.

第一章 木屋: 说完这句话，公爵夫人便优雅地迈开她那鹿脚般纤细矫健的小脚，站了起来，朝迪亚娜·德摩弗里纽斯的周围的人群走去。公爵夫人身材中等，像所有年过五十却仍然美丽动人的女人一样，身材有点发胖。在她丰满的体态下，可以看出极度的灵巧。这类女人的灵巧，正是由于她们神经系统的活力控制着肌肉的运动，并赋予其生命力。没有其他原因能解释她那轻盈的步伐和举手投足间无与伦比的高贵。只有祖上从挪亚时代起便是贵族的妇女，才能像埃莱奥诺尔这样，尽管日渐发胖，却还是知道怎样摆出庄重威严的样子。她着一身晨装，雍容典雅有如王后，怡然自得有如少女，一位哲学家在称赞她上身的优美曲线和细心打扮的同时，恐怕要可怜菲罗塞娜了。她一头浓密的、没有染色的秀发，简简单单编成辫子盘在了头上。她骄傲地露出雪白的脖颈、线条精致的双肩，以及久负盛名的双手和手臂，这份骄傲倒也情有可原。莫黛斯特同公爵夫人的其他所有对手一样，都不得不承认她是那种“让我们黯然失色”的女人。事实上，埃莱奥诺尔是如今已寥寥无几的贵妇人之一。她头部的仪态多么威严有气势，她颈部的曲线多么精致优美，她的动作多么协调，举止多么高贵，每一个细节与整体之间配合得多么完美，呈现出多么惊人的艺术美——艺术就像她的第二天性，让她变得崇高，甚至神圣——要试图解释这一切，就好比要分析那些至高无上的东西一样困难。人们像享受帕格尼尼的诗意一样，享受着她的诗意。他们不去自问要通过什么来享受，他们知道原因存在于不可见的心灵之中。
Chapter I The Chalet: So saying, the duchess, a woman of medium height, but a little too stout, like all women over fifty who retain their beauty, rose and walked toward the group which surrounded Diane de Maufrigneuse, stepping daintily on little feet that were as slender and nervous as a deer’s.Beneath her plumpness could be seen the exquisite delicacy of such women, which comes from the vigor of their nervous systems controlling and vitalizing the development of flesh.There is no other way to explain the lightness of her step, and the incomparable nobility of her bearing.None but the women whose quarterings begin with Noah know, as Eleonore did, how to be majestic in spite of a buxom tendency.A philosopher might have pitied Philoxene, while admiring the graceful lines of the bust and the minute care bestowed upon a morning dress, which was worn with the elegance of a queen and the easy grace of a young girl.Her abundant hair, still undyed, was simply wound about her head in plaits; she bared her snowy throat and shoulders, exquisitely modelled, and her celebrated hand and arm, with pardonable pride.Modeste, together with all other antagonists of the duchess, recognized in her a woman of whom they were forced to say, “She eclipses us.”In fact, Eleonore was one of the “grandes dames” now so rare.To endeavor to explain what august quality there was in the carriage of the head, what refinement and delicacy in the curve of the throat, what harmony in her movements, and nobility in her bearing, what grandeur in the perfect accord of details with the whole being, and in the arts, now a second nature, which render a woman grand and even sacred,—to explain all these things would simply be to attempt to analyze the sublime.People enjoy such poetry as they enjoy that of Paganini; they do not explain to themselves the medium, they know the cause is in the spirit that remains invisible.

第一章 木屋: 德肖利厄夫人低头向埃莱娜和她的姑姑施礼，然后，她用平静的语气对迪亚娜说道：“公爵夫人，更衣的时间到了吧？”说完便在她的儿媳和德埃鲁维尔小姐的陪同下走了出去。走出客厅时，她低声跟老姑娘说这话。老姑娘压了压她的胳膊，说：“你真是个可人儿，”——其实意思是，“我万分感谢你刚才给我们帮的忙。”之后，德埃鲁维尔小姐便回到客厅去扮演她的间谍角色了。她的第一个眼神就告诉卡那利，公爵夫人刚刚可不是做样子吓唬人的。这位初出茅庐的外交官明白了，他的伎俩还不足以进行这样的斗争，而他的才智让他选择了一种即使不是更加光彩、至少也是更加老实的姿态。埃内斯特带着莫黛斯特的手帕回来时，诗人抓住他的手臂，把他带到了平台上。

he thus develops the germs of his faculty which lie dormant within him.In like manner Modeste had the instinct to appropriate the distinctive qualities of Madame de Maufrigneuse and Madame de Chaulieu.For her, the sight of these women was an education; whereas a bourgeois would merely have ridiculed their ways or made them absurd by clumsy imitation.A well-born, well-educated, and right-minded young woman like Modeste fell naturally into connection with these people, and saw at once the differences that separate the aristocratic world from the bourgeois world, the provinces from the faubourg Saint-Germain; she caught the almost imperceptible shadings; in short, she perceived the grace of the “grande dame” without doubting that she could herself acquire it.She noticed also that her father and La Briere appeared infinitely better in this Olympus than Canalis.The great poet, abdicating his real and incontestable power, that of the mind, became nothing more than a courtier seeking a ministry, intriguing for an order, and forced to please the whole galaxy.Ernest de La Briere, without ambitions, was able to be himself; while Melchior became, to use a vulgar expression, a mere toady, and courted the Prince de Loudon, the Duc de Rhetore, the Vicomte de Serizy, or the Duc de Maufrigneuse, like a man not free to assert himself, as did Colonel Mignon, who was justly proud of his campaigns, and of the confidence of the Emperor Napoleon.Modeste took note of the strained efforts of the man of real talent, seeking some witticism that should raise a laugh, some clever speech, some compliment with which to flatter these grand personages, whom it was his interest to please.In a word, to Modeste’s eyes the peacock plucked out his tail-feathers.

Chapter I The Chalet: “Monsieur le duc, if you really knew me,” she said, “you would understand how deeply I am touched by your attentions.It is because of the profound respect I feel for your character, and the friendship which a soul like yours inspires in mine, that I cannot endure to wound your self-love.Before your arrival in Havre I loved sincerely, deeply, and forever, one who is worthy of being loved, and my affection for whom is still a secret; but I wish you to know—and in saying this I am more sincere than most young girls—that had I not already formed this voluntary attachment, you would have been my choice, for I recognize your noble and beautiful qualities.A few words which your aunt and sister have said to me as to your intentions lead me to make this frank avowal.If you think it desirable, a letter from my mother shall recall me, on pretence of her illness, tomorrow morning before the hunt begins.Without your consent I do not choose to be present at a fete which I owe to your kindness, and where, if my secret should escape me, you might feel hurt and defrauded.You will ask me why I have come here at all.I could not withstand the invitation.Be generous enough not to reproach me for what was almost a necessary curiosity.But this is not the chief, not the most delicate thing I have to say to you.You have firm friends in my father and myself,—more so than perhaps you realize; and as my fortune was the first cause that brought you to me, I wish to say—but without intending to use it as a sedative to calm the grief which gallantry requires you to testify—that my father has thought over the affair of the marshes, his friend Dumay thinks your project feasible, and they have already taken steps to form a company.Gobenheim, Dumay, and my father have subscribed fifteen hundred thousand francs, and undertake to get the rest from capitalists, who will feel it in their interest to take up the matter.If I have not the honor of becoming the Duchesse d’Herouville, I have almost the certainty of enabling you to choose her, free from all trammels in your choice, and in a higher sphere than mine.Oh! let me finish,” she cried, at a gesture from the duke.

第一章 木屋: 就在这时，这些意志坚定的猎手们——德卢东亲王和德雷托雷公爵是宁录的后人，是圣日耳曼近郊最好的射手——被一阵嘈杂的争吵声吸引住了，他们策马赶到罗桑布赖森林入口处的一块空地上，那里因覆满苔藓的草皮而出名，是集会的指定地点。争吵的原因很快就明了了。德卢东亲王十分崇拜英国习俗，便组建了一只自己的完全英式的猎队，由猎队队长调遣。此时，他的一个队员，一个小个子的英国人——金发白肤、傲慢无礼、十分冷漠，几乎说不了几句法语，穿着干净整洁，这是所有的英国人，甚至是下等阶层的特点——已经站在这块空地的一边。约翰·巴里穿着一件短双排扣常礼服，扣子紧紧地扣在腰部，布料鲜红，扣子上刻着德韦纳伊家徽，还穿着一条白色皮马裤，一双长筒靴，一件带条纹的马甲，戴着黑丝绒领子和披肩。他手里拿着一条小猎鞭，手腕上用丝绳系着一把铜号。这个人是首席猎犬管理员，身后跟着两条纯种猎狗——是猎狐狗，白毛上缀着红褐色斑点，腿很长，鼻子灵敏，头部细长，头顶上长着两只小耳朵。这位猎犬管理员——在英格兰郡颇有名气，德卢东亲王花大价钱才把他弄到手——管理着十五匹马和六十只英国猎犬，这要花费德韦纳伊公爵很大一笔开销。德韦纳伊公爵并不擅长狩猎，却纵容他的儿子沉醉于这一王族不可或缺的嗜好。
Chapter I The Chalet: At this moment the attention of these determined huntsmen—for the Prince de Loudon and the Duc de Rhetore are of the race of Nimrod, and the best shots of the faubourg Saint-Germain—was attracted by a loud altercation; and they spurred their horses to an open space at the entrance to the forest of Rosembray, famous for its mossy turf, which was appointed for the meet.The cause of the quarrel was soon apparent.The Prince de Loudon, afflicted with anglomania, had brought out his own hunting establishment, which was exclusively Britannic, and placed it under orders of the Master of the Hunt.Now, one of his men, a little Englishman,—fair, pale, insolent, and phlegmatic, scarcely able to speak a word of French, and dressed with a neatness which distinguishes all Britons, even those of the lower classes,—had posted himself on one side of this open space.John Barry wore a short frock-coat, buttoned tightly at the waist, made of scarlet cloth, with buttons bearing the De Verneuil arms, white leather breeches, top-boots, a striped waistcoat, and a collar and cape of black velvet.He held in his hand a small hunting-whip, and hanging to his wrist by a silken cord was a brass horn.This man, the first whipper-in, was accompanied by two thorough-bred dogs,—fox-hounds, white, with liver spots, long in the leg, fine in the muzzle, with slender heads, and little ears at their crests.The huntsman—famous in the English county from which the Prince de Loudon had obtained him at great cost—was in charge of an establishment of fifteen horses and sixty English hounds, which cost the Duc de Verneuil, who was nothing of a huntsman, but chose to indulge his son in this essentially royal taste, an enormous sum of money to keep up.

Chapter I The Chalet: Now, when John arrived on the ground, he found himself forestalled by three other whippers-in, in charge of two of the royal packs of hounds which had been brought there in carts.They were the three best huntsmen of the Prince de Cadignan, and presented, both in character and in their distinctively French costume, a marked contrast to the representative of insolent Albion.These favorites of the Prince, each wearing full-brimmed, three-cornered hats, very flat and very wide-spreading, beneath which grinned their swarthy, tanned, and wrinkled faces, lighted by three pairs of twinkling eyes, were noticeably lean, sinewy, and vigorous, like men in whom sport had become a passion.All three were supplied with immense horns of Dampierre, wound with green worsted cords, leaving only the brass tubes visible; but they controlled their dogs by the eye and voice.Those noble animals were far more faithful and submissive subjects than the human lieges whom the king was at that moment addressing; all were marked with white, black, or liver spots, each having as distinctive a countenance as the soldiers of Napoleon, their eyes flashing like diamonds at the slightest noise.One of them, brought from Poitou, was short in the back, deep in the shoulder, low-jointed, and lop-eared; the other, from England, white, fine as a greyhound with no belly, small ears, and built for running.Both were young, impatient, and yelping eagerly, while the old hounds, on the contrary, covered with scars, lay quietly with their heads on their forepaws, and their ears to the earth like savages.

第一章 木屋: 无论狗还是人，在猎队队长面前都变得安静有礼，好像都意识到了他至高的尊贵。亲王布置了一天的工作，因为一次狩猎就像是一次战役，而查理十世的猎队队长就是森林里的拿破仑。多亏他为法国狩猎界引入了良好的体制，他才能专门思考狩猎的技巧和战略。现在，他从容地给德卢东亲王的团队安排了一项特殊任务。他料到王室猎犬会把鹿赶到位于城堡正前方的皇家森林里，而他们的任务就是在那之后把鹿赶到水边。亲王把最艰辛的活儿交给了他的老猎手们，然后又利用了英国人巴里用以在猎队立足的特长，给他机会去展示他的马和猎犬在野外的速度，这样，就很好地照顾到了两边人的自尊心。这样，两国的两种狩猎体系便可以并行不悖地发挥出最佳水平。
Chapter I The Chalet: Dogs and men became silent and respectful before the Royal Huntsman, as though each recognized his dignity as supreme.The prince laid out the day’s work; for it is with a hunt as it is with a battle, and the Master of Charles X.‘s hounds was the Napoleon of forests.Thanks to the admirable system which he has introduced into French venery, he was able to turn his thoughts exclusively to the science and strategy of it.He now quietly assigned a special duty to the Prince de Loudon’s establishment, that of driving the stag to water, when, as he expected, the royal hounds had sent it into the Crown forest which outlined the horizon directly in front of the chateau.The prince knew well how to soothe the self-love of his old huntsmen by giving them the most arduous part of the work, and also that of the Englishman, whom he employed at his own speciality, affording him a chance to show the fleetness of his horses and dogs in the open.The two national systems were thus face to face and allowed to do their best under each other’s eyes.

第一章 木屋: 就在这时，只见十六个骑手组成的队伍越来越近，领头的是四位戴着绿色面纱的女士。莫黛斯特由她的父亲、马厩大总管和拉布里埃陪同，走在最前头，旁边是由德赛里齐子爵护卫的德摩弗里纽斯公爵夫人。骑在她们后面的是德肖利厄公爵夫人，她正冲着身旁的卡那利微笑着，没有一丝怨恨的痕迹。他们来到空地，在那里，那些身穿红衣、佩带号角的猎手们被猎犬簇拥着，组成了一幅足以让凡德莫兰动笔的画面。德肖利厄公爵夫人虽然体态丰腴，但还是很有风度地骑在马背上，来到莫黛斯特跟前。头天晚上她一句话都没跟这个年轻女子说，现在她却觉得不去避开莫黛斯特，才符合自己的尊贵身份。
Chapter I The Chalet: At that moment the cavalcade of sixteen riders was seen to approach at the head of which were the green veils of the four ladies.Modeste, accompanied by her father, the grand equerry, and La Briere, was in the advance, beside the Duchesse de Maufrigneuse whom the Vicomte de Serizy escorted.Behind them rode the Duchesse de Chaulieu, flanked by Canalis, on whom she was smiling without a trace of rancor.When they had reached the open space where the huntsmen with their red coats and brass bugles, surrounded by the hounds, made a picture worthy of Van der Meulen, the Duchesse de Chaulieu, who, in spite of her embonpoint, sat her horse admirably, rode up to Modeste, finding it more for her dignity not to avoid that young person, to whom the evening before she had not said a single word.

第一章 木屋: 猎队队长刚表扬完这些女士能够准时赶来，让人赞叹，埃莱奥诺尔就屈尊去观察莫黛斯特小手里那根闪闪发亮的精美马鞭，并礼貌地请莫黛斯特给她看看。

第一章 木屋: 在这重大的日子里，事关爱情和财产的重大利益问题都敲定了。这天只给猎队队长带来了一个担忧，那就是鹿会不会跑过池塘，并在城堡前的草坪上被射杀。因为他这样水平的猎手就像象棋大师，在某些情况下能够预测将死王棋的阵势。这位幸福的老人如愿以偿，追猎十分精彩。而第三天的围猎下雨了，各位女士也就不再出场，让他松了口气。
Chapter I The Chalet: This great day, in which such vast interests of heart and fortune were decided, caused but one anxiety to the Master of the Hunt,—namely, whether or not the stag would cross the pond and be killed on the lawn before the house; for huntsmen of his calibre are like great chess-players who can predict a checkmate under certain circumstances.The happy old man succeeded to the height of his wishes; the run was magnificent, and the ladies released him from his attendance upon them for the hunt of the next day but one,—which, however, turned out to be rainy.

第一章 木屋: 十二月初，德普兰为德拉巴斯蒂夫人动了手术。当她恢复视力后第一次看见埃内斯特·德拉布里埃时，她抓住莫黛斯特的手，在她耳边轻声说：“要是我，也会挑他的。”
Chapter I The Chalet: When, early in the month of December, Madame de La Bastie, operated upon by Desplein, recovered her sight and saw Ernest de La Briere for the first time, she pressed Modeste’s hand and whispered in her ear, “I should have chosen him myself.”

第一章 木屋: 第二年二月底，拉图奈尔已经签好所有普罗旺斯的地产契约。大约也是那个时候，拉巴斯蒂家族得到了国王给予的莫大荣誉，国王为两个年轻人签署了婚约，并批准将拉巴斯蒂家族的头衔和家徽传给拉布里埃，从此，这个头衔就变成了拉布里埃-拉巴斯蒂。大约四月底的时候，拉巴斯蒂的地产由宫廷特许定为限嗣继承。拉布里埃结婚的时候，证婚人是卡那利，还有那位他曾为其担任过五年秘书的内阁大臣。新娘的证婚人是德埃鲁维尔公爵和德普兰。米尼翁一家给了德普兰一份大礼，以表心意，并一直对他念念不忘、感激不尽。
Chapter I The Chalet: Toward the last of February all the deeds for the estates in Provence were signed by Latournelle, and about that time the family of La Bastie obtained the marked honor of the king’s signature to the marriage contract and to the ordinance transmitting their title and arms to La Briere, who henceforth took the name of La Briere-La Bastie.The estate of La Bastie was entailed by letters-patent issued about the end of April.La Briere’s witnesses on the occasion of his marriage were Canalis and the minister whom he had served for five years as secretary.Those of the bride were the Duc d’Herouville and Desplein, whom the Mignons long held in grateful remembrance, after giving him magnificent and substantial proofs of their regard.

第一章 木屋: 今后，在这部关于我们礼仪和习俗的长篇故事里，我们可能还会再见到德拉布里埃-拉巴斯蒂先生和夫人。明眼人会注意到，跟一位受过教育且聪明伶俐的女子结为连理，是多么甜蜜、多么舒心的事情，因为莫黛斯特头脑聪明，不会去作卖弄文采的蠢事，她是她丈夫的骄傲和幸福，也是她的家人、以及她周围所有人的骄傲和幸福。
Chapter I The Chalet: Later, in the course of this long history of our manners and customs, we may again meet Monsieur and Madame de La Briere-La Bastie; and those who have the eyes to see, will then behold how sweet, how easy, is the marriage yoke with an educated and intelligent woman; for Modeste, who had the wit to avoid the follies of pedantry, is the pride and happiness of her husband, as she is of her family and of all those who surround her.
